ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ A PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda With the commentaries CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya, BhÄrgava- BhÄskara-VrÌ¥tti and PaÃ±casandhi Critically edited, translated & annotated by Madhav M. Deshpande 1997

Dedicated with affection to my loving twin daughters Manjushree & Madhushree

Preface In her Foreword to Tatyana Elizarenkovaâ€™s fascinating work Language and Style of the Vedic RÌ¥á¹£is (SUNY Press, 1993), Wendy Doniger makes an interesting distinction between â€œthe modern, trendy, obscureâ€ disciplines such as semiotics, and â€œthe ancient, dusty, arcane discipline of Vedic philology.â€ By this yardstick, the present work proudly fits within the latter type. This work simultaneously continues and criticizes the work of the great American Sanskritist, W.D. Whitney, who published the first edition of this text with the title Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in 1862, and Surya Kanta, who produced the magnificent edition of a different Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in 1939. It is the result of my own research that spans more than two decades. During this period, many trendy varieties of linguistics came to pass. Fortunately perhaps, I have been more interested in the history of both modern and ancient linguistic theory, than in becoming an ardent follower of any one of the transient theories. I have used my knowledge of modern phonetics and phonology to elucidate the ancient theories of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas so that they can be made comprehensible to a modern reader. However, my approach has been primarily textual and historical, rather than theoretical. It was in 1974 while reading the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ with my student James Bare at the University of Michigan that I detected a number of faulty readings and made a note of possible emendations. That very same year, during a visit to Pune in search of manuscripts, I found half a dozen manuscripts of this text at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute and the Vaidika Samshodhana Mandala. To my delight, these manuscripts supported many of my emendations to Whitneyâ€™s text. This led me to think about preparing a critical edition of this text. The critical edition, however, could not be properly undertaken without gaining access to many more manuscripts of this text which were known to exist in different libraries around the world. In the year 1979, several more manuscripts became available to me. These came from the Staatsbibliothek Prussischer Kulturbesitz of Berlin, the library of the University of TÃœbingen, the Asiatic Society of Calcutta, and the Scindia Oriental Institute of Ujjain. In 1980, I found a manuscript in Banaras at the home of an Atharvaveda reciter, Pandit Narayan Shastri Ratate. Twelve years later, several important manuscripts were obtained in 1992 from the

library of the Sampurnananda Sanskrit University in Banaras. In the summer of 1995, I found three rare manuscripts of the KramapÄá¹­ha and the Jaá¹­ÄpÄá¹­ha of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Pune, which significantly assisted my interpretation of this text. In the midst of my other research, my work on this project continued on and off from 1974. I thank all the institutions that supported my research during this long period: 1974, U.S. Department of Education, through the Center for South and Southeast Asian Studies, University of Michigan. 1976, Rackham Graduate School Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1979-80, Rackham Graduate School Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1990, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1992-93, American Institute of Indian Studies, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Office of the Vice- President for Research, the University of Michigan. Numerous people have helped me throughout this long period in many different ways. I would like to specifically thank the following individuals who helped me in acquiring manuscripts: Dr. Dieter George and Dr. Hartmut-Ortwin Feistel, Staatsbibliothek Prussischer Kulturbesitz in Berlin. Dr. N.B. Marathe of the Central Reference Library, Calcutta, (currently at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Pune). Dr. Amalendu De, the Asiatic Society, Calcutta. Dr. K. Gruessner, Library of the University of TÃœbingen. Dr. V. Venkatachalam, Director, Scindia Oriental Institute, Ujjain. Pandit Narayan Shastri Ratate, Durga Ghat, Banaras. Dr. B.N. Misra, Librarian, Sampurnananda Sanskrit University, Banaras. Dr. T.N. Dharmadhikari, Vaidika Samshodhana Mandala, Pune. Dr. R.N. Dandekar, Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Pune.

A major part of this work was carried out at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute during my various research visits, but most intensively during 1992-93, and the summer of 1995. Besides the excellent manuscript collection of this institute, my daily conversations with Dr. R.N. Dandekar, Dr. M.A. Mehendale, Dr. A.M. Ghatage, and Dr. G.B. Palsule were most exciting. Many knotty problems of this text and its interpretation were solved during our afternoon tea. I thank all these scholars, and especially Dr. Dandekar, who introduced me to the mysteries of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda at the University of Poona, when I was studying for my Masterâ€™s degree in Sanskrit in the years 1966-68. In the U.S., my most sincere thanks go to Professor George Cardona. In spite of his own heavy commitments, Cardona has gone through this entire work and made numerous suggestions for improvement. At home in Ann Arbor, my colleague Professor John C. Catford, Professor (Emeritus) of Phonetics, University of Michigan, took a keen interest in this work. He read my translations with great interest and made suggestions to make them comprehensible to non-Sanskritist linguists. Finally I wish to thank my wife Shubhangi and my daughters Madhushree and Manjushree who have tolerated my eccentricities while I was lost in deep communication with my manuscripts and my computer. I dedicate this work to my two lovely daughters, Madhushree and Manjushree, who have brought immense joy to me and my wife. The book is typeset using Nagari and Roman diacritics fonts which I developed over the past several years. These fonts are named after my daughters. The Nagari font is titled Madhushree and the Roman diacritics font is titled Manjushree. During the long time it has taken to finish this project, I have learned a great deal about the history of the grammatical traditions in ancient India, and I hope that this book will spur further interest in this â€˜ancient, dusty, and arcane,â€™ but highly important, branch of Vedic philology. While much of this work criticizes the views of Whitney and Surya Kanta, I wish to express my great indebtedness to these two predecessors. The more I read and analyzed their contributions, the more respect I have developed for their wisdom and industry. October 24, 1995Madhav M. Deshpande Ann Arbor, Michigan

-i- Preface In her Foreword to Tatyana Elizarenkovaâ€™s fascinating work Language and Style of the Vedic RÌ¥á¹£is (SUNY Press, 1993), Wendy Doniger makes an interesting distinction between â€œthe modern, trendy, obscureâ€ disciplines such as semiotics, and â€œthe ancient, dusty, arcane discipline of Vedic philology.â€ By this yardstick, the present work proudly fits within the latter type. This work simultaneously continues and criticizes the work of the great American Sanskritist, W.D. Whitney, who published the first edition of this text with the title Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in 1862, and Surya Kanta, who produced the magnificent edition of a different Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in 1939. It is the result of my own research that spans more than two decades. During this period, many trendy varieties of linguistics came to pass. Fortunately perhaps, I have been more interested in the history of both modern and ancient linguistic theory, than in becoming an ardent follower of any one of the transient theories. I have used my knowledge of modern phonetics and phonology to elucidate the ancient theories of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas so that they can be made comprehensible to a modern reader. However, here my approach has been primarily textual and historical, rather than theoretical. It was in 1974 while reading the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ with my student James Bare at the University of Michigan that I detected a number of faulty readings and made a note of possible emendations. That very same year, during a visit to Pune in search of manuscripts, I found half a dozen manuscripts of this text at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute and the Vaidika Samshodhana Mandala. To my delight, these manuscripts supported many of my emendations to Whitneyâ€™s text. This led me to think about preparing a critical edition of this text. In the year 1979, several more manuscripts became available to me. These came from the Staatsbibliothek Prussischer Kulturbesitz of Berlin, the library of the University of TÃœbingen, the Asiatic Society of Calcutta, and the Scindia Oriental Institute of Ujjain. Twelve years later, several important manuscripts were obtained in 1992 from the library of the Sampurnananda

-ii- Sanskrit University in Banaras. In the summer of 1995, I found three rare manuscripts of the KramapÄá¹­ha and the Jaá¹­ÄpÄá¹­ha of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Pune, which significantly assisted my interpretation of this text. In the midst of my other research, my work on this project continued on and off from 1974. I thank all the institutions that supported my research during this long period: 1974, U.S. Department of Education, through the Center for South and Southeast Asian Studies, University of Michigan. 1976, Rackham Graduate School Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1979-80, Rackham Graduate School Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1990, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, Faculty Research Grant, University of Michigan. 1992-93, American Institute of Indian Studies, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Office of the Vice- President for Research, the University of Michigan. -iii- A major part of this work was carried out at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute during my various research visits, but most intensively during 1992-93, and the summer of 1995. I thank all these scholars, and especially Dr. Dandekar, who introduced me to the mysteries of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda at the University of Poona, when I was studying for my Masterâ€™s degree in Sanskrit in the years 1966-68. In the U.S., my most sincere thanks go to Professor George Cardona. In spite of his own heavy commitments, Cardona has gone through this entire work and made numerous suggestions for improvement. At home in Ann Arbor, my colleague Professor John C. Catford, Professor (Emeritus) of Phonetics, University of Michigan, took a keen interest in this work. He read my translations with great interest and made suggestions to make them comprehensible to non-Sanskritist linguists. I must also thank Professor Michael Witzel, the editor of the series, for making numerous helpful suggestions. Finally I wish to thank my wife Shubhangi and my daughters Madhushree and Manjushree who have tolerated my eccentricities while I was lost in deep communication with my manuscripts and my computer. I dedicate this work to my two lovely daughters, Madhushree and Manjushree, who have brought immense joy to me and my wife. The Nagari font is titled Madhushree and the Roman diacritics font is titled Manjushree. The more I read and analyzed their contributions, the more respect I have developed for their wisdom and industry. October 24, 1995Madhav M. Deshpande Ann Arbor, Michigan

INTRODUCTION

  1. Critical Edition of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ 1.1. William Dwight Whitney, the great American Sanskritist, pub- lished the first edition of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ in the journal of the American Oriental Society in 1862. This edition was based exclusively on a single manuscript of this text which Whitney found in Berlin. Whitney fully realized that this manuscript (= Chambers 143) was in bad shape, and attempted to find more manuscripts in European and Indian libraries. Having failed in his search for more manuscripts, and having realized the importance of this text for the study of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya-Atharvaveda, which he and Roth had edited and published from Berlin in 1856, Whitney decided to edit and publish this text. In the introduction to his edition, Whitney makes the following comments about his lone manuscript source (Whitney 1862: iv): Most unfortunately, considering the extreme rarity of the work, the manuscript is a very poor one. Not only is it everywhere excessively incorrect, often beyond the possibility of successful emendation; it is also defective, exhibiting lacunae at several points. Some may be of opinion, then, that the publication of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya upon its authority alone is premature, and should not have been undertaken. Emphasizing the â€œfaintness of the hope that additional manuscripts would later be obtainableâ€ (Whitney 1862: iv) and â€œthe peculiar interest of this class of works,â€ (ibid.) Whitney published his excellent edition in 1862, with a translation and notes based on the commentary in the Berlin manuscript. From this lone poor manuscript, Whitney could only salvage the text of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. He extensively used and cited the commentary in that manuscript, though due to the poor condition of the manuscript, he did not publish the complete text of this commentary. Considering the odds against Whitney, one must admit that he produced a masterly edition which has been widely used by scholars since its publication. 1.2. The Berlin manuscript did not call the text by the title Atharva- veda PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. However, Whitney argued (1862: iii):

2 INTRODUCTION The treatise was first brought to light, and its character deter- mined, by Roth. It was recognized by him as being what is indicated by our title, a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya to a text of the Atharvaveda. That it has any inherent right to be called the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya to the Atharvaveda is not, of course, claimed for it; but, considering the extreme improbability that any other like phonetic treatise, belonging to any other schools of that Veda, will ever be brought to light, the title of Atharvaveda PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya finds a sufficient justification in its convenience, and in its analogy with the names given to the other kindred treatises by their respective editors. Whitneyâ€™s text has been widely used under the name of the Atharva- veda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. The above paragraph from Whitney needs to be read care- fully, and one should note that he nowhere asserted that this text is the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya of the Atharva-Veda, an accusation hurled at him unjustly by Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 31): â€œWhitney turns an APr into the APr.â€ Whitney never made such a claim. Whitneyâ€™s modest claim that the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ belongs to the class of PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas was indeed not outlandish. Support for the same conclusion comes from an important source. Uvaá¹­a in his introductory comments on the RPR quotes CA (1.1.2-3: à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š, à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡) and introduces it as (M.D. Shastriâ€™s edition, Vol. II, p. 23): à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ â€˜so it is said in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya of the Atharvaveda.â€™ The second likely tradi- tional source of information is the commentary ChÄyÄ by VaidyanÄtha PÄya- guá¹‡á¸e on NÄgeÅ›abhaá¹­á¹­aâ€™s Uddyota. In his MB on P.1.1.10 (à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¥Œ), PataÃ±jali quotes a sequence of rules from some text, and they look very similar to CA (1.1.29-32). Ramadeva Tripathi (1977: 141) ascribes to PÄyaguá¹‡á¸eâ€™s ChÄyÄ a remark that these rules are cited from the Åšaunaka PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. I have not been able to trace this remark to citations of ChÄyÄ in the Nirnaya Sagara edition of the MB. However, I find a remark à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿, Nirnaya Sagara Edition of the MB, Vol.I., Bombay, 1917, edited by Pt. Shivadatta Kuddala, p. 228. This comment is followed by the abbreviation dÄ. This abbreviation indicates that the comment belongs to the editor, rather than to VaidyanÄthaâ€™s ChÄyÄ. It is possible that the learned editor was familiar with Whitneyâ€™s edition of the CA, which called it the Atharva-Veda- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. In any case, one can at least say that a traditional Pandit did not see anything wrong in calling this text a Åšaunaka PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 3 This is also supported by the Ä€tharvaá¹‡a-PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­a (= Atharva-VidhÄna) included in the Åšiká¹£Äsaá¹ƒgraha (p. 479). It refers to a ÅšaunakÄ«ya-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya and to the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«-Åšiká¹£Ä : à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«cd à¥¥ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¯ à¤µà¥ˆ à¥¥ à¥¬ à¥¥ From the description of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya as svara-vará¹‡a- vibhÄgajam, one can be certain that the PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­a is referring to the CA. 1.3. The subsequent scholarship on the Atharvaveda has happily dis- proved Whitneyâ€™s earlier bleak expectations. In 1880, Whitney himself pub- lished â€œCollation of the Second Manuscript of the Atharvaveda PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyaâ€ in the tenth volume of the Journal of the American Oriental Society. Albrecht Weber was instrumental in drawing Whitneyâ€™s attention to this manuscript which was purchased by Georg BÃœhler for the Government of Bombay. This second manuscript collated by Whitney is now deposited at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute (# 11/1870-71). Whitney duly notes that this second manuscript gives the title of the work simply as CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ throughout. It also calls itself CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«-VyÄkaraá¹‡a in some places. Whitney, however, still insists on calling this text Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. 1.4. In 1923, Vishva Bandhu Shastri published a different treatise from Lahore under the name Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. This edition is based on six different manuscripts. Referring to Whitneyâ€™s earlier statements, Vishva Bandhu Shastri pointed out that many new manuscripts of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ had also been found and preserved and that â€œa new and revised edition of the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ has thus become a matter of necessityâ€ (Atharva- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, edited by V. B. Shastri, p. 12). However, Vishva Bandhu Shastri seems to have been unaware of Whitneyâ€™s collation of the second manuscript, and he did not undertake the task of preparing this new revised edition of the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. In 1937, Surya Kanta Shastri prepared a critical edition of this other Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya for his Ph.D. at Oxford, and this text has been pub- lished from Lahore in 1939. This text includes Vishva Bandhuâ€™s text as one of the versions, and is obviously different from the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. In fact, several manuscripts which contain this Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya also contain the text of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. Thus, the labors of Vishva Bandhu Shastri and Surya Kanta Shastri have conclusively proved the existence of two separate texts, i.e. the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ and Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya,

4 INTRODUCTION and that the text that Whitney then called the Atharvaveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya must now be called simply the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. 1.5. The existence of other manuscripts of CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ became known to the world of scholarship since Weber noticed in 1863 a second manuscript in the Literarisches Central-Blatt (No. 29). This was just one year after Whitney published his edition. Later, more manuscripts of the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ were noticed by Vishva Bandhu Shastri and Surya Kanta Shastri. Additionally, in 1937, the curator of the Scindia Oriental Institute, Ujjain, Sadashiv L. Katre, discovered a manuscript titled Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a, which is identical with the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. He published a detailed notice of this manuscript and its comparison with Whitneyâ€™s text (Katre 1938- 39). However, Katre does not show any awareness of the existence of the other manuscripts of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ which were noticed by Vishva Bandhu Shastri and Surya Kanta Shastri. I have myself been interested in this text for many years and have lo- cated several new manuscripts of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. The library of the Vaidika Saá¹ƒsodhana Maá¹‡á¸aá¸·a, Pune, has three manuscripts of this text, two of which bear the title Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. These two manuscripts also contain commentaries on this text by BhÄrgava BhÄskara and KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa, and in an article published in 1976, I have discussed some points connected with these manuscripts. In the course of my personal search for more manuscripts of this text at Banaras in December 1979, I located a manuscript of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ with a Maharashtrian Brahmin reciter of the Atharvaveda, Shri Narayan Shastri Ratate, and with his kind permission was able to obtain a Xerox copy of the same. A further significant discovery is that of a manuscript at the Asiatic Society, Calcutta, which contains the same commentary as in the Berlin manuscript used by Whitney, and that this manuscript, though incomplete, is in a much better shape. This is a great help in editing the text of this commentary. 2. Description of the Manuscripts 2.1. Below, I shall briefly describe all the manuscripts which are utilized in the preparation of this critical edition: A.CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Pune. No. 1/1873-74. Devanagari. Complete. Folios: 12-21, 10" x 5 1/2". From Bikaner. Â± 1700 A.D. The entire manuscript contains PaÃ±capaá¹­alikÄ, Dantyoá¹£á¹­hyavidhi, KÄlÄtÄ«taprÄyaÅ›citta, CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ and AtharvaprÄti- Å›Äkhya. There is no information about who copied this manuscript, when and

F.CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. Gore collection, Vaidika Saá¹ƒÅ›o- dhana Maá¹‡á¸aá¸·a, Pune. No. 4177. Devanagari. Complete. Folios 1-12, 9 1/2" x 4 1/2". From Mahuli near Satara. 1819 A.D. The date is specified as: à¤¶à¤•à¥‡ à¥§à¥­à¥ªà¥© à¤µà¥ƒà¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥§à¥®à¥­à¥­ à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥à¤²à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾. It also mentions 180 as the measure of the work (granthasaá¹ƒkhyÄ, 180x32 = number of syllables?). The manuscript came from the Gore family, originally belonging to Mahuli near Satara. This family was in charge of the Atharvavedic priestcraft for the king of Satara. Later the family moved to Sangli. The manuscript occasionally uses the Avagraha, but does not use PrÌ¥á¹£á¹­hamÄtrÄs. G.KautsavyÄkaraá¹‡asya CaturÄdhyÄyÄtmakasya BhÄrgavabhÄskarÄ«- yavrÌ¥ttiá¸¥. Gore collection, Vaidika Saá¹ƒÅ›odhana Maá¹‡á¸aá¸·a, Pune. No. 4178. Devanagari. Incomplete. Folios: 1-24, 7.9" x 4.2". From Sangli, Maha- rashtra. Â± 1700 A.D. This manuscript contains a commentary by BhÄrgava BhÄskara. An important feature of this manuscript is that in contrast with all other manuscripts it gives three numbers for each rule, i.e. numbers for the AdhyÄya, PÄda, and SÅ«tra. It occasionally uses the Avagraha, but does not make use of the PrÌ¥á¹£á¹­hamÄtrÄ. In its incomplete state, it covers rules 1.1.10 to 1.4.8, or Whitney 1.8 to 1.99. H.CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«-BhÄá¹£ya. Staatsbibliothek Preussischer Kultur- besitz, Berlin. Chambers 143. Complete. Folios: 1-77, 8 1/4 " x 3 3/4". From North India. Saá¹ƒvat 1714 (= 1656 A.D.) This is the manuscript used by Whitney for his edition. In this manuscript of the commentary, there is a general pattern as follows. First a SÅ«tra is stated. Then it is explained and analyzed in the commentary. Then the SÅ«tra is again repeated at the end of the commentary. These three readings of the SÅ«tra are respectively labeled Ha, Hc, and Hb. I.Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. Oriental Institute, Ujjain. No. 3576. De- vanÄgarÄ«. Complete. Folios: 1-12. 11 1/4" x 6". Belonged to BÄá¸·aÅ›ÄstrÄ« Garde from Gwalior. Â± 1700 A.D. 8 INTRODUCTION of PrÌ¥á¹£á¹­hamÄtrÄs. The first and the last folios have a stamp in English showing that the last owner was Mr. S.B. Vaidya of Durgaghat, Banaras, an Atharvavedin Brahmin. P.CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«. Sarasvati Bhavana Library, Sampurnanda San- skrit Vishvavidyalaya. Banaras. No. 2074. Devanagari. Complete. 10 1/4" x 4 1/5". Folios 1-27. CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ extends from folio 19 to 25. The ms. contains MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä, Jyotiá¹£am, ChandaÅ›citi, PaÃ±capaá¹­alikÄ, Dantyo- á¹£á¹­hyavidhi, KÄltÄ«taprÄyaÅ›cittam, CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ, and Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. It is a relatively old ms., and it makes occasional use of PrÌ¥á¹£á¹­hamÄtrÄs. On folio 13, it gives the date of copying as à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥®à¥« à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤—à¤¶à¤°à¤µà¤¦à¤¿ à¥« à¤—à¥à¤°à¥Œ à¤²à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥. However, on folio 27, at the end of the manu-script, a different hand adds à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥©à¥ª à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡ à¤†à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¤¿ à¥§à¥« à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¤‚à¤šà¥‹à¤²à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€ à¤‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚à¤¥ à¤­à¤£à¥‡ à¤›à¥‡ à¤ªà¤‚à¤šà¥‹à¤²à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€ à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤œà¥€ à¤•à¤¨à¥‡à¤° (?) à¤­à¤£à¥‡ à¤›à¥‡. It looks like the ms. belonged to the PaÃ±colÄ« family of Gujarat. The original ms. probably goes back to Saá¹ƒvat 1685, and that it was supplemented and corrected by another hand in Saá¹ƒvat 1734. The same person, ÅšrÄ« ÄªÅ›vara PaÃ±colÄ«, is referred to in the ms. C above, and both the manuscripts probably belong to the same family. It is clear that the same hand has added corrections to both of these manuscripts. 2.2. I propose the following genealogy for these manuscripts. L A B D P M J H N C E F O I G K CA-VyÄkaraá¹‡a Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a Ur ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ X Y

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 9 2.3. Taking into account the significant shared errors and other shared deviant features, the following groups of manuscripts seem to have strong relationships. The number given in the bracket stands for the shared errors and other shared deviant features noted in this edition: A-B-D (47), A-B (44), A- B-D-M-J (16), A-B-D-M (11), A-B-D-J (4), A-B-L (4), B-D (21), C-E-F (6), C-E-F-I (5), C-H-N (4), E-F (27), E-F-H (4), E-F-I (28), F-I (4), H-N (42). It is not necessary to record information about groups of manuscripts which share one or two errors. The above chart takes into account this information. Some of these relationships are particularly complex. For example, consider the relationship between A, B, and D. All three share 47 common deviations, and hence must go back to a common source. However, A and B share 44 common deviations which are different from the 21 common deviations shared by B and D. This must mean that the source of A and B must be slightly different from the source of B and D. In my opinion, the only way to resolve this situation is to suggest that the manuscript B used multiple sources. One of its sources was shared in common with A. However, another source for B was shared in common with D. The manuscripts O and P became available to me after all other manuscripts were already collated and the basic relationships were determined. I have shown their appropriate relationships in the diagram above, though I have not given counts of shared deviant features. This stemma should be viewed only as a convenient grouping of the manuscript material. One must keep in mind the possibility and the proba- bility that the persons copying and correcting the manuscripts used various sources, and this accounts for the erratic readings, which violate the otherwise plausible linkages between the manuscripts. Thus, while the manuscripts B, C, D, and P, all derive from Anahilapurapattana (= Patan in Gujarat), the manuscript C seems to share closer links with the manuscript E from Kaá¹‡vÄlaya in Gujarat and F from Maharashtra. One may also note that the mss. C, E, and F contain only the text of the CA, while the mss. in the X group contain other texts besides the CA, and they usually contain the same set of texts. As a general observation, it is interesting to note all the manuscripts seem to derive from the Western regions ranging from Rajasthan to Maharashtra, and that the regions of Southern and Eastern India are not represented in these available manuscripts. 3. New Features of the Critical Edition 3.1. Here I shall briefly indicate some of the important gains which are already evident from the manuscript material now available to us. Whitney

10 INTRODUCTION had divided his text only into four AdhyÄyas. He knew that each AdhyÄya had four PÄdas, but his manuscript was not clear on these divisions. Hence, he could not subdivide each AdhyÄya into PÄdas. The manuscript material now available settles this issue once and for all. Below I have given the colophons occurring at the end of the first PÄda of the first AdhyÄya as found in the various manuscripts. A, B, M, Pà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Cà¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Dà¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ E, Fà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Gà¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¥¤ H, Nà¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥ªà¥§ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤‚à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Ià¥ªà¥§ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Jà¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Oà¥§ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥§ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ Since all of these colophons occur at the same juncture, we can now be completely certain where the PÄdas end, and we can now subdivide the text properly. 3.2. Several prose and metrical passages found in the Berlin manu- script were relegated by Whitney to the commentary. He did not consider them to be part of the text of the CA. Several of these passages are found in almost all the manuscripts which give only the text of the SÅ«tras of the CA. This helps us assign these passages to the text of the CA, rather than to the text of the commentary. For instance, Whitney (1.105) reads as follows: à¤–à¤£à¥à¤µà¤–à¤¾à¥© à¤‡ à¤–à¥ˆà¤®à¤–à¤¾ à¤‡ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¤¾à¥© à¤‡à¤¦à¤¾à¥©à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¥©à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¥©à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥© à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¥‹à¤¦à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥€à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‹à¤¦à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥€à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¥© à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¶à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¥©à¤®à¤µà¤¶à¥‡- à¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¥©à¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤¾à¥©à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney includes this long passage in the Berlin manuscript in the text of the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ, but stops abruptly, while the passage actually continues further in that manuscript:

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 11 à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ The entire passage with some minor variations is now supported by the manuscripts A, B, D, E, F, H, I, J, M, N, O and P and it is most certainly a part of the text of the CA. There are many such passages. On the other hand, many passages which are ascribed to the commentary by Whitney are not found in any of the manuscripts of the CA, and hence we know that they in- deed do not form a part of the CA. 3.3. The new manuscripts help us detect rules which are missing in Whitneyâ€™s edition and in the Berlin manuscript. Many of these rules were noticed by Whitney himself in his â€œCollation of the Second Manuscriptâ€ in 1880, and were again noticed by S.L. Katre (1938-39: 384). Now with the help of the substantially increased manuscript evidence, we can be more certain about the text of these rules. 3.4. The manuscripts occasionally offer a different splitting of rules from what has been offered by Whitney. 12 INTRODUCTION Whitney (1.16):à¤†à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Now, all the manuscripts we have give just one continuous rule as: à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¥€à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ The manuscript G in fact provides a single number (i.e. 1.1.16) for this rule. 3.5. Against the reading of the Berlin manuscript, i.e. Â°kaá¹‡á¹­hyaá¸¥, Whitney emended the text to Â°kaá¹‡á¹­haá¸¥. Now the Berlin manuscript stands supported by all manuscripts, except I which supports Whitneyâ€™s emendation. However, I believe it is most likely that this widely shared reading is an error going back to the archetype. Whitney (1.25): à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤®à¥. However, I believe it is most likely that this widely shared reading is an error going back to the archetype. Consider the following rules: Whitney (1.66): à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥. ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 13 jecture, which is now fully supported by the manuscripts C, D, E, F, I, J, M, N, O and P. Whitney (3.29): [à¤¨] à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ. There is no support for na in the Berlin manuscript, and this is Whitneyâ€™s conjecture. It is now supported by the manuscripts A, B, D, E, F, I, J, M, N, O and P. 3.7. I hope I have sufficiently illustrated the new features of the present critical edition of the CA alias Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a, and the extent to which it replaces Whitneyâ€™s pioneering work. It is hoped that this critical edition of the CA will open up new dimensions for the study of the Atharva- veda and its ancillary literature. As indicated above, the new manuscript material leads to a wholly new numbering for the rules of the CA. Most of the manuscripts do not provide any numbering whatsoever. However, there are several manuscripts which do provide numbering of the rules in different ways. For instance, manuscript G provides a continuous numbering for all rules. It gives the number of the AdhyÄya, the PÄda, and the SÅ«tra. Manu- script I provides numbering within each PÄda, mostly for rules 10, 20, etc. The mss. H and N provide cumulative numbers for the PÄdas and AdhyÄyas. The ms. O also provides, in its colophons, totals for the rules in each PÄda. The numbers provided in these different mss. do not always agree with each other, but tell us something about the different textual traditions, some of which included more material than others. Sometimes we find that a given tradition of transmission split a rule into two, or joined two rules into one. Such changes obviously affected the counting of rules in the text. Below, I have provided a complete numbering of the CA rules found in this edition, along with the corresponding numbers in Whitneyâ€™s edition, and the numbers found in different manuscripts: 3.8. This edition presents not only the revised text of the CA, but a fairly complete text of the commentary CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya (= CAB) based on two manuscripts. It further offers partial texts of the commentaries VrÌ¥tti by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara and a reworking of the CA rules with a commentary called PaÃ±casandhi by KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa, along the lines of Bhaá¹­tojÄ« DÄ«ká¹£itaâ€™s SidhÄnta- KaumudÄ« and AnubhÅ«tisvarÅ«pÄcÄryaâ€™s SÄrasvata-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. Both of these commentaries are edited here on the basis of single manuscripts preserved at the Vaidika Saá¹ƒÅ›odhana Maá¹‡á¸aá¸·a at Pune. The three commentaries are discussed in some detail later in this introduction in the context of the successive degrees of PÄá¹‡inian influence. We know nothing about the authors

14 INTRODUCTION of these commentaries, beside their names. For the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya, we do not even know the name of its author. In general terms, one may say that the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya belongs to a period closer to the KÄÅ›ikÄvrÌ¥tti on PÄá¹‡ini, while the other two commentaries seem to follow Bhaá¹­á¹­ojÄ« DÄ«ká¹£itaâ€™s SiddhÄntakaumudÄ«. The CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya is also very closely linked to the tradition as represented by the Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya edited by Surya Kanta. In several hundred cases, the CAB cites the first few examples from a long list of examples fully listed under the rules of the APR. In my notes on the CA, I have fully indicated this relationship. On the other hand, the commentaries of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara and KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa are completely unaware of the existence of the CAB or the APR, and explain the rules of the CA more on the basis of the parallel rules of PÄá¹‡ini. Even here, one notices that the commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara shows full familiarity with the text of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, while KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa hardly ever cites examples from the AV. The CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«- bhÄá¹£ya is closely familiar with an ancient Åšiká¹£Ä which is in part also contained in the AV PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­a called Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala, but is not familiar with either the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä or the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. In contrast with this, the latter two commentaries show no awareness of the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä cited by the CAB. On the other hand, they show direct familiarity with the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä and the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. Thus, the present edition provides means to understand the changing nature of the CA tradition from a period going close to that of PÄá¹‡ini to a period coming close to that of Bhaá¹­á¹­ojÄ« DÄ«ká¹£ita. During this long period, the text of the CA underwent successive interpretations at the hands of commentators who were gradually more and more influenced by the tradition of the PÄá¹‡inian commentaries. It is hoped that more manuscripts of these commentaries will come to light in the future and a more complete account of this tradition can be eventually put together. However, I am delighted to present the available materials in this edition. I have been engaged in collecting and interpreting these materials almost since 1975 when I first noticed the manuscripts available in Pune at the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute and at the Vaidika Saá¹ƒÅ›odhana Maá¹‡á¸aá¸·. Now I have made use of almost every known manuscript (and also some not listed in Aithal 1991) in preparing this edition which marks a substantial advance over the edition prepared so valiantly by Whitney in 1862 on the basis of a single manuscript.

18 INTRODUCTION AdhyÄya 1, PÄda 4. CAWhitneyMss. 1.4.1.1.92.G: 1.4.1. 1.4.2.1.93.G: 1.4.2. 1.4.3.1.94. 1.4.4.1.95. 1.4.5.1.96. 1.4.6.1.97. 1.4.7.1.98.G: 1.4.7. 1.4.8.1.99.G: 1.4.8. 1.4.9.1.100. 1.4.10.1.101. 1.4.11.1.102. 1.4.12.1.103. 1.4.13.1.104. 1.4.14.1.105. Colophons: C: 103 (cumulative); H, N: 13 (for this PÄda); I: 110 (cumula- tive); O: 19 (for this PÄda). While the figures given in C, H, and N are close, though not identical, with the numbers in our edition, the numbers given in O and I are somewhat problematic. It is not clear for instance, how O arrives at the number 19 for the rules in this PÄda. The text found in I and O does not offer any additional rules. AdhyÄya 2, PÄda 1. CAWhitneyMss. 3.4.1.3.75. 3.4.2.3.76. 3.4.3.3.77. 3.4.4.3.78. 3.4.5.3.79. 3.4.6.3.80. 3.4.7.missing 3.4.8.missing 3.4.9.missing 3.4.10.missingI: 10. 3.4.11.missing 3.4.12.3.81. 3.4.13.3.82. 3.4.14.3.83. 3.4.15.3.84. 3.4.16.3.85. 3.4.17.3.86. 3.4.18.missing 3.4.19.3.87. 3.4.20.3.88. 3.4.21.3.89. 3.4.22.3.90. 3.4.23.3.91. 3.4.24.3.92. 3.4.25.3.93. 3.4.26.3.94. 3.4.27.3.95. 3.4.28.3.96.I: 29. Colophons: H: 105 (cumulative for this AdhyÄya); I: 125 (cumulative for this AdhyÄya); O: 29 (identical with the count in I). The difference of twenty rules in the counting for this AdhyÄya in the mss. H and I can be explained only on the assumption that H considered certain passages as belonging to the

26 INTRODUCTION commentary. This refers in all likelihood to CA 3.3.1-5 and CA 3.3.26-35. In our count, these are 15 rules, which Whitney relegated to the commentary. However, as the colophon in O on AdhyÄya 3, PÄda 3 shows, some traditions counted 40 rules in this PÄda, instead of our 35. There is a strong possibility that the verses in CA 3.3.1-4, and the prose in CA 3.3.5, were counted as having two rules each. This accounts for 20 rules. It is clear that the ms H of the CAB contains all these passages and yet does not count them as SÅ«tras. On the other hand, the ms. I gives 125 as the total number of rules in this AdhyÄya, indicating that it includes these passages as part of the text. This is also supported by the ms. O. AdhyÄya 4, PÄda 1. 28 INTRODUCTION 4.1.64.4.42. 4.1.65.4.43. 4.1.66.4.44. 4.1.67.4.45. 4.1.68.4.46. Colophons: H: 47. This agrees with Whitneyâ€™s exclusion of CA 4.1.1-22 as belonging to the commentary and not to the text of the CA. On the other hand I gives 98 as the number of rules in this PÄda, while O gives 99 as the number of the same rules. Our number is 68. How do we account for this difference? We can only suggest that the passages in CA 4.1.1-22 were differently sliced into separate sÅ«tras by the traditions represented by I and O. While the manuscript H physically contains these passages, it does not count them among the SÅ«tras of the CA. We have no way of knowing how exactly these passages were subdivided. AdhyÄya 4, PÄda 2. 30 INTRODUCTION 4.3.26.4.97. 4.3.27.4.98. 4.3.28.4.99. 4.3.29.4.100.I: 30. Colophons: H: 102 (cumulative for this AdhyÄya); I, O: 30 (for this PÄda). AdhyÄya 4, PÄda 4. CAWhitneyMss. 4.4.1.4.101. 4.4.2.4.102. 4.4.3.4.103. 4.4.4.4.104. 4.4.5.4.105. 4.4.6.4.106. 4.4.7.4.107. 4.4.8.missing 4.4.9.4.108. 4.4.10.4.109.I: 10. 4.4.11.4.110. 4.4.12.4.111. 4.4.13.4.112. 4.4.14.4.113. 4.4.15.4.114. 4.4.16.4.115. 4.4.17.4.116. 4.4.18.4.117. 4.4.19.4.118.I: 20. 4.4.20.4.119. 4.4.21.4.120. 4.4.22.4.121. 4.4.23.4.122. 4.4.24.4.123. 4.4.25.4.124. 4.4.26.4.125. 4.4.27.4.126.I: 26.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 31 Colophons: F: 580 (total for all AdhyÄyas); G: 174 (for this AdhyÄya); I: 27 (for this PÄda), 174 (for this AdhyÄya), 516 (total for all AdhyÄyas); O: 27 (for this PÄda). Our total for all the rules of the CA is 483, while Whitneyâ€™s total comes to 435. The difference is accounted for by Whitneyâ€™s exclusion of certain passages which he thought belonged to the commentary rather than to the text of the CA. The figure 516 found in the ms. I as the total for all the rules is explainable by supposing that this counting resulted because of primarily the included verses being represented as each containing at least two SÅ«tras, if not more. There are actually no extra passages as such. The figure 580 found in the ms. F as the total of all rules could possibly accounted for if we assume that each of the included verses is equivalent to four SÅ«tras. Such a calculation comes close to this figure. Again, we must note that the ms. F does not actually have any extra passages as such. 4. General Features of the Ancient Indian Phonetics1 4.1. Ancient Indian Phonetics 4.1.1. The tradition of phonetic analysis and description of Sanskrit in ancient India developed as one of the traditional tools used for the preserva- tion and propagation of the Vedas, the religious scriptures of the ancient Hindus and it eventually came to be incorporated in a vastly developed tradition of Sanskrit grammar. While the Vedic literature was originally composed by individual Vedic priests and was orally maintained by generations of Vedic priestly families, eventually the Vedic texts came to be collected and edited into organized volumes, and systematic efforts were made to preserve both the texts themselves as well as the understanding of the meaning and the ritual application of these texts. The results of this organized effort have survived in the form of manuals of various kinds pertaining to various Vedic schools. Among these manuals, many deal with topics of linguistic interest, i.e. phonetics (Åšiká¹£Ä), metrics (Chandas), etymology (Nirukta), and grammar (VyÄkaraá¹‡a). The treatises on phonetics, generally divided into two types called Åšiká¹£Äs and PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, deal with specific Vedic texts and their recitation, rather than dealing with Sanskrit or Vedic language as such. This makes the

1 This section of the Introduction is a revised and expanded version of my article â€œAncient Indian Phoneticsâ€ which appeared in The Encyclopedia of Language and Linguistics, Volume 6, Pergamon Press, Oxford, 1994. I am grateful to the publisher for granting me permission to incorporate this revised version here.

32 INTRODUCTION phonetic manuals very special in some sense. The observations contained in the phonetic manuals are of a non-generalized, highly specific nature, and thus they provide for us a microscopically detailed picture of the sounds of Sanskrit as used in specific oral scriptural traditions. They contain a highly developed set of analytical tools and terminology which has won the admiration of Western linguists and Sanskritists ever since the discovery of Sanskrit by the West (cf. Whitney 1884, Allen 1953: 3ff). 4.2. Origins of Sanskrit Phonetics 4.2.1. The various Vedic texts were produced in different regions of India, beginning with about 1500 B.C. in the Northwestern corner, and the texts produced in one region were carried orally into other areas. During this movement, there was social and linguistic contact and convergence with peo- ples who were historically of non-Indo-European backgrounds, e.g. Dravidi- ans, Tibeto-Burmans, and Austro-Asiatics. As a result of this contact and convergence, the Indo-Aryan dialects continuously went on changing and slowly a gap began to develop between the language of the preserved ancient scriptures and the language of the contemporary colloquial usage. This gap began to affect both the phonetic form of the orally preserved scriptural texts as well as their comprehension. A realization of this gap and its perceived negative impact on the preserved scriptural texts is indeed the starting point of the development of the analytical efforts reflected in the manuals left to us by the Vedic schools. On the phonetic side, it is quite clear that the same text was pronounced with slight differences eventually leading to doubts as to the exact wording. Emergence of sounds such as the retroflex consonants within the Indo-Aryan dialects was a gradual process leading to more or less retroflexed versions of the same Vedic text. The accents of ancient Vedic dialects were preserved as musical pitch variation in the recitation of Vedic texts, but these were no longer used in the colloquial contemporary dialects. Thus, it became increasingly difficult to naturally pronounce the Vedic texts with proper accents. The late Vedic texts (e.g. Åšatapatha-BrÄhmaá¹‡a 1.6.3.8-10) narrate an interesting story about how a demon named Tvaá¹£á¹­rÌ¥ mispronounced a ritual expression and achieved disastrous results. The demon wished to have a son who would slay god Indra. Thus, he should have asked for a son who would be indraÅ›atrÃº â€˜Indraâ€™s slayer.â€™ However, being an ignorant demon, he mispronounced this expression as Ã­ndraÅ›atru which gave him a son who was killed by Indra. The version of this story in the Åšatapatha BrÄhmaá¹‡a says that the demon actually should have said: indrasya Å›atrur vardhasva. This has been

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 33 interpreted by scholars like Johannes Bronkhorst to suggest that using the proper accents for compounds had already become so difficult by this time, that the text asks that the compound be broken down to a phrase to avoid the confusion once for all. This story has been cited by phoneticians and grammarians to indicate why it is so important to learn how to properly pronounce the Vedic scriptures. 4.2.2. The pre-scientific phase of Sanskrit phonetics is already mani- fest in the earliest Vedic literature. The terms aká¹£ara â€˜letter, sound, syllableâ€™ and pada â€˜metrical foot,â€™ [and â€˜wordâ€™ in some contexts] go back to the different phases of the Vedic literature. Thieme (1985) has presented an important conjecture concerning the beginnings of Sanskrit phonetics. Thieme translates the first verse of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya-Atharvaveda as follows: à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‘à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘ à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¥’ à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤šà¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¬à¤²à¤¾à¥’ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥‘ à¤…à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥‘à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¥‡ à¥¥ (à¤¶à¥Œ.à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§) â€œThe thrice seven that go around, wearing all the shapes – let the Lord of Speech put their powers into my bodyâ€™s parts today.â€ After detailed argumentation, Thieme concludes that this verse refers to twenty-one sounds of Sanskrit as distinctly conceived by the earliest Vedic thinkers and he lists them as follows: a i u rÌ¥ e o ai au8 vowels y r l v4 semi-vowels k c á¹­ t p5 occlusives Å› á¹£ s h4 spirants Thieme (1985: 563) argues that â€œthe sacred number â€˜thrice sevenâ€™ could indeed be taken as the number of the abstract forms (ÄkrÌ¥ti-), of the types, the kinds (vará¹‡a-) of sounds of the sacred language.â€ Such a listing, if indeed this is what is intended by the verse, would indicate that certain phonetic features were perhaps understood more clearly by this time than others, and that the number twenty-one, in all likelihood, is a reflection of this early pre-scientific phase, rather than an explicit representation of the â€œtypesâ€ of Sanskrit sounds as found in the later developed texts on Sanskrit phonetics. Perhaps, the distinctions between the different points of articulation were implicitly understood, while the distinctions of quantity, voicing, aspiration, etc. were not arrived at.

34 INTRODUCTION 4.2.3. However, there is one major difficulty in accepting Thiemeâ€™s interpretation. It is not clear that all the classes of sounds listed by him in order to arrive at the number twenty-one were definitely recognized by the ancient phoneticians in India. We find several phonetic categories mentioned explicitly in late Vedic texts like the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka (2.2.4): à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥€à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚, à¤¯à¥‹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾, à¤¯ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€œThus, this [collection of] a thousand brÌ¥hatÄ« verses comes into existence. Of that collection, the consonants (vyaÃ±jana) are the body, the voice (ghoá¹£a = vowels) is its soul, and the spirants (Å«á¹£man) are its vital breath.â€ In the ChÄndogya-Upaniá¹£ad (2.22.5), vowels (svara) are distinguished explicitly from consonants (vyaÃ±jana), and among the consonants, a distinction is made between stops, i.e. sparÅ›a â€˜contact sounds,â€™ and spirants, i.e. Å«á¹£man â€˜aspiration soundsâ€™: à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¬à¤²à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ … à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ … à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾ à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤­à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€œAll vowels (svara) should be pronounced with resonance (ghoá¹£a) and force. … All spirants (Å«á¹£man) should be pro- nounced open, and not constricted or spitted out. … All stops (sparÅ›a = contact sounds) should be pronounced slightly in- complete.â€ 4.2.4. While these terms seem to have been well established by the period of the Ä€raá¹‡yakas, such is indeed not the case with the category of antaá¸¥sthÄ. The Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka (3.2.1) tells us that the specific category of semi-vowels (antasthÄ / antaá¸¥sthÄ) was newly proposed by the scholar Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya, but that it was as yet not recognized by the author of the Aitareya- Ä€raá¹‡yaka. à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥€à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤®à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤‚ à¤²à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤(à¤ƒ)à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µ à¤¨ à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œOf this self, the breath is like the spirants (Å«á¹£man), the bones the mutes (sparÅ›a), the marrow the vowels (svara), and flesh and blood the fourth part, the semi-vowels (antasthÄ). So says

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 35 Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya. However, only three elements have been taught to us.â€ We know from other evidence (Deshpande 1979: 261) that the scholarly tradition of Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya came from the Northeastern region of Magadha, and that it is an innovative tradition, which among other things admitted more retroflexion into the oral text of the RÌ¥gveda, and that its views were contested by others. If indeed the above statement of the Aitareya- Ä€raá¹‡yaka can be interpreted as an indication that the category of antaá¸¥sthÄ was a relatively late category, this then raises serious doubts concerning Paul Thiemeâ€™s interpretation of the first verse of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya-Atharvaveda as referring to twenty-one types of Sanskrit sounds including the four antaá¸¥sthÄ sounds. If the inference based on the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka is correct, it would seem more likely that in a much more ancient period, such as the composition of the AV hymns, the vowels and the semi-vowels were not analytically distinguished from each other. Since the semi-vowels are not covered by either the term sparÅ›a or Å«á¹£man appearing in the Ä€raá¹‡yaka literature, the non- distinction of semi-vowels from vowels is perhaps the strongest possibility for the earlier period. If vowels and semi-vowels were not yet clearly distinguished at this early period of the composition of the Saá¹ƒhitÄs, we may need to reconsider our understanding of the early form of the Saá¹ƒhitÄs as conceived by the pre-Ä€raá¹‡yaka traditions. I am simply mentioning this subject here. I shall deal with it exhaustively on another occasion. 4.3. Emergence of Formal Phonetic Analysis 4.3.1. Sometime around 700 B.C., a standardized ordered alphabet of Sanskrit called aká¹£arasamÄmnÄya had come into existence. By this process, I am referring to an ordered presentation or grouping of Sanskrit sounds, with no necessary connection with any form of writing. This standardization was necessitated, among other things, by an increasing diglossic gap between the language of the orally preserved Vedic texts and the contemporary Sanskrit, as well as the vernacular languages. There was a perceived loss of the natural ability to correctly pronounce and recite the Vedic scriptures. The discussions concerning the need to study Sanskrit phonetics as seen in the introductory chapter of the MB of PataÃ±jali (Â± 100 B.C.) show that the origin of the analytical tradition of Sanskrit phonetics lies in the urge to preserve the standardized pronunciation of the Vedic texts and to protect them from further deterioration.

36 INTRODUCTION 4.3.2. The earliest scholars who seem to have paid attention to the form of the Vedic texts, especially their wording and pronunciation, are ÅšÄkalya, ÅšÅ«ravÄ«ra MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya, and Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya. The Aitareya- Ä€raá¹‡yaka (3.2.6) points to the fact that ÅšÄkalya followed the tradition of the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keyas to a large extent:2 à¤…à¤¥ à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤®à¤¿à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤‚à¤¸à¤¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¥ˆ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¬à¤²à¤‚ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¹à¥ˆà¤¤à¥Œ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ƒà¤šà¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¸à¤¬à¤²à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¿à¤•à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥€à¥©à¤ à¤…à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤à¥© à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥€à¥©à¤ à¤…à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤à¥© à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ƒà¤šà¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¥‹ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤- à¤®à¥ƒà¤šà¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¥‹ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾- à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ (Edited by A.B. Keith. Oxford University Press, 1909, pp. 138-9) Now KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡ahÄrÄ«ta proclaims this secret doctrine, as it were, re- garding speech to him. PrajÄpati, the year, after creating creatures, burst. He put himself together by means of the meters, therefore it is the saá¹ƒhitÄ. Of that saá¹ƒhitÄ, the letter á¹‡ is the strength, the letter á¹£ the breath, the self. He who knows the saá¹ƒhitÄ and the letters á¹‡ and á¹£, he knows the saá¹ƒhitÄ with its breath and its strength. … If he is in doubt whether to say it with an á¹‡ or without an á¹‡, let him say it with an á¹‡. If he is in doubt whether to say it with an á¹£ or without an á¹£, let him say it with an á¹£. Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya says: â€œIf we repeat the verses according to the Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and if we recite according to the teaching of the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya, then the letters á¹‡ and á¹£ are obtained for us.â€

2 The ÅšÄá¹ƒkhÄyana-Ä€raá¹‡yaka 8.11 (ed. by Bhim Dev, Vishveshvarananda Vaidika Research Institute, Hoshiarpur, 1980) contains an important variant of the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka passage: à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ƒà¤šà¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¥‹ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ƒà¤šà¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¥‡, à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¨à¥‹ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ While the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka passage clearly indicates that ÅšÄkalya was a follower of the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya school on certain matters, the ÅšÄá¹ƒkhÄyana- Ä€raá¹‡yaka makes this relationship a little less clear. The introductory section called Vargadvaya at the beginning of the RÌ¥gvedaprÄtiÅ›Äkhya seems to suggest that the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keyas were more ancient, and it seems more likely that the relationship as inferred from the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka is historically justified.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 37 Sthavira ÅšÄkalya says: â€œIf we repeat the verses according to the Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and if we recite according to the teaching of the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya, then the letters á¹‡ and á¹£ are obtained for us.â€ 4.3.3. These authorities were also perhaps some of the earliest schol- arly figures who attempted to construct rules for combining words of the PadapÄá¹­ha to produce a continuous scriptural text (saá¹ƒhitÄ). The general assumption seems to have been that the continuous Vedic texts needed to be explicitly produced by applying the rules of sandhi to the word-by-word texts provided by scholars like ÅšÄkalya (cf. padaprakrÌ¥tiá¸¥ saá¹ƒhitÄ, NR 1.17; RPR 2.1). Thus, these early traditions did not offer any details on how to segment the received continuous texts, but they were engaged in figuring out the rules of sandhi which applied to the word-by-word texts to recreate the continuous texts. Thus, the concern of these early phoneticians and exegetes was two- fold, i.e. the proper pronunciation of the Vedic texts and figuring out the rules for performing sandhi operations on the word-by-word texts to produce the continuous texts. The first concern was responsible for developing the analytical study of the articulation of sounds, while the second concern was responsible for the search for features and groupings of these sounds which could be used in formulating the rules of sandhi. In these two concerns, we can see the origins of the phonetic and phonological theories of the ancient Indian phoneticians and grammarians. 4.3.4. The word Å›iká¹£Ä refers to training in general, and phonetic or recitational training in particular. It appears in the TaittirÄ«ya-Upaniá¹£ad (1.2) which refers specifically to six types of training involved in phonetic education, i.e. vará¹‡a â€˜sounds,â€™ svara â€˜accents,â€™ mÄtrÄ â€˜quantity,â€™ bala â€˜force,â€™ sÄma â€˜even articulation,â€™ and santÄna â€˜continuity in recitation.â€™ In later times, over a hundred texts called Åšiká¹£Äs were produced by different authorities. Most of the surviving Åšiká¹£Ä texts are of a relatively late period. The most well known among these Åšiká¹£Äs is the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä attributed by the tradition to the fa- mous Sanskrit grammarian PÄá¹‡ini. Other important Åšiká¹£Äs include the VyÄsaÅ›iká¹£Ä, the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, the YÄjÃ±avalkyaÅ›iká¹£Ä, and the NÄradaÅ›iká¹£Ä. A few of these Åšiká¹£Ä texts, such as the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä and the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, are non-â€œsectarianâ€ in the sense that they do not attach themselves to a particular Vedic school, and deal with the Sanskrit language in a generic way. However, most Åšiká¹£Ä texts are â€œsectarian.â€ They are attached to particular Vedic schools, and deal with the recitation of particular Vedic texts. They often provide the most minute details of the recitational practice.

38 INTRODUCTION 4.3.5. The second category of texts dealing with Sanskrit phonetics, traditionally considered to be more authoritative than the Åšiká¹£Äs, is represented by the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. As the word prÄtiÅ›Äkhya [< prati â€˜eachâ€™ + Å›ÄkhÄ â€˜branchâ€™] suggests, each branch of the Vedic literature was ideally expected to have a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya text attached to it. Among the surviving texts of this type, we must mention the following important treatises. The RÌ¥gveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya attributed to Åšaunaka belongs to the ÅšaiÅ›irÄ«ya branch of the RÌ¥gveda, which is no longer extant. It refers to the views of ÅšÄkalya, whose edition of the RÌ¥gveda survives, but there is no extant PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya attributed to ÅšÄkalya. The TaittirÄ«ya- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya is attached to the TaittirÄ«ya school of the Black Yajurveda. The VÄjasaneyi-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya is attached to the White Yajurveda. A text called the BhÄá¹£ika-SÅ«tra deals with the recitation of the late Vedic prose text of the Åšatapatha-BrÄhmaá¹‡a belonging to the tradition of the White Yajurveda. There are five texts which fall in the general category of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas of the SÄmaveda. Of these five texts, only the RÌ¥ktantra deals with the general discussion of phonetics. There are two texts, i.e. the Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya and the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ, associated with the ÅšaunakÄ«ya school of the Atharvaveda. The exact dating of the Åšiká¹£Äs and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas has been a topic of long-standing debates. In general, one can say that the existing Åšiká¹£Äs seem to be â€œall of them, young, elaborations of the definitions laid down in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas,â€ (Thieme 1935: 85-6). The existing PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas themselves seem to have old and new textual layers in them, some pre-dating the grammarian PÄá¹‡ini (Â± 500 B.C.), others reflecting post-PÄá¹‡inian develop- ments. 4.4. Formation of Sanskrit Alphabet 4.4.1. Referred to by the term aká¹£ara-samÄmnÄya â€˜collective state- ment of sounds,â€™ an ordered Sanskrit alphabet, with no reference to writing intended, seems to have come into existence by the time the late Vedic literature (about 700 B.C.) was produced. A distinction between vowels and consonants was already made. The consonants were generally divided into three categories, sparÅ›a â€˜contact sounds,â€™ antaá¸¥sthÄ â€˜in-between sounds,â€™ and uá¹£man â€˜aspiration sounds.â€™ The first category included stops and nasals, the second category included semi-vowels, and the third category included spirants. A further amplification resulted in the following generally accepted alphabet:

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 39 Vowels:a Ä i Ä« u Å« rÌ¥ rÌ¥Ì„ lÌ¥ e o ai au Consonants: sparÅ›a:k khg gh á¹… cchjjhÃ± á¹­á¹­há¸á¸há¹‡ tthddhn pphbbhm antaá¸¥sthÄ:yrlv Å«á¹£manÅ› á¹£sh Additional sounds: AnusvÄraá¹ƒ Visargaá¸¥ JihvÄmÅ«lÄ«yaá¸« (before k, kh) UpadhmÄnÄ«yaáº– (before p, ph) 4.4.2. The above alphabet, or rather the formal listing of sounds, is accepted with minor differences by all the Åšiká¹£Äs and PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. The al- phabet shows a tacit awareness of several features of sounds, and a certain ordering of those features. The vowels are grouped into several sub-groups. The first group is represented by the vowels a, Ä, i, Ä«, u, and Å«. These are the basic simple vowels. They are ordered back-to-front in terms of their points of articulation, i.e. throat (kaá¹‡á¹­ha), palate (tÄlu), and lips (oá¹£á¹­ha). This order is the reverse of the front-to-back order of listing the sounds in western linguistics, e.g. p, t, k. To these basic simple vowels are added the vocalic rÌ¥, rÌ¥Ì„, lÌ¥, (and lÌ¥Ì„ for some traditions). All these together, beginning with a, are called samÄna â€˜simpleâ€™ vowels. They are grouped into pairs of short and long vowels, and each pair is often subsumed under a common generalization called vará¹‡a, e.g. the vowels a and Ä belong to the family or type designated by the term a-vará¹‡a. After the simple vowels comes the group of four vowels, i.e. e, o, ai, and au. These four are generally called sandhyaká¹£aras â€˜compound-vowels.â€™ Out of these four, the first two are often, though not always, described as monophthongs, while the latter two are most often explicitly called dvi-vará¹‡a â€˜consisting of two sounds,â€™ i.e. diphthongs. The principle of back-to-front ordering in terms of the points of articulations is maintained even in the sub- groups e, o, and ai, au. As we move to the category of sounds called sparÅ›a

40 INTRODUCTION â€˜contact sounds, â€™ i.e. stops and nasals, we see several converging principles at work. The five horizontal groups are each called a varga â€˜group,â€™ i.e. k(a)- varga, c(a)-varga, á¹­(a)-varga, t(a)-varga, and p(a)-varga. The vertical ordering of these groups shows the same back-to-front ordering, with the k(a)-varga at the back end of the spectrum of points of articulation and the p(a)-varga at the front end of the same spectrum. The palatal, the retroflex, and the dental groups are ordered between the velar and the labial groups. The vertical lines intersecting these five groups show other phonetic features. The first vertical group, i.e. k, c, á¹­, t, and p, consists of voiceless unaspirated stops. The second vertical group, i.e. kh, ch, á¹­h, th, and ph, consists of voiceless aspirated stops. The third vertical group, i.e. g, j, á¸, d, and b, consists of voiced unaspirated stops. The fourth vertical group, i.e. gh, jh, á¸h, dh, and bh, consists of voiced aspirated stops. The fifth vertical group, i.e. á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m, consists of nasals. 4.4.3. The order of consonants in each of the five horizontal groups of stops and nasals is significant for other theoretical reasons as well. Desh- pande (1976) shows that there were theorists who reduced the total number of primitive sounds to a much smaller number and argued that other Sanskrit sounds were built by combining these primitive sounds. The principal sources of information on these ancient theories are the RPR (13.13; 13.15) and the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä text quoted by the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya on CA (1.1.12): à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¹à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤‚à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥€à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¥€à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤‹.à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾. à¥§à¥©.à¥§à¥© à¥¥ â€œWhen the air (coming up from lungs) is associated with a spe- cific desire of the speaker, that air, being transformed into a sound through specific articulatory effort, attains to various auditory forms, because of the acquisition of various proper- ties.â€ à¤†à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨, à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¥ à¤‹.à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾. à¥§à¥©.à¥§à¥« à¥¥ â€œSome call a the voice of the voiced [consonants], and the á¹ƒ [the voice] of the nasal [consonants]. They also say that the aspiration of the [voiceless] aspirated [stops] is [due to a com- bination] with a homorganic spirant, and [the aspiration] of the voiced [aspirated stops] is [due to a combination] with the voiced [spirant, i.e. h].â€

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 41 Ancient Åšiká¹£Ä quoted in CAB on CA (1.1.12): â€˜à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥ˆà¤°à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¤®à¤¨à¥€à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤à¥à¤šà¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ â€œThe thirds and the firsts, combined with homorganic spirants, become the fourths and the seconds. Such is the decision. Another phonetician says: The fourth is [derived] through a combination with h. Some scholars say that there are only five stops, i.e. the firsts [of the respective series]. They are trans- formed into other sounds through their acquisition of different properties. [The firsts, i.e. k, c, á¹­, t, and p], combined respec- tively with these factors, i.e. á¸« (= jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya), Å›, á¹£, s, and áº– (= upadhmÄnÄ«ya), are known as the seconds, [i.e. kh, ch, á¹­h, th, and ph]. The same [firsts], when combined with voice (ghoá¹£a), are known as the thirds, [i.e. g, j, á¸, d, and b]. [When the thirds are further] combined with a second element, a spirant, they are known as the fourths, [i.e. gh, jh, á¸h, dh, and bh]. When the firsts, combined with voice, are nasalized, they are known as the fifths, [i.e. á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m]. Thus, the properties of the sounds are traditionally recounted.â€ Thus, for instance, in the series k, kh, g, gh, and á¹…, the first consonant k is deemed to be a primitive consonant. By adding the voiceless velar aspi- ration, i.e. á¸« (jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya), to the primitive k, one derives the voiceless aspirate stop kh. It is important to note that the aspirated stops are called soá¹£man â€˜fused with a spirantâ€™ in Sanskrit indicating their compound nature in terms of these early phonetic theories. My best guess is that this theory developed after the period of the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka, which knows the term Å«á¹£man, but not soá¹£man. The latter is obviously derived from the former, and hence comes after the former, at least logically, if not also chronologically. Similarly, the

42 INTRODUCTION sound g is derived by adding the primitive voice (ghoá¹£a) a to the primitive consonant k. Thus, naturally, the category of voiced consonants is called ghoá¹£avat â€˜with voice,â€™ indicating that the feature of voice is also looked at as an add-on feature. The sound gh is derived by adding the voiced aspiration h to k. The final nasal of the series, i.e. á¹…, is derived by adding the primitive voiced nasal á¹ƒ (anusvÄra) to the primitive consonant k. Thus, the order of these consonants represents the results of prior theoretical considerations which are explicitly discussed in texts like the RPR and the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä quoted in the CAB (Deshpande 1976). 4.4.4. After these â€˜contactâ€™ sounds, the alphabet lists the semi-vowels or â€˜in-between-soundsâ€™ (antasthÄ / antaá¸¥sthÄ), i.e. y, r, l, and v. At the very end are listed the spirants, Å«á¹£man â€˜aspiration sounds,â€™ i.e. Å›, á¹£, s, and h. The semi-vowels, i.e. y, r, l, and v, as well as the three sibilants, i.e. Å›, á¹£, and s, also exhibit the back-to-front ordering in terms of the points of articulations of the included sounds. It seems that the phoneticians intended the final h as a separate addition to the first three sibilants. The first three are voiceless sibilants, while the final h, is a voiced aspiration. Most texts also add the sounds á¹ƒ, á¸¥, áº–, and á¸«. Among these sounds, the sounds, á¸¥ (visarga) is a voiceless h sound. The sounds á¸« (jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya) and áº– (upadhmÄnÄ«ya) are variants for á¸¥, before k, kh, and p, ph, respectively. The nature of the sound represented by á¹ƒ, the anusvÄra, is highly debated in the ancient texts. The general consensus is that it is an oral-nasal generic sound which changes to homorganic nasals in accordance with what follows. An unchanged or un- changeable á¹ƒ is found only before the spirants and r. This predominant context of spirants for the anusvÄra led some texts like the RPR to include this sound in its list of spirants (Å«á¹£man). Since there was a feeling that an anusvÄra could be prolonged in length in recitation, the same text says that an anusvÄra may be considered to be either a vowel or a consonant. Most of these texts discuss several other sounds and their features. Besides the á¹ƒ (= anusvÄra) which is generally described as an oral-nasal sound, most texts also posit another sound called nÄsikya, which is deemed to be a pure nasal sound. Additionally, most texts talk about fractional vowels, such as the ones which go in the make-up of a vowel normally represented as rÌ¥, i.e. âˆ‚râˆ‚. The phonetic treatises also go into details of what are clearly transitional sounds. For instance, the texts talk about a nasal gà¤ (= Î·?) intervening between the consonants g and n in a word like agni. Such consonants are called Yamas. The texts also go into details of accents (= pitch variation) and nasalization of vowels, as well as three- and four-moraic vowels. According to these texts,

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 43 one can also get contextual nasal variants for all vowels, and the semi-vowels y, v, and l, i.e. á»¹, á¹½, and lÌƒ. 4.5. Descriptive Techniques & Terminology 4.5.1. The descriptive and the prescriptive goal of the ancient Indian phonetic tradition was to be able to clearly distinguish between different sounds of Sanskrit, so that one will not be mistaken or mispronounced for another. Verse 10 of the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä says: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¤ à¥¥ Sounds are distinguished from each other on the basis of accents (svara), time or duration (kÄla), point of articulation (sthÄna), manner (prayatna), and type of phonation (anupradÄna). Here the term svara â€˜accentâ€™ refers to the pitch distinctions denoted by the terms udÄtta â€˜high,â€™ anudÄtta â€˜low,â€™ and svarita â€˜rising-falling.â€™ The term kÄla â€˜durationâ€™ refers to units of time it requires to pronounce a given sound. Consonants are generally considered to be of a half-mora (ardha-mÄtrÄ) length, while vowels can be of one, two, three and four morae in length. The one-mora vowels are called hrasva â€˜short.â€™ The two-mora vowels are called dÄ«rgha â€˜long.â€™ Vowels with three and four morae length are called pluta â€˜prolonged.â€™ The term sthÄna â€˜place, point of articulationâ€™ refers to points on the articulatory track, i.e. uras â€˜chest,â€™ kaá¹‡á¹­ha â€˜throat,â€™ jihvÄmÅ«la â€˜tongue-root,â€™ tÄlu â€˜hard-palate,â€™ mÅ«rdhan â€˜cerebrum, roof of the oral cavity,â€™ dantamÅ«la â€˜alveolar ridge, root of teeth,â€™ danta â€˜teeth,â€™ and oá¹£á¹­ha â€˜lips.â€™ The list of points of articulation sometimes also includes nÄsikÄ â€˜nose.â€™ The term prayatna â€˜mannerâ€™ refers to how the physical organ called karaá¹‡a â€˜articulatorâ€™ relates to the point of articulation, i.e. sparÅ›a â€˜contact,â€™ upasaá¹ƒhÄra â€˜approximation,â€™ vivrÌ¥ta â€˜open,â€™ etc. The term karaá¹‡a â€˜articulatorâ€™ generally refers to different parts of the tongue, such as the tip, the middle, and the root, as well as the sides or edges and the middle. It also refers to teeth in the case of labio-dental sounds like v, and to the lower lip in the case of labial sounds like b. For nasalized vowels such as Ã£, Ä©, Å©, áº½, and Ãµ, the nose is often considered to be the articulator, while for the nasal consonants á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m, the nose is considered to be the point of articulation (Deshpande 1975: 11-12). The texts show a great diversity of opinion on many of these classifications (cf. Allen 1953, Bare 1976). The final category is that of anupradÄna â€˜phonation, emission.â€™ Generally, there are two types of emission,

44 INTRODUCTION i.e. Å›vÄsa â€˜breathâ€™ and nÄda â€˜resonance,â€™ resulting from two different positions of the glottal chords, vivrÌ¥ta â€˜openâ€™ and saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta â€˜closeâ€™ respectively.
