The emission of the type of breath further results in voiceless sounds, while the emission of the type of resonance further results in vowels and voiced consonants. Some texts like the TaittirÄ«ya-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya claim that there is a third type of emission called hakÄra â€˜the h sound, voiced aspirationâ€™ when the glottal chords are in a position in-between open and close, and this type combines voice or resonance with aspiration and is termed breathy voice in modern phonetics. This type of emission is found in the voiced spirant h, as well as in voiced aspirate stops such as gh, jh, á¸h, dh, and bh. The ancient Indian texts use two different terms, nÄda and ghoá¹£a to refer to voicing. We are often told that the feature of nÄda is shared by vowels and ghoá¹£avat consonants, lit. consonants possessed of ghoá¹£a, voiced consonants. Modern scholars have debated the question of whether or not this refers to two different types of resonance. Some have suggested that the distinction has no articulatory basis, but that it is phonologically motivated. Others have suggested a possible articulatory basis, namely that the first, i.e. nÄda, is produced by the closure of glottal chords, and that the secondary amplification, i.e. ghoá¹£a, is produced by a closure in the oral chamber created by the contact between the articulator and the point of articulation (cf. Deshpande 1976, Cardona 1983). 4.5.2. Certain features are considered as plus/minus features in ancient Indian phonetics, while others are considered as more/less features. The terms ghoá¹£avat (voiced) and aghoá¹£a (voiceless) indicate that the feature of ghoá¹£a â€˜voiceâ€™ is a plus/minus feature. On the other hand, the feature of aspiration, especially when designated by the term prÄá¹‡a, appears as a more/less feature. The sounds which are called unaspirated in Western ter- minology are called alpaprÄá¹‡a â€˜with less prÄá¹‡a,â€™ while the aspirated sounds are called mahÄprÄá¹‡a â€˜with greater prÄá¹‡a.â€™ Similarly, the notion of prayatna â€˜effort, mannerâ€™ is expressed in some texts in binary terms sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a/asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜with or without contact between the articulator and the point of articulation,â€™ while in other texts, this notion is expressed in terms of degrees of openness and contact i.e. vivrÌ¥ta â€˜open,â€™ Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta â€˜slightly open,â€™ vivrÌ¥tatara â€˜more open,â€™ and vivrÌ¥tatama â€˜most open,â€™ sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜in contact,â€™ and Ä«á¹£atsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜in slight contact.â€™ 4.6. What is distinctive? 4.6.1. Several scholars have devoted their attention to a possible distinction between phonetics and phonology in the context of the ancient traditions of Sanskrit phonetics and grammar (cf. Deshpande 1975, Bare 1976,

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 45 Cardona 1983). Often the term vará¹‡a is translated with the term â€˜phonemeâ€™ in modern expositions of Sanskrit phonetics. The Sanskrit grammarians do indeed discuss minimum pairs like kÅ«pa/sÅ«pa/yÅ«pa. However, the term vará¹‡a does not strictly refer to a phoneme in modern linguistics. For Sanskrit phoneticians, the sounds n and Ã± are distinct vará¹‡as, while they would be only allophones for a modern linguist. On the contrary, the sounds a and Ä would be separate phonemes for a modern linguist, but they belong to the same vará¹‡a for Sanskrit phoneticians and grammarians. On the other hand, the Sanskrit phoneticians and grammarians do indeed have a notion that certain features of sounds are relevant in some descriptive contexts, while they are not relevant in other contexts. KÄtyÄyana in his comments on PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar often brings up the notion that the features (guá¹‡a, quality) of accent (svara), nasality (ÄnunÄsikya), and duration (kÄla) are distinctive (bhedaka), See: Deshpande (1975: 50ff; 203, note 442; 207, note 466). According to the fully developed phonetico-grammatical doctrines of Sanskrit grammarians, the term avará¹‡a refers to the whole family (e.g. avará¹‡a-kula) of the following eighteen sounds: a, Ä, Ä3, Ã¡, ÄÌ, ÄÌ3, Ã , ÄÌ€, ÄÌ€3, Ã£, ÄÌƒ, ÄÌƒ3, Ã£Ì, ÄÌƒÌ, ÄÌƒÌ3, Ã£Ì€, ÄÌƒÌ€, ÄÌƒÌ€3. 4.6.2. The distinctions of length, accent, and nasality are not relevant for inclusion in a vará¹‡a. On the other hand, the term akÄra refers to the six tokens of short a differing in accent and nasality, but not in length. The grammarian-phoneticians knew that in formulating some rules of sandhi, they could achieve maximum descriptive economy by resorting to the vará¹‡a groupings, while for other rules, the -kÄra grouping seemed more economical, and for still other rules, one needed to make a highly specific reference to a token with a specific length, nasality, accent etc. The grammarian-phoneticians make several important distinctions in their terminology. For instance, two sound tokens are sarÅ«pa â€˜with identical phonetic shape,â€™ if and only if they have all identical phonetic features, including length, nasality, accents, etc. Two vowel-tokens are grouped in the same x-kÄra group, if they have the same point of articulation, articulator, manner, and quantity. They could differ in nasality and accent, and still be part of the same x-kÄra group. Two sounds are savará¹‡a â€˜homogeneousâ€™ with each other if they share the same point of articulation and the same manner. These different groupings were used to formulate different rules in Sanskrit grammar, and allowed descriptive optimization. The notion of maximal featural proximity (Äntaratamya) is one of the principles used in Sanskrit grammar to determine the choice of a substitute from among a choice of alternatives (cf. Bare 1976, Hueckstedt 1995). 4.6.3. The Sanskrit grammarian-phoneticians were also aware of another distinction, i.e. that of the speed of delivery or tempo, i.e. fast, medium,

46 INTRODUCTION and slow. These modes of recitation are discussed in KÄtyÄyanaâ€™s VÄrttikas on PÄá¹‡ini 1.1.70 and 1.4.109. NÄgeÅ›abhaá¹­á¹­a, in his Uddyota (MB, Vol. I, Pt. I, p. 378) quotes the following verse: à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤²à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¥ The verse says that different modes of delivery were considered to be appropriate for different contexts. The fast speed is supposed to be used when a person is reciting the mantras for his own study. In the ritual use of the mantras, one is supposed to use the medium speed. A teacher is supposed to use the slow speed to recite the mantras while teaching his students. Using an inappropriate speed at the wrong occasion creates unacceptable situations, and in this sense, the speed or tempo is a distinctive feature at this level. However, these differences of tempo had no euphonic or grammatical value. This has been clearly recognized by KÄtyÄyana in his VÄrttika: siddhaá¹ƒ tv avasthitÄ vará¹‡Ä vaktuÅ› cirÄciravacanÄd vrÌ¥ttayo viÅ›iá¹£yante, MB (Kielhorn edn.), Vol.I, p. 181. Further they noticed that a consonant such as k seemed to acquire a certain degree of voicing in intervocalic positions, but that it was not to be distinguished from the generic k for all practical purposes. 4.6.4. In the work of BhartrÌ¥hari, the grammarian-philosopher of Â± 500 A.D., we find a new representation of these different levels of distinctive- ness. These different levels of distinctiveness are seen in terms of a production model. There is a notion that there are ontologically eternal true sounds (sphoá¹­a, vará¹‡a) which are temporally manifested by the physical sounds of two kinds, primary physical sounds (prÄkrÌ¥ta-dhvani) and secondary physical sounds (vaikrÌ¥ta-dhvani). There are several different views found in BhartrÌ¥hariâ€™s VÄkyapadÄ«ya and in his commentary on PataÃ±jaliâ€™s MB regarding the relationship between the real sounds, the primary physical sounds, and the secondary physical sounds, and these have been ably discussed in detail by S.D. Joshi (1967: 20-34). For our present purpose, suffice it to say that the level of sphoá¹­a â€˜true sound,â€™ in general, seems to reflect only the features of point of articulation, manner, voicing, aspiration, etc., but not duration or tempo. The sphoá¹­a level is said to be beyond temporality, while the primary manifesting sounds have the feature of duration or length. The secondary manifesting sounds, which are further reverberations of the primary manifesting sounds, reveal the feature of tempo. Thus, in general, we get concentric circles representing different features. As a production model, I do not think BhartrÌ¥hariâ€™s ideas will rank very high in the evaluation of modern

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 47 phoneticians. On the other hand, the diagrammatic perception of the various phonetic features as concentric circles moving out from more distinctive to less distinctive offers an interesting view of these features and deserves to be explored further. 5. Phonetics vs Phonology in Indian Grammatical Tradition 5.1. â€˜Phoneticsâ€™ versus â€˜Phonologyâ€™ in Modern Linguistics 5.1.1. There are a number of distinctions made explicitly in modern linguistics for which there are no exact parallels in the traditions of Sanskrit Åšiká¹£Äs, PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, and VyÄkaraá¹‡a. One such distinction is that between the categories of â€˜phoneticâ€™ versus â€˜phonemicâ€™, or to use a more recent term, â€˜phonologicalâ€™. Both phonetics and phonology, in their various brands and branches as practiced in modern linguistics, represent a study of the sound system of a given language. Without getting into too many technicalities, we can describe the difference between these two allied fields in the following way. Phonetics aims at studying the articulatory and the acoustic processes involved in the production of the sounds used by a given language. The very basic material which is being studied may be called phonic material, i.e. the sounds of a language as they are produced and perceived. The next level of understanding may be reached in what may be called phonemic. At this level, an analyst may be looking for features which are distinctive in some sense. The notion of â€˜phonemeâ€™ in structural linguistics attempted to come to grips with this question. There may be two instances of the phonic material which may be different in some respect, and yet may be perceived by both the speaker and the listener as being two instances of the same sound. This kind of an approach leads the analyst to distinguish between differences among the sounds which matter, and the differences which do not matter. Now the whole notion of what matters is a complex notion in itself and later we shall explore this complexity in some detail. At this point, suffice it to say that the traditional notion of â€˜phonemeâ€™ dealt with one such level of what matters, and came up with a concept that for a given language, there was a fixed inventory of distinctive sounds. This lead the structural linguists to work on determining such inventories for various languages, and to debate whether a given phone or

48 INTRODUCTION sound-instance was an independent phoneme, or merely an allophone, a contextual variant of a phoneme. Eventually, the emphasis on inventories of phonemes, and the debate on a semi-metaphysical question of whether such phonemes exist, gave way to a study of what came to be known as distinctive features. The sounds came to be viewed as bundles of features, some of which were viewed as being distinctive in some sense. The emphasis on the discovery of phonemes then shifted to the determination of a set of distinctive features for a given language. The next level of understanding of the sounds of a language is reached in a branch of linguistics which is now generally called phonology. In terms of the current state of the science of linguistics, the branch of phonemics is very much dead, while the branches of phonetics and phonology are very much alive and prospering. What does phonology deal with? Phonology deals with the study of relationships between the sounds and features of these sounds as part of a system. It focuses on the behavior of sounds in relation to each other, and investigates the questions of how the behavior of sounds can be described in the form of predictable rules. Such rules may make use of various groupings of sounds, their features etc., and can be formulated at increasingly abstract levels. Phonetics and phonology may be studied both in synchronic as well as diachronic aspects. In both such approaches, one can raise the question of not only â€˜howâ€™ the sounds behave, but go further and raise the question of â€˜whyâ€™ the sounds behave in a particular way. The answer to the question of â€˜whyâ€™ may then be given in various different ways. For a given pattern of behavior of sounds, the answer may lie in the current phonetic features of those sounds, or such a behavior of sounds may simply reflect an inherited pattern of behavior, not fully justifiable in terms of the current features of the given sounds. This leads to some interesting and important possibilities. It is relatively easy to see that phonological groupings of sounds may be motivated by the phonetic features of the given sounds. However, one cannot discount the possibility and the probability that the phonological behavior of sounds may in some cases lead sounds with originally divergent phonetic features to move closer to a more homogeneous phonetic character. 5.1.2. The tradition of Sanskrit phonetics represented in the Åšiká¹£Äs, PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, and Sanskrit Grammars clearly does not have any interest in the historical study of Sanskrit, and hence one cannot find any explicit discussions in this tradition in this regard. At the same time, one need not assume that this tradition has been left untouched by the history of the language itself. Similarly, even though the tradition has no explicit separate terms for what we call phonetics and phonology in modern linguistics, one need not assume that

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 49 the ancient grammarians and phoneticians did not have some of the same concerns. We need to look for what such concerns may have been, and the ways in which such concerns have surfaced in the ancient literature. While we must make every effort to make sure that we are not superimposing a modern set of concepts on the statements of the ancient grammarians, we should leave no stone unturned to find out the distinctions that they made, and the ones which they did not make. A good deal of work has been done in this direction by scholars like George Cardona, Paul Kiparsky, myself, my student James Bare, and more recently by Robert Hueckstedt. In what follows, I shall briefly describe the kind of research which has been going on in this field for the past twenty some years. Many of the details, which I shall report, involve long- standing controversies, though here I shall not proceed in a polemical fashion. 5.2. â€˜Vará¹‡aâ€™ versus â€˜Phonemeâ€™ 5.2.1. In modern expositions of Sanskrit grammar and phonetics, especially the ones coming from India, there has been a tendency to use the term â€˜phonemeâ€™ to render the Sanskrit term vará¹‡a. Whatever the historical origins of the term vará¹‡a, and we shall not deal with that question here, the term has been used with a wide latitude of reference in Sanskrit literature. Perhaps the term vará¹‡a is very much like the English term â€˜letter,â€™ making an oblique reference to the art of writing. The widest possible meaning of the term vará¹‡a is â€˜sound, letter.â€™ In this wide sense, it appears in expressions like vará¹‡a-samÄmnÄya, where it seems to be identical in meaning with the term aká¹£ara, cf. aká¹£ara-samÄmnÄya. If the term vará¹‡a refers to sounds listed in the traditional Sanskrit alphabet, including the often unlisted sounds (ayogavÄhas), e.g. á¹ƒ and á¸¥, can this use of the term vará¹‡a be identical in meaning with the sense of the term â€˜phonemeâ€™ in structural linguistics? Most of the sounds listed in the Sanskrit alphabet do qualify for the term â€˜phoneme,â€™ but not all. In order that a sound should qualify for the term â€˜phoneme,â€™ we must have minimal pairs of words which differ in just one sound. PataÃ±jaliâ€™s kÅ«pa / sÅ«pa / yÅ«pa analysis does look similar to the analysis with minimal pairs in structural linguistics. However, the fact is that for sounds like á¸¥, á¹…, Ã±, á¸«, and áº–, we cannot find minimal pairs in Sanskrit. For example, we have the pair bhÄna / bhÄá¹‡a, where the change of just one sound produces another word with a distinct meaning. Through analysis like this, we can conclude that the Sanskrit alphabet includes some vará¹‡as which are not phonemes, but are allophones in modern terminology. Why were such sounds considered to be vará¹‡as? Here, the distinctive background of the Sanskrit phonetic tradition must be fully

50 INTRODUCTION appreciated. There seem to be two possible reasons for treating a sound like Ã± to be a separate vará¹‡a. The first reason seems to be that the distinction of allophones versus phonemes is foreign to the Indian tradition. The Indian tradition was also a prayoga-Å›Ästra â€˜a science of performance,â€™ and obviously it did desire that a reciter should pronounce Ã±, where it was required, and should not mispronounce it as n, or á¹‡. Even if there are no minimal pairs for Ã±, every Vaidika knows that Ã± must be distinguished from other sounds in recitation. Secondly, the phoneme-allophone analysis applies when we are taking into account only one language at a time. Several Åšiká¹£Äs, including the more popular PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä (v. 3), say: à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤ƒ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤ƒà¤·à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤­à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥‡ à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤, â€œIn the opinion of Åšiva, there are 63 or 64 sounds in Sanskrit as well as in Prakrit.â€ Besides the initial uncertainty about the exact number of vará¹‡as, the verse clearly points out that these are the vará¹‡as for both Sanskrit and Prakrit together. In Prakrit we can find minimal pairs involving Ã±, e.g. Ã±Äá¹‡a versus nÄá¹‡a(ka). Such a pair may make Ã± a legitimate phoneme for Prakrit. For Indian phoneticians, Ã± was simply distinct from n, á¹‡, and á¹…. Thus, the notion of phoneme must be distinguished from that of vará¹‡a. We must appreciate the similarities as well as the differences. 5.3. â€˜Vará¹‡a,â€™ â€˜Varga,â€™ and â€˜Savará¹‡aâ€™ 5.3.1. Now we can move to a narrower, and a more technical usage of the word vará¹‡a. In this narrow usage, the word -vará¹‡a is distinguished from -kÄra. The word vará¹‡a, when affixed to a short vowel, e.g. i-vará¹‡a, stands for the whole class of i-sounds differing in length, accents, and nasality. PataÃ±jali uses the term a-vará¹‡a-kula for such a class. Thus, there is a-vará¹‡a, but not Ä- vará¹‡a, ai-vará¹‡a, ka-vará¹‡a, or ya-vará¹‡a. Instead of these, we have Ä-kÄra, ai- kÄra, ka-kÄra, and ya-kÄra. The term a-kÄra is also a generalization in that it refers to varieties of short a, which may differ in accent and nasality. For the groups of stops, one could not use the term vará¹‡a, but one called the group of k, kh, g, gh, and á¹…, by the term ka-varga. In older works like the Åšiká¹£Äs and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, membership within a vará¹‡a-group, or a varga-group was generally defined simply by listing the sounds, cf. à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‡, TPR (1.3), also: Deshpande (1975: 85ff). This is generally the meaning of the term savará¹‡a in the Åšiká¹£Äs and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, i.e. these sounds belong to the same vará¹‡a. The term kavarga was defined by just picking out the first item of the list and saying: this is the k- class.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 51 5.4. From Definitions by Listing to Featural Definitions 5.4.1. As we move from the Åšiká¹£Äs and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas to PÄá¹‡ini, we see a qualitative difference in the way the groupings of sounds are defined. Here, there are two modes of defining groups. The first way is to make shortforms (pratyÄhÄras) based on the listings in the ÅšivasÅ«tras. The second way is to access members of a group through the procedure called savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a â€˜accessing a class of savará¹‡as by referring to a single token.â€™ While the Åšiká¹£Äs and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas defined the phonetic features of Sanskrit sounds, it was PÄá¹‡ini who showed a superior ability to define groupings of sounds in terms of their phonetic features. This is how his definition of savará¹‡a differs significantly from the definitions found in most of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas: P.1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥). The rule says that any two sounds are called savará¹‡as of each other if and only if they share the same Äsya- prayatna â€˜oral effort.â€™ The term Äsyaprayatna was eventually interpreted as referring to two features: sthÄna â€˜place of articulationâ€™ and Äbhyantara-prayatna â€˜internal effort,â€™ i.e. the manner in which the karaá¹‡a or the articulator was related to the place of articulation.â€™ PÄá¹‡ini himself did not specify the phonetic categories he had in mind, although the later PÄá¹‡inian commentators have provided those details for us. Here we shall not go into the question of whether the later PÄá¹‡inian tradition has given us historically reliable phonetic classifications for PÄá¹‡ini. In any case, this single generalization in PÄá¹‡ini covered the two separate notions in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, i.e. savará¹‡a and savarga. Once this was accomplished, PÄá¹‡ini introduced his general and limited procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a through his rules P.1.1.69 (à¤…à¤£à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ) and P.1.1.70 (à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯). In terms of the progress of linguistic theory, this indeed marked an advance. 5.5. Problems of the New Phonology in PÄá¹‡ini 5.5.1. The new featural definition of savará¹‡a in PÄá¹‡ini, and the procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a, achieved new theoretical success, and yet in the wake of this success, it brought with it new problems, which the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas were generally not faced with. I shall mention here two such problems. The phonetic features assumed by PÄá¹‡ini were such that the vowels and the spirants (Å›, á¹£, s, and h) had the same prayatna, i.e. the degree of closure or openness between the articulator and the place of articulation. This would have made some vowels savará¹‡as of some consonants, and the procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a would have allowed a vowel to stand for its consonantal

52 INTRODUCTION savará¹‡a. PÄá¹‡ini did recognize the possibility of such undesired over-extension of the notion of savará¹‡a, and to prevent it, he formulated his rule P.1.1.10 (à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¥Œ). In general terms, the rule is supposed to say that vowels cannot be savará¹‡as with consonants. This shows the limitations of featural groupings for functional purposes. In spite of the common phonetic features, vowels and consonants must be grouped apart from each other. On the other hand, consider the opposite problem with a and Ä. Traditionally, Ä was described as an open (vivrÌ¥ta) sound, while a was described as a close (saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta) sound. Thus, their prayatna being different from each other, they would not become savará¹‡as of each other, and then they cannot be grouped together. To get over this problem, PÄá¹‡ini apparently pronounced an open short a throughout his grammar, which was restored to a close short a by the last rule of his grammar, i.e. P.8.4.68 (à¤… à¤…). This made these two sounds technically savará¹‡as of each other throughout his grammar, and only the very last rule, invisible to the rest of the grammar, restored it to its true pronunciation. There is a moral to this story. Sounds with common phonetic features can have a different functional load, and sounds with different phonetic features may have the same functional load. This same result has been achieved by some texts by using terms like savará¹‡avat. In the later PÄá¹‡inian tradition, the sounds rÌ¥ and lÌ¥ were legislated to be each otherâ€™s savará¹‡as in spite of the difference in their phonetic features (cf. VÄrttika 4 on P. 1.1.10: à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ). 5.6. Vará¹‡arÅ«pa versus Vará¹‡ÄkrÌ¥ti: From Phonetic Features to Metaphysics 5.6.1. If the difference between the Åšiká¹£Äs and PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas3 on the one hand and PÄá¹‡ini on the other can be caracterized as a move from groupings by listing to groupings by features, especially in the context of the notion of savará¹‡a, the difference between PÄá¹‡ini and KÄtyÄyana may be characterized as a move from featural phonology to metaphysical phonology. To describe this move briefly, we can say that for PÄá¹‡ini, the sounds listed in the ÅšivasÅ«tras stand for themselves to begin with, and they stand for their savará¹‡a class only as a result of the procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a. As we have seen before, membership to the class of savará¹‡a is controlled by the featural definition of the class given by P.1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥). Where the procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a does not apply, the given sound stands just for itself. The basic notion of a sound standing for â€˜itselfâ€™ is expressed by PÄá¹‡ini through the

3 This is a broad generalization about this literature, and has specific exceptions which may be post-Paninian, e.g. the VÄjasaneyi-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 53 term rÅ«pa â€˜phonetic shapeâ€™ of a sound, and this notion has been incorporated in expressions like sarÅ«pa, asarÅ«pa, and in the fundamental rule P.1.1.68 (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾). Thus, the form of a word is basically viewed by PÄá¹‡ini in terms of its phonetic shape. Moving away from this featural phonology of PÄá¹‡ini, KÄtyÄyana, perhaps under the influence of the emerging philosophical schools such as those of VÄjapyÄyana and VyÄá¸i, proposes a new brand of metaphysical phonology. This proposal says that one should assume that the listing of the ÅšivasÅ«tras is not a listing of tokens, but a listing of sound-genera or ÄkrÌ¥tis, which would naturally represent a whole class sharing a given ÄkrÌ¥ti, without any special rules. If such is the case, then one does not need a large part of the PÄá¹‡inian procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a: Vt. à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤£à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯- à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥, on P.1.1.69. This proposal of KÄtyÄyana, which I have dis- cussed at length in Deshpande (1975: 17-31), is fraught with difficulties. I shall briefly mention the following: 1) A metaphysical definition of ÄkrÌ¥ti of a sound becomes impression- istic in terms of oneâ€™s ability to identify its membership. 2) Generally any member covered by an ÄkrÌ¥ti would be able to stand for the whole class. This obliterates the distinction between sounds directly listed in the ÅšivasÅ«tras, i.e. the aá¹† sounds, and the sounds not directly listed in the ÅšivasÅ«tras, i.e. the non-aá¹† sounds. 3) The procedure of ÄkrÌ¥tigrahaá¹‡a cannot completely replace the PÄá¹‡inian procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a. This is so, because the ÄkrÌ¥ti of i can cover Ä«, but the ÄkrÌ¥ti of k does not cover kh, g, gh, and á¹…. This is admitted by KÄtyÄyana, who suggests that even after accepting the procedure of ÄkrÌ¥tigrahaá¹‡a, one would still need the procedure of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a to cover these vargas of consonants. Thus, in general the metaphysical phonology proposed by KÄtyÄyana has been relatively ineffective and in the later PÄá¹‡inian tradition, there are few supporters for it. 5.7. Phonetics versus Behavior: The Case of Sandhyaká¹£aras 5.7.1. The treatment of the Sanskrit sandhyaká¹£aras in the Indian tradition is illustrative of several other important points. The sounds e, o, ai,

54 INTRODUCTION and au are all generally called sandhyaká¹£aras in Sanskrit texts, implying that the tradition views them as composit sounds in some sense. However, very few texts suggest that all these sounds have distinct components. Generally, the older texts treat the sounds e and o as monophthongs, and ascribe a single point of articulation to these sounds, even while treating them as sandhy- aká¹£aras. On the other hand, all texts treat the sounds ai and au as diphthongs. The older texts explicitly call these sounds dvivará¹‡a â€˜consisting of two sounds,â€™ and ascribe to them two points of articulation. However, at the same time, these older texts are quick to point out that for all practical purposes these sounds, i.e. ai and au, are to be treated as if they are single sounds (CA 1.1.40: à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ). These sounds behave as if they are single sounds. They do not constitute two syllables either for metrical or grammatical purposes, and phonologically behave as long vowels, rather than as sequences of short vowels. This phonological behavior of these two diphthongs as monophthongs has sometimes clouded even the supposedly phonetic description of these sounds. Several texts tell us that the sounds e and o are vivrÌ¥tatara, the sounds ai and au are vivrÌ¥tatama, and the sound Ä is still more open. If the sounds ai and au are phonetically dvivará¹‡a sounds, it makes no sense to say that they are even more open than e and o. To my mind, the above statement reflects a confusion caused by the lack of proper discrimination between the phonetic and the phonological levels, and the superimposition of one level upon the other. We shall later look at some other cases where the phonological behavior may have colored the phonetic classifications in Sanskrit texts. 5.8. SthÄna versus Karaá¹‡a: The Case of V 5.8.1. The featural phonology brings with it the responsibility to explicitly define and specify a finite set of phonetic features for the sounds of a language. Any lack of clarity in the description of the phonological system in this regard can lead to problems which were not faced by those who practiced groupings by listing. As an example, consider the case of the sound v. Most of the older Åšiká¹£Äs and PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas list v among the oá¹£á¹­hya â€˜labialâ€™ sounds without any further comment. These texts must be distinguished from those texts which further specify that the karaá¹‡a â€˜articulatorâ€™ for v is the â€˜tips of teethâ€™ (cf. VPR 1.81). If the teeth or their tips are only a karaá¹‡a for v, we can still consider v to be an oá¹£á¹­hya sound, since such terms as oá¹£á¹­hya are seen as always referring to the point of articulation and not the articulator. The texts which come still later, such as the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä say that v is a

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 55 dantyoá¹£á¹­hya sound. Since many of these late texts pay little attention to the notion of karaá¹‡a, the subsequent tradition has interpreted this term to mean that the sound v has two points of articulation. This sound is dantya as well as oá¹£á¹­hya, and, therefore, it should be included in both categories. What was PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s own intention? He has remained silent on the details of the phonetic features, and has left it to his successors to worry about the problems caused by his silence. Consider, for instance, the rule P.7.3.73 (à¤²à¥à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤¹à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹à¤²à¤¿à¤¹à¤—à¥à¤¹à¤¾- à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‡à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡). The rule says that after the listed roots, the affix -ksa- of the aorist is optionally (or preferably, if one accepts Kiparskyâ€™s interpretation of vÄ) deleted before a middle termination beginning in a dantya sound. The affixes -dhvam and -ta are undoubtedly dantya-initial affixes. However, the affix -vahi raises doubts. Is it a dantya-initial affix, or is it not? If the teeth functioned only as karaá¹‡a for v, then it is not a dantya sound, since the term dantya should properly refer only to the point of articulation. However, the KV, relying upon the late phonetic texts says that since v is a dantyoá¹£á¹­ha sound, it must be included among dantya sounds, as well as among oá¹£á¹­hya sounds (cf. à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, KV on P.7.3.73). This leads to the derivation of forms like aduhvahi, as well as adhuká¹£Ävahi. Whether this statement is historically accurate is a major question. This question has been debated elsewhere in detail, cf. Cardona 1964, Deshpande 1975a and 1981. Suffice it to say that the choice of going for featural phonology requires a degree of precision which is sometimes lacking in the Sanskrit texts, and this lack of precision may have contributed to a certain degree of confusion. Similar confusion is also noticeable on the exact status of nÄsikÄ â€˜nose.â€™ 5.9. Ä€ntaratamya versus YathÄsaá¹ƒkhya: The Case of iko yaá¹‡ aci 5.9.1. In the last several years, a major discussion has taken place among scholars such as myself, George Cardona, and recently, Robert Hueckstedt. This question revolves around the use of the principle of Äntaratamya â€˜maximal featural proximityâ€™ stated in P.1.1.50 (à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ) versus the principle of yathÄsaá¹ƒkhya â€˜one-to-one substitutionâ€™ stated in P.1.3.10 (à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) in deciding appropriate substitutions in some rules of PÄá¹‡ini. There are cases of substitution like P.3.4.101 (à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ) where it is beyond doubt that the substitution must be made on the basis of yathÄsaá¹ƒkhya. This rule says that tas, thas, tha, and miP are replaced by tÄm, tam, ta and am, respectively. Similarly, there are cases like P.8.4.53 (à¤à¤²à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¶à¥ à¤à¤¶à¤¿), where we must apply the principle of maximal featural

56 INTRODUCTION proximity or Äntaratamya. This rule says that jhaL sounds are replaced with jaÅš sounds, before jhaÅš sounds. The group referred to by jhaL includes the consonants jh, bh, gh, á¸h, dh, kh, ph, ch, á¹­h, th, c, á¹­, t, k, p, Å›, á¹£, s and h. On the other hand, the substitutes denoted by the shortform jaÅš include j, b, g, á¸ and d. The unequal number of originals and substitutes makes it an ideal candidate for the application of the principle of maximal featural proximity. However, rules like P.6.1.77 (à¤‡à¤•à¥‹ à¤¯à¤£à¤šà¤¿) raise difficult questions. Here, the originals are denoted by the shortform iK, while the substitutes are denoted by yaá¹†. hese shortforms are expanded just to i, u, rÌ¥, lÌ¥, and y, v, r, l, respectively, then one can think of the possibility of one-to-one substitution. However, in order to make sure that the rule would also apply to the change of Ä« to y , one must expand the list of originals to cover all the homogeneous varieties of i, u, rÌ¥ and lÌ¥, by P.1.1.69 (à¤…à¤£à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ). If this is done before effecting the substitution, then one gets unequal numbers of originals and substitutes, and one needs to use the principle of maximal featural prox- imity. On P.1.1.50, PataÃ±jali (MB, Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., p. 10) says that the problems of P.6.1.77 can be resolved even with yathÄsaá¹ƒkhya : à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥. However, on P.1.3.10 (à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥), he says (MB, Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., p. 267) that the problems of P.6.1.77 can be resolved even with Äntaratamya : à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥. Are there four originals and four substitutes, or is the number of original and substitutes different? This depends upon when exactly we apply savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a to ik and yaá¹‡. Recently, Robert Hueckstedt has published a monograph that reviews the long traditional debate relating to the interpretation of P.6.1.77, and I believe the final conclusion regarding PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s own intention, if there is one, is still elusive. This example demonstrates that in using listings and features, PÄá¹‡inian grammar at times lacks sufficient clarity, and this has lead to such as-yet- unresolved problems. 5.10. Did Phonology influence Phonetics? The Case of rÌ¥ and r. 5.10.1. Earlier I have mentioned the case of ai and au which are simultaneously described as being dvivará¹‡a â€˜composed of two constituent sounds,â€™ and yet being vivrÌ¥tatama, i.e. even more open that e and o. In my view, this situation has occurred either because these sounds are phonetically diphthongs, but phonologically behave as single sounds, or because the conception of these sounds as dvivará¹‡a is the inherited doctrine, while, at least dialectally, these sounds have been reduced to monophthongal pronunciation

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 57 similar to vowels in the English words at and all. Since the levels of phonetics and phonology were not sufficiently distinguished, the statements in the texts leave room for speculation. Such discrepancies are also found as regards the sounds r and rÌ¥. The older texts generally consider rÌ¥ as a jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya â€˜velarâ€™ sound, and r as a dantamÅ«lÄ«ya â€˜alveolarâ€™ sound. The undoubtedly retroflex sounds are á¹£, and the á¹­avarga. However, notice the fact that the same old texts also specify that a dental n coming after r, rÌ¥, or á¹£ is retroflexed. This would seem to show that a dantamÅ«lÄ«ya â€˜alveolar,â€™ a jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya â€˜velar,â€™ and a mÅ«rdhanya â€˜retroflexâ€™ have the same phonological function, i.e. they are cerebralizers, though not all cerebrals themselves. Perhaps such a statement was gradually viewed as being inappropriate, and the later texts started calling r and rÌ¥ also mÅ«rdhanya â€˜retroflexâ€™ sounds. Most modern scholars still wonder how these sounds can be phonetically retroflex. It is thus possible that in this case the phonological behavior of sounds has led the ancient phoneticians and grammarians to reclassify the phonetic categories of the concerned sounds to remove the seeming inconsistencies. Such may also be the case of the oral effort for vowels and spirants. Most ancient works, including PÄá¹‡ini, seem to hold that vowels and spirants are all vivrÌ¥ta â€˜open.â€™ Precisely for this reason, PÄá¹‡ini had to formulate his rule P.1.1.10 (nÄjjhalau) to prevent the impending sÄvará¹‡ya â€˜homogeneityâ€™ between vowels and spirants. This rule, to say the least, has created enormous problems of interpretation. To get over these, PataÃ±jali, among others, proposed to differentiate the oral effort for vowels from that of the spirants. The vowels were now classified as â€˜openâ€™ (vivrÌ¥ta), while the spirants were classified as â€˜slightly openâ€™ (Ä«á¹£ad-vivrÌ¥ta). Whether such a distinction is phonetically justified is not clear. However, this distinction certainly made the phonological statements clearer, and seems to have been greeted with joy by the later grammarians, even at the cost of having to sacrifice P.1.1.10 (nÄjjhalau), cf. NÄgeÅ›abhaá¹­á¹­aâ€™s statement: à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤œà¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¤¹à¤¾à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯- à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ, à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤š à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤, BrÌ¥hacchabdenduÅ›ekhara, vol. I., p. 48. â€œIf, however, having set aside the inertia caused by oneâ€™s trust in the SÅ«tras, commentaries etc., one can say that there is no homogeneity [between sounds like i and Å›], whose homo- geneity P.1.1.10 aims to prohibit, on the basis of a difference in

58 INTRODUCTION their articulatory effort, then, [by all means], let there be seven [distinct] articulatory efforts, and let there not be the rule P.1.1.10. 5.11. NÄda versus Ghoá¹£a: Phonetic and/or Phonological? 5.11.1. Another such debate which has kept modern scholars busy revolves around the terms nÄda and ghoá¹£a. Most ancient texts clearly define nÄda as a type of phonation produced when the glottal chords are closed. The vibration produced by the closed glottal chords is called nÄda. All voiced sounds have it, including vowels and voiced consonants. Now consider the term ghoá¹£a. Hardly any text defines how ghoá¹£a is produced. However, they all use the terms ghoá¹£avat, ghoá¹£in, and aghoá¹£a, implying at the very least that ghoá¹£a is a certain feature which some sounds have, and others do not. What complicates the debate is the fact that most older texts say that nÄda is the phonation for vowels and ghoá¹£avat consonants. This possibly suggests that ghoá¹£a is a feature only for some consonants, but not for vowels. 5.11.2. This last statement is the beginning of the whole controversy. Some scholars have followed up the above conclusion and have attempted to identify what ghoá¹£a as a separate voicing feature may have meant, cf. Desh- pande (1976). Cardona (1986) has argued for a different view. I cannot do justice to his extensive treatment of this question here, but to state his conclu- sion in his own words (p. 79-80): â€œThough ghoá¹£avat (â€˜voicedâ€™) and aghoá¹£a (â€˜voicelessâ€™) might at first blush seem to be purely phonetic class names, the use of these terms with reference to voiced and voiceless consonants alone is based on a phonological distinction.â€ 5.11.3. I tend to believe that for the ancient phoneticians, ghoá¹£a was also a phonetic term, which may then have had phonological uses as pointed out by Cardona. Whether modern phonetics can identify two types or degrees of voicing need not decide whether the ancient phoneticians viewed ghoá¹£a to be a phonetic feature of sound, cf. RPR 13.15 (à¤†à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°- à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥), RPR 13.18 (à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¤° à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥Œ) and the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä quoted by the CAB on CA (1.1.12). Such texts lead one to believe that the ancient phoneticians and grammarians did indeed view ghoá¹£a as a vará¹‡aguá¹‡a which some sounds have and others do not. Such a view is supported by the lists of prayatnas or vará¹‡aguá¹‡as in various texts. Uvaá¹­a on RPR (13.21) lists ghoá¹£atÄ and aghoá¹£atÄ as vará¹‡aguá¹‡as â€˜features of sound.â€™ The grammatical texts in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition also list ghoá¹£a and aghoá¹£a among the bÄhya-prayatnas, besides nÄda and Å›vÄsa, and suggest that in their opinion these are phonetic

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 59 features. If one says that nÄda and ghoá¹£a are distinct phonological features with no distinct phonetic reality, then one could perhaps say that a lack of clarity between the levels of phonetics and phonology may have led the Sanskrit tradition to come up with pseudo-phonetic features in some cases. On the other hand, this offers us an opportunity to investigate a possible distinction in the kind of voicing involved in the articulation of vowels and voiced consonants. I have suggested that ghoá¹£a may possibly refer to the amplification or perhaps friction added to the original voicing caused by the glottal closure in the pronunciation of voiced consonants. Such an added amplification or friction can be attributed to the partial or complete closure of the oral organs in the utterance of voiced consonants. For example, the implosion for unreleased voiced stops like b feels like a form of oral vibration distinct from the vibration of the glottal chords, and it may have been interpreted by the ancient phoneticians as the feature of ghoá¹£a, distinct from nÄda â€˜vibration of the glottal chords.â€™ Also see: Ralf Stautzebach 1994: 287. 5.12. No explicit â€˜phonologyâ€™ versus â€˜phoneticsâ€™ 5.12.1. To reiterate my main point, the Sanskrit phonetic and gram- matical traditions did not explicitly distinguish between the phonetic and the phonological levels in their description. However, it is clear that they were faced with many dilemmas in trying to correlate the phonetic features of sounds to their phonological behavior. In doing so, sometimes they made explicit distinctions between what we would call the phonetic character of a sound and its phonological behavior. At other times, the phonological behavior of sounds may have led the ancient grammarians into consciously or unconsciously creating pseudo-phonetic distinctions to match the observed differences in phonological behavior. In any case, the above analysis shows the promise as well as the limitations of the science of phonetics and grammar as practiced in ancient India. 6.PÄá¹‡inian Impact on the Tradition of the CA 6.1. Surya Kantaâ€™s Proposal concerning two types of PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas 6.1.1. In the introduction to his magnificent edition of the APR (p. 24), Surya Kanta proposed that the evolution of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya literature

60 INTRODUCTION shows that in their formative period, there were essentially two types of PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. Type A, represented by the APR, contained exhaustive listings (gaá¹‡as) of examples showing certain patterns of linguistic behavior, but no generalized rules. This was the first step. Type B, represented by the CA, containing generalizations, exceptions to generalizations etc., but not exhaustive lists (gaá¹‡as). This was the second step. Surya Kanta (ibid, p. 25) claims that â€œthe evolution of B would throw into abeyance Aâ€, and that â€œB being descriptive would be easily reduced to the abstract sÅ«tra style.â€ 6.2. Surya Kantaâ€™s view of the existing PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya texts 6.2.1. We shall briefly summarize below, Surya Kantaâ€™s more exten- sive discussion (ibid, pp. 25ff): a) Existing PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas represent a mixture of the types A and B, and there are no pure representatives of the types A and B. b) Surya Kanta assumes that the type A is inherently earlier than the type B, i.e. the listings of instances were made prior to the stage of generalizations. However, on the basis of direct quotations of the CA rules in the APR, he admits that the CA is older than the APR. Thus, an actual text showing generalizations is older than the text which is primarily a set of listings. In actuality, listings are dependent on generaliza- tions, and generalizations are dependent upon listings. 6.3. Vedic grammar and the grammar of contemporary Sanskrit 6.3.1. We may observe that even the PadapÄá¹­has presuppose a set of grammatical generalizations, on the basis of which the original Saá¹ƒhitÄ was segmented into Padas, and occasionally into their components. The gram- matical theory, though not clearly spelled out by the PadakÄras must be

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 61 assumed to have existed, and can be inferred to a certain extent from the PadapÄá¹­has, cf. V.N. Jha (1987). The ancient PadapÄá¹­ha/PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya type grammars worked under two different pressures or had two slightly divergent targets: i) narrow target = to describe just the text of a particular ÅšÄkhÄ of a particular Veda ii) wider target = to describe the generic Sanskrit language: Vedic and post-Vedic Sanskrit taken together. Even the PadapÄá¹­ha manifests features of post-Vedic dialects of San- skrit like those of ÅšÄkalya and others, cf. Cardona (1991), and is not free from the implicit influence of the grammar of contemporary Sanskrit. The narrow target of describing the texts of a particular ÅšÄkhÄ, in practice could not be separated from considerations of post-Vedic Sanskrit, and the concerns of a generalized grammar of Sanskrit at large. The Vedic texts were maintained orally by Brahmins who used the more contemporary forms of Sanskrit in their academic and ritual activity, and hence the existence of the Vedic texts was fully circumscribed by the use of the contemporary forms of Sanskrit. Secondly, the recitational segmentations and recombinations often created sequences which were not strictly speaking Vedic, and these were more directly subject to the rules of the contemporary usage of Sanskrit. This is the case, for instance, when ÅšÄkalya adds the word iti after certain forms in the PadapÄá¹­ha, or when the words are reversed in their order in the Jaá¹­ÄpÄá¹­ha, i.e. a+b+b+a+a+b. This phenomenon of active recitational switching between Vedic grammar and the grammar of contemporary Sanskrit is discussed in my paper â€œGrammars and Grammar-Switching in Vedic Recitational Variations,â€ (Deshpande, 1994). Thus, one may not necessarily assume that there ever existed grammatical texts, some precursors of our PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, which were strictly related to the facts of a particular ÅšÄkhÄ, and were not at all influenced by or concerned with the general grammar of contemporary Sanskrit. 6.4. The Perceived Role of General Grammar in Relation to PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas 6.4.1. PataÃ±jali indeed asserts that the PadakÄras should follow the Grammarians, and the Grammarians should not follow the PadakÄras (à¤¨ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ, à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥, MB, Kielhorn edn., Vol.II., p. 85).

62 INTRODUCTION The PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition as we know it does seem to accept a view that its specifications are to be understood on the background of a general grammar of Sanskrit. This is seen from the following discussions 6.4.2. Consider CA 1.1.3-4 (à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡). The com- mentary CAB on this rule says: à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤½- à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤š.à¤†. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œ[On] thus it is in this [branch]. In this branch, such is con- sidered to be the [specific, non-optional] doctrine. In the generic [grammar of Sanskrit], namely in P.8.4.45, [the proce- dure of changing a stop to its corresponding nasal, before a nasal] obtains optionally. What is the generic description? This is the tradition of grammar. [The CA] will state [its own specific, i.e. non-optional, procedure] in 2.1.5.â€ This suggests the relation between a general grammar of Sanskrit and a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya as that between a generic description of a language comprising all its dialectal and temporal manifestations and a specific description of a specific text. The general grammar of Sanskrit had to introduce a number of options, due to its goal of describing the large variety of linguistic phenomena under its coverage, cf. à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¹à¥€à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¯ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥, MB on P.2.1.58 and P.6.3.14, â€œIndeed this science [of grammar] is concerned with all Vedic traditions [taken together], and hence it is not possible to choose a unique [= non-optional] path [of description, which would apply only to a specific Vedic branch].â€ On the other hand, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya literature relates to us the specific choices made by a specific textual tradition. 6.4.3. Uvaá¹­a, in his introductory commentary on the first Paá¹­ala of the RÌ¥gveda-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, discusses this relationship at length. He presents two opposing views. Some claimed that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas are statements of ex- ceptions to the rules of a general grammar of Sanskrit, while others claimed them to be independent treatises. Finally, Uvaá¹­a says: à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ, RPR, Vol.II., p. 23, â€œOf these two views, one may choose the one which is deemed to be beneficialâ€. However, he has paid greater attention to the first alternative, namely that the relationship of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya to a general grammar of Sanskrit is that of a specific description to a generic description. He says (RPR, Vol.II., pp. 21-23):

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 63 à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¥‡à¤£à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤‚, à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ - â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‹à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ- à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ … à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿; à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ … à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨, à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ â€˜à¤‹à¤šà¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥à¤˜à¤®à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¤à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥¬.à¥§.à¥§à¥©à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€˜à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨â€™ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿- à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œThe purpose of [this] science [of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya] is [to clarify] that the rules which are generically expressed in the Åšiká¹£Äs, metrics (chandas) and grammars are [effective] in this branch in a restricted manner. This verse elucidates the purpose of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. The rules are stated generically in the Åšiká¹£Äs and other texts. For example, in the Åšiká¹£Ä statement â€˜rÌ¥, á¹­-series, r and á¹£ should be cerebral,â€™ the sound r is generically said to be a cerebral sound in all Vedic traditions. Thus, all the Åšiká¹£Äs generically prescribe the points of articulation, articulators, phonation etc. for sounds with reference to all Vedic branches, but they do not specifically say in which branch the sound r is invariably cerebral, and where it is [invariably] alveolar. Therefore, this [science of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya] is undertaken to settle such [questions]. Similarly, the grammar makes generic statements, for example P.6.1.133. This [PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya] is undertaken to settle this question. The words [listed in P.6.1.133, i.e. tu, nu, gha etc.] are consistently free from lengthening in this entire textual tradition [of the RV]. Thus, the rules which are generically stated by the Åšiká¹£Äs, metrics, and grammars, indifferently with respect to all Vedic branches, are specifically settled by this [PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya] with respect to this particular Vedic branch. This is the purpose of this ancillary tradition. The same purpose is expressed in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya of the Atharvaveda [= CA] in rules CA (1.1.3-4). Such is the

64 INTRODUCTION significance of this rule: Whatever [procedure] obtains optionally through generic descriptions is settled in a restrictive way in this Vedic branch. This way the purpose of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya is explained.â€ 6.4.4. On VPR (6.24: à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¿), which provides a list of Upasargas, Uvaá¹­aâ€™s commentary says: à¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤… à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£- à¤ªà¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ - â€˜à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤†à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ,â€™ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾- à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œThese twenty upasargas [as listed in VPR 6.24] retain their natural accent. The natural accent as stated in the grammar is taken for granted in this tradition. Thus, there are the [follow- ing] grammatical rules: â€˜The nipÄtas have their first syllable high-pitched. So do the upasargas, except abhi.â€™â€ Anantabhaá¹­á¹­aâ€™s commentary on the VPR also repeats the same SÅ«tras of some VyÄkaraá¹‡a. These rules are not found in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar, but are found in the Phiá¹­sÅ«tras (80, 81) ascribed to ÅšÄntanava. In any case, the dis- cussion assumes that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas take for granted the prescriptions of the general grammar of Sanskrit. 6.4.5. The commentary VaidikÄbharaá¹‡a by GopÄlayajvan on TPR uses the word mÅ«laÅ›Ästra â€œoriginal scienceâ€ for PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules (cf., on TPR 5.14, 5.33, 7.16, 9.10, 10.9, 11.1, 13.4, 14.4) and views the rules of the TPR as statements of exceptions applicable exclusively to the text of the TS. The TPR (19.5: à¤¨ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡) makes a reference to a pÅ«rvaÅ›Ästra, a prior grammatical system, and again GopÄlayajvan says: à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•- à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, â€œThe tradition of grammar which forms the basis of this science [of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya] is referred to as a prior [= foundational] science.â€ 6.4.6. The same term pÅ«rvaÅ›Ästra is used in the CAB on CA (4.4.27) and seems to have the same reference, namely PÄá¹‡inian grammar. The above evidence indicates that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition viewed itself as a description of specific linguistic features found in specific texts, and for more generic facts, it took for granted the prescriptions of the general grammar of Sanskrit. For most of the commentatorial tradition, this general grammar of Sanskrit was non other than that of PÄá¹‡ini.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 65 6.5. Which general grammar do the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas and their commentators assume? 6.5.1. The commentators, as discussed earlier, seem to refer to PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar while discussing the general grammar taken for granted by the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. I would like to make some important historical distinctions in using the term â€˜grammar.â€™ We must make at least the following distinctions: a) general grammatical principles taken for granted by the PadakÄras, but not spelled out clearly by them. b) general grammatical principles taken for granted by the authors of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. c) grammatical system as taken for granted by the commentators. 6.5.2. It is important to make a distinction between these various notions of grammar, so that we may hope to have a clear understanding of the changing historical situation. For example, the PadapÄá¹­ha provides us a seg- mentation of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ as a fait accompli. In general, it provides a word-for- word segmentation of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ-text. However, in many cases, it separates the members of compounds, and the base from certain affixes. What we possess is not a theory of segmentation, but the segmentation itself, or the lack of it, and hence we can only indirectly infer the grammatical categories which were used by the authors of the PadapÄá¹­ha, cf. V.N. Jha 1987. For instance, we do not know in some cases whether the PadakÄra viewed the segments separated by an Avagraha as members of a compound, or as a base and an affix. For instance, the rule CA (4.1.49: à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥) and the commentary CAB on it raise such a question concerning the segment krÌ¥tvaá¸¥. For PÄá¹‡ini, we know that the item krÌ¥tvasUC is indeed an affix, cf. P.5.4.17 (à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¤£à¤¨à¥‡ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤šà¥). On the other hand, the facts of the AV PadapÄá¹­ha are such that krÌ¥tvas is sometimes separated by an Avagraha, and sometimes it is not, e.g. aá¹£á¹­a-krÌ¥tvaá¸¥ (AV 11.2.9) is separated by an Avagraha, but daÅ›akrÌ¥tvaá¸¥ (AV 11.2.9) and saptakrÌ¥tvaá¸¥ (AV 12.2.29) are not separated by an Avagraha. The author of the CA says that where it is separated by an Avagraha, it is a case of a SamÄsa â€˜compound.â€™ For PÄá¹‡ini, it is a case of affixation. All we know about the PadapÄá¹­ha is that krÌ¥tvas is sometimes sepa- rated by an Avagraha. We do not know whether the author of the PadapÄá¹­ha treated this as a case of compounding or affixation, or whether these specific

66 INTRODUCTION distinctions between compounding and affixation developed later on. Here, we should note another interesting dimension of this problem. While it is clear that by invoking the category of SamÄsa, the author of the CA demonstrates his familiarity with a grammatical system, that grammatical system is indeed not that of PÄá¹‡ini. Consider for instance, CA 4.1.50 (à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š). Taken in the context of the previous rule, i.e. CA 4.1.49 (à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ …), this rule also relates to the treatment of a segment as a member of a compound, and its consequent segmentation by an Avagraha. There are two points to be taken into account in this case. The expression jÄtÄ«yÄdi refers to a Gaá¹‡a or a listing. However, there are no examples of jÄtÄ«ya attested in the AV. This means that the CA is indeed bringing in a Gaá¹‡a from some generalized grammar of Sanskrit. However, while the CA, and probably the grammatical source from which it takes this generalized Gaá¹‡a, treat this as a case of compounding (samÄsa), PÄá¹‡ini (5.3.69: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤°à¥) clearly treats this as a case of affixation. Thus, one can assert that the author of the CA is familiar with a generalized grammar of Sanskrit, but that grammar need not be identical with that of PÄá¹‡ini. 6.6. Generalized description of Sanskrit as the occasional target of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas 6.6.1. While the term â€˜PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyaâ€™ does indeed seem to imply that ideally there should be a specific PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya text for each distinct ÅšÄkhÄ, and that the specific text should not aim at linguistic phenomena extending beyond its chosen Vedic ÅšÄkhÄ, the authors of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, for reasons not clearly understood by us, often sojourn into such external territories. GopÄlayajvan in his commentary VaidikÄbharaá¹‡a on TPR (11.9) discusses this question: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ (Mysore edn., p. 317), â€œIndeed a rule, for which one does not find an example in oneâ€™s own Vedic branch, should be explained as having examples in other Vedic branches.â€ This issue comes up very often in interpreting the rules of the CA. Consider the following instances: 1) CA (4.2.5-6: à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ). CA (4.2.5: à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥) says that the word á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä« is not split with an Avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha, due to doubts regarding the exact boundaries of the member ele- ments. In part, this statement is simply an observation that the word á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä« is not split with an Avagraha. On the other hand, the remainder of the statement, i.e. sandehÄt, is a criticism of the author of the PadapÄá¹­ha, who apparently could not overcome this alleged sandeha. The rules CA (4.2.5-6) in fact

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 67 represent a clear effort on the part of the author of the CA to overcome this element of sandeha, and in a way mark a grammatical advance over the PadapÄá¹­ha. However, of what practical consequence are these rules? The new derivation does not lead to a new segmentation with an Avagraha, but only to a better understanding of the etymology of these words. Such an advance, though indeed praiseworthy, is of little utility in either converting the PadapÄá¹­ha into Saá¹ƒhitÄ, or in explaining why a certain segmentation is the way it is. Strictly speaking, this is an advance in the territory of general grammar of Sanskrit, which has its scope extending far beyond that of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. 2) CA (1.3.2: à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ). This rule, like PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule P.8.2.18 (à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤°à¥‹ à¤²à¤ƒ), derivationally links the forms of klÌ¥p/kalp with those of krÌ¥p. What is the practical utility of such a rule for a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya? While it marks an advance in the understanding of the derivation of the forms of klÌ¥p, the sound- change taught by this rule remains unutilized in the crucial area of the Pada<>Saá¹ƒhitÄ relationship. This change does not figure in the process of samÄpatti or restoration of the supposedly original sounds of an item in Pada and Krama variation. The forms of klÌ¥p are not restored to krÌ¥p. Thus, this remains an advance in the area of grammatical derivation, which is strictly speaking outside the scope of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. 3) CA (1.3.25: à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). This rule teaches that the long Ä of the listed roots becomes nasalized before the affix -san. Out of these three roots, only the forms of mÄn, e.g. mÄ«mÄá¹ƒsamÄnÄá¸¥ (AV 9.1.3) is attested in the ÅšAV. Why should this text concern itself with other roots? Should we assume with Surya Kanta, that the forms of these other roots may have occurred in a sup- posedly more genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension? I, rather, tend to agree with Whitney. He shows the similarity of this CA rule with P.3.1.6 (à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¬à¤§à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯) and suggests that, in the present rule, the CA is simply carried away by the urge to account for facts of the general grammar of Sanskrit. 6.7. Connection of the CA with the traditions of Sanskrit Grammar. 6.7.1. The following examples show how intricately the CA is con- nected with some traditions of Sanskrit grammar. Some of these features, but not all, look like those of the PÄá¹‡inian grammar, and it is possible that both the texts are drawing upon certain common sources. The CA does not share PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s ultra-algebraic style, but it shares a number of common terms, and other features. These are a few illustrations:

68 INTRODUCTION 1) CA (1.3.10: à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯): aprÌ¥kta, cf. P.6.1.67 (à¤µà¥‡à¤°à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯). 2) CA (1.3.12: à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡): saptamyartha, cf. P.1.1.19 (à¤ˆà¤¦à¥‚à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡). 3) CA (1.3.13: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ): dvivacana, cf. P.1.1.11 (à¤ˆà¤¦à¥‚à¤¦à¥‡à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥). 4) CA (1.3.16: à¤…à¤®à¥€ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤®à¥): bahuvacana, cf. P.7.3.103 (à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡ à¤à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥). 5) CA (1.3.19: à¤†à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡): Ämantrita and anÄrá¹£a, cf.
