à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¯à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨ (not found in CA)à¥¤ à¥¯à¥ª. à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ (not found in CA)à¥¤ …à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¥ This whole section is a new creation in imitation of PÄá¹‡inian rules. g) On PS 126: à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤°à¥‚à¤ª à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ … à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£ à¤…à¤µà¤²à¤®à¥à¤¬ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‡ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤²à¤®à¥à¤¬ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥€à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ h) On PS 132: à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤‰à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤• à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ, à¤—à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤¦à¤•à¤®à¥, à¤°à¤¾à¤® à¤Šà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤¨à¤ƒ, à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤Šà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ, à¤‡à¤²à¤¾ à¤† à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤²à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ i) On PS 133: à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤à¤•à¤ƒ à¤…à¤°à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¤®à¥à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£ à¤‹à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¤² à¤‹à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¤œà¤²à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤µ à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤µà¤²à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 79 6.12. The changing nature of the CA tradition On the basis of the above evidence tracing the historical changes which occurred in the CA tradition, we can draw the following conclusions. The CA itself was perhaps familiar with PÄá¹‡inian, or perhaps PÄá¹‡ini- like, terminology, and occasionally it does venture into explanations of formations which do not occur in the AV, but on the whole it is an authentic description of a particular phase of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV. Generally, the text is concerned with the AV, and represents a distinct tradition. The Metrical Authority, an ancient Åšiká¹£Ä relating to the AV tradition, predates the later MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä. It shows substantial familiarity with PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s system, and yet it shows a true independent view of Sanskrit phonetics, not colored by what one finds in the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. We can safely assume that this ancient Åšiká¹£Ä predates the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. The CAB shows even greater familiarity with the PÄá¹‡inian tradition, perhaps with the KV. Its phonetic description is beginning to show signs of the influence of the late PÄá¹‡inian tradition, though it does not directly quote the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. However, it is clear that its deviations from the quoted Metrical Authority are in the direction of the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. At the same time, it is genuinely related to the Atharvavedic tradition, and it has a very close connection with the APR edited by Surya Kanta. The commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara shows a deep influence of the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. It looks like it has no knowledge of either the CAB or the Metrical Authority quoted by it. On the other hand, it quotes PÄá¹‡ini, the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä, and the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. Its interpretations are colored by this late phase of the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. However, at the same time it must be admitted that it is closely linked with the Atharvavedic tradition, and it cites a large number of examples from the text of the Atharvaveda. The last text, i.e. KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsaâ€™s KautsavyÄkaraá¹‡e PaÃ±casandhiá¸¥, is a truly different text. It is an SK-style reorganization of the CA rules, clearly dominated by the SK. It is only peripherally part of the Atharvavedic tradition. The examples cited by this commentary are hardly different from those of the SK, and rarely does it cite anything from the AV. It is an effort to write a grammar of the classical language using the rules of the CA, supplemented by a set of new rules based on the PÄá¹‡inian system. KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsaâ€™s work is also largely influenced by AnubhÅ«tisvarÅ«pÄcÄryaâ€™s SÄrasvata-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. The above survey indicates how the tradition of the CA gradually lost its individuality and came under the direct influence of the dominant grammatical paradigm, i.e. the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. This influence perhaps kept the tradition

80 INTRODUCTION of the CA alive, but in the process of keeping it alive, the CA tradition was gradually drained of its grammatical and phonetic distinctiveness, and, in this sense, the PÄá¹‡inian influence must be viewed as a negative force, and not a positive help in the interpretation of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition. 7. The AV PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas and the ÅšAV Text- Transmission 7.1.General Issues of Saá¹ƒhitÄ Formation and Transmission 7.1.1. In his MB, PataÃ±jali says that the Atharvaveda has nine differ- ent recensions (cf. à¤¨à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ, MB, Vol.I, p. 9). However, the Saá¹ƒhitÄ of the Atharvaveda is available to us at present only in two major recensions, i.e. the ÅšaunakÄ«ya and the PaippalÄda. The two recensions differ in their overall organization of the material, and the readings for individual verses differ in hundreds of places. The readings found in any one recension are authentic only in so far as they represent that particular recension of the Atharvaveda, and there is no intrinsic claim for any reading to represent the Ur-Atharvaveda, if indeed there was such a thing. With the Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs, scholars have proposed two distinct phases of oral transmission. Oldenberg (1890, 1962: 28), referring to the Saá¹ƒhitÄ of the RV, says: â€œThe study of Åšaunakaâ€™s work [= RPR] affords us the proof that from that time on the Vedic hymns, protected by the united care of grammatical and religious respect for letters, have suffered no further appreciable corruptions.â€ However, worth noting are his comments on the pre-redaction textual transmission: â€œIn some cases, isolated details of the additions of prior epochs were caught and clung to with felicitous acumen; in others, no hesitation was had in wiping out of existence entire domains of old and genuine phenomena to suit half-correct theories, so that the most patient ingenuity of modern science will only be able to restore in part what has been lostâ€ (1890, 1962: 27). He further reminds us that â€œthe collection was re- corrected on repeated occasions. It is conceivable enough that thus the original structure, yes, even the existence itself of special hymns was often injured, effaced, or destroyedâ€ (1890, 1962: 26). The first phase represented the pre- redaction period of the oral transmission, uncontrolled and unguided by any systematic efforts at standardization, while the post-redaction phase was characterized by a great deal of systematic standardization of the text in its organization as well as its pronunciation. This second phase began with the work of scholars like ÅšÄkalya for the RV, and Åšaunaka for the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 81 PataÃ±jali refers to ÅšÄkalyaâ€™s well-prepared Saá¹ƒhitÄ (cf. à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥, MB on P.1.4.84, Vol.I, p. 347) of the RV. Åšaunaka probably did the same thing for the AV Saá¹ƒhitÄ and prepared its PadapÄá¹­ha. As it has been documented more fully for ÅšÄkalya, the PadapÄá¹­ha reflects his understanding of the words of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ. It also reflects certain features of his own dialect of Sanskrit (Cardona 1991). Finally, the Saá¹ƒhitÄ was to be rebuilt by changing the PadapÄá¹­ha by applying the rules of Sandhi, and hence in certain respects, the Saá¹ƒhitÄ, thus arrived at, reflected more modern features, as compared to the original compositions of the Vedic seers which are now lost to us. Thus, a given Saá¹ƒhitÄ represents not precisely the original compositions of the Vedic seers, but compositions as they were received, understood, interpreted, and organized by a particular Saá¹ƒhitÄkÄra. As this is true of ÅšÄkalyaâ€™s recension of the RV, so it must be true of Åšaunakaâ€™s recension of the AV. 7.1.2.With all this, one may develop an impression that such recen- sions or Saá¹ƒhitÄs, once they were so well put together by the respective Saá¹ƒhitÄkÄras, must have been essentially immutable, not susceptible to any further change. As we shall see, such an expectation is wide-spread, but in fact unfounded. For instance, we know that PÄá¹‡ini knew ÅšÄkalyaâ€™s RV Saá¹ƒhitÄ, as he directly quotes ÅšÄkalyaâ€™s opinions in several places (cf. à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯, P. 8.3.19; à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡, P.1.1.16). However, can we be certain that he knew ÅšÄkalyaâ€™s recension exactly as we know it today? Did he know the RV with á¸· for intervocalic á¸, or did his version not have this feature? In my opinion, the latter alternative is more likely. If the RV recension of ÅšÄkalya which has come down to us shows somewhat different features than what were known to PÄá¹‡ini, is it possible for us to say that only one of these versions is a true ÅšÄkalya recension, and that what survives is not a ÅšÄkalya recension in a real sense? Or should we rather abandon the view of the supposed immutability of these recensions, and accept a view that the recensions once formulated by scholars like ÅšÄkalya and Åšaunaka did undergo a slow process of marginal change. Some of this change was imperceptible phonetic change for a long time, but eventually such changes accumulated over a period of time. In spite of such changes, it was still possible for the successive generations of redactors to believe that they were still maintaining the ancient recension formulated by ÅšÄkalya or Åšaunaka. If we accept such a view of the transmission of Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs, we may have a different understanding of how these Saá¹ƒhitÄs were transmitted. Here we shall investigate some of these questions in relation to the text-transmission of the

82 INTRODUCTION ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV Saá¹ƒhitÄ and the exegetical tradition represented by the AV PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. 7.2. The CA and the text of the ÅšAV 7.2.1. Though the 1856 Roth-Whitney edition of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ of the AV came out before Whitneyâ€™s 1862 edition of the CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ, Roth and Whitney were already in possession of the then known single Berlin manuscript of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ with the commentary CAB. Although this lone manuscript was terribly corrupt, Whit- ney was able to extract a working text of the CA before he and Roth finalized the text of their edition of the AV. Since they were editing the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, they could see the value of the rules of the CA in the process of establishing the text of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ. However, their AV manuscripts did not always agree with the prescriptions of the CA. Whitney dutifully notes this divergence in his notes on the CA. In such cases, Roth and Whitney were faced with the question of whether to follow the authority of the manuscripts, or to abandon the manuscripts and follow the rules of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ in set- tling the reading to be selected. There were several assumptions to be made in deciding this question. The text to be finally printed as that of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV must ideally represent the text as settled by Åšaunaka. Secondly, the text which called itself ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ must also be assumed to reflect the opinions of Åšaunaka as regards the Saá¹ƒhitÄ and the PadapÄá¹­ha of this school. Therefore, on the face of it, it seemed that one could follow the CA in settling the text of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ. In practice, the Roth-Whitney edition of the ÅšAV Saá¹ƒhitÄ follows the CA and rejects the manuscripts in some places, and follows the manuscripts and rejects the CA in other places, and Surya Kanta has rightly criticized Whitney and Roth for this haphazard behavior: â€œWhat RW (= Roth-Whitney) have done in such cases is this, that, either they have ignored the CA authority, adopting the unanimous reading of the Vulgate mss., or they have flouted the Vulgate mss., and followed the formerâ€ (APR, Intro., p. 32). 7.3. Surya Kantaâ€™s assumption of the â€˜lost original ÅšaunakÄ«ya AVâ€™ 7.3.1. In 1923, Vishva Bandhu (= VidyÄrthÄ«) published a text by the title the AtharvaprÄtiÅ›Äkhya, and in 1939, Surya Kanta published his magnifi- cent expanded and annotated edition of the same AtharvaprÄtiÅ›Äkhya. All the

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 83 manuscripts used for this text directly called it AtharvaprÄtiÅ›Äkhya. Until then, the title AtharvaprÄtiÅ›Äkhya was used with reference to the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ edited by Whitney. Whitney himself knew that the CA did not call itself a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, and yet he argued (1862: iii): â€œThe treatise was first brought to light, and its character deter-mined, by Roth. It was recognized by him as being what is indicated by our title, a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya to a text of the Atharvaveda. That it has any inherent right to be called the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya to the Atharvaveda is not, of course, claimed for it; but, considering the extreme improbability that any other like phonetic treatise, belonging to any other schools of that Veda, will ever be brought to light, the title of Atharvaveda PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya finds a sufficient justification in its convenience, and in its analogy with the names given to the other kindred treatises by their respective editors.â€ The above paragraph from Whitney needs to be read carefully, and one should note that he nowhere asserted that the CA is the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya of the Atharva-Veda, an accusation hurled at him unjustly by Surya Kanta (Atharva- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, Introduction, p. 31): â€œWhitney turns an APr into the APr.â€ Whitney never made such a claim. Whitneyâ€™s modest claim that the CA was â€˜a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyaâ€™ of the AV was clearly not out of line, and now stands supported by a reference in Uvaá¹­aâ€™s commentary on the first Paá¹­ala of the RÌ¥gveda- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya: (M.D. Shastriâ€™s edition, Vol. II, p. 23): à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ - â€˜à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨â€™ - à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤, â€œThus, the same purpose is mentioned in the Ä€tharvaá¹‡a-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya rule evam iheti ca vibhÄá¹£ÄprÄptaá¹ƒ sÄmÄnyena (= CA 1.1.3-4, Whitney 1.2). The meaning of this rule is as follows: Whatever obtains optionally in a generic grammar of Sanskrit is settled in a particular way in this branch. Thus, the purpose of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya is explained.â€ Clearly, Uvaá¹­a refers to CA as an Ä€tharvaá¹‡a- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. 7.3.2. Anyway, now we are fortunately in possession of two texts which belong to the category of PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas for the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda, or are we mistaken? If we are to believe Surya Kanta, we are indeed mistaken. To put his claim in his own words: â€œThe Atharva-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya belongs to the AV., and the CA belongs to the ÅšaunakÄ«ya School of this Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and not to the AV. in generalâ€ (APR, Intro., p. 32). He argues that the APR clearly does not belong to the PaippalÄda tradition, nor does it call itself ÅšaunakÄ«ya at any place, and therefore it belongs to a non-PaippalÄda and a non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV. This, he calls, â€˜the AV,â€™ in contrast with the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, which he assumes must be the subject of the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. He offers the following arguments to support his case. For

84 INTRODUCTION each argument, I have provided only a few sample examples, though Surya Kanta has offered a large number of such examples. 7.3.3.Argument a: 7.3.3.1. In a number of places, the Vulgate of the AV, the text repre- sented by the manuscripts, agrees more closely with the description in the APR, than with the description in the CA: â€œThe APR cites 3,236 AV. passages, and the number of citations is probably larger than that contained in any other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. Out of this large number, there are hardly ten passages, where the Vulgate mss. do not follow the sanction, explicit or implicit, of the APR, while there occur hundreds of passages in the CA., where not a single Vulgate ms. follows the sanction of this treatise, besides those typical cases, where CA specifically prescribes a certain saá¹ƒdhi for a chosen passage, but that saá¹ƒdhi is not carried out in that passage even by a single Vulgate ms.; and this is significantâ€ (APR, Intro., p. 32). 7.3.3.2. For example, consider CA (1.4.3, Whitney 1.94: à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾) and its examples. This rule says that if we have a sequence such as nicakh-kh-nuá¸¥, the first kh changes to k, and we get the form nicak-kh-nuá¸¥. Thus, we should get id-dh-ma, and not idh-dh-ma; rurud-dh-re, and not ru- rudh-dh-re. In practice, the manuscripts of the Vulgate do not show forms like nicak-kh-nuá¸¥. We only get nicakh-nuá¸¥. Thus, the CA rule is not obeyed by the manuscripts of the Vulgate. Therefore, the Vulgate is not truly ÅšaunakÄ«ya. 7.3.3.3. Another such example is CA (2.1.6, Whitney 2.6: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥). This rule requires that in a combination like godhuk-Å›ete, the final k of the first word be replaced by kh. This doctrine is explicitly ascribed to Åšaunaka by VPR (4.119: à¤…à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯). However, the manu- scripts of the Vulgate of the AV do not follow this rule, and hence, according to Surya Kanta, the Vulgate is not ÅšaunakÄ«ya. 7.3.3.4. Referring to CA (2.1.9, Whitney 2.9: à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥), Surya Kanta again points out that the Vulgate manuscripts do not show forms like pratyaá¹…-k-Å›ete, and concludes: â€œ(1) that CA records sandhis for the Åšaunaka AV; (2) that these are not observed by the Vulgate mss.; (3) that the Vulgate does not represent the Åšaunaka Å›ÄkhÄ, but some otherâ€ (APR, Intro., p. 40).

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 85 7.3.4.Argument b: 7.3.4.1. In a number of places, the CA seems to be explaining usages which are not found in the Vulgate text of the AV, and Surya Kanta proposes that such usages must have existed in a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. 7.3.4.2. For example, consider CA rules (1.3.24, Whitney 1.86: à¤¹à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¤¿) and (1.3.25, Whitney 1.87: à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). The first rule refers to desiderative forms of the roots han and gam. While the desiderative of han is attested in the AV, the desiderative of gam is not. Similarly, of the three roots cited in CA (1.1.26, Whitney 1.26), only the desiderative forms for mÄn are attested in the Vulgate of the AV, but the desideratives of Å›Än and dÄn are not so attested. Surya Kanta argues that the desiderative forms of gam, Å›Än and dÄn must have occurred in the original ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, and their absence in the Vulgate of the AV proves that the Vulgate is not ÅšaunakÄ«ya. 7.3.5. Argument c: 7.3.5.1. The commentary CAB often quotes instances to illustrate the CA rules which are not found in the Vulgate text of the AV. Surya Kanta proposes that such instances must have existed in the genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. 7.3.5.2. For example, the CAB on CA (1.1.16, Whitney 1.14-16) quotes an instance which appears in the manuscripts as prÄmÅ« ca roha. This is not found in the Vulgate of the AV. Surya Kanta cites this as an example which occurred in the so-called genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, which is now lost. Whitney, I believe correctly, amends the manuscript reading to prajÄá¹ƒ ca roha, AV (13.1.34). 7.3.5.2. To cite another example, the CAB on CA (1.1.28, Whitney 1.28) cites an instance punÄ raktaá¹ƒ vÄsaá¸¥, which not attested in the Vulgate of the AV. Surya Kanta asserts that this example comes from the now lost genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV. 7.3.6. Argument d: 7.3.6.1. In some places, the APR explicitly goes against the rules of the CA, and in such cases, the manuscripts of the AV generally seem to be closer to the APR, than the CA. Therefore, the AV as found in the currently available manuscripts does not represent the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension.

86 INTRODUCTION 7.3.6.2. For example, on CA (2.3.6, Whitney 2.65: à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¤°à¤‚à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥- à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ), the CAB says: à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¥- à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤­à¥‡à¤·à¤œà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥¬.à¥©) à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤œà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥©à¥§). Thus, the CAB says that the change of a visarga to á¹£ before krÌ¥á¹‡otu occurs [only] in the three listed examples. Referring to the same three instances, the APR (148) says: à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨, â€œThere is no change of visarga to s (and then to á¹£) in these three examples.â€ This would suggest that in the view of the APR, one was expected to maintain a visarga in these cases. Surya Kanta points out that the Vulgate manuscripts follow the APR, and not the CA. Then he concludes that the Vulgate is not a ÅšaunakÄ«ya text. 7.3.6.3. Based upon an extensive examination of the CA, CAB, and the APR, in relation to the existing manuscripts of the AV, Surya Kanta arrives at the following conclusions: 1)The APR belongs to the Vulgate. 2)CA goes with the Åšaunaka School 3)the two are not one. Besides these conclusions, Surya Kanta has given a detailed compari- son of the readings for the AV as known to the APR and the readings as known to SÄyaá¹‡a. SÄyaá¹‡a shows hundreds of different readings, â€œmore than 300 readings in the first four KÄá¹‡á¸as aloneâ€ (APR, Intro., p. 56). SÄyaá¹‡a claims to represent the ÅšaunakÄ«ya version of the AV, and yet these different readings exist in the text known to him. Surya Kanta suggests that one should check the mss. of SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary to see if they conform to the sanctions of the CA, and then decide whether he really commented on the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. In any case, he would like to assert that whatever ÅšÄkhÄ is represented by SÄyaá¹‡a is not the same as the one represented by the APR. 7.4. Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusions: 7.4.1. Based on the above discussion, we can list below the conclu- sions drawn by Surya Kanta as I understand them. Conclusion 1: The recensions or Saá¹ƒhitÄs, once they were prepared by scholars like Åšaunaka, were for all practical pur- poses immutable.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 87 Conclusion 2: The ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ totally reflects the opinions of Åšaunaka, and hence the picture of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ gathered from the CA must be viewed as a faithful representa- tion of the original Saá¹ƒhitÄ prepared by Åšaunaka. Conclusion 3: The CA was designed to deal exclusively with the linguistic facts of the original ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and nothing more. Therefore, all usages targeted by the rules of the CA must have existed in the original Åšaunaka AV, which is not found in the Vulgate mss. Conclusion 4: The CA and the APR represented different ÅšÄkhÄs of the AV, and are unrelated to each other. Conclusion 5: The CAB is a completely faithful explanation of the CA rules, and does not represent any change. The CAB, like the CA, is a true ÅšaunakÄ«ya text, and that all the examples cited by the CAB must have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV. Conclusion 6: Even though SÄyaá¹‡a claims to be commenting on the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, his text actually represents a non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. Some of these conclusions have been explicitly articulated by Surya Kanta, while others can be inferred from his arguments. 7.5. Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s claims and assumptions.5 7.5.1.Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 1: 7.5.1.1. In my opinion, this conclusion is unacceptable. It can be demonstrated that while PÄá¹‡ini knew the RV Saá¹ƒhitÄ of ÅšÄkalya, the form in which he knew it was not totally identical with the form of the RV Saá¹ƒhitÄ as we know it. The PaippalÄda as found in Kashmir and in Orissa shows in-

5In my annotations on the rules of the CA in this critical edition, I have discussed these issues at a number of places. See Notes on the following CA rules: 1.1.10, 1.2.4, 1.2.9, 1.3.15, 1.3.16, 1.3.24, 1.3.25, 2.1.2, 2.1.9, 2.1.12, 2.1.14, 2.1.19, 2.2.1, 2.2.8, 2.2.11, 2.2.12, 2.2.13, 2.3.4, 2.3.6, 2.3.8, 2.3.14, 2.3.15, 2.3.16, 2.3.17, 2.4.6, 3.1.5, 3.1.20, 3.2.10, 3.2.24, 3.2.31, 3.4.5, 3.4.6, 3.4.24, 4.2.16, 4.2.21, and 4.3.13.

88 INTRODUCTION credible variation of detail, and there is every reason to believe that these Saá¹ƒhitÄs underwent change in the process of transmission. S.P. Pandit gives a vivid account of his encounters with a reciter of the AV, KeÅ›ava Bhaá¹­: â€œhe was more shocked that the several mss. of that Veda … exhibited numerous varieties of reading, and still more horrified when he found that the text he knew by heart and which was as it had been improved by Gaá¹‡eÅ› Bhaá¹­ DÄdÄ was the worse for improvements.â€ (AV, VVRI edition, Vol. I, p. xvii). Pandit amply demonstrates how the Vaidikas practised what they called ÅšuddhÄ«- karaá¹‡a â€˜purification, restorationâ€™, and often knew the inherited traditional reading, besides the improved reading. For the Vaidikas, the results of such a ÅšuddhÄ«karaá¹‡a did not reflect a change from the original, but, on the contrary, a way of restoring the original. Thus, while in historical terms, a great deal of change occurred in the transmission of a ÅšÄkhÄ, this change was not admitted by the Vaidikas, who continuously tried to restore what they thought was the original. Thus, we cannot maintain any notion of immutability of a ÅšÄkhÄ-text. 7.5.2. Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 2: 7.5.2.1. While the CA does call itself ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ, it would not be ap- propriate to assume that it provides a picture of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ as it was originally prepared by Åšaunaka himself. The CA claim to the title ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ should only be understood to mean that it respects Åšaunaka as the founder of its tradition, and that it belongs to that school. When it comes to details, the CA openly admits that it deviates from the opinions of Åšaunaka, and hence represents the ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition as it had changed over a period of time. 7.5.2.2. For instance, consider CA (1.1.10, Whitney 1.8: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ) and the CAB on this rule: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤†à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤ à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥. Åšaunakaâ€™s doctrine held that the voiceless unaspirated stops, occurring at the end of words, should be changed to voiced unaspirated stops. However, the CA and the CAB both point out that such a doctrine is not to be applied in actual recitation. Inter- estingly, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on this rule refers to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyanaâ€™s opinion in the RPR (1.15-16: à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤ƒ), and states: à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥, â€œBecause [we] follow ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, in [the recitation of] this Veda, [we] accept the first members of the stop-series as word-final [consonants in prepausal situations].â€ The lesson to be learned from this comment is that a tradition claiming itself to be in the line of Åšaunaka felt no hesitation in occasionally deviating from the opinion of

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 89 Åšaunaka, and following the opinions of another scholar like ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana. Thus, the claim that the CA represents the unsullied views of Åšaunaka can not be entertained. 7.5.3.Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 3: 7.5.3.1. In most cases, it is true that the rules of the CA deal exclu- sively with the linguistic facts of the AV. However, this is not true in absolute terms. Whitney has pointed out numerous cases, where the CA is venturing into an explanation of the facts of Sanskrit beyond what is attested in the AV. This probably occurred because the author of the CA had before him general treatments of Sanskrit at large, and in many cases he drew upon such gener- alized sources. 7.5.3.2. For example: CA (1.3.25, Whitney 1.87: à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). While the rule relates to the desiderative forms of three roots, only the forms of mÄn are attested in ÅšAV. However, these three roots are also grouped together in P.3.1.6 (à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¬à¤§à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯), and it is very likely that the CA rule was based on a concern for the general grammar of Sanskrit. 7.5.3.3. Consider CA (3.4.24, Whitney 3.92: à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤­à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). This rule refers to a Gaá¹‡a, the Ká¹£ubhnÄdigaá¹‡a, and says that in these forms the n does not change to á¹‡. However, no forms of ká¹£ubh where this would be applicable are available in the ÅšAV. But notice that PÄá¹‡ini 8.4.39 (à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤­à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š) prescribes the same thing and refers to the same Gaá¹‡a. Thus, it is safer to assume that occasionally the CA was drawing upon generalized grammars of Sanskrit, and hence occasionally its rules extend beyond the linguistic facts of the AV. 7.5.4.Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 4: 7.5.4.1. This argument is unacceptable for numerous reasons. As Surya Kanta himself notes, several Gaá¹‡as referred to in the CA by the first instance are fully listed in the APR with the same first instance. Similarly, in 95 percent of the cases, the examples quoted in the CAB are simply the first few instances of long lists found in the APR. This could not have occurred unless these two texts were somehow genetically linked. 7.5.4.2. Surya Kanta himself notes that the mss. of the APR are mostly found in the same bundles which also contain the text of the CA, as well as many clearly ÅšaunakÄ«ya texts. The colophons in these ms. bundles indicate that these mss. were copied, preserved and studied by ÅšaunakÄ«ya families (e.g. the PaÃ±colÄ« family of Gujarat), and the texts of the Vulgate also

90 INTRODUCTION largely come from these same families. Thus, the ÅšaunakÄ«yas preserved and studied both of these texts and they also preserved the Vulgate text of the AV, and saw no contradiction. 7.5.4.3. The few cases, where the APR explicitly rejects the formulation of the CA, and where the mss. of the Vulgate follow the APR should be accounted for by resorting to linguistic change within a given tradition over a period of time. Such for instance is the case of CA (2.3.6, Whitney 2.65: à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¤°à¤‚à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ). As discussed earlier, the CAB says that the change of visarga to s (and then to á¹£) before krÌ¥á¹‡otu occurs only in three instances. However, the APR (148) says that one does not change the visarga to s (and then to á¹£) in these three cases. It is possible to account for these statements as reflecting a possible historical development. 7.5.4.4. Whitney, on this rule, says: â€œIn all these (= three) passages, however, the manuscripts read, without dissent, visarjanÄ«ya before the k. … Other instances in which krÌ¥á¹‡otu has an unaltered visarjanÄ«ya before it are tolerably numerous.â€ Thus, instead of simply talking about two different re- censions represented by these two texts, one could make a better case for a possible historical change within the same tradition: 1) CA - Unconditional change of visarjanÄ«ya to s before krÌ¥á¹‡otu. 2) CAB - This change occurs only in three instances. 3) APR - The above change does not occur in any instances. 7.5.4.5. Such a general direction of possible change in the oral text is further supported by the following observations of W.S. Allen (1953: 51): â€œIn later, though still ancient, times there appears to have been a tendency for -á¸¥ to extend its usage to contexts other than in pausa. The earliest of these extensions was to the position before the initial fricatives Å›-, á¹£-, s-, where it replaced the homorganic final -Å›, -á¹£, -s (indraÅ› Å›Å«raá¸¥ > indraá¸¥ Å›Å«raá¸¥, &c). This practice was then extended to the position before the velar and labial voiceless stops: in connexion with this innovation we find mentioned the names of Ä€gniveÅ›ya, VÄlmÄ«ki, ÅšÄkalya, and the MÄdhyandina school, whilst the ancient grammarian ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana is quoted as holding to the more conservative practice.â€ Allen also refers to A.H. Fryâ€™s view that â€œthe spread of -á¸¥ was due to the writers of Classical Sanskrit operating with a phonemic orthography.â€ The last comment is especially significant, since we are dealing with relatively late manuscripts for editing our texts.

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 91 7.5.5.Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 5: 7.5.5.1. There is no reason to believe that the CAB is a totally faithful interpretation of the CA and that it does not add anything to the CA reflecting either historical change in the transmitted text of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, or new influences from other grammatical traditions such as that of PÄá¹‡ini. 7.5.5.2. The discussion in the previous section shows a possibility of a gap between the views held by the CA and the CAB. Here is another example. On CA (2.3.3, Whitney 2.62: à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤•à¤ªà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯- à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥), the CAB first discusses all the instances directly referred to by the CA rule, and finally adds: à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¾à¤®à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©à¥¯). This added instance is not covered by the list of exceptions in the CA rule itself. However, it is covered by the APR (201). Thus, it is possible that this exception was not intended by the author of the CA, but developed later on and was accounted for by both the CAB and the APR. 7.5.5.3. In very many cases, the CAB offers lists of examples which are not found in the AV, but are taken most probably from the PÄá¹‡inian com- mentaries like the KV. I have already discussed a number of such examples above in section 6.9.3. Considering the profusion of such non-AV PÄá¹‡inian examples in the CAB, one cannot agree with Surya Kanta that every example cited by the CAB, not found in the Vulgate of the AV, must have occurred in the so-called genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV. I must also point out that Whitney had already cited all these PÄá¹‡inian examples from the CAB in his edition of the CA. However, Surya Kanta remains totally silent about all these examples. If the CAB can cite all these examples, there is no reason to assume that every example cited by the CAB must be a genuine AV example. Even an example like à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ in the CAB on CA (1.1.28, Whitney 1.28) which is not traced in the AV, and is ascribed by Surya Kanta to his genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, is found in the KV on P.1.3.14 (à¤°à¥‹ à¤°à¤¿), and could have been taken from such a PÄá¹‡inian commentary. 7.5.6.Critique of Surya Kantaâ€™s Conclusion 6: 7.5.6.1. At the very beginning of his BhÄá¹£ya on the first KÄá¹‡á¸a of the AV, SÄyaá¹‡a says: à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥

92 INTRODUCTION â€œThe meaning of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya branch shall be explained by pointing out its application in the ritual actions mentioned earlier.â€ This makes it clear that in his own opinion, SÄyaá¹‡a was commenting on the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension and none other. We should be willing to accept a strong possibility that, like the separate textual transmission of the PaippalÄda recension in different regions of India, the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension also underwent slightly divergent developments in different parts, cf. Mishra, R.C. 1984. These different sub-schools were not always in touch with each other, and probably underwent independent ÅšuddhÄ«karaá¹‡a â€˜purification / restorationâ€™ (and a-ÅšuddhÄ«karaá¹‡a for that matter) in different regions. As it has been shown by Vishva Bandhu and Pandit, such regional traits are manifest in the manuscripts of the AV. â€œLooking to the nature of the several MSS., I group them as follows: A, B, C, D, E, R, Sm, Cs, P, P2, J, and Cp, come from Gujarat, though not from the same original source. They are untainted by any attempts to revise the tradition of the text and probably represented the original form of the true tradition of the text. Bp, Bh, K, Km, V, and Dc, are on the other hand representatives of the Atharvaveda as it was revised in the Deccan; where it was introduced about 160 years ago, under the influence of the school of the RÌ¥gvedins and was further subjected to changes in relation to the text of SÄyaá¹‡ÄcÄrya by Gaá¹‡eÅ› Bhaá¹­ DÄdÄ after his visit to Åšriá¹…geri, and his discovery there of SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentaryâ€ (AV, VVRI edition, Vol. I, Intro., p. xxvi). 7.5.6.2. It is also clear that the late commentators of the CA, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara and KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa, were unaware of the existence of CAB, and were working not on CA, but on what they called Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a. Generally speaking, the CA manuscripts are located in the regions of Gujarat and Rajasthan. The manuscripts which call their text Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a are generally located in Ujjain and Deccan. Not a single manuscript of the CA has been found in the southern parts of India. As Panditâ€™s introduction shows, the Deccan tradition of the AV became aware of SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary at a very late time, when a Maharashtrian AV reciter visited Åšriá¹…gerÄ« and then became aware of its existence. It is also not unlikely that the southern tradition of the

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 93 ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV was not aware of the existence of the CA and its commentaries. SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary, which refers to PÄá¹‡ini and later grammarians in that tradition hundreds of times, does not refer either to CA or to APR even once. Thus, one can make a probable assumption that the text-tradition of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV received by him was not in contact with either the CA or the APR. However, for that reason, one need not discard his claim that he too was working with â€˜aâ€™ ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition. 7.6. Surya Kantaâ€™s â€˜star exampleâ€™ Re-examined. 7.6.1. Surya Kanta (APR, Intro., p. 42) points to a passage in the APR which proves conclusively to him that the currently preserved text of the AV is not that of the true ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ. This is a dual reference in APR (140c) and (3g) to the passage tannastapaá¸¥ (AV 12.3.12). The question is whether this should be understood as a combination of taá¹ƒ naá¸¥ or tat naá¸¥. APR (140c: à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¥ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¹à¤¤ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤·à¤£à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¬à¤¾à¤§à¥‡) refers to this passage and says that tannas should be analyzed as tam naá¸¥. Referring to the same passage, APR (3g) says: à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¤•à¤‚ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥‡à¥¤. Surya Kanta (APR, Intro., p. 42) translates this passage as: â€œAlso in another Å›ÄkhÄ of the AV; tan nas tapaá¸¥ (12.3.12); tat, masc., nom. sing. ends in a (= saá¸¥); the same in neut. ends in t; (this is so found) in the school of Åšaunaka.â€ For Surya Kanta, â€œThe wording is explicit. Åšaunakas read in the Pada tat naá¸¥, against tam naá¸¥ of the APrÅš. APr. 140c and 3g taken together give: - 1. tam naá¸¥; APrÅš.; so SPP. with all his authorities. 2. tat naá¸¥, Åšaunakas; so Whitney with all his mss.â€ 7.6.2. What does this passage mean? One must concede that it refers to an observed difference in the recitation of the PadapÄá¹­ha, and that the reading tat naá¸¥ is ascribed by the author of the APR to a tradition described as Åšaunaka. However, this does not and should not be taken to mean that the reading tat naá¸¥ belongs to the so-called pure genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ which is now lost. It in fact does not refer to the view of Åšaunaka, or directly to the PadapÄá¹­ha as constituted by Åšaunaka, but to the tradition as constituted by the ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄdhyÄyikÄ. This is clear from CA (1.1.10, Whitney 1.8: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ) and the commentaries CAB and BhÄrgava-BhÄskara-VrÌ¥tti. It was Åšaunakaâ€™s doctrine that the words ending in the first members of the stop-series should be recited as ending in the third members, e.g. tad / naá¸¥. However, the rule and the commentaries inform us that such was no longer the practice, and that in the recitation as it was

94 INTRODUCTION known to the author of the CA, the words were to be recited as ending in the first members of the stop-series, e.g. tat / naá¸¥. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, in his commentary on CA 1.1.10, clearly ascribes the practice of the followers of the CA to the doctrine of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana: à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥. Thus, it is clear that the word Å›aunaka as used in APR (3g) refers not to some Ur-ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, now lost, as assumed by Surya Kanta, but to the followers of the CA, who had openly diverged from the genuine doctrine of Åšaunaka. Additionally, as Surya Kanta notes himself, these two views, e.g. tam naá¸¥ versus tat naá¸¥, continued to manifest in the manuscripts of the Vulgate of the AV, and it is not the case that the manuscripts of the Vulgate took no notice of the view ascribed to Å›aunaka by the APR. What this suggests is a picture of a diversified recitational tradition of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ. While it is perfectly appropriate to say that the reading taá¹ƒ naá¸¥ was not followed by the adherents of the CA, the texts as we have them do not distinguish these readings as some being ÅšaunakÄ«ya and others as non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya. 7.7. Need for a new approach to the study of the transmission of the Veda 7.7.1. To conclude, I would like to say that in order to have a realistic notion of what happened to the Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs as they were transmitted over centuries in different regions of India, one needs to give up certain stereotypes regarding the nature of the transmission of the Vedic texts. One need not belittle the enormous efforts made by the Vaidikas to transmit these texts without change. However, our critical assessment must not be swayed by such respect. The Vaidikas who transmitted the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Saá¹ƒhitÄ never thought that they were changing anything, and yet change did indeed take place. When they did change something, either this change was unconscious change, or they thought that they were purifying the text and were restoring the pristine original. The CA, the CAB, the APR, the various manuscripts, and SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary must all be looked at for traces of what transpired during this long and diversified process of transmission. All these sources are changing manifestations of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya textual tradition and there is no need to deny the title â€˜ÅšaunakÄ«yaâ€™ to any one of them. Moving away from the unreachable goal of reaching the Ur-form of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya text, or any other Vedic text for that matter, we should look at the changing vicissitudes of a Vedic tradition more carefully. Here, we are more likely to find a realistic historical picture of what real Vaidikas, copyists, reciters, and interpreters did to a text, which had no independent existence from what these custodians did to it. This is all the

ÅšAUNAKÄªYÄ€ CATURÄ€DHYÄ€YIKÄ€ 95 more significant in the case of the transmission of the Atharvaveda. For reasons which we cannot discuss here in great detail, the population of Vaidikas who pursued the Atharvavedic traditions is minuscule at present, in comparison with the followers of the RÌ¥gveda and Yajurveda, and there is reason to believe that it was so even in the past. This may have to do with the historically traceable lower status given to the Atharvaveda by the other traditions reflected in its early exclusion from the TrayÄ«, and probably also due to the Ä€bhicÄrika rites practiced by the Atharvavedic priests. This is analogous to the social relations of the Brahmaá¹‡a families who perform the funerary rites, and the refusal of even the Atharvavedic reciters to recite the funerary hymns of the Atharvaveda as noted by Pandit. It is indeed the case that the Atharvaveda that we possess today comes to us from extremely limited sources. Most manuscripts found in the Gujarat area seem in fact to point to one single prominent Atharvavedic family, the PaÃ±colis. From the manuscript colophons alone one can reconstruct several generations of PaÃ±colis involved in the transmission of the Atharvaveda. With very small numbers of reciters, and often the reciters of the other Vedas taking over the recitation of the Atharvaveda to cater to the demand for the Ä€bhicÄrika rites (as reported to me by the late Pt. NÄrÄyaá¹‡a ÅšÄstrÄ« Raá¹­Äá¹­e of Banaras), the transmission has indeed suffered through the ages, and hence the Atharvaveda material we possess is in a relatively less authentic state in comparison with other Vedic traditions. In any case, we possess enough material to trace the development of the Atharvaveda transmission in various regions of Western and Southern India. Any detailed discussion of such efforts lies clearly outside the scope of this Introduction. However, the interpretation and the transmission of the CA and the transmission of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya Atharvaveda have been closely related to each other, and this edition hopes to further a clearer understanding of these relations. __________________________________

à¥¥ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¥ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥ à¤¨à¤®à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤—à¤£à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—- à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‡ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹- à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾- à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¥‹ à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¤²à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤²à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¥ - à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥à¤²à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤²à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¶à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¶à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥‹à¤—à¤¸à¤‚à¤²à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤‹à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤š à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤—à¤£à¤œà¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤®à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥€à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤¦à¤®à¥(?) à¤­à¤œà¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¥¥à¥§à¥¥ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ à¥© à¥¥ à¥§.à¥§.à¥§. à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ Absent in Whitney. Found in E, F, G, H, I, N, and O. G: 1.1.1. Translation: Thus [begin the phonetic doctrines in relation to the Veda] of the Aá¹…giras. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - H and N list this rule without any comment.

98à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤—à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¸ à¤‹à¤·à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤®à¥ - â€˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤®à¥‚ à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤®à¥, à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤—, à¥§.à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤- à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¤²à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤—à¤° …â€™[missing text] Note: The incomplete quotation in the BhÄrgava-BhÄskara-VrÌ¥tti is from the Gopatha-BrÄhmaá¹‡a (PÅ«rvabhÄga, 1.7, p.6): à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤®à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¤¦à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®- à¤¤à¤ªà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤—à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¤°à¤¸à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.1). Found in B, D, E, F, Hb, I, J, K, L, Nab, O, and P. Translation: Here are defined the [phonetic/phonological] characteristics of nouns, verbs, prepositions, and particles, the four types of words, as they occur in combination [with the following words, as in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha] and before pause [or in isolation, as in the PadapÄá¹­ha]. Note: The word prÄtijÃ±am refers to the notion of pratijÃ±Äna (cf. CA 1.1.10), and this refers to a doctrine or a view explicitly held or stated by a teacher, in contrast with vrÌ¥tti â€œrecitational practice.â€ In most cases, the pratijÃ±Ä and the vrÌ¥tti are expected to agree with each other. However, this is not always the case. There is a general expectation that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas take the existence of the PadapÄá¹­ha for granted and then teach the rules for converting the PadapÄá¹­ha into Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. Such an expectation is created by the statement à¤ªà¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ (NR 1.17; RPR 2.1: à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ). This statement is inter- preted in two opposite ways. The first interpretation is that the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha is the basis for the PadapÄá¹­ha. This is historically valid, since the PadapÄá¹­ha is an analysis of the words of the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. However, the more commonly accepted interpretation is that the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha has the PadapÄá¹­ha for its basis, i.e. the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha is derived by applying the rules of Sandhi to the Pada- pÄá¹­ha. With this interpretation in mind, one expects the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas to provide

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾99 rules for converting the PadapÄá¹­ha into the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, and not the other way around. However, as Whitney (1862: 10) notes: â€œOur own work gives in its fourth chapter the rules for the construction of the pada-text itself, as does also the VÄjasaneyi PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ This is more in line with the neutral statement of the present rule. It lays equal emphasis on the sandhya characteristics, as well as the padya characteristics. This is clear in its use of the dual forms: à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥Œ (à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¥). In general, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas are not concerned with the full derivation of grammatical forms, as are the grammars of Sanskrit. This contrast is brought out by the commentary CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya. Also see Whitneyâ€™s comments on TPR (3.1, pp. 82ff): â€œIn the other treatises (Rik Pr vii.-ix., VÄj. Pr. iii. 95-128, Ath. Pr. iii.1-25), the rules tell us in what situations a vowel originally short is lengthened: This is more in accordance with the general method of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, which take for granted, upon the whole, the existence of their ÅšÄkhÄs in the analyzed condition of the pada-text, and proceed to construct the saá¹ƒhitÄ from it. Here, on the contrary, we are told what vowels, long in the ordinary text, are to be shortened when thrown out of combination with their surroundings. Such dissolution of the continuity of the text takes place, first, in pada, whenever a pause - either the avagraha sepa- rating the two members of a compound, in its repetition after iti, or the longer pause that divides between two words - comes to stand between the vowel in question and the consonant which was its next neighbour in saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ I thank Prof. Cardona for drawing my attention to this section of the TPR. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤—à¥à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€(à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€?)à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®(H, N: à¤®à¤¾) à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤²à¥€à¤¢â€™à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¢à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¢à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°(H, N: Â°à¤¦, Whitney: Â°à¤°)à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤§à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥ªà¥¦)à¥¤ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥§)à¥¤ à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ (cf. â€˜à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥©.à¥§à¥©) à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ (cf. â€˜à¤¢à¥à¤°à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤½à¤£à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥¬.à¥©.à¥§à¥§à¥§) à¤µà¥ˆà¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤

100à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ Note: Whitney (1862: 11) expresses some doubt as to whether the commentator here refers to PÄá¹‡ini or to some other authority. The expressions used are so obviously PÄá¹‡inian, that we need not entertain any such doubt. The CAB is fully conversant with PÄá¹‡ini, and by the term vyÄkaraá¹‡a, it refers to PÄá¹‡ini alone. Compare the CAB on the next rule. This need not mean that the CA itself necessarily presupposes PÄá¹‡ini. However, the commentatorial tradition is firmly rooted in the awareness of PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar as the grammar par excellence. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©. à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.2), Ha, I, Na: à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡. B, D, E, F, J, K, L, M, O and P: à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ Translation: [This treatise] also [defines that the phonetic/ phonological features of the words] in this [tradition] are such and such. Note: Whitney combines this rule with the following one in a single rule, following the CAB. However, having done that, he still feels that the rule is â€œsomewhat obscure and of difficult constructionâ€ (Whitney 1862, p. 11). He then refers to Max MÃœllerâ€™s rendering of this rule (M. MÃœller, RPR, p. xii): â€œwhat by the grammatical text books is left free, that is here thus and thus, so says the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ Whitney criticizes this interpretation by saying that â€œit leaves the ca unexplained, and supposes the iti to be in another place, making the rule to read rather evam iha vibhÄá¹£ÄprÄptaá¹ƒ sÄmÄnya iti; … It seems necessary, in order to account for ca, to bring down prÄtijÃ±am as general predicate from the preceding rule; and the iti must be understood as pointing out that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya says evam iha, â€˜so and so is proper here,â€™ respecting any matter which the rules of grammar leave doubtfulâ€ (Whitney, 1862, p. 11). Whitney is correct in bringing down the word prÄtijÃ±am from the previous rule to give a better account of ca in this rule. However, such an interpretation fits better if the portion ending in ca is a separate rule, as the majority of mss. now indicate. Additionally, the rule is not obscure, and its interpretation is further assisted by the fact of it being quoted by Uvaá¹­a in his introduction to the RPR (M.D. Shastri edn., Part II, p. 23) in a discussion of the exact relation between the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition and the tradition of grammar. However, Whitney does make a problematic statement: â€œit (= CA) does not at all imply or base itself upon the general science of grammar and its text book, but is an independent and a complete treatise as regards its own subject.â€ While it is an

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾101 independent treatise, it clearly assumes the prior existence of general grammars of Sanskrit, and seems to imply that it is related to the general science of grammar as a statement of particular features of a Veda branch would relate to a generic description of Sanskrit at large. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ (H, N: à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤‚, Whitney: à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚) à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤š.à¤†. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¤§à¥‘à¤™à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¥’ à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯ à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥’à¤£à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤£à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¹à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª.)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤šà¥ˆ(à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥¬.à¥§.)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in AV, fabricated example cited in KV on P.8.4.45)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥ª. à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ A combines this with à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ. Translation: [These phonetic/phonological features of the words] obtain optionally in a generic [grammar of Sanskrit]. Note: This rule contrasts the function of a generic grammar of Sanskrit with that of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. A PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya ideally aims at strictly de- scribing the linguistic features of words as they occur in a particular Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄ text, and , therefore, it is expected to be highly specific. A general grammar of Sanskrit, on the other hand, is expected to cover all the different textual traditions and dialects of colloquial Sanskrit, and hence it ends up making optional statements. This precisely accords with PataÃ±jaliâ€™s explana- tion as to why PÄá¹‡ini was forced to use different option-terms. (à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¹à¥€à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¯ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥, MB on P.2.1.58 and P.6.3.14). Also see Uvaá¹­aâ€™s introductory comments on the first Paá¹­ala of the RPR (M.D. Shastri edn., Vol.II, p. 23):

102à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¹ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¥‡à¤£à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤‚, à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ - â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‹à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ- à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ … à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿;
