A, B, D, E, F, J, K, L, M, P: Â°à¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: A sound occurring at the end of a word [i.e. a pada in the PadapÄá¹­ha] is termed padya. Note: As Whitney (1862: 12) points out, the term padya is â€œnot found at all in either of the Yajur-Veda PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, or in PÄá¹‡ini, and in the Rik PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya it means â€˜member of a compound word.â€™â€ By its etymology, the word would simply mean â€˜belonging to a pada,â€™ and hence the need for a precise definition. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾103 à¥§.à¥§.à¥¬. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.4): à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒÂ°. A, B, D, E, F, Hab, I, J, L, M, Nab, O, P: Â°à¤¨à¥ƒÂ°. Translation: [Any] vowel, other than lÌ¥, may occur at the end of a word. Note: All the manuscripts share the mistaken reading à¤…à¤¨à¥ƒà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ. How- ever, I agree with Whitneyâ€™s reading. As the CAB clearly shows, the only excluded vowel is lÌ¥. Whitney (1862: 12) provides information on how several other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas also exclude lÌ¥ from the sounds which may occur at the end of words, i.e. padas in the PadapÄá¹­ha. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘â€™ (H: à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾, Whitney: à¤¹à¥à¤®, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥©.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥€à¤²à¤¾â€™ (not found in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤§à¤¿â€™ (â€˜à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¥‘- à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥®.à¥¨à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‚â€™ (â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‚â€™, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒâ€™ (Whitney: no such case in AV, … take instead pitrÌ¥bhiá¸¥, e.g. vi.63.3; pitrÌ¥lokam, xviii.4.64)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¥‘à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆâ€™ (H, N: à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡, Whitney: à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ. à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥Œâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥¨à¥ª.à¥­)à¥¤ Note: While the ms. H reads brahmÄ, the ms. N reads brahma, and this is the reading chosen by Whitney. It seems to be the correct reading in view of the fact that the commentary is clearly offering examples of short and long vowels in a fixed sequence. This would make the reading brahmÄ unsuitable. The word nÄ«lam is found in AV (14.2.48), and nÄ«lena is found in AV (15.1.8). However, the VVRI concordance does not record any occur- rence of nÄ«lÄ in the Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs. Whitney (1862: 12) appropriately notes that rÌ¥ appears only at the end of the first member of a compound, or before a case affix, but not exactly at the end of inflected words. This reminder is important in view of the fact that the word pada, though not defined in this text,

104à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ applies not only to inflected nominal and verbal items, it also covers nominal bases as they appear in compounds and before certain case terminations. The PadapÄá¹­ha typically separates members of compounds, and nominal bases before bh- initial case terminations and -su. The sound rÌ¥ does appear in such environments, and, therefore, it is legitimately a padya sound. à¥§.à¥§.à¥­. à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.5). Translation: [The sounds] l and á¸¥ may also [occur at the end of words]. Note: As Whitney (1862: 13) points out, the RPR (xii.1) and the VPR (i.86) omit l from the list of pada-final sounds. The other two AV words ending in l are Å›al and phal â€œin xx. 135.2, 3, a part of the text of which our treatise takes no accountâ€ (Whitney, 1862: 13). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥Œ à¤š à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥®. à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.6). Translation: The first and the last [members in each series of] stops [may also occur at the end of words]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: In listing the possible pada-final stops, the commentary includes c and Ã±. This inclusion must be canceled by the very next rule, which says that members of the c-series cannot occur pada-finally. Whitney (1862: 13) gives a detailed account of which stops are more or less frequent in the pada-final position. Also compare: VPR (i. 85), and RPR (xii. 1).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾105 à¥§.à¥§.à¥¯. à¤¨ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.7). B, D, P: Â°à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤ƒ. Translation: [But] not the [members of the] c-series. Note: Since only the firsts and the lasts of the stop-series qualify to occur at the end of words according to CA 1.1.8, one needs to exclude only c and Ã±, and not the whole c-series. Perhaps the expression cavargaá¸¥ is felt to be more economical as compared to the expression cakÄraÃ±akÄrau. The notion of economy often applies at the level of expression, rather than reference. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤šà¤›à¤œà¤à¤ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - [ms G resumes with folio 4a] à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒà¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤¿à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤·à¥’- à¤£à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¬.à¥©à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥„à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥©à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯. à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: The incomplete initial word of the BhÄrgava-BhÄskara-VrÌ¥tti is most likely sparÅ›ÄnÄm. Thus, the commentary makes it explicit, that among the stops, only eight stops may occur at the end of the padas. Concerning the word-final á¹…, Whitney (1862: 13) points out that it â€œappears only as final of masculine nominatives singular of derivatives of the root aÃ±c.â€ Note that BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s example is pratyaá¹…. The example Å›Ä«rá¹£aá¹‡-vatÄ«m offered by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is important, because, as Whitney (1862: 13) notes: â€œá¹‡, [occurs] only in a few instances, at the end of the first member of a compound, where, by a specific rule (iv. 99 = CA 4.3.28), it is left in the pada in its saá¹ƒhitÄ form.â€ Whitney himself came up with the example à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥ (ÅšAV vi.108.2). It is difficult to see why BhÄrgava-BhÄskara could not find an example in the ÅšAV. The form à¤¶à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤·à¥’à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¥‘, not à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥, is attested in ÅšAV (10.1.2).

106à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥¦. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.8). J, K, L: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ A, L: à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿. B, D: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨à¥à¤¨. Ha, Na: à¤µà¥ƒà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ. G: 1.1.10. I: 1.10. Translation: It is a precept of Åšaunaka that the words (= padas) ending in the first [members of the stop-series, i.e. voiceless unaspirated stops, should rather] end in the third [members, i.e. voiced unaspirated stops]. [Such, however, is] not the [recitational] practice. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’- à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¥’- à¤·à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ª(W: à¤†?)à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ (H, N: à¤®à¤¾à¤‚, Whitney: à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥) à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥ (H, N: à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚, Whitney: à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥, Whitney: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚?) à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤ à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¥¥â€™(Source.?) à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Note: The verse quoted in the commentary comes to us in a mutilated form. A related verse or a version of the same verse appears to have strayed into the text of this commentary on the next rule. This intrusion appears only in the manuscript H. The intruding passage reads: à¤•à¤¾(H: à¤œà¤¾)à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ … The last statement of the com- mentary, i.e. à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ looks like a quarter of a missing Anuá¹£á¹­ubh verse. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¾- à¤™à¥à¤—à¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤•à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¤ à¤‹à¤•à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿- à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤ƒ - â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾107 à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤‹.à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾. à¥§.à¥§à¥«-à¥§à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara adds some important information, namely that while the CA mentions the opinion of Åšaunaka, it does not follow its prac- tice, and that the practice of the AV tradition follows the view of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana. In view of the fact that we are dealing with the so-called ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, it is curious to find that the surviving tradition follows the view, not of Åšaunaka, but that of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana. While the CA mentions ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyanaâ€™s views in other contexts, e.g. CA 2.1.24 (à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯), it does not do so in this case. The view, which the commentator attributes to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, is simply assumed to be the default view. The citation of the RPR in BhÄrgava- BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary shows that Åšaunakaâ€™s view was also shared by GÄrgya. This rule provides a fitting answer to Surya Kantaâ€™s excessive claims about the ÅšaunakÄ«ya-ness of this text. It is indeed called ÅšaunakÄ«yÄ CaturÄ- dhyÄyÄ«ikÄ and no doubt belongs to the tradition of Åšaunaka. At the same time, one must keep in mind that this tradition was not immutable, and in the course of time, it came to adopt in practice the doctrines of other sages like ÅšÄkaá¹­Ä- yana, which were historically at variance with the views of Åšaunaka. Also see CA 4.1.52, and the CAB on that rule. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥§. à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.9). Hb: à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ. G: 1.1.11. Translation: [It is] also [the precept of Åšaunaka] that [the pada-final thirds, i.e. voiced unaspirated stops] have a weak articulatory contact. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¥¤ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ â€˜à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯â€™ (à¤š.à¤†. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤• à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¥‡ à¤µà¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯ à¤‰à¤¦à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥’à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¥’ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™

108à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤‰à¥‘ à¤à¥’à¤µ à¤®à¥‘à¤¹à¤¾à¤¯à¥’à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª. à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤†à¤ªà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤ Note: Whitney (1862: 15), following Weberâ€™s suggestion, correctly removes the following passage from H: à¤œà¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥. This intervenes between à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ … à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿. While H has this spurious passage, N does not have it. Also see the note on the previous rule. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤…à¤§à¤¿- à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: This rule is indeed somewhat unclear. Part of the reason for this lack of clarity is that the expression adhisparÅ›am is extremely rare in the Sanskrit phonetic literature. It has been used adverbially in CA 2.1.24 (à¤²à¥‡à¤¶- à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯), and etymologically it can simply mean â€œas regards contact.â€ There are several possible interpretations. a) This interpretation is supported by the CAB. According to this in- terpretation, the rule simply means: â€œAdhisparÅ›a is also a precept of Åšaunaka, though such is not the recitational practice.â€ Then, for the meaning of the term à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥, we are referred to CA 2.1.24 (à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯). Accord- ing to this rule, in the opinion of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, the euphonic y and v were pro- nounced slightly (= à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ) as regards contact (à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥), i.e. as weak glides. The same view is then ascribed to Åšaunaka in the present rule. Such an inter- pretation seems less likely, because it would be unnatural that the text would refer a certain view to Åšaunaka in one place and to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana in another place. b) What seems more likely is that the expression à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥ is used as an abbreviation for the longer phrase à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥ found in CA 2.1.24. The phrase then refers to â€œpartial or incomplete articulation.â€ With this generic meaning, one may assume that rule CA 1.1.11 (à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥ à¤š) is more closely connected to the doctrine as taught in CA 1.1.10. It could then be interpreted to mean: According to the precept of Åšaunaka, the padas ending in the first members of the stop-series should rather end in the third members of the stop- series, and that these third members, i.e. voiced unaspirated stops, are articu- lated incompletely or partially, i.e. without their contact being released. This is my preferred interpretation.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾109 BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary proposes that both the firsts and thirds of the stop-series were called à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶ according to Åšaunaka. Presuma- bly they were all pronounced with a weak articulation according to Åšaunaka, though such was not the recitational practice supported by the CA. This inclu- sion of both the categories has no textual support, though in terms of the gen- eral history of Indo-Aryan, all final stops are weak, see: R.L. Turner (1960: 11-19). According to Allen (1953: 70), this rule, taken along with the previous one, â€œis perhaps to be interpreted as indicating a realization as voiceless stops, but with the lax articulation characteristic of the voiced stops.â€ It is not clear to me whether the term à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥ indicates â€˜lax articulation characteristic of the voiced stops.â€™ I think that this term is more like an equivalent of à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤° â€œhaving a lighter articulatory effortâ€ or à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ â€œa reduced articulation.â€ It is most probably the non-release of the closure making it a weak articulation, rather than a lax articulation. There is a clearer reason for not accepting Allenâ€™s interpretation. The rule is not trying to make a generic distinction between voiceless and voiced stops, but a distinction between final voiced stops versus non-final voiced stops. Since all voiced stops have the feature of laxness, one cannot use this feature to distinguish between final and non-final voiced stops. On the other hand, it is clear that while one cannot have unreleased non-final voiced stops, it is possible to have unreleased final voiced stops. Allen also does not recognize the fact that the rules refer to actual recitational or articula- tory differences, and not mere theoretical differences. He (1953: 70) renders them as: â€œWords ending (sc. according to orthodox doctrine) in voiceless stops, end according to Åšaunaka in voiced stops, but they are not so treated (sc. phonologically); they have lax contact.â€ As we have noted above, this is not a phonological distinction, but a distinction in recitational practice, and the term vrÌ¥tti refers to articulation in recitation. Whitney (1862: 15) did think of another possibility: â€œOr is adhisparÅ›a to be interpreted as the name of a slighted or imperfect utterance, and did Åšaunaka teach such an utterance as belonging to a final mute, which wavered, as it were, between sonant and surd? This appears somewhat more plausible, but not sufficiently so to be accepted as at all satisfactory: there is no question of a difference of contact of the organs (sparÅ›a) in such a case.â€ I do not believe that the CA refers to such a wavering pronunciation. It rather refers to two different practices consistently followed by different schools of reciters. However, I agree with Whitney that the term à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤®à¥ is used to refer to incomplete articulation. Whitney (1862: 16) also refers to Weberâ€™s conjecture that the passage means that â€œwhen the padyas enter into sandhi, they are to be

110à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ converted into trÌ¥tÄ«yas before nasals (e.g. tad me, not tan me): but this is only pratijÃ±Änam, not vrÌ¥tti.â€ Whitney rejects this interpretation. However, the last part of Weberâ€™s interpretation, â€œbut this is only pratijÃ±Änam, not vrÌ¥tti,â€ is sup- ported by the commentary CAB. That means that, like the precept of Åšaunaka taught in the previous rule, this rule also teaches a precept of Åšaunaka, which is not carried out in the recitational practice. If this is true, then it cannot refer to the weakening of euphonic y and v, since that is part of the recitational practice (cf. CA 2.1.24: à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯). I take the rule to refer to the weakening or non-release of the final voiced unaspirated stops. Åšaunaka evidently supported the weak pronunciation of the final voiced unaspirated stops, while the recitational practice maintained the voiceless unaspirated stops at the end of words. The weakening of final stops in general can draw support from what happens in the Prakrit languages, see R.L. Turner (1960: 11-19). All final stops are lost in Prakrit, except the nasals are retained in some form or another for a much longer time. It is likely that the recitational practice, perceiving the danger of losing the weak consonants, went in the other direction and strengthened them. Devoicing may have been seen as a move in the direction of preservation. The medial voiceless stops were voiced in most Prakrits, and then were lost in some, as in MahÄrÄá¹£á¹­rÄ«. However, the voiced medial stops were devoiced in the northwestern PaiÅ›ÄcÄ« where they were preserved and protected from loss. For HinÃœber (1981: 127) this PaiÅ›ÄcÄ« feature is purely orthographical â€œwithout any bearing on PaiÅ›ÄcÄ« phonetics.â€ I am yet to be convinced by this argument. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥¨. à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.10). A, B, D, I (orig), J, L, M (corr), O: à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ. Translation: The seconds and the fourths [in the five stop- series] are termed soá¹£man â€œaspirated [stops, lit. combined with a spirant].â€ Note: The term soá¹£man literally means â€œwith Å«á¹£man.â€ Most of the later commentators on phonetic treatises interpret the term to mean â€œwith aspiration,â€ and take the term Å«á¹£man to refer to aspiration, cf. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ, Uvaá¹­a on RPR 1.13. On the other hand, a more historically apt interpretation is suggested by the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä text quoted in the CAB. According to this view, the aspirated stops are born through a combination of the unaspirated stop with a voiced or voiceless spirant. Thus, at an earlier period, the term soá¹£man probably meant â€œcombined with a

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾111 spirant,â€ rather than â€œcombined with aspiration.â€ Compare RPR (13.16-17): à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¥ (à¤à¤•à¥‡) à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¥ The simple fact is that these are different views. However, I believe that the view of soá¹£man as â€œcombined with a spirantâ€ must be the earlier view, since the term Å«á¹£man as it is attested in its oldest occurrence in the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka (2.2.4, 3.2.1) and the ChÄndogya-Upaniá¹£ad (2.22.2) already seems to refer not to aspiration as such, but to spirants. Thus, historically, it is more likely that the term soá¹£man first meant â€œcombined with a spirant,â€ and then, in certain schools, came to mean â€œwith aspiration.â€ The interpretation â€œwith aspirationâ€ fails to account for the difference between the groups denoted by the terms Å«á¹£man and soá¹£man, and points more closely in the direction of the later term mahÄprÄá¹‡a, which does not distinguish between these two sub-groups. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤–à¤›à¤ à¤¥à¤«à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤˜à¤à¤¢à¤§à¤­à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥ˆà¤°à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾[à¤ƒ] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿[à¤ƒ] à¥¥â€™ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¤®à¤¨à¥€à¤·à¤¿à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤à¥à¤šà¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿- à¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‹ à¤­à¤µ(H, N: à¤µà¥‡)à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤ (Whitney: à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥

112à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤¶à¥à¤š (H, N: à¤•à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤š) à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿(H, N: à¤¹à¤¿, Whitney: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿)à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¤à¥(H, N: à¤¨à¥) à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ˆ(W: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ˆ)à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¥‹à¤§ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤£ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¥â€™ (Source?) Note: The pippalyÄdi gaá¹‡a and the doubling of consonants in the words listed in this gaá¹‡a are dealt with in CA (3.2.5: à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥). For further information on this gaá¹‡a, see the Note on CA (3.2.5). à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤° à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤”à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯- à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤”à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯- à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤®à¥‡ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤•à¤šà¤Ÿ- à¤¤à¤ª, à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤—à¤œà¤¡à¤¦à¤¬ à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤–à¤›à¤ à¤¥à¤«, à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤˜à¤à¤¢à¤§à¤­ à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¤ à¤à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤”à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯- à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara offers a more simplistic view. All aspirated stops are produced by a combination of a non-aspirated stop with pulmonary h (= aurasya-hakÄra). BhÄrgava-BhÄskara further adds an important clarification. Even though the proposed explanation regards aspirated stops as combinations of unaspirated stops with h, the commentator hastens to add that the combina- tion is not regarded as a consonant-cluster, because the h sound which is added is a sound with a weaker effort (laghu-prayatna-tara). Thus, a short vowel pre- ceding such an aspirated stop does not become a heavy (guru) syllable. A

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾113 better explanation, of course, is that the aspiration, or the h- sound, is not an added sound, but is part of the basic phonation (anupradÄna), cf. TaittirÄ«ya- PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya (2.6: à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ). However, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara does not worry about explaining the difference between voiced and voiceless aspirated stops. The interpretation found in the CAB offers an explanation of this difference. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥©. à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.11). G: 1.1.13. Translation: The final [members of the five stop series] are termed nasal. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤­à¤µ- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤® à¥¤ Note: Compare the usage of the terms prathama and uttama in PÄá¹‡ini, outside of the context of phonetic lists, referring to the third and the first person forms in the verbal paradigms, cf. PÄá¹‡ini 1.4.101 (à¤¤à¤¿à¤™à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤£à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‹- à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ). The term prathama refers to the group which appears first in the list, while the term uttama refers to the group which appears at the end of the list. Thus, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s paraphrase of the term uttama by antya offers the clearest interpretation. One should also note that while the term anunÄsika is used here to refer to the final members of the stop-series, i.e. á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m, it is used elsewhere more generically to include the nasal vowels, cf. CA 1.3.6 and CA 1.3.8. Generally, the term anunÄsika refers to those sounds which involve both the oral and nasal passages in their articulation, cf. CA 1.1.27 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥) and P.1.1.9 (à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ), and this often leaves sounds like the anusvÄra and nÄsikya uncovered by this term. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥ª. à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.12). G: 1.1.14.

114à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ Translation: In the case of voiceless [consonants], the [type of] phonation [or emission] is Å›vÄsa â€˜[voiceless, non-resonant] breath.â€™ Note: The term anupradÄna raises a number of conceptual and historical problems. While Whitney generally renders this term by â€˜emitted material,â€™ he also mentions the view of the RPR (xiii. 2) that Å›vÄsa and nÄda are prakrÌ¥ti â€˜material cause,â€™ or the original phonic material out of which the different sounds are fashioned. Whitney offers another translation of the term anupradÄna as â€˜a giving along forth, a continuous emission.â€™ In my view, in the period which predated the formation of the available phonetic treatises, the anupradÄna view originally contrasted with the prakrÌ¥ti view, and these two terms referring to the same phenomenon, in all likelihood, originally represented two somewhat different perspectives on the phonic material covered by the terms Å›vÄsa and nÄda. Instead of the meaning â€˜along with,â€™ the term more directly stands for â€˜that which is subsequently contributed.â€™ Such a notion does not make sense in terms of our modern notions of the process of articulation. However, in ancient India, there did exist a school of phonetics which argued that anupradÄna is like the resounding vibrations of the sound of a bell. The clearest exposition of this view is found in the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä: â€œHowever, others say: When nÄda â€˜resonant air-streamâ€™ is subsequently contributed to the sound produced by the contact of the point of articulation and the articulator, then through the mixture of nÄda and that sound, ghoá¹£a â€˜voiceâ€™ is produced. When Å›vÄsa â€˜non-resonant air-streamâ€™ is subse- quently contributed [to the sound produced by the contact of the point of articulation and the articulator], then through the mixture of Å›vÄsa and that sound, the aghoá¹£a â€˜voiceless soundâ€™ is produced,â€ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤œà¥‡ à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥Œ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥‹à¤½- à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, cited by K.C. Chatterji (1964: 240). This view cited by the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä as the view of some other scholars (à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥‡) goes hand in hand with the etymological meaning of the term anupradÄna, and may have had a different significance as compared to the prakrÌ¥ti view represented by the RPR, TPR etc. Supporting evidence for such an interpretation of the original meaning of the term anupradÄna may be extracted from some ancient practices of silent or rather airless recitation (upÄá¹ƒÅ›u). In the BrÄá¸¥maá¹‡a literature, a priest is often advised to perform the recitation of a certain Mantra in an upÄá¹ƒÅ›u fashion. For example, the Aitareya-BrÄhmaá¹‡a (1.27, Anandashrama edn., Pt. I, p. 115) says: à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¾ à¤šà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥, â€˜one should, therefore, act with oneâ€™s

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾115 speech in an upÄá¹ƒÅ›u fashion.â€™ SÄyaá¹‡a explains this as: à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ â€˜in such a way that others will not hear the sound.â€™ This does not mean that one should recite the Mantra simply in oneâ€™s mind. In the specific upÄá¹ƒÅ›u mode, one does all the movements of the articulatory organs, except that there is no sound coming out, i.e. there is no phonation. BÃ¶htlingk and Roth in their PW on this term cite passages which clearly distinguish between an upÄá¹ƒÅ›u recitation from a mÄnasa â€˜mentalâ€™ recitation. A more technical explanation of the term upÄá¹ƒÅ›u is found in the definition: à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥ (TPR 23.6): â€œUpÄá¹ƒÅ›u is without sound, without application of mind, but with articulating action.â€ The commentary TribhÄá¹£yaratna paraphrases the word karaá¹‡avat by prayatnavat, and says that this is given specifically to distinguish this form of recitation from silence: à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤£à¥€à¤‚à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥. This conception is very important, because it divides the articulatory process into two parts, phonation and the movements of the articulatory organs. Since the upÄá¹ƒÅ›u mode of recitation clearly assumes the presence of the movements of the articulatory organs without the presence of phonation, one can extrapolate that the addition of phonation leads to a recitation which then becomes audible. Most likely, it is this type of recitational practice which led to the perception of phonation as a secondary or an add-on feature. This closely corresponds to one of the two descriptions of anupradÄna given by the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, as something that is added on to the sound produced by the contact of an articulator and a point of articulation Such an older meaning for the term anupradÄna is made likely by the use of the verb anu+pra+dÄ in the Vedic literature. For instance, the TS (2.2.1.4-5) reads: à¤ªà¤·à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¤µà¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾ à¤ªà¥‚à¥’à¤·à¤£à¥‘à¤®à¥‡à¥’à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¥’à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¥‡à¥’à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¥‘ à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥’ à¤¸ à¤à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¥‘ à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤‚à¥’ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¤¨à¥à¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤¯à¥‘à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¤à¤¿, â€œPÅ«á¹£an is the giver of power and strength, verily he (= sacrificer) has recourse to PÅ«á¹£an with his own share; verily he (= PÅ«á¹£an) gives to him power and strength.â€ The previous passage speaks: â€œVerily Indra and Agni he has recourse to with their own share; verily they two place power and strength in him; with power and strength he approaches the battle and conquers in it (TS 2.2.1.3).â€ Thus, the verb anu-pra-dÄ is used in the sense of contributing something to someone who does not already have it. Also see MS (2.1.1). The word rasÄnupradÄna also occurs twice in YÄskaâ€™s Nirukta (7.10, 10.34). In the first occurrence (NR 7.10), Sarup translates it by â€˜releaseâ€™ of waters [by Indra by means of slaying of the demon VrÌ¥tra], and in the second occurrence, as â€˜gift of juice.â€™ This also goes along with my suggestion (cf. Introduction, 3.2.2) that in the formative stages of Sanskrit phonetics, the distinction between the points of articulation of sounds was probably understood earlier than the distinction

116à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ between voiced/voiceless consonants, and aspirated/unaspirated consonants. This is what may have allowed some early traditions to view, for example, k as the representative consonant, which subsequently came to be differentiated between k, kh, g, gh etc. through various combinations of primitive sounds. A similar view is found in the Åšiká¹£Ä verses cited on CA (1.1.12). Also see RPR (13.5-6), and Deshpande (1976). Thus, the notion of voicing, aspiration, and nasality as added features to a basic non-nasal voiceless unaspirated consonant is a fairly old conception, and it occurs independently of the concerns of the definition of homogeneity (sÄvará¹‡ya) in these texts. Also compare the term anunÄsika to anupradÄna; both share the prefix anu, and probably both hint at the â€˜add-onâ€™ character of these features as conceived by some of these old traditions. However, it looks as if the term anupradÄna soon lost its original ety- mological meaning and was shared by most of the schools, including the ones which espoused the prakrÌ¥ti view. This is also clear from the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä itself, where the other school does not subscribe to the â€˜subsequentâ€™ character of nÄda and ghoá¹£a, and yet calls them anupradÄna. In these traditions, the term anu- pradÄna has been understood differently. George Cardona (personal commu- nication) suggests that in traditions such as the TPR (2.4-10: à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¥¤ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡à¤·à¥à¥¤ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ) the word â€œanupradÄna could be derived with lyuá¹­ denoting either an instrument or an object: that by which the sounds are produced or that which is emitted in producing the sounds.â€ This is in accor- dance with the interpretation of the term anupradÄna as given by the commen- tary TribhÄá¹£yaratna on TPR (2.8): à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ However, one may note that the most likely earlier etymological mean- ing of the term anupradÄna as an â€˜added or subsequently contributed factorâ€™ is eventually picked up by the later texts when they use the term bÄhyaprayatna â€˜external effortâ€™ to refer to these types of phonation. While most scholars have translated the term anupradÄna by â€˜phonic material,â€™ Allen (1953: 23) renders it by â€˜secondary feature,â€™ thus capturing the etymological significance of the term. Following the lead of PataÃ±jali and the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, he lists anupradÄna under â€˜extra-buccal processesâ€™ (bÄhyaprayatna). While this accurately repre- sents the view of PataÃ±jali and the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, we must keep in mind that such a global division of internal versus external efforts is not common to the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. And yet, as has been hinted above, the term anupradÄna in its etymological meaning may have implied the secondary or external nature of this feature.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾117 A somewhat different explanation is suggested by Cardona (personal communication): â€œGiven that the TaittirÄ«ya- and RÌ¥kprÄtiÅ›Äkhyas very deliber- ately and carefully distinguish between descriptions of speech production and statement of phonological entities, I think it wise to accept that anupradÄna was used as equivalent to prakrÌ¥ti with reference to Å›vÄsa, nÄda and their combina- tion (hakÄra in TPR terms). The other view, which takes anupradÄna as refer- ring to features added to basic sounds is obviously based on the primacy of Äbhyantaraprayatna with respect to savará¹‡a sets. … The RPR/TPR descriptions do indeed describe the articulatory process. The alternative way, wherein one has a basic sound defined by sthÄna and prayatna to which anupradÄnas are added, is patently a blend of phonetics and phonological considerations.â€ For a detailed argument in this direction, see: Cardona (1986). We may also point out that some texts use the term anupradÄna as an adjective for the terms Å›vÄsa and nÄda, and hence in these texts the word appears in the masculine gender. However, other texts, such as the Ä€piÅ›ali- Å›iká¹£Ä (8.11, Yudhishthir MÄ«mÄá¹ƒsaka edition: à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡), use the term in the neuter gender, indicating that it is used as a substantive. In any case, there is no doubt about the reference of the term. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤–à¤›à¤ à¤¥à¤«à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤®à¥Œ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥Œ à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾, à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤§à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥§à¥­) Note: The commentary on this rule is found only in the manuscript N, and hence was not available to Whitney who worked with only the manuscript H. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¬à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¤–à¤šà¤›à¤Ÿà¤ à¤¤- à¤¥à¤ªà¤« à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸ à¥¤à¥¬à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤·à¤¡à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤

118à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ Note: The categorization of the various types of anupradÄna as types of bÄhyaprayatna is not relevant to the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition, but is a reflection of the influence of the PÄá¹‡inian school. The commentator brings in categories from the PÄá¹‡inian school to explain the usage of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. To some extent, this is indicative of the fact that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya traditions, in the course of time, became secondary traditions, and had to be explained in terms of the main-stream paradigm of PÄá¹‡inian grammar. The distinction between bÄhya- prayatna and Äbhyantaraprayatna is relevant to the definition of homogeneity within the PÄá¹‡inian school, but has little relevance to the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition, Cf. Deshpande (1975: 11). There is also an important assertion made in the verse cited by the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya and in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary that the yamas or the nasalized twins or transitional nasal allophones of voiceless sounds like k and kh are also voiceless. Interestingly, the CAB itself does not list these voiceless yamas. On the other hand, the CAB on the next rule explicitly lists the voiced yamas: gÌ and gÌh. One does not quite know whether the notion of voiceless yamas was felt to be somewhat uncomfortable. While other PrÄti- Å›Äkhyas do list yamas for k, kh etc., there is no explicit indication that these are voiceless. While Whitney (1862: 18) does refer to the sonant nasalized twins for g and gh, he does not mention the fact that the nasalized twins for k, kh etc. are listed by the verse cited in the CA as voiceless consonants. In fact, for some reason, Whitney does not refer to the verse cited in that commentary at all, even though it does occur in the ms. of the CAB which was available to him. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥«. à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.13). B (orig), D, F, Hab, O(corr): Â°à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥. G, I, O(orig): Â°à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥. A, B: Â°à¤·à¥‹ is corrected to à¤˜à¥‹. G: 1.1.15. Translation: In the case of voiced [consonants] and vowels, the [type of] phonation [or emission] is nÄda â€˜resonance.â€™ Note: For a critique of Max MÃœllerâ€™s and Whitneyâ€™s refusal to accept the voiced h, and the combination of voice and aspiration in sounds like gh, jh, á¸h, dh, and bh, and the subsequent rebuttal of this early misunderstanding, see: Allen (1953: 35ff). The notion of â€˜breathy voiceâ€™ is now commonplace in modern phonetics, see: Peter Ladefoged (1971: 12-13; 1973).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾119 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ à¤š à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤—à¤œà¤¡à¤¦à¤¬à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤˜à¤à¤¢à¤§à¤­à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤°à¤²à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤—à¤‚à¤˜à¤‚ à¥¤ à¤…à¤†à¤†à¥© à¤‡à¤ˆà¤ˆà¥© à¤‰à¤Šà¤Šà¥© à¤‹à¥ - à¥ à¥© à¤Œà¤²à¥„à¤²à¥„à¥© à¤à¤[à¥©] à¤à¤à¥© à¤“à¤“[à¥©] à¤”(H, N: à¤“à¥©) [à¤”à¥© not listed in H, N]à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¤¯à¤®à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥‡à¤· à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥§à¥¬) Note: The commentary interestingly lists the long vocalic lÌ¥Ì„ which does not occur in Sanskrit and is not accepted by most traditions. It is equally un- clear whether it is the commentator or the copyist who is responsible for this inclusion. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥) à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤—à¤˜à¤™à¤œà¤à¤à¤¡à¤¢à¤£à¤¦à¤§à¤¨à¤¬à¤­à¤®à¤¯- à¤°à¤²à¤µà¤¹ à¥¤à¥¨à¥¦à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹ - Note: The statement of this rule as well as similar rules in other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas raise the legitimate question of whether the terms nÄda and ghoá¹£a are co-extensive with each other. Literally interpreted, the rule would seem to suggest that, while vowels and the ghoá¹£avat consonants share the feature of nÄda, the separate mention of ghoá¹£avat consonants, apart from vowels, seems to suggest at least a possibility that vowels may not have the feature of ghoá¹£a. The question boils down to this. Is there a phonetic distinction intended between the notions of nÄda and ghoá¹£a, or is this distinction in some sense phonological and not phonetic? This has led to a lively debate among scholars, cf. Deshpande, (1976); Cardona, (1983, 1986), and Stautzebach (1994: 287). The commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara has been clearly misled by a wrong reading for the rule, i.e. à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥. Such a reading presumes the existence of the term aghoá¹£avat. While the term ghoá¹£avat is a common term, its opposite is always aghoá¹£a, and not aghoá¹£avat. It also comes up with an

120à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ interpretation which excludes vowels from having the feature of nÄda. Such a view is not at all acceptable, and it simply shows a deteriorating state of phonetic scholarship reflected in this late commentary. Such a view originates in a certain misunderstanding due to the fact that the emission-features are relegated to the category of bÄhyaprayatna â€˜external effort,â€™ and the external effort features are useful in the PÄá¹‡inian phonology only in the context of selecting a substitute with maximal featural proximity (Äntaratamya). Since, in practical terms, such a consideration of substitutes, in terms of external efforts, applies only to the substitutes for consonants, one develops a misperception that vowels do not have the emission features. This misguided view has been articulated by several late texts, cf. the following statement from Pandit JagadÄ«Å›ÄcÄrya CitrÄcÄrya (1969: 13): à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥Œ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥¬. à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¥€à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.14-16). All the manuscripts treat this as a single SÅ«tra. A, B, D, L: à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¥ˆÂ°. G: 1.1.16. Translation: In one and the same register, a syllable with high [tone, pitch] is termed udÄtta, one with a low (lit. non- high) [tone, pitch] is termed anudÄtta, and one with a falling (lit. cast down, thrust down from high to low) [tone, pitch] is termed svarita. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¤®à¥‡(H, N: à¤®)à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥- à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨à¥€à¤šà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤†à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾à¤‚ (H: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤®à¥‚, Whitney: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤‚) à¤šà¥’ à¤°à¥‹à¤¹à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥©à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ [only N:] â€˜à¤§à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤šà¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤œà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥­. à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¯à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤µà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney, I think, properly amends the mss. reading à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‚ à¤š à¤°à¥‹à¤¹ to à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤°à¥‹à¤¹ which is attested in the known text of the AV. Surya Kanta

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾121 (APR, Introduction, p. 40), on the other hand, believes that the ms. reading is probably the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya reading, and that it is not found in the currently known Vulgate of the AV, because it is not the genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. Allen (1953: 89) particularly commends the CA for making an impor- tant specification in this rule: â€œthe AP, in describing the udÄtta as high and the anudÄtta as low, made the important specification, â€˜within the same registerâ€™ (= samÄnayame); the pitches, that is to say, are relative and not absolute - a point which is specifically made by PataÃ±jali: The terms â€˜highâ€™ and â€˜lowâ€™ have no absolute signification.â€ For a detailed discussion of the term Äká¹£ipta, see: Allen (1953: 87-88). It is not simply the falling tone, but it carries the meaning of thrusting down. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨- à¤¯à¤®à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤…à¤†à¤‡à¤ˆà¤‰à¤Š- à¤‹à¥ à¤Œ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤• à¤ˆà¤‚

à¥‘ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«à¥©.à¥§; à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«à¥­.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯ à¤ˆà¤‚

à¥‘ à¤šà¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¦, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¯)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾à¤½à¤ªà¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾123 (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¤ƒà¤½à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥®, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥§.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§à¥®)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¨à¤¨- à¤ªà¤¾à¥‘à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¥’ à¤¤à¤¨à¥‚à¥’à¤½(G: à¥©)à¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤°, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥­. à¥§)à¥¤ à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‚à¤• à¤†à¤¹ (Åšiká¹£Äsaá¹ƒgraha, MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä, verse 80)à¤ƒ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¥€à¤šà¥‹ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥‚à¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤à¤µà¤‚ â€˜à¤¶à¤šà¥€à¥’à¤½(G: à¥©)à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (part of à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤°, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Following the PÄá¹‡inian school, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara says that there is no long lÌ¥Ì„ in the usage of Sanskrit. Interestingly, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara refers to different head movements of the reciter to indicate different accents. The anudÄtta is indicated by the lowering of the head. The udÄtta is indicated by the slight raising of the head. The svarita is indicated by raising the head even higher to look upwards to the heaven (svar). Especially interesting is his folk-etymological linking of the word svarita with svar â€˜heaven,â€™ and the upward movement of the head of the reciter. This also corresponds to the orthographic vertical mark to indicate a svarita. While the western scholars have focused upon the â€˜fallingâ€™ character of svarita, the Indian tradition may have looked at the initial high tone as the distinguishing mark of a svarita. Several texts say that the initial portion of a svarita is not just a high tone (udÄtta), but that it is a super-high tone (udÄttatara), cf. RPR (3.45) and VaidikÄbharaá¹‡a on TPR (1.41). In Vedic recitation, when an udÄtta is followed by a svarita, the tone rises from high to super-high, before falling. For gestures accompanying the different pitches used by different tradition, see: Allen (1953: 91). The reading of the second verse from the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä quoted in the commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is slightly different from the one seen in the Åšiká¹£Äsaá¹ƒgraha edition (p. 470): à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¥€à¤šà¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¦à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥‚à¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥­. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.17). G: 1.1.17.

The statement of PÄá¹‡ini 1.2.32 (à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¥) is clearer in saying that a half-short-vowel quantity at the beginning of a svarita is udÄtta. It is also certain that the CA rule is identi- cal in meaning with PÄá¹‡ini 1.2.32. Therefore, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s interpreta- tion of this rule does not seem to be correct. For him, irrespective of the number of mÄtrÄs in a svarita vowel, fully the first half portion is udÄtta. If such were the intention, the CA rule might as well be framed with the expres-

SK on P.1.2.32 (p. 5): à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿- à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥®. à¤®à¥à¤–à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (1.18). G:1.1.18. Translation: In the oral tract (lit. mouth), there are the [following] distinctions of the articulator [karaá¹‡a â€˜the instru- ment, the moving organ,â€™ in contrast with the relatively static sthÄnas â€˜points of articulationâ€™]. Note: The rendering of mukha by â€˜oral tractâ€™ needs some comment. It is not always clear whether or not to include nÄsikÄ â€˜noseâ€™ as part of mukha. While CA (1.1.26: à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾) lists nÄsikÄ as an articulator for the pure nasal nÄsikya sounds under the general heading of our present rule, CA (1.1.27: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥) mentions oral and nasal tracts separately and says that both of these are used for the articulation of nasalized sounds (anunÄsika). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤®à¥à¤–à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤•à¤š- à¤Ÿà¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤®à¥à¤–à¥‡ à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara seems to have confused the notion of prayatna as it appears in the PÄá¹‡inian school with that of karaá¹‡a in this text. The first term refers to the manner in which the articulator (karaá¹‡a) relates to the point of articulation (sthÄna). On the other hand, the second term refers to the articulator. Historically speaking, the term prayatna originally did not even have this meaning. Its meaning, most probably, was simply â€œeffort.â€ This is the meaning seen even in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules like P.8.3.18 (à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾- à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯). Here, the term laghu-prayatna-tara does not refer to the manner in

126à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ which the articulator relates to the point of articulation, but to the general articulatory effort. In this case, it refers to a weak articulatory effort. Most probably, the term prayatna had the same generic meaning in P.1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥), but that it was explained by the commentators by using more refined categories which were developed in later times. It seems that words like sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜touching, in contactâ€™ were originally used as adjectives of the word karaá¹‡a â€˜articulatorâ€™ to distinguish the different positions of the articulator. This is seen in the CA and in the RPR (13.8ff: à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ …) These differences of the position of the karaá¹‡a later came to be denoted by the term prayatna. The VPR (1.43: à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ) is probably the earliest text which came to clearly distinguish between the terms karaá¹‡a â€˜articulatorâ€™ and Äsyaprayatna â€˜effort,â€™ see: Deshpande (1975: 9-11, 94- 97). The CA clearly first describes the articulators for different sounds, and then it describes the positions of those articulators. However, it does not use the term prayatna to refer to these different positions of the articulators (karaá¹‡a). à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥¯. à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.19), G: Â°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤ƒ. A, B, L, M: Â°à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¤‚à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ. G: 1.1.19. Except G, all mss. support the reading à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ. While the reading adhara- kaá¹‡á¹­hyaá¸¥ is clearly justified on the basis of the manuscript evidence, one wonders if adharakaá¹‡á¹­haá¸¥ was the original reading. The oldest commentary CAB knows the reading adharakaá¹‡á¹­haá¸¥. It is possible that -kaá¹‡á¹­hyaá¸¥ was an ancient error which was copied blindly by most manuscript traditions. Translation: For the glottal sounds, the lower part of the glottal area [is the articulator]. Note: Allen (1953: 59) prefers to render kaá¹‡á¹­hya with â€˜glottal.â€™ However, it is not clear what is exactly meant by the distinction of lower glottal area versus upper glottal area. Whitney renders kaá¹‡á¹­ha with throat. However, the same word kaá¹‡á¹­ha is used to describe the production of resonance and voiceless breath, depending upon whether kaá¹‡á¹­ha is open or closed. Such a description better fits the glottis, rather than throat in a broad sense. Now what could adharakaá¹‡á¹­h(y)a refer to, in contrast with the rest of the kaá¹‡á¹­ha ? If we take kaá¹‡á¹­ha to refer just to the glottis, then it is difficult to make the distinction of lower versus upper glottis. However, it is possible that the word kaá¹‡á¹­ha referred to the entire throat area inclusive of the glottis. The upper part of this kaá¹‡á¹­ha was involved in the production of velar sounds, while the lower part,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾127 i.e. the glottis, was involved in the production of the vowel a etc. Since, the only moving part of this kaá¹‡á¹­ha in the sense of the whole throat area was the glottis, the text could refer to it to be the articulator for the vowel a etc. These difficulties of accurate classification probably explain why some texts opted to describe the k-series as a kaá¹‡á¹­hya series, while others chose to describe it as a velar series with a distinct point of articulation, i.e. the root of the tongue. In a view that a and k were both kaá¹‡á¹­hya sounds, one could not truly say that they had the same karaá¹‡a. Such a reasoning may have led the ancient phoneticians to differentiate these two by positing different points of articulations for them. In any case, the description of the process of articulation of these glottal sounds as given in the CAB is very dubious: â€œthe upper kaá¹‡á¹­ha is the place of articulation and it is approached by the lower kaá¹‡á¹­ha.â€ This reference to lower kaá¹‡á¹­ha as the articulator, in spite of its understandable parallelism with the notion of the lower lip as the articulator for labials in CA (1.1.25), hardly makes sense. Perhaps, such absurdities may have led other texts to declare that glottal sounds do not have a distinct karaá¹‡a of their own. For them, the point of articulation and the articulator are the same, cf. à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ, Ä€piÅ›ali- Å›iká¹£Ä (2.9, p. 3, Yudhishthira Mimamsaka edition). Allen (1953: 59) has an enlightening discussion on the classification of a, h, and -á¸¥ as kaá¹‡á¹­hya â€˜glottalâ€™ sounds: â€œTo class the open vowels as â€˜glottalâ€™ appears at first sight an indefensible procedure. It becomes less so when we perceive the conceptual framework underlying these statements. It will be remembered that the TP referred to a â€˜neutralâ€™ position of the articulatory organs, in which the tongue is extended and depressed, and the lips are in the position for a. The classification of a as glottal begins to make sense if we assume that it was viewed as a â€˜neutralâ€™ vowel in the sense of involving no special intra-buccal articulatory effort.â€ Where the difference of opinion arises is the question of karaá¹‡a for these â€˜glottalâ€™ sounds. The CA is perhaps making a unique effort to find a karaá¹‡a for these sounds, for which, according to other traditions, there is no distinct karaá¹‡a (Allen 1953: 49, 59). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®- à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥‡à¤¨ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹- à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤†à¤†à¥©à¤¹[à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ] (H, N: à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ)à¥¤ à¤à¤à¤“à¤” à¥¤

128à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ â€˜à¤…à¤§à¤ƒ [only N: à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£- à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤¦à¥Œà¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤µà¥‹]à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥§à¥®-à¥§à¥¯) Note: The reading for these verses in the printed version of the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala is slightly different: à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥‹à¤½à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯ à¤ à¤” à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥§à¥®à¥¥ à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¯à¥‡(à¤¯à¥‹?)à¤°à¥à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥à¥§à¥¯|| p. 204. Allen (1953: 17) points out the similarity of the definitions of sthÄna and karaá¹‡a given by the CAB to Kenneth Pikeâ€™s terms â€˜point of articulationâ€™ and â€˜articulator.â€™ Also compare TPR (2.31-34): à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ The CA does not give us a list of which sounds it considers to be kaá¹‡á¹­hya. That task has fallen to the commentators. The CAB and the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä text it cites agree that the label of kaá¹‡á¹­hya â€˜glottalâ€™ be given to a, Ä, Ä3, h, and á¸¥. Then comes the difference. While the cited Åšiká¹£Ä verse says that the initial elements of the diphthongs ai, and au are also glottal, the CAB goes one step ahead and adds e and o, implying that these sounds are not mono- phthongs, and that their initial elements are also glottal. In doing so, it agrees with the statements found in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA (1.1. 28). à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤ƒ) à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤…à¤¹à¤…à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤ƒ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ - à¤¬à¤¿à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: While the CAB appropriately maintains the distinction between the point of articulation (sthÄna) and the articulator (karaá¹‡a), BhÄrgava- BhÄskara has confused the two notions. The rule, taken in its proper context, says that the lower kaá¹‡á¹­ha is the articulator of those sounds which have kaá¹‡á¹­ha

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾129 as their point of articulation. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara interprets the rule to mean: â€œThe point of articulation for these sounds is the lower kaá¹‡á¹­ha.â€ This is not correct. This confusion is continued in many of the following rules. On this particular rule, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara does seem to maintain a certain distinction of the CA tradition from that represented by the texts such as the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä (1.2) and the prose PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä (1.2) which treat the k- series as kaá¹‡á¹­hya, in addition to a, h, and á¸¥.
