Translation: For velar sounds (lit. tongue-root sounds), the base (lit. root) of the jaw [is the articulator]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤‹à¥ à¥ à¥©à¤•à¤–à¤—à¤˜à¤™ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·á³²à¤–à¤¨à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤Œà¤²à¥„à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯ à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥¦, *à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ) Note: Whitneyâ€™s emendation for the last quarter of the verse: à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ There is no support for this reading. Also for the difficult-to-read segment à¤Œà¤²à¥„, Whitney reads à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤ and refers to AV 10.10.23. Neither H, nor N supports Whitney. A comparison of the way à¤Œ and à¤²à¥„ are written in the manuscript N in the commentary on CA 1.1.32 leaves no doubt that the se- quence here refers to these two sounds. It may also be noted that the transmis- sion of the CAB and that of the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala may have occurred independently. The reading à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ is not found among the variants in the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala manuscripts.

130à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¤•à¤–à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤–à¤—à¤˜à¤™à¤…á³²à¤• à¤…á³²à¤– à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¹à¤¨à¥‹- à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¬à¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤§à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡ à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤›à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: Again, the commentators differ as to which sounds are to be listed as velar sounds. The CAB and the Åšiká¹£Ä it cites list the k-series of stops, the rÌ¥ and lÌ¥ vowels, and the allophone of á¸¥ before k, kh, i.e. á¸« (jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya). For a detailed review of the velar classification for rÌ¥ and lÌ¥ vowels, see Hans Henrich Hock (1992). Following the late PÄá¹‡inian tradition, BhÄrgava- BhÄskara removes the rÌ¥- and lÌ¥-vowels from the list of velars. For him, the rÌ¥- vowels are retroflex, while the lÌ¥-vowels are dental. See BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA 1.1.22, 24. The confusion of the notions of sthÄna and karaá¹‡a continues into this rule in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary. This is explainable in part because he identifies the referents of the words jihvÄmÅ«la and hanumÅ«la. If these two words refer to the same thing, then how can the point of articulation be differ- ent from the articulator? It needs to be pointed out that these terms do not refer to the same thing. Another point to consider is that BhÄrgava-BhÄskara does not include the sounds rÌ¥ and lÌ¥ among the jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«yas. For him, rÌ¥ is a mÅ«rdhanya sound, while lÌ¥ is a dantya sound. This is more in line with later texts in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition like the SiddhÄntakaumudÄ«. The CAB, on the other hand, seems to reflect an older view. The final comment of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara that the word jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya is derived by adding the affix cha (! Ä«ya) to the word jihvÄmÅ«la shows how he takes the PÄá¹‡inian system for granted both for himself, and for his readers. In the phonetic literature, there is indeed a good deal of confusion in the case of sounds such as these concerning which of the organs is the point of articulation and which is the articulator. While the CA rule literally seems to say that the hanumÅ«la is the articulator and that the jihvÄmÅ«la is the point of articulation, the TPR (ii. 35: à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡à¤¨ à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿) presents a reverse doctrine. While the CAB seems to offer a straight forward interpretation of the CA statement, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara seems to have been influenced by other tra- ditions. Thus, the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä (2.4: à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) states that the jihvÄ-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾131 mÅ«la is the articulator for jihvya sounds. The same doctrine is found in the prose PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä (2.3). à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥§. à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.21). G: 1.1.21. Most mss. read jivham. Translation: For palatal sounds, the middle of the tongue [is the articulator]. Note: Again, the CA itself does not tell us which sounds are included in the category of palatal sounds. For that we have to rely upon the commentators who differ from each other on this point. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤à¤¯à¤¶à¤šà¤›à¤œà¤à¤ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤ˆà¤ˆà¥© à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤µà¥‡(Whitney: à¤²à¥à¤µà¥ˆ)à¤¯à¤¶à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥§) Note: The verse cited by the CAB seems to hold a slightly different view as compared to that of the commentary. The commentary, if correctly reproduced by the manuscripts, seems to include both e and ai among the sounds produced at the palate, besides the i-vowels and the c-series. On the other hand, out of e and ai, the verse seems to include only the sound e. This may be a reflection of the old view that e was a pure monophthongal tÄlavya sound, while ai, atrue diphthong, was a composite sound with distinct points of articulation for its two parts, kaá¹‡á¹­ha for the first part and tÄlu for the second part. The emendation suggested by Whitney does not seem to lead to an acceptable text. It is hard to see how ai could be included without the inclusion of e. On the other hand, it is easy to see how e could be included without the inclusion of ai. Bolling and Negelein (1910: 302) report that the mss. A and E of the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala support the reading *tÄlvai-, while the rest of the mss. support the reading tÄlve-. Allen (1953: 52) also makes an important point: â€œNo difficulty is provided by the description of the c-series, which at the period described by out treatises appear still to have been true palatal plosives rather than pre-palatal affricates such as are general in modern Indian pronunciation.â€ The modern pronunciation neither uses the middle of the tongue, nor the point of articula-

132à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ tion named as tÄlu. This tÄlu as intended by the Sanskrit phoneticians must have been farther back on the oral dome as compared to the point touched during the pronunciation of the retroflex stops. This must be so given the back-to-front ordering of the consonantal vargas. However, the modern pro- nunciation uses a point slightly above the alveolar ridge and pressed against it not the middle of the tongue, but a portion of the tongue much closer to the tip of the tongue. The historical alternations between palatal and velar consonants are also an indication that the palatal point of articulation was much farther back and closer to the velar point, than being closer to the alveolar ridge as it is in the modern pronunciation. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‹ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¾- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤šà¤›à¤œà¤à¤à¤¯à¤¶ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°- à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥- à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara includes neither e nor ai among the pure tÄlavya sounds. This is similar to his exclusion of o and au from the list of the pure oá¹£á¹­hya sounds later on. The reason is that he treats these four sounds, in line with the late PÄá¹‡inian tradition, to be sounds with double points of ar- ticulation, kaá¹‡á¹­hatÄlu and kaá¹‡á¹­hauá¹£á¹­ha respectively for e, ai, and o, au, cf. BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA1.1.28. This brings out a significant difference between the CAB and the commentary by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara. The former is most certainly a relatively earlier text and is relatively free from the influence of the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. It seems that, as time went on, the com- mentaries were influenced more and more by the PÄá¹‡inian school. This is at- tributable to the fact that while the PÄá¹‡inian school flourished, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya tradition became more and more dormant, and the late efforts seen in the commentaries like those of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara were essentially efforts to in- terprete these texts in familiar PÄá¹‡inian terms. à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¨. à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.22). G: 1.1.22. J, K: à¤ªà¤°à¤¿ for à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿. P reads à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿ for à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿. Most mss. read jivhÄgram.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾133 Translation: For cerebral [or retroflex sounds], the rolled back tip of the tongue [is the articulator]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿- à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤°à¤·à¤Ÿà¤ à¤¡à¤¢à¤£ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥§. *à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ) Note: While the cited verse makes no reference to r or rÌ¥, the enumera- tion in the commentary includes r, which is described elsewhere in the CA (1. 1.28) as being alveolar and not cerebral. The inclusion of r among the mÅ«r- dhanyas is relatively late. Thus, the cited verse seems to represent an earlier phase in the development of Sanskrit phonetics. Neither the cited verse nor the commentary makes a reference to rÌ¥, because that sound is considered to be a jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya by this text. On the other hand, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary below includes rÌ¥ among the mÅ«rdhanyas. This is again a reflection of his following the late PÄá¹‡inian tradition. Interestingly, he excludes r from the list of mÅ«rdhanyas. Allen (1953: 32) discusses the Indian description of retroflexion and comments that â€œto consider the retroflex articulations on the same terms as the velars, palatals, dentals, or labials is, even from the point of view of the Indian descriptive framework, not entirely justified.â€ He feels (ibid, p. 33) that â€œthe retroflex series … is articulated as our treatises recognize, â€˜by rolling back the tip of the tongueâ€™ - that is to say, the place of articulation is not automatically determined by the application of the closure-processes to the apical articulator: there is need of a further prayatna, â€˜articulatory effort,â€™ which might with con- sistency have been included at this point.â€ I feel that the curling back of the tongue has not been treated as a prayatna, firstly because the notion of prayatna is defined somewhat narrowly as referring to degrees of contact or lack of it, between the articulator and the place of articulation. Furthermore, given the same point of articulation and the articulator, one does not have a choice of whether or not to curl up oneâ€™s tongue. Thus, curling up oneâ€™s tongue is not a feature of choice, with other factors being constant. It is just sheer necessity. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¬à¤¿à¤²à¥‡ à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¹à¤¨à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤‹à¤Ÿà¤ à¤¡-

134à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤¢à¤£ à¤à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤·à¤£à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§- à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥©. à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (1.23). G: 1.1.23. Translation: For the sound á¹£, the bowl-[shaped tongue is the articulator]. Note: Whitney feels that á¹£ should not have been singled out for a special treatment among the cerebral sounds, and that this rule may have been â€œvery possibly a later interpolation in the text of our treatise. … It can hardly be claimed that this rule adds to the distinctness of our apprehension of the char- acter of this sibilant, which is clearly enough exhibited by its relation to the other lingual sound.â€ In any case, the rule is found in all manuscripts, and there is no reason to consider it to be an interpolation, cf. TPR (2.45): à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥. In contrast to Whitney, Allen (1953: 26) admiringly calls this: â€œa rather more graphic description,â€ and cites a similar description by Grammont. The commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara also adds some graphic description of its own. While for the other cerebral sounds, it is the rolled back tip of the tongue which becomes the articulator, the pronunciation of á¹£ was supposed to be done in such a way that the middle of the tongue had a dip, and the lower sides of the front edges of the tongue touched the sides of the palatal region. The Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä says that all cerebral sounds are produced with â€œthe part next to the tip, or the under-side of the tip,â€ Allen (1953: 53). It is possible that the CA made a distinction between the rest of the cerebral sounds and the á¹£. The CA distinction is at least internally well supported, because it says that the middle of the articulator remains open, i.e. without contact. Thus, the tongue turned into a bowl-like shape, the sides of the front of the touched the sides of the curvature of the oral cavity, leaving the middle without contact. In contrast with this, the tip of the tongue had a direct contact in the pronunciation of cere- bral stops. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤¡à¤¾à¥‘à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥€à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤·à¤¡à¥à¥‘ à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾135 à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¥Œ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§(G: à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾)à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª. à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.24). G: 1.1.24. Most mss. read jivhÄgram. Translation: For dental sounds, the tip of the tongue spread flat [is the articulator]. Note: Whitney translates prastÄ«rá¹‡a as â€˜thrust forward,â€™ and this might imply that the tip of the tongue was pressed against the upper teeth. The com- mentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, on the other hand, lends support to Allenâ€™s (1953: 56) rendering of prastÄ«rá¹‡a as â€˜spread, flat.â€™ The commentary describes the tongue as spread out flat like the leaf of a Vaá¹­a â€˜banyanâ€™ tree. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤²à¤¸à¤¤à¤¥à¤¦à¤§à¤¨ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾(H, N: à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾) à¤²à¤¸à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤â€™ (à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥¨) Note: According to the CAB, the only dental sounds are l, s, and the t-series. The sound lÌ¥ is included among the velars (jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya). In the verse cited in the CAB, the reading *dantyÄ for dantÄ is found in the mss. A and E of Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala, but dantÄ is supported by the other mss (Bolling and Negelein, 1910: 303). à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°- à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤ƒ (G: à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ)à¥¤ à¤Œà¤²à¤¸à¤¤à¤¥à¤¦à¤§à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥ƒà¤¤à¤µà¤Ÿà¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤Ÿ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤

136à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ Note: In contrast with the CAB and the verse cited therein, the late tradition recorded in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary treats lÌ¥ to be a dantya sound. It is clear that BhÄrgava-BhÄskara follows here the late PÄá¹‡inian school. At the same time, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara seems to give an explanation of the articulation of dentals which makes them more like dantamÅ«lÄ«ya. Accord- ing to him the tip of the tongue touches the root of the teeth (à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿). If the blade of the tongue is truly flat, we would expect a true dental, rather than an alveolar pronunciation. It is not clear whether BhÄrgava- BhÄskara intends the normal pronunciation of dentals to be more like the alveolars, or just that a clear enunciation (sphuá¹­a-uccÄra) of the dentals was more like alveolars. One possible interpretation of these comments is that even though the CA calls these sounds dentals, they were pronounced like alveolars in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s own tradition. The RPR (1.9) also supports the alveolar pronunciation for the sounds which are normally considered to be dentals. It is of some interest to note that BhÄrgava-BhÄskara generally follows the tradition of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä, and that there is no support for the alveolar pronunciation of dentals in that text. Thus, the source of this deviation remains somewhat obscure. à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥«. à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ [à¥à¤¯]à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.25), G: 1.1.25: Â°à¤·à¥à¤ à¤®à¥. All other manuscripts support the reading given above. However, I wonder whether the reading Â°à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ is not an ancient error going back to the archetype of all the available manuscripts. Translation: For the labial sounds, the lower lip [is the ar- ticulator]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤‚(H, N: à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤‚) à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤- à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¥‡à¤¨ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤“à¤“à¥©à¤”à¤”à¥© à¤ªà¤«à¤¬à¤­à¤® à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·á³²à¤ªà¤¿à¤¬à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤Šà¤Šà¥© à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š(Whitney: no à¤š) à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™(Source ?)

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾137 Note: Notice that the cited verse includes v among the labials, while it is not included in the prose listing, perhaps because it is considered to be a labiodental (dantyoá¹£á¹­hya) sound. Here again, the cited verse represents an ear- lier tradition of classification, while the commentary represents a later tradition. There are two slightly different possibilities for v being classified earlier as an oá¹£á¹­hya sound. One possibility is that it was a true glide, more like the English w. The other possibility is that many texts considered teeth to be the articulator for v, but not its point of articulation, and hence in spite of its labio-dentality, it came to be listed as an oá¹£á¹­hya sound. The second possibility has greater textual justification in other phonetic treatises. For further details, see: Allen (1953: 57). Another important factor to note is that many Åšiká¹£Ä texts do not distin- guish between the point or articulation and the articulator for labial sounds, while here the CA seems to make a determined effort to come up with an ar- ticulator for each sound. Compare also CA (1.1.19: à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ). Also compare: Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala 22bcd: … à¤‰à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯ à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤®à¥) à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤“- à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰ à¤…á³²à¤ª à¤…á³²à¤« à¤ªà¤«à¤¬à¤­à¤®à¤µà¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤§à¤°à¤ƒ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾- à¤§à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤…à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ (cf. â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¤à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤†à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Note: Here BhÄrgava-BhÄskara lists v among the oá¹£á¹­hya sounds. However, he explains that v is an exception to other oá¹£á¹­hya sounds in that its articulator is Å«rdhvadantÄgra â€œtips of the upper teeth.â€ For his authority, he refers to the dantauá¹£á¹­hya â€œlabio-dentalâ€ classification for v in the PÄá¹‡inian tra- dition. The PÄá¹‡inÄ«ya tradition, however, does not clearly distinguish between the sthÄna and karaá¹‡a for v. It is curious to note that the text of CA does not have a separate statement, like some other phonetic treatises, concerning the separate karaá¹‡a for v. This makes us wonder if the original text did conceive

138à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ of v as a dantauá¹£á¹­ya sound. If v did not have a separate karaá¹‡a of its own, apart from that of the other oá¹£á¹­hya sounds, and if it was more like the other oá¹£á¹­hya sounds, then it must have been a bilabial sound, like the English w. This may, perhaps, explain why the gap between v and b seemed much smaller within the Atharvaveda tradition, and a separate treatise listing the words with these two sounds, i.e. the text called Dantyoá¹£á¹­hyavidhi, had to be developed within this tradition. Among modern Indian languages, the merger of v with b is seen more frequently in Bengali and the related eastern languages, and occa- sionally in the Hindi-speaking area, cf. Hindi bÄ«s â€˜twentyâ€™. The close connec- tion of the Atharvaveda itself with the tradition of VrÄtyas and the region of Magadha makes such an articulation of v a very old possibility. This may also hint at the eastern origin of the tradition of CA itself, along with that of the Dantyoá¹£á¹­hyavidhi, though no manuscripts of the CA have been found in these eastern parts. à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¬. à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (1.26). G: 1.1.26. Translation: For the sounds with the nose as their point of articulation, the nose [is also the articulator]. Note: Most Sanskrit texts do not distinguish between the point of ar- ticulation and the articulator for the nasal sounds. However, as seen in CA (1.1.19) and (1.1.25), the CA makes a unique effort to distinguish between the point of articulation and the articulator for each sound, even though, as in the present case, they turn out to be the same. Also, it is not immediately clear what the reference of the term nÄsikya is, as distinct from that of the term anunÄsika in the next rule. The commentaries include under the term nÄsikya sounds which are generally recognized as anunÄsika, e.g. á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m. Whitney suggests that the rule should properly apply to â€œmerely the nÄsikya and the yamas.â€ Here, the term nÄsikya refers to a peculiar nasal sound, which is inserted between an h and the following n, á¹‡, or m, and is equivalent to a nasalized hÌ cf. CA (1.4.9: à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨), also see: Allen (1953: 77). How- ever, the tradition conceives it to be a pure nasal sound, rather than as a nasal- ized h. However, what about the yamas? If the yama corresponding to k is a nasalized kÌ, then how is it possible to say that this sound is a pure nasal sound. For instance, the NÄradÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä (Åšiká¹£Äsaá¹ƒgraha, p. 428; Allen, 1953: 76) says that the yama which comes between a non-nasal stop and a nasal is a

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾139 nasal sound homorganic with the preceding stop. Thus, it does not make sense to call it a pure nasal. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¯à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤•à¤‚à¤–à¤‚à¤—à¤‚à¤˜à¤‚ à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤° à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥©) Note: The Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala reads iá¹£yate for ucyate. Also note that the notation kaá¹ƒ-khaá¹ƒ-gaá¹ƒ-ghaá¹ƒ in the commentary refers to the so-called yamas, or the nasalized â€˜twins,â€™ i.e. nasalized transitional segments which come after non-nasal stops, before nasals, cf. CA (1.4.8): à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤¯à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥. Also compare the doctrine of the TPR (21.12): à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ. The TPR actually uses the term nÄsikya to refer to these sounds, instead of using the term yama. This doctrine of yama as an additional transitional segment is different from the doctrine found in the RPR (6. verse 8): à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾ à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥, which teaches that non-nasal stops, before nasal stops, are replaced by the corresponding yamas. In this procedure, the yamas may be said to be nasalized allophones for non- nasal stops, before nasals. I thank George Cardona for bringing this reference to my attention. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤™à¤à¤£à¤¨à¤®à¤…à¤‚ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤™à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara omits the yamas from the list of nasal sounds, and this may also be a reflection of his reliance on the late PÄá¹‡inian school, where the yamas are not given a proper place. The yamas are included

140à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ neither in the ÅšivasÅ«tras, nor referred to in the rules of PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s Aá¹£á¹­ÄdhyÄyÄ«. Thus, one can conclude that using the PÄá¹‡inian tradition for the elucidation of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya text is on the whole a regressive development, and this is what we see in the commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara. The confusion of the notion of nÄsikya and anunÄsika continues in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary. à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥­. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.27). G: 1.1.27. P reads à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾. Translation: For the nasalized sounds, the oral [organ, as well as,] the nose [are the articulators]. Note: Like several previous rules, e.g. CA (1.1.19, 25-26), this rule makes a vain effort to distinguish between the articulator and the point of arti- culation for nasalized sounds, and ends up identifying the same organs as both the point of articulation and the articulator. Here, there is also an additional problem, which neither the CA nor the commentators address clearly. What is the distinction between the nÄsikya sounds and the anunÄsika sounds? The commentators are clearly confused over this issue. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¿à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¥’à¤¶à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¤¤à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¥’à¤¶à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¥’à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¥’à¤¸à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥§à¥¨) Note: Interestingly, the only sound included by the CAB under the category of anunÄsika is the anusvÄra. It leaves out the nasal vowels and con- sonants which are generally referred to by this term in the Sanskrit phonetic texts. Strangely, the CAB uses the word anunÄsikasthÄna as if the word anu- nÄsika referred to a point of articulation. There is no such sthÄna-expression in

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾141 Sanskrit, and the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya is simply giving a paraphrase of the ex- pression anunÄsika, which is comparable to its paraphrases of expressions in earlier rules, cf. oá¹£á¹­hya = oá¹£á¹­hasthÄna, dantya = dantasthÄna, nÄsikya = nÄsikÄ- sthÄna. In this case, majority of the mss. for the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala (= ABCETU) give the reading mukhanÄsikena. This is rejected by Bolling and Negelein in favor of the minority reading mukhanÄsike ye vará¹‡Ä. With the concurrence of reading from the mss. of the CAB, the reading mukhanÄsikena gains in probability. Whether nÄsikÄ is a sthÄna or karaá¹‡a for the anunÄsika sounds is not quite clear from the statement of the rule, and the commentary does not help either. The expression mukhanÄsika seems to refer to a joint mode of articula- tion, without making a further distinction between sthÄna and karaá¹‡a. At the same time, it is to be acknowledged that the term is a popular one. It is seen in the cited Åšiká¹£Ä text, and is also used by PÄá¹‡ini in his rule P. 1.1.8 (à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾- à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ). For a number of sounds, the ApiÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä (2.9: à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨- à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ) openly declares that the sthÄna and the karaá¹‡a is the same organ. Among these are the kaá¹‡á¹­hya, oá¹£á¹­hya, nÄsikya, and anunÄsika sounds. The PÄá¹‡inian commentators do make a distinction in the status of nÄsikÄ in relation to different sounds. For details, see: Deshpande (1975: 11), Bare (1980: 138). The verse cited in the commentary is also important in that it is the only other ancient text, besides PÄá¹‡ini 1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥) and the VPR 1.43 (à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ), to use the term Äsyaprayatna in relation to a definition of the term savará¹‡a, see: Deshpande (1975: 92). Verses 13-15 of the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala are related to savará¹‡a and savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a: à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤•à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¤•à¥‹ à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ - à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤“à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯

142à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤ à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ - à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤“à¤” à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤ à¤…à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥ª) à¥¤ â€˜à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤£à¥€ à¤à¤°à¥’à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥§.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤¯à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¥’à¤¤à¤à¥’ à¤à¤•à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬à¥§.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾â€™ (â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿, à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ, à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤à¤¯à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤à¥’à¤µà¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥’à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¤¿à¥’à¤—à¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara says that nasal e and ai have kaá¹‡á¹­hatÄlu- nÄsikam as their points of articulation, implying that the non-nasal ones have kaá¹‡á¹­hatÄlu as their points of articulation. The inclusion of e, and similarly the inclusion of o, among sounds with double points of articulation is a relatively late phenomenon seen mostly in texts which follow the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara on the next rule actually quotes the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä to this effect. It is not clear why BhÄrgava-BhÄskara does not list the nasal stops under the category of anunÄsika. His description of these sounds given in the commentary under the previous rule exactly matches the description of anunÄsika sounds given here. à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥®. à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (1.28). G: 1.1.28. Translation: For r, the roots of the teeth (i.e. alveolar ridge) [is the articulator]. Note: This rule indicates that the text of the CA itself is confused over the notions of the point of articulation (sthÄna) and the articulator (karaá¹‡a). Generally, the articulator is the moving organ and the point of articulation is the relatively stationary part in the oral tract. Here, one would naturally expect a portion of the tongue, such as the tip of the tongue, to be the articulator, while the alveolar ridge or the roots of the teeth would be the point of articulation. The Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited by the CAB correctly describes dantamÅ«la as a point of

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾143 articulation (sthÄna). On the other hand, the CAB itself is philologically accu- rate in interpreting the CA rule to mean that dantamÅ«la is an articulator (ka- raá¹‡a). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤°à¤¦à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤šà¥€ à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (not in known Vedic texts, quoted in the KV on P.1.3.14: ro ri)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘ à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥’à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¥‚ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ (Whitney: -à¤²à¥‡à¤·à¥) à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (= à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²à¤®à¥, à¥¨à¥ª-à¥¨à¥«) Note: Even the words à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ are found in the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala. This may be an indication that the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala is itself a conflation of earlier texts. The Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala reads à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ for à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯. The example à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ cited by the CAB is not found in the Vulgate of the AV, nor in any other Saá¹ƒhitÄ, BrÄhmaá¹‡a, Ä€raá¹‡yaka, or Upaniá¹£ad. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. However, his example is cited in the KV on P. 1.3.14 (à¤°à¥‹ à¤°à¤¿). à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥€à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤- à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹- à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤Ÿà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹- à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿

144à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ - â€˜à¤à¤ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤“à¤” à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¤œà¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥Œâ€™ à¥¥ (à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾, à¥§à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹ - Note: The rule to says that dantamÅ«la is the karaá¹‡a for r. On the other hand, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara disregards the context of karaá¹‡a for this rule, and treats dantamÅ«la not only as a sthÄna, but as an indication of the vicinity of the real sthÄna for this sound, namely mÅ«rdhan. Treating r as a mÅ«rdhanya, when the rule clearly says that it is dantamÅ«lÄ«ya, shows how the characteri- zations in the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä override the explicit statements of the CA. The Åšiká¹£Ä cited in the CAB reports that there are different views regarding the point of articulation for r and that mÅ«rdhanya and dantamÅ«lÄ«ya are some of the alternative classifications for it. It does not try to interpret the term dantamÅ«lÄ«ya as a near synonym for mÅ«rdhanya, and to this extent, it shows that it is not as much influenced by the PÄá¹‡inian school. Allen (1953: 54) says that while the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä describes r as being a retroflex sound, â€œthe PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas generally require an alveolar articulation (which agrees with the present pronunciation of Sanskrit and the general prac- tice of the modern Indo-Aryan languages).â€ There are two points to be noted here. The first point, as brought out by Allen (1953: 53), is that r (as well as rÌ¥) functions phonologically as a member of the retroflex class, in spite of the probable dialectal variation in its phonetic value. I have suggested (Deshpande, 1979: 284) that it is this phonological retroflexion of r and rÌ¥ which was eventu- ally confused with phonetic retroflexion in later times, perhaps under the pres- sure of facilitating grammatical procedures like substitutions being decided in terms of maximal featural similarity between an original item and its substitute (cf. P.1.1.50: à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ). The second point to note is that the notion of karaá¹‡a receives only scant attention in the later PÄá¹‡inian tradition, as compared to the notion of sthÄna. This is also because the maximum featural similarity (Äntaratamya) between substitutes and their originals is decided in terms of the sthÄna, but not the karaá¹‡a. With a diminishing understanding of factors like karaá¹‡a, the later PÄá¹‡inian tradition in fact becomes much less interested in the true phonetic descriptions of the Sanskrit sounds, except as required to facilitate the procedures of savará¹‡agrahaá¹‡a and Äntaratamya. The verse â€˜à¤à¤ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤£à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥Œ …â€™ is also found in the ÅšaunakaÅ›iká¹£Ä (p. 15).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾145 à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯. à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.29). G: 1.1.29. Translation: In the case of stops (lit. â€˜contact soundsâ€™), the articulator is in contact [with the point of articulation]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤šà¤Ÿ- à¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¡à¤¢à¥Œ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¥‘ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥®) à¤®à¥€à¥’à¤¢à¤‚ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥ª) à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ (Source?) Note: The Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited by the CAB says that, in intervocalic contexts, the sounds á¸ and á¸h are not to be pronounced as normal sparÅ›a sounds with full contact of the articulator and the point of articulation, but should be pronounced without pressing the articulator against the point of arti- culation, and that they should be pronounced with a light articulatory effort. This description makes these sounds into flaps, similar to the intervocalic á¸· and á¸·h of the RÌ¥gveda. This doctrine is not known to the CA itself, and may have developed later on, perhaps under the influence of the RV tradition. It is also not recorded by the commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, and it is not known to the late text, the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä. It is not clear if the presence of such a descrip- tion of á¸ and á¸h points to a distinct source for the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä cited by the CAB. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: The commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara uses the term prayatna to refer to different modes of contact between the articulator and the point of articulation. This is the meaning of this term in the PÄá¹‡inian school. On the other hand, the term probably meant articulatory effort in a generic sense, and this is the sense seen in the term mrÌ¥duprayatna used in the verse cited in the CAB. A similar meaning for the term prayatna must be seen in the term laghu-

146à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ prayatnatara used by PÄá¹‡ini (8.3.18: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯). It seems likely that the term prayatna had the same generic meaning of articulatory effort in the term Äsyaprayatna used by both PÄá¹‡ini (1.1.9: à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥) and the Åšiká¹£Ä text quoted the CAB on CA 1.1.27. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥¦. à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.30). Translation: In the case of semi-vowels, [the articulator] is in slight contact [with the point of articulation]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) à¤ªà¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¯à¤°à¤²à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸- à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°- à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤•à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥€à¤·- à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Note: It is not clear whether the original term was anta-sthÄ or antaá¸¥- sthÄ. The problem becomes more complicated because an underlying antaá¸¥+sthÄ can as well result in the surface form antasthÄ in certain dialects of Sanskrit. As the Aitareya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka (3.2.1) informs us, the earlier categories recognized by its authorâ€™s tradition were only three, i.e. vowels (svara), stops (sparÅ›a), and spirants (Å«á¹£man). This text informs us that the scholar Hrasva MÄá¹‡á¸Å«keya proposed the addition of antaá¸¥sthÄ, and that this new addition was not acceptable to its author. One possible explanation of the term anta-sthÄ might refer to this fact of this category being the last addition. The reading antaá¸¥-sthÄ has been discussed at length by Allen (1953: 29): â€œThe Sanskrit term for the category of semivowels is anta(á¸¥)sthÄ, lit. â€˜standing betweenâ€™. It is tempting, and has tempted modern commentators, to interpret this term as referring to the postulated â€˜intermediateâ€™ degree of contact discussed above, or, like our term â€˜semi-vowelâ€™, to their phonological alternation. The ending -sthÄ, â€˜standingâ€™, however, is more readily applicable to the place which these letters

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾147 occupy in the alphabet, viz. between the stops and the fricatives; and it is doubtful whether the ancient sources provide evidence for any other inter- pretation.â€ Of course, Allen does not consider the reading anta-sthÄ, which is uniformly used by all the manuscripts of the CA. It is, however, clear that the commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara explains this word as if it were antaá¸¥-sthÄ. Allen (1953: 27-28) further discusses the question of whether a sepa- rate prayatna for semi-vowels, apart from that of the vowels is justified. Appa- rently, it seems at first glance like a failure of the Indian phoneticians that they do not see the distinction between vowels and semi-vowels as being phono- logical, than phonetic. However, Allen appropriately refers to palatographic studies of Indian languages which justify the claim of the Indian phoneticians that the semi-vowels involve a slight degree of contact between the articulator and the point of articulation, as compared to that of the vowels. Also, one should remember that the Indian phoneticians were aware of the various degrees of contact involved in the pronunciation of sounds like y and v, depending upon whether they occurred word-initially or medially. Thus, the use of expressions like ati-saá¹ƒsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a-prayatna, laghu-prayatna-tara, and mrÌ¥du- prayatna should be sufficient to indicate the fineness of their observations. Many of these are justified by the palatographic evidence, as well as by what happens to these sounds in PrÄkrit languages. One should also keep in mind that the distinction between â€˜phonologicalâ€™ versus â€˜phoneticâ€™ is a particularly Western distinction, and while there are echoes of this distinction in the con- cerns of the Indian grammarians and phoneticians, one should not expect to see it overtly implemented in their works. The MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä does not know the categories of Ä«á¹£atsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a and Ä«á¹£ad- vivrÌ¥ta. It says that the karaá¹‡a for stops is sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a, while for the semi-vowels, it is the opposite, i.e. asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a, see: à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ (verse 70, Åšiká¹£Äsaá¹ƒgraha, p. 469). BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s explanation of the Ä«á¹£atsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a as â€˜touching (= oc- curring in) the word-final position lightly (i.e. only as a result of certain exter- nal sandhi operations),â€™ is indeed far from what is intended by the text of the CA. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥§. à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.31). N, L, O: à¤‰ for à¤Š. A, B, L: Â°à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤‚. G: 1.1.31. O: Â°à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š. Translation: For the spirants, [the articulator remains] also [slightly?] open [or open, besides being in slight contact?].

148à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤šà¥¤ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥) à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¤¹à¤¾ à¤Š(G: à¤‰)- à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤¨ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—- à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤· à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¾- à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤ , à¥¬à¥®à¥©)à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¡à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­. à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤—à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥ªà¥¦.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¥¤ Note: The interpretation of this rule given in the CAB concludes that the articulator of the Å«á¹£mans is both vivrÌ¥ta and Ä«á¹£atsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a. Following this commentary, Whitney says: â€œthe organ is both in partial contact and open - a rather awkward way of saying, apparently, that its position is neither very close nor very open.â€ Whitney does not reject such an interpretation, and, with the word ca in the rule, this is indeed one of the ways to render this rule. Allen (1953: 26) notes that the notion that the spirants do involve some contact and some openness is justifiable on the basis of texts like TPR (ii.45), as well as on the basis of modern palatographic studies of Indian language. TPR (ii.45) suggests that the spirants are produced at the same points of articulation as the homorganic stops, but that in the case of the spirants, the middle of the articu- lator remains in an open position (à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥). On the other hand, if we remove the ca from this rule following some of the mss. which do not have it, and if we follow BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s reading of the rule and its interpretation, we can take this rule to mean that the articulator remains in an open position in the pronunciation of spirants, and, then, by the next rule, so also for vowels. Such a reading is also justified in view of a likely citation of this rule in the MB (on P.1.1.10). Then there is the possibility that only the word Ä«á¹£at, and not Ä«á¹£atsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a, continues into this rule from the previous rule by the force of ca. This would give us Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta as the mode of articulation for spirants, which accords well with some of the late texts in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition, cf. LaghusiddhÄnta-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾149 kaumudÄ«, on P.1.1.9 (à¤ˆà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤‚, à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥). Such an interpretation is suggested by a likely quotation of this rule in the MB (on P.1.1.10), and PataÃ±jaliâ€™s interpretation of it. PataÃ±jali says: à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥€à¤·à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡. If one accepts this interpretation, then one would have to say that, after this rule, Ä«á¹£at is discontinued, and only the word vivrÌ¥ta continues into the next rule describing vowels. This is what PataÃ±jali has proposed. Such an interpretation is also supported by the interpretive maxim: à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤°, cf. ParibhÄá¹£endu- Å›ekhara, ParibhÄá¹£Ä 78. While the versified PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä (verse 21) says that vowels and spi- rants share the same open (vivrÌ¥ta) articulatory effort (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥), the prose version of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä (3.6-8) reflects the unre- solved situation as described above: à¤ˆà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ, à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾, à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤ƒ. One may note with interest the fact that the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä, which is clearly later than the CA, does not seem to know the distinction between vivrÌ¥ta and Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta. It ascribes vivrÌ¥ta to both vowels and spirants (à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥, verse 70, p. 469). As Whitney himself notes, the TPR (ii.44, 45) and RPR (xiii.3, r.11) holds that both spirants and vowels do not involve contact (asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a). Such also must be PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s own view, i.e. that the vowels and spirants had the same mode of approximation of the articulator. Only with such an assumption can one explain the formulation of P.1.1.10 (à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¥Œ). It prohibits homogeneity (sÄvará¹‡ya) between vowels and consonants. However, the only possibility for vowels and consonants sharing the same point of articulation and oral effort is for vowels and spirants. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥¨. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.32). G: 1.1.32. No such SÅ«tra in A, B, L, O. Translation: Also for vowels, [the articulator remains open]. Note: See the Note on the previous rule for a detailed discussion of textual problems. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤†- à¤†à¥© à¤‡à¤ˆà¤ˆà¥© à¤‰à¤Šà¤Šà¥© à¤‹à¥ à¥ à¥© à¤Œà¤²à¥„à¤²à¥„à¥© à¤[à¤à¥©] à¤à¤à¥© à¤“[à¤“à¥©] à¤”à¤”à¥© à¥¤

150à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤‡à¤‰à¤‹à¤Œà¤à¤à¤“à¤” à¥¤ à¤à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: Note that both the commentaries list the short a among vowels while stating that the effort of the vowels is vivrÌ¥ta. This, of course, has to be negated in view of CA (1.1.36) which says that the effort for a is saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥©. à¤à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.33). G: 1.1.33. A, B, and L: no such SÅ«tra. G and K show the Avagraha. Translation: Some hold that, [for vowels, the articulator is] not in contact [with the point of articulation, in contrast with saying that the articulator is in an open position]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ Note: Whitney on this rule does not read the Avagraha either in the rule or in the commentary and this has misled him into reading the text as à¤à¤•à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ and translating it as: â€œSome consider it as forming a contact.â€ He be- lieved that the rule and the commentator are citing an opinion that â€œin the utter- ance of the vowels the organs are in contact; others that they remain open.â€ This interpretation led him to comment: â€œThe former opinion is too obviously and grossly incorrect, one would think, to be worth quoting.â€ Allen (1953: 28) seems to take the reading given in Whitneyâ€™s edition seriously, and tries to find other evidence from phonetic treatises which say that even vowels involve some contact: â€œIt is presumably to isolated statements such as these (= TPR ii.24, VyÄsaÅ›iká¹£Ä 284) that the AP (= CA) is referring when it gives as the opinion of some sources that contact is involved in the vowels, an opinion which Whitney impatiently dismisses as â€˜… too obviously and grossly incor- rect, one would think, to be worth quoting.â€™â€ In fact, the entire discussion by Whitney and Allen is now outdated, and one must read the rule as eke+asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­am, and this is supported by several manuscripts with a clear avagraha. This is also clear from both the commentaries. The alternatives are the asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜non-contactâ€™ view, versus the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾151 vivrÌ¥ta â€˜opennessâ€™ view, and this makes perfect sense. For details on this division of opinion, see: Deshpande (1976a). The main advantage in choosing the vivrÌ¥ta classification over the asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a classification is that, while it is difficult to think of gradations of asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a â€˜non-contact,â€™ it is perfectly possible to think of gradations of vivrÌ¥ta â€˜open.â€™ Such gradations are seen in the use of the terms Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta â€˜slightly open,â€™ vivrÌ¥tatara â€˜more open,â€™ and vivrÌ¥tatama â€˜most open.â€™ While the notion of Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta may have been merely alluded to in CA (1.1.31), the next rule, i.e. CA (1.1.34), actually uses the term vivrÌ¥tatama. It thus makes sense to conclude that the vivrÌ¥ta classification was the preferred way for the CA, but it wishes to record the asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a alternative upheld by other traditions. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤®à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤†à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£- à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€- à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¤…à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡- à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿ- à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤šà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤®à¥€à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¬à¤¹à¥- à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¥¤ Note: While BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is correct in saying that the term Ä«á¹£advivrÌ¥ta occurs in a number of texts on Sanskrit grammar and phonetics, he is alone in suggesting that this term refers to the effort for vowels. Such an interpretation cannot be correct. It is also clear that BhÄrgava-BhÄskara does not understand the meaning of the term asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a. It does not refer to the lips not touching each other or the mouth not closing during the pronunciation of vowels. It rather refers to the fact that the articulator does not touch the point of articulation in the pronunciation of vowels, but only approximates it. The TPR (ii.31-34: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥; à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥; à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥; à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥) uses the term upasaá¹ƒhÄra â€œapproxi- mation/approachingâ€ for this phenomenon, in contrast with the notion of contact (sparÅ›a). The RPR (13.11: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥) uses the term asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a, while the PÄá¹‡inian tradition generally uses the term vivrÌ¥ta.

152à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥ª. à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.34), E, F (orig), H, I (orig), J (corr), M, N: à¤à¤•à¤¾Â°. F (corr), G, I (corr): à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¤ G: 1.1.34. A, B, and L: no such SÅ«tra. O: à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤‚. Translation: For e and o, [the articulator remains in] the most open [position]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¤•à¥‡à¥‘ à¤¤à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤•à¥‹à¥‘ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥) à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤”à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤²à¥€à¤¬à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤£- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ Note: The text of this rule and the next rule raises some important questions. The fact that the older commentary, the CAB, supports a version of this rule which deals only with e and o, and not with ai and au, makes one support the reading as given here as the older and the original reading. In comparison with other vowels, the vowels e and o are said to be most open (vivrÌ¥tatama), and the next rule says that the effort for Ä is even more open than that. The vowels ai and au are excluded from this discussion, not necessarily because they are less open, but because they are held to be dvivará¹‡a sounds, i.e. combinations of two vowels each, and hence they are not separately dis- cussed. This must be the original situation. Later on, as indicated by the later commentaries, these statements were modified to reflect further gradations. Thus, the version of these rules found in the late commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara says: e and o are more open, ai and au are most open, and Ä is even more open than that. This version is supported by the Ä€piÅ›aliÅ›iká¹£Ä, and the prose versions of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. The fact that the CAB does not yet show the impact of these other PÄá¹‡inian sources perhaps

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾153 indicates its relatively early age. The later commentaries are explicit PÄá¹‡inian interpretations of the CA. One should note that PataÃ±jali himself does not use the notion of vivrÌ¥ta- tama, though several PÄá¹‡inian commentators ascribe it to him, cf. Bare (1980: 87), Deshpande (1975: 35). PataÃ±jali differentiates e and o from ai and au in a different way. For him, the components of e and o are thoroughly fused (praÅ›liá¹£á¹­a) with each other. On the other hand, ai and au are true composite sounds (samÄhÄravará¹‡au), cf. à¤à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤™à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿- à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤šà¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤, MB (MLBD edn.), Vol. I, Sec. I, p. 62; and that the components of ai and au, i.e. a, i, and u, are vivrÌ¥tatara â€˜more openâ€™, cf. à¤¯à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤ªà¥€à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¥‡ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥, MB (ibid.), p. 84. Also: à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤šà¥Œ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥Œ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ, MB (ibid), p. 78. This discussion offers an important insight into what probably hap- pened to the Sanskrit phonetic traditions in later times. If indeed the sounds ai and au are true diphthongs, or composed of two vará¹‡as (dvivará¹‡a) as the ancient Indian tradition calls them, then it makes no sense to ascribe vivrÌ¥tatama effort to these sounds, as their effort can only be the effort of the individual components. The description vivrÌ¥tatama seems to suggest a more unitary char- acter to these sounds, which is not justifiable in terms of the ancient dvivará¹‡a characterization, but makes sense if the pronunciation of these sounds was something like what it is in modern standard Hindi. In modern standard Hindi, a Sanskrit word like maithilÄ« is pronounced with the first vowel being almost equivalent to that in the English word â€˜at.â€™ This may have been the phonetic basis for saying that ai and au are vivrÌ¥tatama sounds. Such early mono- phthongization of ai and au, at least in certain dialects, may be suggested by the fact that Sanskrit ai and au are reduced to e and o in Prakrits, cf. Sanskrit mai- treya > PÄli metteya. The other reason to distinguish between the efforts of e and ai, and o and au, is that the later tradition considers these sounds to be kaá¹‡á¹­hatÄlavya and kaá¹‡á¹­hauá¹£á¹­hya respectively. Without the differentiation between their efforts, these sounds would become savará¹‡as with each other, and that would cause a great deal of confusion. Thus, it is possible that such a phonological reasoning may have led the later grammarians to distinguish between the efforts of these sounds. The importance of the original reading of this rule lies in that the older phonetic texts consider e and o to be essentially monophthongal like i and u. In that case, how would one distinguish i from e, and u from o? Such a necessity seems to have led to the differentiation in the degree of openness found in this

154à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ rule and the next. The fact that the CA talks only about e and o should be taken as an indication of the monophthongal pronunciation for these vowels, and their inclusion in the category of sandhyaká¹£ara essentially shows how the levels of phonetic and phonological considerations were blurred into each other. The possibility of such further differentiation in the degree of openness (vivrÌ¥ta) makes this alternative more popular in later phonetic texts as compared to the undifferentiated category of non-contact (asprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a), which in all likelihood is the earlier categorization. The lack of finer distinctions between the effort of vowels and sibilants forced PÄá¹‡ini to construct an explicit rule prohibiting the impending homo- geneity of vowels and consonants, i.e. P.1.1.10 (à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¥Œ). If PÄá¹‡ini did not differentiate between the degree of openness between vowels and sibilants, it seems most unlikely that he differentiated between the degree of openness between the various vowels. Problems created by such a lack of finer differentiation must have led later grammarians and phoneticians to come up with finer distinctions. Thus, the emergence of these finer distinctions in the degree of openness are in all probability related to the emergence of careful thought regarding problems in the application of homogeneity and sound- substitution being decided in terms of featural proximity between the substitute and the original. This shows the possibility that phonological considerations may have led to further developments of phonetic classifications. Later com- mentators in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition itself have often advocated the position that it better thing to accept a finer sub-classification of openness, and not worry about keeping P.1.1.10 (à¤¨à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤²à¥Œ), cf. Deshpande (1975: 35, 170-171, notes 121-122). à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥«. à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (1.35). G: 1.1.35. Translation: [The articulator] for Ä [remains in an] even more [open position]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤¶à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾155 à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ˆà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾- à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¤¿(à¤¤à¤¿?)- à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: It is interesting to note that the text of the CA moves from vivrÌ¥ta to vivrÌ¥tatama to â€˜even more open than that.â€™ One would expect perhaps the use of vivrÌ¥tatara to describe the position for e and o, and vivrÌ¥tatama to de- scribe the position for Ä. This felt gap in the terminology is made up by the later version of the previous rule found in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary: e and o are vivrÌ¥tatara â€˜more open,â€™ ai and au are vivrÌ¥tatama â€˜most open,â€™ and Ä is even more open than that. As for PÄá¹‡ini, it seems that he probably did not distinguish the degrees of openness, beyond assuming that the short a was a saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta â€˜closeâ€™ sound, in contrast with other vowels which were all open. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥¬. à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.36). G: 1.1.36. G and K show the Avagraha. Translation: The sound a i[relatively] close[r vowel, in comparison with Ä which is an open vowel]. Note: Note the different syntax of this rule. In the previous rules, words like vivrÌ¥ta are neuter words, because they are used to modify the word karaá¹‡am, which continues throughout this section. However, here the word saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta is used as a qualification of akÄraá¸¥, and is, therefore, a masculine word. One can also raise another interesting question. When we say that Ä is a most open sound, and that a is a closer sound, this openness or closeness, as a feature of the karaá¹‡a refers not to the openness or closeness of the glottal aperture, but to the gap between the articulator and the point of articulation. For the vowels a and Ä, however, the point of articulation given is kaá¹‡á¹­ha, and the articulator mentioned is the lower part of kaá¹‡á¹­ha. What sort of openness are we talking about that distinguishes between a and Ä? It cannot be the relative openness of the glottal aperture. It must be the wider opening of the oral cavity, i.e. wider opening of the mouth. This point has not been discussed clearly by any Sanskrit text.

156à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤ƒ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤œà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤¹ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ â€˜à¤… à¤…â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥¬à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤… à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤… à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤®à¥à¤–à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤- à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤§à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤½à¤§à¥‹à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥«.à¥©) à¥¤ Note: The PÄá¹‡inian tradition holds that the short a is a saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta sound, while the long Ä is a vivrÌ¥ta sound. The CA classification is somewhat similar. However, since the CA does not present a featural definition of the notion of savará¹‡a, there is no dilemma within this text about how to have a and Ä become savará¹‡as of each other, in spite of their featural difference. PÄá¹‡ini was indeed faced with such a dilemma, which he sought to resolve by artificially treating (or pronouncing?) a as a vivrÌ¥ta sound within the grammatical derivational process, and reinstating the object language saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta a as the last step of all derivations, cf. P.8.4.68 (a a). The Åšiká¹£Ä text quoted by the CAB (on CA 1.1.27), i.e. à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ, defines the notion of savará¹‡a in a way similar to that of PÄá¹‡ini 1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥). However, we have no information on how such a text would resolve the problem of homogeneity between a and Ä. One should also note the interesting explanation given by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara. He says that the vowel a is pronounced as an open (vivrÌ¥ta) sound in non-final positions, but that it is pronounced as a close (saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta) sound when it occurs in the word-final position. While he describes openness as wider opening of the mouth (à¤®à¥à¤–à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥), the only such explantion known to me, his explanation of saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta is even more graphic: â€œhaving turned the lower lip into the shape of a cup (i.e. having rounded lower lip?), one should cover the lower teeth.â€ Such a description of a close a takes it closer to the pronunciation of the Bengali a (= Å). It is very doubtful if the ex-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾157 planation of saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta given by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is historically accurate as an interpretation of the CA or of PÄá¹‡ini. However, it does seem to have been based on some actual regional trait of pronunciation. This pronunciation of a must be clearly differentiated from a truly neutral position of all organs advo- cated for a by texts like TPR (1.113), cf. Allen (1953: 59). à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥­. à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.37). G: 1.1.37. Translation: [The members of] the rÌ¥ class, [i.e. rÌ¥, rÌ¥Ì„, and rÌ¥Ì„3, are] fused with [consonantal] r. Note: The above rule does not clearly define the nature of the fusion of the constituent elements. According to the general description in Sanskrit texts, in the constitution of a rÌ¥ vowel, a consonantal r is flanked by two frac- tional vowels, i.e. âˆ‚râˆ‚. The actual phonetic quality of the vocalic fractions was probably determined by the consonants in the vicinity, though most Sanskrit texts tend to look at these vocalic fractions as partial a vowels. Some Sanskrit texts give more precise proportions of the vocalic and consonantal components for rÌ¥ vowels. Thus, for instance, the SarvasammataÅ›iká¹£Ä (19) says that a short rÌ¥ has four equal parts: There are two quarter-mora particles of the consonantal r in the middle flanked by quarter-mora vowels, i.e. âˆ‚rrâˆ‚, cf. Allen (1953: 62). The Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited by the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya seems to offer a close parallel: a half mora quantity of the consonantal r, flanked by quarter-mora vowels. Also see the Notes and the commentary on CA 1.4.10-11. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥ƒ- à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤­à¥‘à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤¬à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ƒà¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¥’- à¤°à¤¦à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¯à¥à¤—à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‹ à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ (Whitneyâ€™s emendation: à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¾) à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤–à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤£à¥‡ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ (?) à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤²à¥‡à¤·à¥‡ à¤Š(à¤¤à¥‚?) à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ (Source?)à¥¥â€™
