à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥€- à¤‹à¤¤à¥€â€™à¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¿à¤¦à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ- à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: The example Å›aá¹ƒsaty rÌ¥bhum is not found in any Vedic text. The same is the case of the example yady rÌ¥á¹‡am. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara presents some interesting arguments why the r element in the vocalic rÌ¥ must be situated between two vocalic fractions. He quotes an alternative view held by others that the r is situated in the beginning, followed by a vocalic fraction. BhÄrgava- BhÄskara rejects such a view. It is interesting to note that such a view reflects the latter-day pronunciation of this vowel either as ri or ru. Such pronuncia-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾159 tions, if they were to be taken seriously, would lead to a lot of undesirable phonological consequences. Thus, while the actual pronunciation of rÌ¥ did in- deed change, its phonological behavior remained like that of a vowel. While the sandhi rules remained an inherited and fixed feature of Sanskrit, the actual pronunciation of Sanskrit sounds was heavily influenced by the local factors. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥®. à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (1.38). G: 1.1.38. O, P: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾. Translation: For long and extra-long [rÌ¥ vowels, i.e. rÌ¥Ì„ and rÌ¥Ì„3], the first mora [is fused with the consonantal r]. Note: This rule seems to say that in lengthening the rÌ¥ vowels, it is the post-r vocalic fraction that is lengthened, and not the pre-r vocalic fraction. It also makes clear that the lengthening applies only to the vowel portion, and not to the consonantal portion. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‡à¤«- à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥„à¤¨à¥ à¤†à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤µâ€™ (?, â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤µâ€™, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥„à¤à¤°à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¥’à¤®à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥¦)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the text of the commentary à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ as it stands, Whitney says: this â€œis a palpable blunder for saá¹ƒsprÌ¥á¹£á¹­arephÄ bhavati.â€ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤— à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤à¤•à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤à¤•à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: While the CAB on this rule is mostly uninformative, BhÄrgava- BhÄskara seems to offer a very strange interpretation. Whitney appropriately interprets the rule to mean that only the first mora for rÌ¥Ì„ and rÌ¥Ì„3 is so combined

160à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ with consonantal r. It is the subsequent vocalic element which undergoes lengthening. Whitney states in clear terms: â€œthe r-element which it contains is not prolonged.â€ BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, disregarding the wording of the rule, says that the middle third portion is the consonantal r, i.e. the r also undergoes the process of lengthening. For long rÌ¥Ì„, his interpretation is especially strange. According to him. the first entire mÄtrÄ of long rÌ¥Ì„ is purely vocalic, followed by a half-mÄtrÄ of consonantal r, followed by a half-mÄtrÄ of a vocalic element. This directly contradicts the statement of the rule: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥¯. à¤¸à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.39). C, Ha, N, E, F, I, O: Â°à¤ŒÂ°. A, B, D, J, K, M, P: Â°à¤®à¥ƒà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚. G: 1.1.39. Translation: [The members of] the lÌ¥-class, [i.e. lÌ¥, lÌ¥Ì„, and lÌ¥Ì„3 , are fused] with [consonantal] l. Note: This rule, in close parallel with the previous rules, presents the constitution of lÌ¥ as being equivalent to âˆ‚lâˆ‚, or to âˆ‚llâˆ‚ if we accept each constitu- ent to be of a quarter-mora quantity. It is interesting to note that the CA uses the term lÌ¥vará¹‡a, suggesting that there are more varieties than just the short lÌ¥. However, it does not have a specific rule for long (lÌ¥Ì„) and prolonged (lÌ¥Ì„3) vowels, corresponding to CA (1.1.38). The CAB does not cite any example of these long and prolonged varieties, though the Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited in the com- mentary does refer to long lÌ¥Ì„. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥ à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤šà¥€à¥‘à¤•à¥¢- à¤ªà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤à¥à¤šà¥’à¤¦à¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤•à¥¢à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯. à¥§à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤šà¥€à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤²à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤Œà¤²à¥„ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥‹ à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (Source?) Note: Whitney corrects the first quarter of the verse to: à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤š à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤²à¤ƒ. The cited verse is not a quotation from the Vará¹‡apaá¹­alam, but from some other source. The Vará¹‡apaá¹­alam (verse 33d: à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¤¾) explicitly

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾161 rejects the existence of long lÌ¥Ì„. On the other hand, the cited verse seems to accept it. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤—à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤²à¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤®à¥à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤°à¥‹ à¤²â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥§à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤šà¤¾à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤à¤µ à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ƒ- à¤•à¤¾à¤—à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤šâ€™ (?) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥ â€˜à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤ …â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥®à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤- à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤‹à¤Œà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹ à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara offers some informative comments on vocalic lÌ¥. He says that the long lÌ¥Ì„ is not found in Sanskrit, except in the alpha- bets found in the MantraÅ›Ästra. For details, see: RamajÃ±Ä PÄá¹‡á¸eya, VyÄkaraá¹‡a- darÅ›anapÄ«á¹­hikÄ, p. 51, SarasvatÄ« Bhavana AdhyayanamÄlÄ 11, SampÅ«rá¹‡Änanda Saá¹ƒskrÌ¥ta ViÅ›vavidyÄlaya, Banaras. There are actually several texts which accept the long lÌ¥Ì„, though they cannot cite its occurrence in any attested word, cf. Manomohan Ghosh (1938: 51). On the other hand, it is possible to find an extra-long (pluta) lÌ¥Ì„3 by applying the normal rules of PÄá¹‡ini. The pluta lÌ¥Ì„3 is not attested among the Vedic examples of pluta vowels, though it is possible, according to the rules of the PÄá¹‡inian system, to have a form with a pluta lÌ¥Ì„3. There is a long debate concerning the inclusion of lÌ¥ in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s ÅšivasÅ«tra: rÌ¥-lÌ¥-K, and the MB (on the ÅšivasÅ«tra: rÌ¥-lÌ¥-K) argues that one must include lÌ¥ in the ÅšivasÅ«tra rÌ¥-lÌ¥-K, in order to get a prolonged lÌ¥Ì„3 in vocative forms like klÌ¥Ì„3ptaÅ›ikha. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara alludes to this discussion. The quotation à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤š is not found in any known works ascribed to Åšaunaka. It is, however, quoted by Ramadev Tripathi (1977: 75) as belonging to verse 5 of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä. It appears in verse 2 of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä reconstructed by Manomohan Ghosh (1938: 1). It also occurs in the AgnipurÄá¹‡a version of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä as verse 3; verse 5 of the PÄá¹‡inÄ«yaÅ›iká¹£Ä presented by the commentary PaÃ±jikÄ and Åšiká¹£ÄprakÄÅ›a, the Yajus Recension, and the RÌ¥k Recension. Manomohan Ghosh (1938: 50, 53)

162à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ wrongly translates this as: â€œand the pluta lÌ¥ is duá¸¥sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a.â€ The original verse is simply a continued listing the sounds included in the alphabet and includes the duá¸¥sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a sound as well as the prolonged lÌ¥Ì„3 as belonging to the total listing. The term duá¸¥sprÌ¥á¹£á¹­a refers to the retroflex á¸· (= à¤³) found in the RÌ¥gveda, and is not a description of the prolonged lÌ¥Ì„3 as understood by Ghosh. à¥§.à¥§.à¥ªà¥¦. à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.40). Hb, Nb: Â°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿. G: 1.1.40. I: 40. O: Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£Â°. P: Â°à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤ŸÂ°. Translation: The composite-sounds [= e, o, ai, and au] have, [within each], fused [component] sounds, and [yet] they behave as single sounds. Note: Whitney and Allen (1953: 63) render the phrase à¤à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ by â€˜they are treated as single letters.â€™ In my opinion, a better translation is offered by â€˜they behave…â€™ The rule thus draws a distinction between the per- ceived phonetic nature and the phonological behavior. For instance, metrically these vowels form single syllables. It is clear from the plural form sandhyaká¹£arÄá¹‡i, that the text refers by this term to all four sounds, i.e. e, o, ai, and au, and not just to ai and au. As seen earlier, the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä text cited in the CAB on CA (1.1.21, 25), seems to say that the sounds e and o have a single point of articulation, in contrast with ai and au, and that their monophthongal character seems to be supported by CA (1.1.34: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥), the present rule clearly brings them under the term sandhyaká¹£ara. The term sandhyaká¹£ara is generally translated as â€˜diphthong,â€™ and this raises the question of why the sounds e and o should come under this term. To begin with, we must disabuse ourselves of the notion that the term sandhyaká¹£ara refers to a diphthong. It refers literally to a composite-sound, and the composite character is more in terms of their perceived origin, rather than in terms of their current articulation. Thus, phonetically the sounds e and o were monophthongs for the CA, and yet in terms of their origin they were seen as being born out of a combination. Allen (1953: 64) says: â€œIt will be noted that even where the monophthongal value of e/o is phonetically estab- lished, the feeling for its phonological equivalence to a+i/u still prevails.â€ However, the combination of elements in e and o, as compared to the combination in ai and au, was perceived to be of a different nature by most

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾163 Sanskrit texts. The first pair represents a true fusion where the components can no longer be separately perceived, while the second pair has perceptible components. For the first type of combination, PataÃ±jali uses the term praÅ›liá¹£ta, while for the second type of combination, he uses the term samÄhÄra, cf. MB (Kielhorn edn), Vol.I., p. 62: à¤à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤™à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Also: à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤šà¥Œ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥Œ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ, MB (ibid), p. 78. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤(?)à¤à¤à¥© à¤(?)à¤à¤à¥© à¤“(?) à¤“à¤“à¥© à¤”(?)à¤”à¤”à¥© à¥¤ Note: It is not clear why the commentary offers three varieties of each diphthong. This is probably just an error under the influence of the triple listings for other vowels. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ à¤ à¤“ à¤” à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥ƒà¥’à¤¹à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤£à¤¾à¥ˆà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦. à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤Ÿà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤…à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤‰à¤à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡ à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤à¤•à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨) à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥‹ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¥‹à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥©.à¥­.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥§.à¥ªà¥§. à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (1.41). G: 1.1.41. E, F, O(orig): Â°à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾Â°. Translation: [The behavior of the sounds] ai and au [as single sounds] does not hold in the context of the prescription of their points of articulation (sthÄna).

164à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ Note: The listing of the four sounds in the commentaries is problem- atic. The rule clearly uses a dual form, and, after dissolving the sandhi in naikÄ- raukÄrayoá¸¥, it can be sensibly either ekÄra+okÄrayoá¸¥, or aikÄra+aukÄrayoá¸¥. Out of these two possibilities, Whitney opted for the second one, while BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, and the CAB too, would like to have it both ways to include all the four sandhyaká¹£aras. The interpretation I have given above is supported by Whitney. On this rule, Whitney says: â€œWhat the meaning and value of the rule is is not alto- gether clear: I can see no other application of it than to forbid the inclusion of ai among the palatals only, and of au among the labials only, since they are both throat-sounds as well. By implication, then, e and o would admit of being ranked as merely palatal and labial.â€ This is in part because Whitney takes the word sthÄnavidhi to refer to â€˜prescription of the point of articulation.â€™ The CAB as well as the ancient Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited therein are unclear on this rule. Whitney derives the following meaning from the verse cited in the CAB: â€œperhaps the meaning is that, while the beginning and end of Äi, for instance, are clearly a and i, a mora in the middle of the sound is of a mixed character.â€ The verse seems to refer to a half-mora element which is of mixed character. I think this is a plausible interpretation. On the other hand, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary seems to sup- port an interpretation like: â€œ[The behavior] of the sounds e/ai and o/au [as single sounds, however], does not [hold] in the context of substitution [sthÄna- vidhi , i.e. substitution of the constituents of these sounds by protracted varie- ties].â€ BhÄrgava-BhÄskara draws our attention to the other possible meaning of the term sthÄnavidhi, i.e. substitution, cf. P.1.1.49 (à¤·à¤·à¥à¤ à¥€ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾). With this other meaning of the word sthÄnavidhi, i.e. substitution, there is a different possible context for this rule. In the context of substitution, the sounds ai and au do not behave as single sounds, i.e. their different components receive dif- ferent substitutes. The best example to illustrate this different behavior of the components is offered in the PÄá¹‡inian process of deriving the prolonged versions for e, o, ai, and au. Compare PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules P. 8.2.105 (à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤š à¤‡à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥Œ) and 8.2.106 (à¤à¤šà¥‹à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥‚à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥Œ). The first rule says that when ai and au are prolonged, it is the i and the u elements of these composite sounds that get prolonged. Thus, a prolonged ai is equivalent to a+Ä«3, and a prolonged au is equivalent to a+Å«3. The next rule says that, for a non-pragrÌ¥hya e, o, ai, or au, except in a call from afar, the sound e and ai are prolonged to Ä3+i, and o and au to Ä3+u. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules clearly refer to the components in the context of substitution.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾165 In the examples khaá¹‡vakhÄ3i and khaimakhÄ3i offered by BhÄrgava- BhÄskara, we assume that an original e has been changed to Ä3i, cf. BhÄrgava- BhÄskara lists khaá¹‡vakhe and khaimakhe as the non-pluta forms under CA (1.2.22). On the other hand, Whitney guesses on CA (1.4.5 = W 1.96) that the original non-pluta forms are â€˜probablyâ€™ khaá¹‡vakhÄi and khaimakhÄi. If Whitney is correct, we have the change of ai to Ä3i. However, I agree with the Roth-BÃ¶htlingk lexicon in considering these forms to be vocatives of the female frog-names khaá¹‡vakhÄ and khaimakhÄ, and hence the non-pluta voca- tive forms are khaá¹‡vakhe and khaimakhe, rather than khaá¹‡vakhai and khai- makai. This is also supported by SÄyaá¹‡a on ÅšAV (4.15.15). BhÄrgava- BhÄskara also offers an example of an original o changing to Ä3u in the form vÄyÄ3u (< vÄyo). This example is not attested in the ÅšAV. Of these two possible interpretations, the first one is the more likely interpretation, because the rule occurs in the context of describing the articula- tion of sounds, rather than in the context of substitution. The second argument which goes against the interpretation of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is that the so-called substitution for different parts of a diphthong in the context of pluta is never taught as a rule in the CA. It is simply taken for granted, because the pluta forms appear both in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha and the PadapÄá¹­ha. Therefore, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara was forced to bring in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s substitution rules, which clearly refer to components of the diphthongs. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£- à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤à¥© à¤“à¤”à¥© à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤š à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒ(à¤¸à¥ƒ?)à¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ (à¤¨à¤ƒ?) à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (Source?)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript N has à¤¨ in the last quarter of the verse, but the syntax of the verse still remains corrupt. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤®à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥Œ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤“- à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥- à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤–à¤£à¥à¤µà¥’à¤–à¤¾à¥©à¤‡à¥’ à¤–à¥ˆà¤®à¥’à¤–à¤¾à¥©à¤‡à¥’ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥«)à¥¤

166à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ â€˜à¤à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¥©à¤‰ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤- à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¥©à¤‰â€™ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ (à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¬.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤ªà¤¤à¥Œâ€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤š à¤‡à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥Œâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿- à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¨ à¤- à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤”à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦[à¤šà¥]à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: For the accentuation of the example from AV (4.15.15), see Note on CA (1.4.5). The VVRI Vedic concordance lists RV (9.96.12) as the only Saá¹ƒhitÄ occurrence for saá¹ƒ tiá¹£á¹­ha, but the source for à¤à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¥©à¤‰ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤  is as yet unknown. There is no occurrence of saá¹ƒ tiá¹£á¹­ha in the BrÄhmaá¹‡as and Ä€raá¹‡yakas. à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥ªà¥§ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ E, F: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ A, B, D, M, P: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ J: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ I: à¥ªà¥§ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ G: à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤—à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¥¤ O: à¥¥à¥§à¥¥à¥ªà¥§à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥ªà¥§ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¥¤ ______________________

à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¤ à¥à¥©à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§. à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.42), A, G, I, Hac, P: Â°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ B, C, D, E, F, Hb, J, K, M, N, O: Â°à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ. G: 1.2.1. Translation: The á¸¥ (= visarjanÄ«ya) is an abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna [â€˜off- glideâ€™] sound. Note: The term abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna is difficult to interpret, because it does not occur elsewhere in the grammatical literature, and because, in its few occur- rences in the GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tras etc. it is simply used as a term referring to visarga;, for passages in the GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tras, see: Ä€Å›valÄyana-GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tra (1.15.4-5), PÄraskara-GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tra (1.17.1-6), and Gobhila-GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tra (2.8.14). For further references, see L. Renou (1942: 376). But the significance of the term itself is hardly accounted for. It looks like an older term for visarga or visarjanÄ«ya, which was discontinued in later Sanskrit. Secondly, the mss. are divided over the readings abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna and abhi- niá¹£á¹­hÄna. PÄá¹‡ini (8.3.86: à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥) derives the formation abhi- niá¹£á¹­Äna from abhi+nis+!stan as a Å›abdasaá¹ƒjÃ±Ä â€˜technical term referring to a linguistic unit.â€™ However, the other reading is not without some justification. Whitney remarks on this rule: â€œPÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule must be taken as conclusive re- specting the derivation and form favored in his time, or by his school; but the analogy of the words abhinidhÄna, abhinihita, abhinihata, abhinipÄta cannot but suggest abhiniá¹£á¹­hÄna as the true form, coming from the root sthÄ with the pre- fixes abhi and ni.â€ In my own opinion, the form abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna is the original form, the lectio difficilior, and hence probably the original reading. What does the word abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna mean? Whitney on this rule says: â€œThe BÃ¶htlingk-Roth lexicon gives it … the meaning â€˜an expiring or vanishing

168à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ sound (ein verklingender Laut),â€™ but this is merely a conjecture, and by no means so well supported by the etymology of the word (which would suggest rather â€˜a sounding forth, a resonanceâ€™) as to be placed beyond the reach of question.â€ Recently, S.M. Katre (1987: 1039) seems to have followed the BÃ¶htlingk-Roth interpretation in translating the term as â€˜a phoneme that dies away.â€™ Such an interpretation makes no sense in view of the non-technical example offered in the KV on P.8.3.86: à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¤™à¥à¤—à¤ƒ. Here it must refer to the reverberations of the sound of the drum. Therefore, I agree with Whitneyâ€™s interpretation. Perhaps, the best modern technical paraphrase would be â€˜off-glide.â€™ The meaning of the term abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna is probably close to that of visarga or visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. â€˜to be released, emitted.â€™ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾(N: à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾)- à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª. à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ) à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤œà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤§à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾- à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤•à¥‘à¤«à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥Œâ€™ (Whitneyâ€™s AV: à¤•à¥‘à¤«à¥Œà¥’à¤¡à¥Œ, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤•à¥à¤²à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¨à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤–à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¬. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤šà¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤–à¥‘à¤¨à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥’à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¥’à¤¡à¤ƒ(à¤•à¥à¤¤?) à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤£à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤¨à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ à¤£à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­. à¥§à¥¦à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥’à¤¹à¥à¥’à¤²à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤«à¤Ÿà¥ à¤•à¥‘à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤«à¥’à¤²à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (?)à¥¤ à¤†à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥‡ (which one?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¨à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥‘à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¥€à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤·à¤¡à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥©. à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤¨à¥’à¤¶à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤ªà¤¤à¥‘à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥®.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¨à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦. à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¥‡à¥’à¤¨à¤µà¤ƒà¥’

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾169 à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤°à¥à¤ƒà¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¶à¤ƒà¤¸à¥â€™ (?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤®à¥â€™ (?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥‡à¤§à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸-à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥©.à¥®à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥-à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara gives a somewhat different interpretation of the term abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna. According to him, it does not refer just to a normal visarga (i.e. á¸¥), but to visarga as it changes to á¸« (= jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya) before k, kh, or to áº– (= upadhmÄnÄ«ya) before p, ph. Such changes may be due to external or internal sandhi. We have no way of evaluating BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s inter- pretation, except to say that it does not agree with the general usage of the term abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna in the GrÌ¥hya-SÅ«tras, where it seems to be a plain and simple equivalent of the generic visarga. The CAB also seems to interpret this term as a generic equivalent of visarga, and the examples it cites are of word-final visarga before pause. Therefore, the chances of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara being cor- rect are slim. The example à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤«à¤²à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤ƒ is found in RV (10.97.15), TS (4.2.6.4), and VS (12.89). It is also found in the Mantra-BrÄhmaá¹‡a (1.5.1), edited by Satyavrat SÄmaÅ›ramÄ«, Calcutta, 1947. It is not traced to any known Ä€raá¹‡yaka. However, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara cites it as an Ä€raá¹‡yaka example. The example à¤¯à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤®à¥ is found in the KV (on P.8.3.38: à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ). For the textual variation concerning the example à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤«à¥‹à¤¡à¥Œ from AV (10.2.4) and its interpretation, see Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 568). à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¨. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.43), C, E, H, I, N, P: single SÅ«tra: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ A, B, D: two SÅ«tras: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¨(à¤¤ in D)à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ F, G, J, K, M: the first of the two SÅ«tras ends with Â°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ G numbers the two SÅ«tras: 1.2.2, 1.2.3. Translation: Holding a consonant back [i.e. not releasing it, or checking it] is termed abhinidhÄna. Note: Following Whitney, Varma (1929: 137) and Allen (1953: 71- 72) take CA (1.2.2-3) as representing a single rule. The manuscripts are split half and half on this issue. Among the commentaries, the CAB takes the entire

170à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ stretch (CA 1.2.2-3) as being a single rule, a definition or description of abhi- nidhÄna. BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary, on the other hand takes these two to be separate rules. The first rule is a definition of abhinidhÄna, while the second one a definition of the term sannatara. I have given these as two rules, because mss. from different groups seem to treat these as two rules. The manuscript G numbers these two rules separately, and with this numbering, the CA 1.2.10 appears as 1.2.10 in both I and G. On the other hand, I do not agree with BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s notion that rule 1.2.3 defines a separate term, i.e. sannatara. I think rule 1.2.3 is simply a supplement to 1.2.2, and, hence is a further description of abhinidhÄna. Whitney uses the terms implosion and explosion to refer to the two phases involved in the pronunciation of consonants. The first step, especially clear in the case of stops, is indicated by the formation of contact between the articulator and the point of articulation. The sound becomes more audible with the release of that contact, referred to by Whitney by the term explosion. When a stop is followed by another stop, or by a pause, then the utterance of the first stop basically ends with the first phase, and there does not follow a clear release of the contact, making the consonant weakly audible. Whitney gener- ally treats this as a description of indistinct pronunciation. He saw many diffi- culties in this description, and explained those difficulties â€œby supposing that the Hindus had not made a complete physical analysis of the phonomenon, and hence that their descriptions of it partake of vagueness and inconsistency; and also, that they have brought together under the name abhinidhÄna things not entirely accordant, although analogous, in character.â€ Since Whitney was unhappy with the first explanation of the notion of incomplete utterance, he came up with a second hypothesis (p. 36): â€œAn alter- native view to which I have myself been somewhat attracted is that by the abhinidhÄna is meant the instant of silence which intervenes between the clo- sure of the organs for the first mute, and their opening for the second: that the Hindu theory regards, in the word Äpta, for example, the utterance of the p as complete by the closure of the lips upon the preceding Ä, and that of the t as complete by the unclosure of the tongue before the following a, while the brief interval of suspended utterance separating the two acts is abhinidhÄna.â€ A few modern scholars have taken this to represent Whitneyâ€™s final view, cf. Vijay Shankar Pandeya (1987: 183). It is, however, not clear whether Whitneyâ€™s statements concerning the â€˜Indian notions of the complete utterance of a stopâ€™ are correct. On the other hand, Whitney finally arrives at the following under- standing (p. 36): â€œFatal objections, however, to this explanation are: the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾171 treatment of the phenomenon as something affecting the former consonant, not interposed after it; the difficulty of assuming any such interval of silence in the case of a concurrence with sonant and nasal mutes; and the non-applicability of the theory to the case of a final consonant. The term vyaÃ±janavidhÄraá¹‡a must therefore be understood as used simply in antithesis to the saá¹ƒyuktam of rule 49 (= CA 1.2.9: à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥): whereas, in other cases of concurrence of consonants, there is actual combination, with partial assimilation of the latter to the former (rule 50 = CA 1.2.10), here each is held apart from the other as distinct.â€ Whitney realizes that this explanation may not be applicable to the word-final consonants, but states that â€œit is allowable to regard as contemplated in a general description or designation of a phonetic phenomenon its principal case only.â€ Allen (1953: 70ff.) comes up with a more positive understanding of this phenomenon. More than an interval of silence, the term abhinidhÄna refers to an unreleased consonant, either before another consonant making the con- junction weak and excludable from the notion of saá¹ƒyukta â€˜conjunct conso- nants,â€™ or occurring at the word-final position, making the consonant midway between a voiced or a voiceless consonant, as debated in CA (1.1.10: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ). Allen (1953: 71) describes abhinidhÄna as: â€œthe non-release of a consonant, more particularly a stop, when followed by a stop, and parallels the French term â€˜implosion.â€™â€ The notion of â€˜implosionâ€™ makes eminent sense in the case of a stop followed by a stop, particularly when we see deaspiration of the first stop, aspiration being a feature of the release or â€˜explosion.â€™ However, the term abhinidhÄna seems to refer to overall weakening of the initial consonant of a consonant-cluster, and of the final consonant before pause. This overall weakening makes such consonants subject to changes of all kinds, especially subject to progressive assimilation in sandhis and loss of final consonants in Prakrits. Allen (1953: 70ff) correctly links this non-release of the consonant with both the contexts, i.e. a not-too-tight consonantal contact as well as the word-final position. It must be noted that the notion of abhinidhÄna, its nature, and scope, were a highly disputed topic among the various traditions, and the phenomenon probably also varied dialectally, cf. Varma (1929: 133-147). For another recent discussion of this term, also see: Ralf Stautzebach (1994: 312-313). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®- à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥‹(à¤½?)à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤œà¤ªà¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸-

172à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾- à¤¤à¥‹(à¤½?)à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤œà¤ªà¤¨à¥‡ â€˜à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¯.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥‹à¥‘à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤•à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨. à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤¶à¤ªà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥ªà¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥- à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥ªà¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤²à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥€à¤šà¤¯à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’- à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤à¥à¤œà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¤®à¥à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤§à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤¦à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥‘à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¯.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara takes abhinidhÄna as a continued descrip- tion of the visarga and its contextual substitutes. For him, when a visarga, or

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾173 its contextual substitute, combines with the following consonant, both the con- sonants together are called abhinidhÄna. This interpretation cannot be correct. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥©. à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.43) combines with the previous SÅ«tra. Translation: [The sound termed abhinidhÄna in the previous rule is] squeezed, weaker, and has reduced breath or voice. Note: As explained in the Note on the earlier rule, I have treated this as a separate rule, and yet I think it is a continuation of the previous descrip- tion. The term vyaÃ±janavidhÄraá¹‡am, in the previous rule, referring to â€œholding apart or backâ€ of a consonant, seems like a description of the consequences of a certain phonetic process, and that process is described more fully in the present rule. The three terms contained in this rule describe different di- mensions of this articulatory process. The term pÄ«á¸ita, lit. â€˜pressed,â€™ seems to refer to the non-release of the contact between the articulator and the point of articulation. The term hÄ«naÅ›vÄsanÄda refers to weak emission involved, whether the consonant be voiced or voiceless. The term sannatara presents some further difficulties. It is translated by Whitney (p. 34) as â€˜quite weakened,â€™ and Varma (1929: 137) and Allen (1953: 72) generally follow Whitney. The term avasannatara appears in the Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited in the CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya on the previous rule. Elsewhere, i.e. P.1.2.40 (à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ), the term sannatara is used to describe the lowest pitch level, lower than the normal low-pitch (anudÄtta). This is for a low-pitch syllable which precedes an udÄtta â€˜high-pitchâ€™ or a svarita â€˜rising- fallingâ€™ syllable. Thus, sanna in this context refers to low-pitch, and sannatara refers to a pitch lower than the normal low-pitch. It is not clear if there is any shared value in the use of the same term in these two different contexts. Per- haps, the term implies in a generic manner the low level of effort involved in both the lowest-pitch vowels, and the unreleased stops, and in this sense may be comparable to the term laghu-prayatna-tara. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - See the commentary on the previous rule. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹[à¤ƒ] à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥€à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸

174à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤• à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ª à¥¤ à¤¶ à¥¤ à¤· à¥¤ à¤¸ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤°à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥ˆ- à¤°à¥à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤- à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤“à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤°à¤¸à¥‡à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¯à¥‹à¥’- à¤­à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¥’ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¨à¥‹à¥‘ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬. à¥§à¥¨à¥®.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‘à¤¥à¥€ à¤°à¥‡à¥’à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥’à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¥‚ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚- à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¥’- à¤®à¥à¤¹à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦. à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara takes this rule to be a definition of the term sannatara which he claims applies to a visarga which changes in certain sandhis in such a way that it survives neither as a sibilant, nor as a y or an r. It is doubtful if the rule has any such meaning. The term hÄ«na-Å›vÄsa-nÄda is taken

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾175 by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara to mean a sound which has neither Å›vÄsa nor nÄda. This is clearly unacceptable. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥ª. à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.44). G: 1.2.4. O: Â°à¤®à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ. Translation: Before a stop [lit. â€˜contact consonant,â€™ includ- ing the nasals á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, and m], there is abhinidhÄna [i.e. lack of release] of a stop. Note: The CA unconditionally refers to all stops, including nasals, in this rule. This includes conjuncts of homorganic as well as non-homorganic stops, and it also includes combinations of nasals and non-nasals. One of the interpretations proposed for abhinidhÄna by Whitney was a moment of silence between the consonants. However, as Whitney himself recognized, such a moment of silence does not seem possible between, for example, a voiced un- aspirated stop and a homorganic nasal, because the transition between such sounds is far smoother. Therefore, the best conception of abhinidhÄna is represented by â€˜unreleasedâ€™ articulation. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¯.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: As Whitney notes, out of the three examples cited by the CAB, only the last example is found in the (Åš)AV. The form samidbhiá¸¥ is not found in AV, and the references listed for this word in Vishva Bandhuâ€™s A Gram- matical Word-Index to Atharvaveda (p. 622) are actually references for the word samidhaá¸¥, wrongly ascribed to samidbhiá¸¥. One may also note that Surya Kanta has not made the expected suggestion that the first two forms cited by the CAB, which are not found in the Vulgate of the AV, probably occurred in the real ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV which is now lost and that the Vulgate does not represent the true ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension.

176à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥à¥’à¤®à¥à¥’à¤—à¥à¤§à¤¿à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ Note: According to BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, the whole cluster of stops gets the designation abhinidhÄna. This does not seem to be correct. The phrase à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ … à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ is comparable to substitution or alteration, in the classical PÄá¹‡inian fashion, where the genitive case represents the sthÄnin â€˜item undergoing substitution, item being replaced,â€™ and the item in the nominative represents the ÄdeÅ›a â€˜substitute,â€™ cf. P.1.1.49 (à¤·à¤·à¥à¤ à¥€ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾). à¥§.à¥¨.à¥«. à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.45). G: 1.2.5. Translation: Also at the end of a word [before pause in the PadapÄá¹­ha] and [at the end of the first member of a compound, or at the end of a nominal base] in separation [of the members of a compound or of the base from the case-ending in the PadapÄá¹­ha, a stop is reduced to abhinidhÄna]. Note: Heffner (1952: 119): â€œThe contact and hold phases are usually easy to observe, the release may be obscured, notably for instance, when the stop is the final element of the breath group. In the phrase, and then he went to sleep, the final [p] of sleep is often not released by the labial â€œexplosion," but by the lowering of the velum for the resumption of normal breathing, the lips having simply remained closed. Such a release is usually not audible.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤ƒà¥’ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤½à¤¸à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤²à¤¾à¥’- à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤½à¤‡à¥‘à¤µâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤–à¤²à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤½à¤‡à¤µâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney correctly points out that the phrase à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ â€œhas no business here: that case is included in the preceding rule, and the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾177 present precept applies to the pronunciation of a final as a final, without any reference to what may follow.â€ In all the cases cited by the commentator, the word-final stop is followed by a pause, rather than by another stop. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤¾(à¤ª?)à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤šà¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤¸à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤­à¤µ- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤—à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤®à¥à¤½à¤ªà¥‘à¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤—à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥ªà¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤˜à¥’à¤°à¥à¤®à¥’à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©. à¥ªà¥­)à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤¿à¤°à¤£à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥­.à¥«.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤§à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦. à¥©à¥¬.à¥§à¥ª, not in AV, but found in the late text Gaá¹‡eÅ›a- AtharvaÅ›Ä«rá¹£a)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥©.à¥­)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤à¥à¤šà¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥«à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’à¤à¥à¤šà¥’-à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥«à¥¦)à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara also brings the words sparÅ›asya sparÅ›e pare into this rule and says that this rule applies to a stop which occurs at the end of a word and is followed by the initial stop the next word. With this in- terpretation, he says that the previous rule applies to stops in non-final position. For BhÄrgava-BhÄskara to be correct, one must assume that one is dealing with external sandhi applications, and not with what happens to the word-final stop in the PadapÄá¹­ha before pause. In that case, the rule would be dealing with two entirely unrelated situations, one a situation of a word-final stop followed by a word-initial stop, and the second a situation where the word-final stop is followed by an avagraha, a mini-pause to mark the separa- tion of the members of a compound in the PadapÄá¹­ha. This seems to be a very unlikely combination. The best way is to take this rule to apply to the word- final stops before pause in the PadapÄá¹­ha.

178à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ Another feature of BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s interpretation is that he views the term abhinidhÄna as applying to both the stops involved in a conjunct. This does not seem to be correct. It is interesting to note that all the instances of the word hiraá¹‡maya- listed in Vishva Bandhuâ€™s Grammatical Word-Index to the Atharvaveda (p. 678) are from the PaippalÄda Atharvaveda. However, it should be noted that the word hiraá¹‡maya as a variant for hiraá¹‡yaya does occur in the mss. of the ÅšAV. See the variants given for hiraá¹‡yayÄ«m in AV (10.2.33) in the VVRI edition. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¬. à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.46). G: 1.2.6. Translation: The consonant l [is reduced to abhinidhÄna] before spirants. Note: Whitney notes that â€œonly spirants before which l is found actu- ally to occur in the Atharvaveda are Å› and h.â€ Whitney has discussed the de- tails of how this notion is highly eclectic and that other treatises propose differ- ent treatments for l under similar circumstances. His own response to this prescription, however, is: â€œI must confess myself unable to explain why either l before a spirant, or the nasals before h, as taught in the next rule, should suf- fer or be regarded as suffering the obscuring process of abhinidhÄna.â€ As far as the case of the abhinidhÄna taught by the present rule is concerned, Varma (1929: 147) says: â€œThis probably refers to a sporadic phenomenon in some of the dialects, for in the majority of cases we should expect Svarabhakti after l or r before fricatives. The fact that this sporadic phenomenon actually existed in some dialects is corroborated by PrÄkrit vassa-, side by side with, in the major- ity of cases, varisa-, valiÅ›a-.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿- à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤¬à¥‘à¤²à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¥’ à¤µà¤¿ à¤°à¥‹à¥‘à¤¹â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤—à¥‘à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¥’ à¤¬à¤²à¥à¤¿à¥‘à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¹à¤²à¥à¤¹à¥‹à¥’ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the expression balhikÄn cited as an example of this rule, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 260) says: â€œThe PrÄt. rule i.46 (= CA

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾179 1.2.6) applies, if we may trust the comment, to the name in d (in AV 5.22.5) and proves it to be bÃ¡lhika, and not bÃ¡hlika; the mss. vary between the two, the majority giving -lh-; but the testimony of no ms. is of any authority on this particular point; Ppp. appears to have -hl-.â€ The APR (175: à¤—à¤²à¥à¤¹à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤²à¥à¤¹à¥Œ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ) supports the CA rule. Witzel informs (in personal communication) that the Orissa mss regularly have -lih-, -liÅ›- etc. The last two examples cited by the CAB are also found, though in reverse order, in APR (175). Translation: The sounds á¹…, á¹‡, and n [are reduced to abhini- dhÄna] before h.

180à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ Note: Whitney on the previous rule expresses his inability to explain why the change prescribed by the present rule should occur, and for some reason, Varmaâ€™s (1929) extensive discussion of abhinidhÄna does not cover the cases which come under the present rule. The only real examples from the AV are those of á¹… and n being followed by h. This occurs only for word-final á¹… and n before word-initial h, in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. In the PadapÄá¹­ha, the word- final á¹… and n would be followed by a pause, and hence would be reduced to abhinidhÄna by CA (1.2.5). These sequences do not occur word-internally. The example with sugaá¹‡ offered in the commentaries is an artificial example. It is, then, not entirely clear why á¹‡ was included in this rule. Fabricated examples with gaá¹‡ or sugaá¹‡ are found in the CAB on CA (2.1.9) and (3.2.2), and also in the Åšiká¹£Ä verse cited in the CAB on CA (3.2.2). The late commentators in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition also resort to sugaá¹‡, cf. SiddhÄntakaumudÄ« on P.8.3.32 (à¤™à¤®à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤šà¤¿ à¤™à¤®à¥à¤£à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥). One may note that the KV on the same rule comes up with an example with an artificial vaá¹‡. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥ à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥¯.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¤£à¥ à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¥€à¥‘à¤¨à¥ à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤®à¥‚à¤¨à¥ à¤¹à¥‡à¥’à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨- à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥ à¤¹â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤—à¤£à¥ à¤¹à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¨à¥ à¤¹à¤°à¥‘à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥©à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥®. à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.48). G: 1.2.8. Translation: [The abhinidhÄna is] also called ÄsthÄpita [â€˜arrestedâ€™]. Note: The CAB seems to say that ÄsthÄpita is simply another name for the abhinidhÄna. Whitney has followed the CAB in interpreting ÄsthÄpita as just another name for the abhinidhÄna. He says that this alternative title â€œdoes not notably help our comprehension of it (= abhinidhÄna): the word admits of being translated, in accordance with the explanation of abhinidhÄna offered

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾181 above, â€˜made to stand up to, or against;â€™ but it may also be rendered â€˜stopped,â€™ that is, â€˜silenced,â€™ and so may favor another theory of the phenomenon.â€ Allen (1953: 72) follows Whitney, except that he translates the term ÄsthÄpita as â€˜arrested,â€™ and takes it to be just another name for abhinidhÄna. RPR (4.1) uses the term ÄsthÄpita to refer to consonant+consonant sandhi. It is therefore likely that the terms ÄsthÄpita and abhinidhÄna would have a largely overlapping area of application. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾- à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤† à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤® à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤†à¤—à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤†à¤—à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿- à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‚à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥ªà¥®.à¥ª) à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‘à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (W: à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ, à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥«.à¥§) à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤™à¥- à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¤¿à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¦) à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«. à¥¬.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤à¥à¤šà¥à¤›à¥’à¤²à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥â€™ (W: à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤‚, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: Quite a different interpretation for the rule is proposed by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara in his commentary. He takes the term ÄsthÄpita as being equivalent to Ägama â€˜augment, appended item,â€™ in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. According to his explanation, the consonantal augments inserted between either two consonants, or between a consonant and a vowel, are referred to by the term ÄsthÄpita. According to him, such a consonantal augment, along with the preceding and the following consonant is given the name abhinidhÄna. For instance, in an example like tÄn+savitaá¸¥, by following CA (2.1.9: à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥), a euphonic t is inserted between the final n and the initial s, giving us tÄn-t-savitaá¸¥. According to the interpretation suggested by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, this euphonic t would be reduced to an abhinidhÄna, i.e. â€˜an unreleased stop.â€™ The dialectal instability of such augments is indicated by the fact that these are made optional in PÄá¹‡ini (8.3.28-31). The abhinidhÄna character of such a sound would indeed manifest in such instability. However, we do not have any way to confirm independently that the term ÄsthÄpita was used to refer to such â€˜augments.â€™

182à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ The examples à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤™à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¤¿à¥’ and à¤†à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤ need to be distinguished from other examples. Here, the augments á¹… and n are immediately preceded by á¹… and n, but are followed by vowels. It may also be noted that the manuscripts of the AV do not exhibit these readings with the added augments. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¯. à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.49). G: 1.2.9. A, B, D: Â°à¤¤à¥à¤ªÂ° for Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¯Â°. Translation: [A consonant, involved in a consonant+conso- nant combination], other than these [i.e. listed under the cate- gory of abhinidhÄna], is called saá¹ƒyukta â€˜conjunct.â€™ Note: It should be noted that the scope of the notion of saá¹ƒyoga is different from that of the term saá¹ƒyukta, though both of these terms are ety- mologically related. The term saá¹ƒyoga as used in CA (1.2.11: à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡) and CA (1.4.7: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ) encompasses all consonant+ consonant combinations, including those covered under abhinidhÄna. On the other hand, the term saá¹ƒyukta excludes the cases of abhinidhÄna. It would seem that the distinction between abhinidhÄna and saá¹ƒyukta was phonetically relevant, but not grammatically. Probably for this reason, PÄá¹‡ini used only the broad notion of saá¹ƒyoga, cf. P.1.1.7 (à¤¹à¤²à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ), and dispensed with the distinction between abhinidhÄna and saá¹ƒyukta. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ (Whitneyâ€™s emendation: à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾(à¤­à¤¿?)à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¬à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥- à¤¬à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¥à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤°à¤¥à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤¡à¥à¤°à¤¥à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥(à¤Ÿà¥?)à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡(?)â€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¤à¥(?)à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥(à¤Ÿà¥?)à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥- à¤ªà¥à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤•à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥(à¤Ÿà¥?)à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾183 Note: Both the manuscripts write à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿ as à¤¤à¥ƒ or à¤¨à¥ƒ. All the examples cited by the CAB are artificial examples produced by combinations and per- mutations of a few words. It is again interesting to note that Surya Kanta does not claim these as belonging to the so-called lost recension of the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV. Surya Kantaâ€™s overall argument is weakened by the obvious existence of such a large number of non-AV examples in this commentary. Examples with Å›ete, sÄye, and á¹£aá¹‡á¸e are found in the KV on P.8.3.28, 29, 30, and 36. These examples are not textual quotations, but possible usages. The wording of the CAB, i.e. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥, creates an im- pression that the term saá¹ƒyoga applies to cases of contact between a final and an initial, but, as Whitney correctly notes, such is not the case. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤‚à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥’à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥®. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥’à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤šà¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¥§à¥§.à¥«. à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥¦à¥­.à¥§, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥§à¥§à¥¨. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§.à¥®à¥¯.à¥©, no occurrence in ÅšAV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥§.à¥§, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥‘[à¤¾à¤ƒ]â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µ(à¤µà¤¾?)- à¤¯à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‘à¤™à¥à¤—à¥’à¤²à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’- [ï†…]à¤¤à¥â€™

(à¤….à¤µà¥‡.

à¥®.à¥¬.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’[à¤·à¥]-à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥’[à¤®à¥]â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤µà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬.à¥¨) à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥’à¤¥à¤¯à¥‘â€™ (â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥’à¤¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¾-(à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¾?)à¤¦à¥à¤¨à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¨.à¥­.à¥®, not found in ÅšAV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¥à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤

184à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara adds another important consideration, namely that the term saá¹ƒyukta not only excludes the cases of abhinidhÄna, but that it also excludes the cases of abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna as defined in CA (1.2.1: à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œ- à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ). Additionally, he includes the combination of an anusvÄra with a consonant under the term saá¹ƒyukta. Such a separate listing of the anusvÄra is prompted by the unclear position of the anusvÄra in relation to the distinction between vowels and consonants. The RPR (1.22: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤š) also lists anusvÄra separately, because of the ambiguous position of the anusvÄra, cf. RPR (1.5: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾). à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦. à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.50). G: 1.2.10. I: 10. Translation: The final half-mora of the previous [consonant, in a case of consonant+consonant combination) has the same karaá¹‡a [= articulator or mode of articulation?] as the following [consonant]. Note: Whitney first says that the word karaá¹‡a in the rule should not be restricted to the notion of â€˜organ,â€™ or articulator, but should be broadly in- terpreted in the sense of â€˜mode of production.â€™ He then points out the main difficulty in interpreting this rule: â€œOf the accuracy of the physical observations which could discover any actual assimilation of the first element of these (e.g. ts, st) and other similar combinations, in its final portion, to the latter, I find it hard to say much in praise: I am unable to discover that any part of the t in vat- sau becomes an s, or any part of s in vaste a t, any more than the s and t. One way of interpreting this rule is to say that in combinations like ts, the transition between t and s is marked by something like th which shares the features of both t and s. The rule in general may mark the propensity toward progressive assimilation.â€ Also compare Heffner (1952: 120): â€œThe precise nature of the move- ments made to effect the contact of a stop consonant are determined (a) by the position or positions at which the stop is produced, and (b) by the position or positions from which the articulating organs have to move to get there. Any sound produced during these movements is inevitably a constantly changing sound: the contact phase or the onset of stop consonants is therefore sometimes called the on-glide of the consonant. Usually the audible sound produced by this onset is a modification of the preceding speech sound, whether vowel or consonant.â€ The CA may be hinting at a modification of this type.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾185 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥Œ(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‹) à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤®à¤¾à¥‘ à¤†à¤¸à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Note: Whitney draws our attention to the fact that this rule is itself a half Åšloka and as such seems to have been quoted from another metrical source, and that the commentary quotes it as the first half of a verse. This raises a possibility that the metrical authority is older than the CA. It seems less likely that a text would take a line from the CA and would turn it into a full Åšloka by adding a second half. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾- à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤•à¥‘à¤«à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥Œâ€™ (Whitneyâ€™s AV: à¤•à¥‘à¤«à¥Œà¥’à¤¡à¥Œ, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¥à¤ à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤µà¥‘à¤²à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤ƒà¥’à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤¤à¥€à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤†à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥©, not in ÅšAV, â€˜à¤†à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥ª.à¥«.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥§. à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (1.51). G: 1.2.11. Translation: A short [syllable, i.e. a syllable with a short vowel], when not followed by a consonant cluster, is [metri- cally called] light.

186à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ Note: Whitney correctly takes the rule as referring to a syllable: â€œThe distinction of syllables, as regards their metrical value, is properly into light (laghu) and heavy (guru); long (dÄ«rgha) and short (hrasva) are terms to be used of vowels only. The neuter gender of the terms in the rule is to be explained by their agreement with aká¹£aram, â€˜syllable,â€™ understood.â€ While the CAB does not explicitly refer to the agreement with the term â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (not attested in any known Vedic text)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚.à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾. à¥¨à¥¯.à¥«, not attested in any Saá¹ƒhitÄ)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾187 à¥¨.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥«.à¥§à¥¬.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤‚à¤¶à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥à¥’à¤à¥à¤šâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨. à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤¤à¥€, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥ƒà¥’à¤¦à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥«.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤²à¤¶à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥ª.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾, à¤¶à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤• à¥¨à¥­, à¤ªà¥ƒ. à¥¨à¥¨, ed. by K.N.M. Divakara Dvijendra, Tripunithura, 1962)à¥¤ Note: For à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ and similar other examples, see: RPR (4.78): à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¨à¥„à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨. à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.52). G: 1.2.12. Translation: [Any] other syllable [is called] heavy. Note: Under the category of heavy syllable, we include (a) syllables with long vowels, and (b) syllables with short vowels followed by consonant clusters. BhÄrgava-BhÄskara also adds syllables which end in consonants and visarga. He adds one more category, i.e. syllables with specially accented vowels, i.e. syllables with svarita vowels. This last category is not substanti- ated by any other text, and probably rests on a faulty citation from Piá¹…galaâ€™s Chandaá¸¥sÅ«tra. BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s citation reads à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥, and this forces him to come up with this last category. The original reading from Piá¹…gala is: à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥. Here Piá¹…gala specifically adds the tri-moraic pluta vowels. This would be automatically taken care of by our CA rule. What is the purpose of defining the terms laghu and guru? These notions are not purposefully used ever again in the CA, the way they are used either by PÄá¹‡ini, or by the metrical texts. The commentary of KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa on this rule clearly says: à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ, â€˜there is no purpose for the terms light and heavy in this system.â€™ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™
