â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤½à¤‡à¥‘à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾189 à¥­.à¥ªà¥«.à¥§, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥ªà¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤—à¤¤à¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤†à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨ à¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ˆ à¤•à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µâ€™ (source?)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°[à¤¾]à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¡à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤ƒâ€™ (source?) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤­à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µ â€˜à¤µà¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¤•à¤¾ à¤¤à¥à¤­à¥Œ à¤œà¥Œ à¤—à¥Œâ€™ (à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒà¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥­.à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤²à¤˜à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥©. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.53). G: 1.2.13. Translation: [A syllable with] a nasalized [vowel is] also [heavy]. Note: From a metrical point of view of the late MIA period, there is a distinction between nasalizing a vowel and adding an anusvÄra. For instance, referring to Jaina Prakrits, A.M. Ghatage (1941: 11) says: â€œThe AnunÄsika does not change the quantity of a syllable, but AnusvÄra makes it long.â€ It is not quite clear what the situation was in Sanskrit, because the nasalized vowels are not attested in metrical texts where the nasalization would make metrical difference. PÄá¹‡ini distinguishes an anunÄsika from an anusvÄra, cf. P.8.3.4 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ). It is clear that nasalization has nothing to do with the light/contrast. What is not clear is whether an anusvÄra made a vowel long. However, the CA does not make any such clear distinction between an anusvÄra and an anunÄsika vowel, and while it does use the term anunÄsika, it does not use the term anusvÄra. Varma (1929: 148) argues that in spite of the fact that the CA does not use the term anusvÄra, it has the same notion of anusvÄra as other phonetic texts. For a detailed discussion of the complicated issues, see: Varma (1929: 148ff); Allen (1953: 40ff). In any case, the CA considers a nasalized short vowel to form a heavy syllable. In terms of its met- rical value, the notion of anunÄsika in the CA is functionally identical with that of anusvÄra elsewhere. For instance, verse (1.4) from Piá¹…galaâ€™s Chandaá¸¥sÅ«tra

190à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ quoted in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on the previous rule makes a sÄnusvÄra â€˜a vowel with the [following] anusvÄraâ€™ into a heavy syllable. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤š à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¿à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¥’à¤¶à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¤¤à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¥’à¤¶à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¥’à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¥’à¤¸- à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¥’à¤¤à¤à¥’ à¤à¤•à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬à¥§.à¥¬) à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª. à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.54). G: 1.2.14. I: à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ Translation: Also at the end of a word [before pause, as in the PadapÄá¹­ha, a syllable is considered to be heavy]. Note: The Sanskrit tradition is more familiar with short syllables at the end of metrical lines being treated heavy for metrical purposes. This accounts for the variant reading à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š in ms. I. Also see BhÄrgava- BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA (1.2.12). The examples cited by the CAB make Whitney think that the rule is re- stricted to such final syllables as end with a consonant, and in corroboration, he refers to TPR (xxii. 14. 15). However, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary in- cludes word-final short vowels, as well as final syllables with short vowels, ending in a consonant. This would indicate that in the recitation of the ÅšAV PadapÄá¹­ha as known to BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, the word-final short vowels were recited as long vowels. This possibility is missed by Whitney and Allen (1953: 85). Since such a recitational practice was commonplace for short vowels occurring at the end of metrical feet, it seems likely to have been ex- tended to all final vowels before pause.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾191 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤‚ à¤š à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥®.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥®.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥­. à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥«. à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (1.55). G: 1.2.15. Translation: [In the syllabic segmentation], consonants belong to the following vowel. Note: As Whitney notes, most PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas agree with each other on this doctrine. Thus, the word dadhi would be segmented into da-dhi, and madhu would be segmented into ma-dhu. Varma (1929: 55ff) has gone into a detailed examination of the rules of syllabication in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. Also see: Allen (1953: 81ff). This is of course a general rule. BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary offers many examples of word-initial consonant-clusters which go with the following vowel. Allen (1953: 82) considers the CA treatment of syllabic division as rep- resenting the generic rules. He also shows that other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas hold dif- fering views on this matter: â€œthe RP allows either the division of a medial consonant-group or its attachment in toto to the following vowel, and the TP attaches to the following vowel a group consisting of consonant+semivowel or stop+fricative.â€ Allen refers to Chatterjiâ€™s opinion that the NÄgarÄ« graphic system may be based on such a syllabic structure. My own conjecture is that the syllabic division allowed by these two texts may have been a result of confusing the notion of written syllable with a spoken syllable, as is certainly evidenced by the syllabic division of the famous GÄyatrÄ« mantra found in one of the Atharva-PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­as, i.e. Anulomakalpa (p.146, Atharvaveda-PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­a,

Translation: [A consonant occurring] at the beginning of a consonantal cluster belongs to the previous [syllable]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¤à¤¿â€™ (the only AV form, â€˜à¤†à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¤à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¤à¤¿â€™ (no attested AV forms for à¤ªà¥à¤°+à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤¹à¤¸à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ (à¤¸à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿?)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾193 Note: Compare a similar passage in the commentary on CA (3.2.3) and the Note thereupon for a possible reconstruction as: à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤¸à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿. While Whitney may be right in criticizing the CAB for offering fabri- cated examples like atra sati, it is not clear to me what to make of Whitneyâ€™s following comment: â€œhe (= commentator) does not note for us the fact that, in the combinations which he presents, the former consonant is to be doubled, by iii. 28, and then inform us to which of the two products of duplication the pre- cept of the rule applies.â€ The rule seems to be a generic enough rule, giving a basic principle, and it does not matter at this stage what the length of the con- sonant-cluster is. The passage of the commentary à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¤¹à¤¸à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ probably re- stores to à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤¸à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿. 194à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°-à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤«à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (not attested in known Vedic texts, late epic form)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥¬.à¥­)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­. à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.57). G: 1.2.17. Translation: A word-final consonant [before pause] also [belongs to the previous syllable]. Note: The term padya has been defined in CA (1.1.5: à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) as referring to the sound occurring at the end of a pada. Also see the Note on CA (1.1.7) for further clarification of the meaning of pada. Though the term gener- ally refers to an inflected item, it occasionally refers to members of compounds and to pre-affixal nominal bases. The CAB examples only illustrate the stan- dard word-final consonants. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥Œ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¥’à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤•â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¦(à¤°à¥à¤¤?)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript variation suhÄrt / suhÄá¸¥ for AV (2.7.5) is noted in the VVRI edition, as well as in the VVRI concordance, Sec. I, Pt. V, p. 3440.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾195 BhÄrgava-BhÄskara also points out that by the force of ca â€˜and,â€™ the rule also refers to anusvÄra and visarga as they occur before consonants (à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡). This would assume that the rule applies to the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, where the final sound of the previous word is immediately followed, without a gap, by the initial of the next word. It is doubtful whether the rule is meant to apply to word-final consonants in other than pre-pausal situations. In all prob- ability, the rule applies only to the PadapÄá¹­ha. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥®. à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤œà¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.58). G: 1.2.18. Translation: [A consonant] resulting from doubling (krama) [on account of the preceding] r and h [also belongs to the previous syllable along with the preceding r and h]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤œà¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¥à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤‚.à¤¶à¥.à¤¯. à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥®.à¥«; à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤µ.à¤¶à¥.à¤¯.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¯.à¥«.à¥©; à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥ª.à¥­.à¥«.à¥¨; à¤®à¥ˆ. à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥§à¥§.à¥«; not in AV, Whitneyâ€™s emendation: â€˜à¤…à¤°à¥à¤šà¥‘,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¬à¥¨.à¥«; not in AV, Whitneyâ€™s emendation: â€˜à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ,â€™ as in â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (?, à¤·à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£ à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¬; not in any Saá¹ƒhitÄ, Whitneyâ€™s emendation: â€˜à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒà¥‘,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥©à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ (not in Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤£à¥‡,â€™ à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥©à¥ª.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬. à¥ªà¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤ªà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in known Vedic texts, Whitneyâ€™s emendation: â€˜à¤…à¤ª à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿,â€™ not in known Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in known Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤ªà¤¹à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in known Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in known Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤

196à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ Note: Whitney justifiably complains about the lack of specificity in the explanation given by the CAB, and the lax orthography of the examples as found in the mss. does not offer any help either. However, what the rule means is clear. CA (3.2.8: à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥), like P.8.4.46 (à¤…à¤šà¥‹ à¤°à¤¹à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡), prescribes doubling of the consonant following r and h. Thus, for instance, in the example arkaá¸¥, by applying CA (3.2.8), we get the sequence arkkaá¸¥. The present rule then says that the first of the doubled consonant, along with the preceding r or h, becomes part of the previous syllable, i.e. the syllabic division is ark-kaá¸¥, rather than ar-kkaá¸¥. The writing of the mss. does not show these doubled consonants in the examples. Whitney includes the example à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ on the basis of other passages in his manuscript, though this example is not found in the commentary on this rule in the manuscript H which was the only manuscript accessible to Whitney. Interestingly, the manuscript N supports Whitneyâ€™s inclusion of this example. Also see the commentary on CA (3.2.8) and the Note thereupon. The only Saá¹ƒhitÄ form attested for vi+!hnu imanuscript variant vihnutasya for vi- hvrÌ¥tasya in PAV (20.13.8). Also compare the text of the commentary on CA 3.2.8. The readings of the examples there support Whitneyâ€™s emendations in most cases. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ƒ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯- à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤œà¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥ƒà¥’à¤¹à¥à¤£à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: We are happily surprised that BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commen- tary answers all the objections Whitney had against the CAB. It gives a crisp interpretation, and the ms. G shows the doubled consonants in writing. Be- sides other elements in the interpretation, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara appropriately points out that this doubling of the consonant after r or h occurs only if this group comes after a vowel (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥). This condition on CA (3.2.8: à¤°à¥‡à¤«- à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥) is provided by the continuing expression svarÄt from CA (3. 2.3). Unfortunately, the CAB on CA (3.2.3) does not make this clear. With this condition, CA (3.2.8) becomes a close equivalent of P.8.4.46 (à¤…à¤šà¥‹ à¤°à¤¹à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾197 à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¯. à¤à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.59). G: 1.2.19. Most mss. read rhasvaá¸¥. Translation: [A vowel] with one mora [duration] is called â€œshort.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥¨à¥­.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥¨) à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤‚ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤®â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥®.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤µà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤¯â€™ (only attested AV form: â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤¯à¥Œ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥©.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µâ€™ (â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the Indian attempts to fix the duration of vowels etc. in minute units of 1/8 of a mora etc., Allen (1953: 84) says: â€œthis un- phonological approach undergoes a further degeneration in statements such as the following (from the PÄá¹‡inÄ«ya-Åšiká¹£Ä verse 49): â€˜1 mÄtrÄ is equivalent to the cry of the blue jay, 2 mÄtrÄs to that of the crow, 3 mÄtrÄs to that of the pea- cock, and 1/2 mÄtrÄ to that of the mongoose.â€™â€ I certainly agree with Allen that such descriptions are unphonological. However, I do not believe that it rep- resents any degeneration. Part of the problem lies in using the dichotomy of phonetic versus phonological in reference to Indian texts, which know of no such overt theoretical distinction. I have discussed some of these issues in the Introduction. Secondly, once we realize that a mÄtrÄ is a unit of time, there ought to be at least an approximate indication of how long a unit of time a mÄtrÄ is and such a need is fulfilled by the statements like the one quoted from the PÄá¹‡inÄ«ya-Åšiká¹£Ä. Another reason I am not willing to accept the notion of degeneration is that it assumes that the earlier texts were free from this practice. However, even the great PÄá¹‡ini seems to refer to a rooster-call in his rule defining the duration of short, long and extra-long vowels, cf. P.1.2.27 (à¤Šà¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‹à¤½à¤œà¥à¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ)Whitney also refers to RPR (xiii. 20) which â€œattempts to fix the length of the short, long, and protracted vowels, by comparing them with the cries of certain birds.â€ Many texts in Indian music also define the

198à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ various musical notes by referring to bird-calls. In a pre-modern age, these were the only available means of approximately indicating the length, pitch etc. The one point which goes against trying to fix the absolute duration of short, long etc. is that the Sanskrit grammarians do admit that there are different modes of delivery (vrÌ¥tti) such as fast (druta), medium (madhya), and slow (vilambita), and that fixing absolute durations would militate against the notion of different speeds of delivery. Whitney, I believe, is correct in saying: â€œIt is the fundamental measure, which cannot itself be defined by anything else.â€ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¦. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.60). G: 1.2.20. Translation: The consonants too [are of one-mora duration each]. Note: Almost all other texts consider consonants to be of half-mora length. The commentary of BhÄrgava-BhÄskara struggles in vain to reconcile the CA view with the general view. It does bring up the topic of the possible metrical value of setting a specific duration for consonants, but does not tackle it successfully. For a clear analysis of this subject, see: Allen (1953: 86). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¤à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥¨à¥­.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥¨) à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤- à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ (à¥¤) à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤•- à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¯à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾- à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥¬.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤

Translation: [A vowel] with two-mora [duration] is a long [vowel]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥©.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¥à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¥‚â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥„à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥„à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥©à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦. à¥©à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¥‹â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥­.à¥§à¥¬) à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥Œâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥¨à¥¯.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¨. à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.62). G: 1.2.22. I: 21. Translation: [A vowel] with three-mora [duration] is a pro- longed (pluta) [vowel]. Note: By convention, number 3 is written after a long vowel to indi- cate a pluta vowel. Also note that PataÃ±jali occasionally refers to pluta vowels with four mÄtrÄs, cf. MB on P.1.1.51, (Kielhorn edn.), Vol. I, p. 120. On P.8.2.106, PataÃ±jali clearly says that a pluta of four mora duration is desirable: à¤‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ. Allen (1953: 84) notes: â€œThe pluta or protracted vowel … is of rare occurrence and is bound to a very limited series of contexts; it represents the over-lengthening of the final vowel of a word or phrase and is used â€˜in cases of questioning, especially of a balancing between two alterna- tives, and also of calling to a distance or urgently. For most phonological pur- poses, however, the pluta vowel may be ignored.â€ We need to keep in mind that there are occasions for non-final vowels undergoing protraction, cf. P.8.2.86 (à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥ˆà¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤®à¥). Also see CA (4.4.21: à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¤à¥), CA (1.4.6: à¤…à¤µà¤¶à¤¾ à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥© à¤‡à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ) and P.6.1.129 (à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡)

200à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ for non-pluta-like behavior of pluta vowels in certain contexts. All pluta vowels found in the text of the ÅšAV are listed under CA (1.4.14). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°(à¤ƒ) à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¥‘à¤¯à¤¾à¥© à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¥©à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§à¥®)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨. à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤à¥’à¥©â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦. à¥§à¥ªà¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤–à¤£à¥à¤µà¤–à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤–à¥ˆà¤®à¤–à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤–à¤£à¥à¤µà¥’à¤–à¤¾à¥©à¤‡à¥’ à¤–à¥ˆà¤®à¥’à¤–à¤¾à¥©à¤‡à¥’ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥«)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥€à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥¬à¥¨ à¥¤ C, E, F: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ A, B, D, J, M, P: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ I: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ G: à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤—- à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¥¤ O: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥§ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥¬à¥¨à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤­à¤¾- à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¥¤ à¥¨ à¥¤ ____________________________________

à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µ- à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¨à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¥à¥©à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥©.à¥§. à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ [à¥¤] à¤¦à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.63), G, O, P: combine this rule with the following. G: 1.3.1. B, C (corr), D, Hc, J, M (corr): à¤·à¥‹ for à¤¸à¥‹. E, G, I, Na (corr) read Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‹Â°, but others read Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤¸à¥‹Â°. Na (orig), Ha: à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥‹Â°. O: Â°à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤•à¤¾Â°. A, B, C, D, M: Â°à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤šÂ°, others: Â°à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¶à¥à¤šÂ° Translation: The final [consonants] of á¹£aá¹£ and puras are replaced with u before the words daÅ›a and dÄÅ›a, respectively, and the initial [d] of these two words is replaced with a cere- bral [á¸]. Note: Whitney points out that the words á¹£oá¸aÅ›a and puroá¸ÄÅ›a are not analyzed in the PadapÄá¹­ha, and are not restored to their theoretical original form in their repetition. This point is also made by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara: à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯- à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤‚à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤‚ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹, à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ. In a way, Whitney is right in saying: â€œand our treatise, accordingly, according to its own programme, has nothing to do with them: and the same is true of the words referred to in the three following rules.â€ The original reason why these words are not analyzed in the PadapÄá¹­ha may be identical with sandehÄt â€˜excessive fusion / confusion of the consti- tuentsâ€™ given in CA (4.2.5: à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥). See the Note on CA (4.2.5). The rules here mark progress of the analytical tradition beyond the state of sandeha manifest in the PadapÄá¹­ha. This is a move in the direction of general grammar. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - (à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹- à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) à¤·à¤Ÿà¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥(H: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·, N: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤¸) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤¯)à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 202 à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤·à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥’à¤¶à¤®à¥â€™, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¥Œà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) à¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¡à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤·à¤·à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶â€™ (â€˜à¤·à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥’à¤¶à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥®.à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡- à¤µà¤‚à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤‚ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥©.à¥¨. à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.64). G: 1.3.2. Translation: The r of [the root] !krÌ¥p is replaced by l. Note: The rule is expected to apply to both, the r which is inside the vowel rÌ¥ (âˆ‚râˆ‚), as well as r occurring independently. Thus, effectively the rule changes krÌ¥p to klÌ¥p, and karp to kalp. The commentary CAB on this rule is missing in the manuscript H, and hence was not available to Whitney. It is, however, found in the ms. N. The CaturÄdhyÄyÄ«bhÄá¹£ya offers examples of krÌ¥p changing to klÌ¥p, but not of karp changing to kalp. Such examples from the text of the ÅšAV are offered by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara. This rule also marks an advance beyond the PadapÄá¹­ha, which does not change l > r. There is also no SamÄpatti of l to r. Thus, one may make a conjecture that the awareness of such a linkage of krÌ¥p to klÌ¥p may have arisen in the post-PadapÄá¹­ha period. Compare P.8.2.18 (à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤°à¥‹ à¤²à¤ƒ). Also note that PÄá¹‡ini refers to the root as krÌ¥p, while the CA refers to the root with the form krÌ¥pi, with krÌ¥peá¸¥ as a genitive. Whitney also makes an interesting comment: â€œNone of the other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas offers anything equivalent. If our treatise has set itself to note the words in which a l appears in the place of a more original r, it should not pass over the words in which the root car becomes cal, as avicÄcala, puá¹ƒÅ›calÄ«, etc., glaha and glahana, which are hardly to be separated from the root grah, udum- bala (viii.6.17), etc.â€ One can perhaps derive a different inference from the rule as it stands, as well as from a number of rules that follow. While in this case, the change of krÌ¥p to klÌ¥p is taught by the rule, suggesting that an etymological

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾203 linkage was acceptable to Indian grammarians, other cases mentioned by Whitney may not have been so acceptable to them. For example, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s DhÄtupÄá¹­ha separately lists car, cal, grah, and glah. On the other hand, as CA (1.3.4: à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ …) indicates, the author of the CA asks us to change l to r in a number of words, where modern linguists may perhaps think of the re- verse direction of historical change. In any case, the rule does not indicate any â€˜historicalâ€™ change. It does indicate, however, that for some not very explicit reasons, the r was felt to be derivationally more basic in some words, while in other words the sound l was felt to be more basic. For a similar discussion, see: PataÃ±jali on P.8.2.18 (à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤°à¥‹ à¤²à¤ƒ). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤šà¥€à¥‘- à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤à¥à¤šà¥’à¤¦à¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤•à¥¢à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯. à¥§à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤šà¥€à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‡à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤šà¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥‡â€™ (â€˜à¤šà¤¾à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥‡,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥«.à¥§à¥¬.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥¢à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV, à¤•à¤ .à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨à¥®.à¥®, à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤‚.à¤¶à¥.à¤¯.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥®.à¥§à¥§, à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤µ. à¤¶à¥.à¤¯.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¯.à¥©.à¥¨, à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥ª.à¥­.à¥¨.à¥¨, à¤®à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥§à¥§.à¥©, à¤•à¤¾à¤ à¤•.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥®.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤™à¥à¤•à¥’à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤•à¥à¥‘à¤²à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¾â€™, à¤•à¤¾à¤ à¤•.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥©à¥«.à¥«, à¤•à¤ . à¤¸à¤‚. à¥ªà¥®.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤¯à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥«à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤•à¥‘à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥ªà¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤ƒ à¤Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥©.à¥©. à¤¨ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.65). G: 1.3.3. Translation: [However, the change of r to l in the forms of the root krÌ¥p] does not occur in words like krÌ¥pÄ.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 204 Note: As Whitney points out: â€œThis is the first instance in our treatise of a rule stated in this form, the words or phrases to which the precept con- tained in the rule refers being conceived to form a series, or gaá¹‡a, of which the first only is given in the rule, and the others comprehended in an et cetera. The form of statement is characteristic of the Atharva PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya (= CA) and of PÄá¹‡ini.â€ It is possible that the CA itself intended â€˜et cetera,â€™ and may not have had a fixed list in mind. No fixed list is known to the APR, or the commenta- tors. PataÃ±jali, under P.8.2.18 (à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤°à¥‹ à¤²à¤ƒ), also makes a similar statement: à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¥‹ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤£à¤ƒ, à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ, à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥€à¤Ÿà¤®à¥. Referring to krÌ¥paá¹‡aá¸¥ and kÄrpaá¹‡yam, Whitney says: â€œIf these two words, which come from altogether another root, actually belong to the gaá¹‡a, it should contain also krÌ¥pamÄá¹‡asya (v.19.13) and akrÌ¥pran (xviii.3.23).â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤ªà¤¾ à¤ªà¤¾à¥‘à¤µà¤•â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤£à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥®.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤ª- à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (not in known Vedic texts, a late epic form)à¥¤ Note: While the manuscript H contains the reading à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ, Whitneyâ€™s conjecture à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒ is supported by the manuscript N. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾205 Note: By citing examples like krÌ¥pÄá¹‡a, kÄrpaá¹‡ya, and karpaá¹­a, which do not appear in Vedic texts, the commentaries are using the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya rules to account for words of the later classical language. à¥§.à¥©.à¥ª. à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.66), Hac: Â°à¤²à¤¿Â° for Â°à¤°à¤¿Â°. A, B, P(corr): Daá¹‡á¸a after à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ. G: 1.3.4. Translation: In pÄdam aá¹…gurim etc., the sound l is replaced by r. Note: In his translation, Whitney says â€˜In pÄdam aá¹…gulim etc.â€™ This is because, following his lone ms. H, he reads the rule itself as â€˜… pÄdam aá¹…gulim …â€™ This is not supported by other manuscripts. However, Whitney did guess correctly: â€œIt is not in accordance with the usage of our treatise else- where to give, in citing a word or phrase in a rule, another form than that which it actually has it in the text: we should have expected here à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿Â°.â€ Whitneyâ€™s expectation is supported by the mss. Again it is not clear here if the text of the CA intended a fixed set of instances. The commentary of BhÄrgava- BhÄskara probably correctly says that the expression Ädi in the rule is to refer to this type of examples: à¤†à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿- à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‘à¤®à¥’à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥®.à¥¬; à¥«. à¥©à¥§.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹ à¤®à¥‚à¥‘à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¥‘ à¤¦à¤¹â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¤¿ à¤®à¥’à¤¯à¥‚à¤°à¥‘à¤°à¥‹à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥§à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤ª(H, N: à¤ªà¥)à¤°à¥à¥’à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤†à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¤¿à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¥’à¤–à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¥€à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤†à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¯à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¦à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·- à¤£à¤®à¥â€™ (MahÄbhÄá¹£ya, on the ÅšivasÅ«tra â€˜à¤²à¤£à¥,â€™ Kielhorn-edn.,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾207 à¤¯.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥«.à¥¨, à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤µ.à¤¶à¥.à¤¯.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥«.à¥«.à¥¯, à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§.à¥¨. à¥§à¥©.à¥©, à¤®à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥¯, à¤•à¤¾à¤ à¤•.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦, à¤•à¤ .à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤²à¤²à¤¾à¤Ÿà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥­.à¥§, VVRI edn., à¥¯.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ Note: Referring to the testimony of the Vedic reciters used by S.P. Pandit, Lanman says: â€œThe student should bear in mind the especial weight of the oral testimony in cases where errors of the eye, as distinguished from errors of the ear, are probable. Thus the testimony of the reciters, at ix.8(13).20, establishes the reading visalpa-, as against visalya- of the Berlin text. Save in AV., the word is otherwise unknown, and, the ms.-distinction between lya and lpa in such a case is worthless, the instance is a typical one to show the value of the recitersâ€™ reading: see Wâ€™s note to vi.127.1,â€ Editorâ€™s in- troduction, Whitneyâ€™s AV translation, Vol. I, pp. lxvi-lxvii. It may thus be said that, to some extent, BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s reading visalpaka is closer to the reading offered by the Vedic reciters. Also, it may be noted that while one does observe the variation visalpaka / visarpaka, the same cannot be said for the word visalyaka, which marks a greater deviation. As Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 967) informs: â€œFor visalpakas (in AV 1the comm. gives visarpakas, explaining it as vividhaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aÅ›Ä«lo vraá¹‡aviÅ›eá¹£aá¸¥; Ppp. has viÅ›a- lyakas.â€ In his commentary, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara has given a very interesting collection of examples where the sounds r and l occur as variants. Some of these examples are also offered by PataÃ±jali on P.8.2.18: à¤µà¤¾à¤²à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤µà¤²à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤²à¥‹ à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤˜à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤²à¤‚ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯ à¤…à¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¬à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¬à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤°à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤²à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¥à¤µà¤¿- à¤²à¥€à¤•à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤°à¥‹à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤²à¥‹à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤²à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤® à¤•à¤²à¥à¤® à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥à¤²à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥©.à¥«. à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.67). G: 1.3.5. Translation: In the case of a deletion of n and m, the previous [vowel] is nasalized.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 208 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤à¥’à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¯à¥‘à¤¾à¤à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤£à¥à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤ à¤…à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¯)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤£à¥€à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤£à¥€ à¤à¤°à¥‘à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥§. à¥­)à¥¤ à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤ªâ€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤¯à¥‚à¤‚à¤°à¥à¤¤,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª. à¥©à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥„à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥„à¤à¤°à¥à¤ªà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: Referring to the CAB, Whitney says: â€œThe commentator offers here only the words viá¹ƒÅ›atiá¸¥ (e.g. v.15.2) and payÄá¹ƒsi (e.g. i.9.3) - which are very ill chosen, since, though each offers an example of a nasalized vowel, neither exhibits an elision of an original nasal mute, according to any rules contained in this treatise.â€ One must however point out that in the example payÄá¹ƒsi, at least according to the PÄá¹‡inian derivation, one would have a dele- tion of an n. Compare the examples offered by the commentators under P.8.3.24 (à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤²à¤¿). One crucial difference is that the PÄá¹‡inian com- mentators assume that a form like yaÅ›Äá¹ƒsi is derived from the string yaÅ›Äns+i, where the n is replaced by the anusvÄra by P.8.3.24. Instead of the notion of an anusvÄra, the CAB speaks of an anunÄsika as a replacement for the vowel preceding the deleted n. It is, however, not clear if such examples were in- tended by the author of the CA, and whether he intended a similar derivation for forms like payÄá¹ƒsi. The deficiency pointed out by Whitney is made up by some of the examples offered by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara. However, some of his examples, would properly come under the next rule. Additionally, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara says that the inclusion of m serves no purpose in this rule, except that n and m together continue into the following rules. For the last example quoted by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, see CA 2.1.28. à¥§.à¥©.à¥¬. à¤¯à¤°à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.68). G: 1.3.6. E, F, G, I, J (corr), O: à¤ªà¤°à¥‹Â° for à¤¯à¤°à¥‹Â°.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾209 Translation: Also when [n and m] are changed [in sandhi] to y, r, or a spirant. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¥à¥‘à¤¾à¤ à¤‡à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤²à¤¾à¥’- à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤à¥’ à¤‡à¥‘à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤–à¤²à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¾à¤ à¤‡à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤‹à¤¤à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¬.à¥§à¥«à¥§.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¥’à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥- à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¥‘à¤œà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‹ à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥’à¤£à¥€ à¤à¤°à¥’à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥§.à¥­) (H adds: â€˜à¤®à¥‹ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿â€™)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤¯à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¤ à¤¬à¥‹à¥‘à¤§à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¥’à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¥‘à¤œà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: The example à¤‹à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤‹à¤¤à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ cited by the CAB is not found in the Vulgate of the AV, and Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. The last three examples cited by the CAB are found under APR (197). The last comment made by the CAB is not immediately clear. What does the term punar-grahaá¹‡a refer to? Whitney says: â€œAs the n must always be converted into the spirant visarjanÄ«ya before it becomes y, it seems superfluous to make separate mention of the latter in the rule. The commentator apparently feels this objection, and ventures for once a defense, as follows: Å«á¹£maá¹‡o grahaá¹‡Ät siddhe punargrahaá¹‡ena kim : nityatvaá¹ƒ na syÄt : rÌ¥tuÌƒr utsrÌ¥jate vaÅ›Ä«; â€˜when the matter is made certain by the use of the term Å«á¹£man, why any farther mention? It is because this does not apply to all cases, as is shown by the instance rÌ¥tuÌƒr utsrÌ¥jate vaÅ›Ä«.â€™ I do not see the point of this defense: it does, indeed explain the mention of r in the rule, but it has nothing to do with that of y.â€ CA 2.1.29 (à¤‹à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¶à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) requires the obligatory change of an n into an r in the listed examples. Thus, in this case, r is not covered by the term Å«á¹£man, and hence its separate mention is necessary. How about y? Whitney says, an n must first change to a visarjanÄ«ya before it becomes y. If such is the case, then why is it mentioned again? I think the explanation given by the commentator applies more aptly to the case of y, though his example only illustrates the case of r. In an example like rathÄn iva, the final n first changes to a visarjanÄ«ya by CA (2.1.27: à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡). Then the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 210 visarjanÄ«ya is changed to y by CA (2.2.2: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ). Finally, by CA (2.1.21: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ), this y is deleted. The commentator assumes the following dilemma. One could apply CA (1.3.6) at the stage rathÄá¸¥ iva and change this to rathÄÌƒá¸¥ iva, with the assumption that the vowel Ä is followed by á¸¥, an Å«á¹£man. However, if one chose not to do so, and change á¸¥ first to y, then, in the stage rathÄy iva, one may not be able to nasalize Ä without a distinct mention of y. In part, this brings up the question of whether a substitute can be treated as being a functional equivalent of the original (sthÄnivadbhÄva). The fact that the rule separately mentions y may be taken as an indication that the CA implicitly had a doctrine of sthÄnivadbhÄva (cf. P.1.1.56 à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤²à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥Œ), where the restriction analvidhau â€˜not in operations dependent on the specific soundâ€™ would have prevented the substitute y from being attributed the phonological properties of the á¸¥ it replaced. The reading found in BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary, however, is à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š, and it has been interpreted in a substantially different manner by this commentary. The significant thing to note is that this reading is not unique to BhÄrgava-BhÄskara, but is supported by a number of other manuscripts, i.e. E, F, G, I, J (corr), O. This includes the entire Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a tradition. In spite of the manuscript support, I do not believe that this is the original reading. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š) à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤£ à¤†à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤Ÿà¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤à¤¶à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§à¥¬.à¥¨à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤à¤¶à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤à¤¹à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥©à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤ªà¥‚à¤à¥‘à¤·à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¿à¤à¥’à¤¹à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Vishva Bandhuâ€™s Grammatical Word-Index to Atharvaveda, p. 671, lists ÅšAV (11.6.21) for an instance of haá¹ƒsaá¸¥. The verse does not con- tain haá¹ƒsaá¸¥, but aá¹ƒhasaá¸¥, and its inclusion is a simple error which should be corrected. à¥§.à¥©.à¥­. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (1.69). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾211 Translation: Also, when a nasalized [vowel] combined with a preceding [non-nasal] vowel is replaced by a single substitute, [that single substitute becomes nasalized]. Note: The existence of a rule such as this may be an indication that a doctrine similar to PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule P. 1.1.50 (à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ) is not fully developed in the CA tradition. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s procedure requires that a substitute should be maximally similar in phonetic features to the original it replaced. Such a gene- ric convention obviates the need for further specialized rules like CA (1.3.7). BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary correctly says that the author of the CA feared that, without such a special rule, the combined result of a nasal and a non-nasal vowel would be a non-nasal [lit. Å›uddha â€˜pureâ€™] vowel. The exam- ple illustrates how PÄá¹‡ini was working with a more refined and comprehensive phonological apparatus as compared with that of the CA. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¥‘à¤ªà¤¾à¤à¥’à¤¶à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¥à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¿à¥‘à¤¬à¤¾à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤à¤¶à¥‹ (N: à¤¶à¤µà¥‹)â€™(à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥®à¥§. à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤°à¥€à¥’à¤¹à¤¯à¥‹à¥’ à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¥‘ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¤à¤½à¤¶à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: Regarding the last example quoted by the commentary, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 540) points out: â€œThe Anukr. requires -yante aá¹ƒÅ›- to be read, although the passage is quoted under PrÄt. 1.69 (= CA 1.3.8) as an example of the elision of initial a with the transfer of its nasalization to the eliding e.â€ The mss. in this case follow the CA prescription, and it is diffi- cult to see why there is not a single ms. which follows the Anukramaá¹‡Ä«. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿- à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¤½à¤…à¤à¤¶à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤à¤¶à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤à¥’à¤¶à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤à¤½à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥©.à¥®. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥© à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (1.70), C, Hb, N, O: do not have à¥©. E, F: use à¤½ for à¥©. G: 1.3.8.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 212 Translation: In the passage puruá¹£a Ä babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3 (AV 10.2. 28), [the final vowel of the word babhÅ«va is replaced by a protracted nasalized vowel] before the pause. Note: The expression avasÄne is used to restrict this change only to the pre-pausal environment. Therefore, this change does not take place when babhÅ«va is combined with iti in the ParihÄra which is part of the Krama recitation. It is not immediately clear whether the rule says anything about what happens in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ, or applies only negatively in the Krama recitation. Whitney seems to prefer almost a negative interpretation: â€œThe pada text reads simply puruá¹£aá¸¥ : Ä : babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3 : and there would be no call for such a rule as that given here, but for the requirements of the krama text, in which babhÅ«va as the last word in a verse, must suffer parihÄra (iv.117 = CA 4.4.18), or repetition with iti interposed, and in which it might be made a question whether the nasality of the vowel should or should not be preserved before iti. This rule teaches us that the nasal quality is lost before the iti.â€ I believe Whitneyâ€™s interpretation is too indirect. The straight forward interpretation is that the final vowel of the expression à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥’ à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µ becomes [prolonged, and] nasalized, before a pause. The fact that it remains non-nasal before iti is an indirect consequence. By mentioning the whole sequence à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥’ à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©, the CA indicates that this change occurs only in this sequence, and not in every case of babhÅ«va. Whitneyâ€™s dilemma arises because of the fact that the PadapÄá¹­ha already has babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3, and hence such a rule is not needed either for the Pada text or the Saá¹ƒhitÄ. However, the CA may not always be proceeding from the Pada form to Saá¹ƒhitÄ form, but occasionally it seems to proceed from the normal form, e.g. babhÅ«va to both the Pada and Saá¹ƒhitÄ forms. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥’ à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤[à¥©]â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤…à¤µ- à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤[à¥©]â€™à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤²à¤¿à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½- à¤°à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤šà¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤[à¤ƒ] à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤• à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¤à¥ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥’ à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µ[à¤ƒ] à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µ-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾213 à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥’ à¤† à¤¬à¥‘à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’ à¤­à¥€à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¤à¥€à¥©à¤â€™ à¥¤ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥ªà¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: BhÄrgava-BhÄskara assumes that the word babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3 is cited to refer to the a class of similar examples, and thus the rule also accounts for similar examples in RV. Or perhaps he means: itiÅ›abdaá¸¥ prakÄrÄrthaá¸¥. In any case, he wishes to extend the scope of this rule beyond its intention. This indicates that the late commentators on the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas were under the generalizing influence of systems like that of PÄá¹‡ini. The rule is originally in- tended to apply only to the word babhÅ«va as it occurs in the specified context, and not to any other instance, let alone to other examples in texts like the RV. à¥§.à¥©.à¥¯. à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.71). G: 1.3.9. Translation: [In becoming nasalized], for rÌ¥ vowels [= âˆ‚râˆ‚], the [vocalic] part following r [becomes nasal, i.e. âˆ‚râˆ‚Ì]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¥ƒà¤à¥’à¤¹à¤®à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥à¥‘à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤£à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«. à¥¨à¥®.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤à¤¹à¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥©à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤à¥’à¤¹- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥¯)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°- à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¥„à¤¨à¥ ….. â€˜à¤¨à¥„à¤á³² à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾â€™ (â€˜à¤¨à¥„à¤á³² à¤ªà¥à¤°- à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿, VSM edn. of the RV, Vol. 4, à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯, à¤ªà¥ƒ. à¥¯à¥®à¥©, à¤‹à¤•à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯ à¥ª.à¥­à¥®)à¥¤ Note: Commenting upon this rule, Whitney says: â€œHere we learn that, when such a vowel is nasalized, the nasal quality does not affect the r, but only the part of a vowel which follows it. Anyone may perceive, however, upon

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 214 trying the experiment, that there is no physical difficulty in the way of nasalizing the r itself.â€ Whitney clearly disregards the fact that the entire tradi- tion of Sanskrit grammar and phonetics is united in declaring that there is no nasal counterpart for r, as indeed there are for y, v, and l. Thus, there was no question of nasalizing the r element. However, it was a legitimate question whether the first vocalic element which precedes the r also becomes nasal. The question becomes all the more necessary, since, in passages like à¤‹à¥’à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¥‘à¤œà¤¤à¥‡ (AV 6.36.2), the consonant r is preceded by a nasal vowel. An explanation of why the latter vocalic fraction becomes lengthened or is nasalized, and not the previous one, may be found in the fact that the vowel rÌ¥ was pronounced in most of the historical period as either ri or ru, and in these pronunciations, the preceeding vocalic fraction almost went unrepresented, and the following vocalic fraction was given a more distinct form. From the present rule, one can infer that the pronunciation of rÌ¥ known to the CA was closer to ri or ru, and hence the only vowel which could be lengthened or nasalized was the vowel following the consonantal r. This is also known indirectly from earlier evidence; i.e., dreÅ›ya, see: Wackernagel, I. 31. à¥§.à¥©.à¥§à¥¦. à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (1.72). G combines this with the next rule and numbers it 1.3.10. Translation: The u as a monophonic [morpheme] is nasal- ized before the word iti [in the PadapÄá¹­ha]. Note: The term aprÌ¥kta literally means â€˜uncombined.â€™ However, P.1.2.41 (à¤…à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ) defines it as referring to an affix that consists of a single sound. In the usage of the CA (1.3.10, 1.3.17, and 4.4.14), it refers to particles which consist of a single vowel. Cf. TPR (1.54) and VPR (1.151). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤Šà¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š) à¤…à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤…à¤µà¥ˆà¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾215 à¥§.à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤â€™ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤‹à¤•à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤˜à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥‡à¤¨â€™ (à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿- à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯ à¥§.à¥­à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤‰ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤°à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Note: Whitney says: â€œIn the pada- text of the Atharvan, as in those of the other Vedas, the particle u is always written uÌƒ iti.â€ BhÄrgava-BhÄskara on the other hand informs us that this practice is not followed by some schools like the TaittirÄ«yas. This is supported by the printed text of the PadapÄá¹­ha of the TS (e.g. 1.1.4, VSM edn, Vol.I., Pt.I., p 71). à¥§.à¥©.à¥§à¥§. à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.73). E, F: omit the Visarga. G combines this with the preceding. I: 16. Translation: [The monophonic particle u, before the word iti in the PadapÄá¹­ha] is also lengthened and is treated as a pra- grÌ¥hya [i.e. is not combined in sandhi with the following iti]. Note: Whitney starts out by saying, â€œAny satisfactory reason why the particle u should be treated in this peculiar manner by the framers of the pada- text is not readily apparent,â€ but comes up with the most likely explanation: â€œIt seems as if the protraction must have been made in order to give the word more substance as an independent pada in the disjoined text, it being the only in- stance of a single short vowel possessing such a value; and as if the nasaliza- tion and addition of iti were intended to mark it more distinctly as an excep- tional case, requiring a different treatment in the saá¹ƒhitÄ-text. PÄá¹‡ini (i.1.17, 18) allows it to be read either u or Å«nÌ.â€ Also see the MB on P.1.1.17 for problems involved in interpreting PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules. As BhÄrgava-BhÄskara notes on the previous rule, the PadapÄá¹­ha of the TaittirÄ«ya-Saá¹ƒhitÄ does not show lengthening, nasalization, or the addition of the word iti to u. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - See the previous rule.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 216 à¥§.à¥©.à¥§à¥¨. à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (1.74). C, Hb, N: omit à¤š. Hb, Nb: à¤‡ for à¤ˆ. G: 1.3.11. Translation: [Word-final] Ä« and Å«, when the formation has a locative sense, are also treated as pragrÌ¥hya [i.e. are not com- bined in sandhi with the following vowel, e.g. i of iti added after a pragrÌ¥hya word in the PadapÄá¹­ha]. Note: The significance of this rule, and the rules which follow, lies in that they offer us some insight into the fact that the PadapÄá¹­ha occasionally gives indications of a syntactic-semantic understanding of the words of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ. Generally speaking, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas do not concern themselves with matters of syntax, except when such syntactic/semantic matters are explicitly reflected in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Another curious fact may also be noted. The CA rule, as well as PÄá¹‡ini (1.1.19: à¤ˆà¤¦à¥‚à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡), treat forms like Äá¹£á¹­rÄ« and urvÄ« as being in the sense of a locative (saptamy-arthe), rather than being irregular Vedic locative forms. It is clear that these forms are viewed by the PadapÄá¹­ha as being exceptional forms. Perhaps, after noticing the absence or deletion of the normal locative affix, there was a certain hesitation to categorize them clearly as locatives (saptamÄ«), though it was clear that the forms had a locative meaning. Also see: MB on P.1.1.19. As Whitney notes, in all these instances, these forms are given as pragrÌ¥hyas in the PadapÄá¹­ha, followed by iti. However, that by itself does not tell us whether the author of the PadapÄá¹­ha intended these forms to be duals, or forms in the locative sense. In any case, the commentators seem to be in fur- ther disarray. On RV (9.12.3), both Venkaá¹­amÄdhava and SÄyaá¹‡a paraphrase the form gaurÄ« with gauryÄm, and SÄyaá¹‡a says: à¤—à¥Œà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. The AV examples, on the other hand, have been treated rather in an inconsis- tent way by [Pseudo]SÄyaá¹‡a. The form Äá¹£á¹­rÄ« (AV 6.27.3) is simply para- phrased with the locative Äá¹£á¹­ryÄá¹ƒ. The form tanÅ« (AV 4.25.5) is actually treated as a locative form, with the locative affix deleted: à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤²à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥­.à¥§.à¥©à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤²à¥à¤•à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ˆà¤¦à¥‚à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾. On the other hand, the form urvÄ« (AV 18.1.32) is taken as an accusative dual and is paraphrased with urvyau. Even though this does not understand the word in the locative sense, it at least accounts for why the word is treated as a pragrÌ¥hya in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Finally, the form mahÄ« (AV 18.1.39) is taken either as an irregular accusative singular (à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ƒ), or it is construed with vÄtÄá¸¥ in the same verse (à¤…à¤¥ à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡). In either

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾217 case, the explanations do not account for why the word should be treated as a pragrÌ¥hya by the PadapÄá¹­ha. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¥€ à¤ªà¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¨à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¥‘ à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘ à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‰à¥’à¤°à¥à¤µà¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥©à¥¨)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤°à¥à¤µà¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¥€ à¤¨à¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥©à¥¯)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥‚ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥‚ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™à¥¤ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¥€à¥’à¤¤à¥€ à¤µà¤¾à¥’ à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ Note: The CAB cites all the same examples as found under APR (63), though in this case the examples occur in a slightly different order. One should also note that the CA rule is identical in wording with APR (63). This means that at least for these two texts, the forms concerned are all in the sense of the locative case. Also note the reading à¤…à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥’à¤¦à¤®à¥ … found in RV (10.165.3) which proves the equivalence of Äá¹£á¹­rÄ« and Äá¹£á¹­ryÄm. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¶à¤•à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤- à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¤¦à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤  âˆ€) â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥‚ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¶à¥‡à¤µà¥‘à¤®à¥ à¥¤â€™ (à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ âˆ€) â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥‚ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤µà¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥«.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥‹à¥‘ à¤—à¤¾à¥ˆà¥’à¤°à¥€ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: The example from the RV is cited by Uvaá¹­a in his commentary on RPR (2.52: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥). It would seem that BhÄrgava-BhÄskara is here referring to Uvaá¹­aâ€™s commentary on the RPR.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 218 à¥§.à¥©.à¥§à¥©. à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (1.75). G: 1.3.12. Translation: [The vowels Ä« and Å«] occurring as finals of dual forms [are also called pragrÌ¥hya]. Note: The words which are designated as pragrÌ¥hya by this rule are followed by iti in the PadapÄá¹­ha, and are not combined in sandhi with the fol- lowing vowels either in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ or in the PadapÄá¹­ha. While for all the AV examples for the previous rule, the absence of sandhi can be illustrated only for PadapÄá¹­ha citations, that is not the case for the examples of the present rule. Here, in a number of cases listed by the CAB, the lack of sandhi is manifest in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ as well. Another curious feature may also be noted. By using dual forms Ä«kÄro- kÄrau in the previous rule, and dvivacanÄntau in the present rule, the CA, at least on the face of it, seems to be designating these sounds, rather than the words ending in these sounds, by the term pragrÌ¥hya. Interestingly, in this case, PÄá¹‡ini seems to be somewhat inconsistent. P.1.1.19 (à¤ˆà¤¦à¥‚à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡) resem- bles CA (1.3.12: à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤š à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡). On the other hand, P.1.1.11 (à¤‡à¤¦à¥‚à¤¦à¥‡à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥) contrasts with CA (1.3.13: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ). In this case, PÄá¹‡ini seems to treat the whole words as pragrÌ¥hyas, while the CA seems to be explic- itly referring to the final vowels alone. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥’ à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤£à¥€à¥’ à¤†à¤­à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤£à¥€à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‚ à¤‰à¥’à¤­à¥Œâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‚ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤†à¤­à¥‘à¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥­.à¥¬)à¥¤ (à¤ªà¤¦ âˆ€) â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¥‚ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‚ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¥‘à¤¨à¥€à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€
