Translation: In the [instances] Ã¡vaÅ›Ä3 (AV 12.4.42) and ÄÌ babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3 (AV 10.2.28), when followed by iti, the e [resulting through the combination of ÄÌ3+i] is not protracted. Note: As Whitney accurately notes, these two examples are some- what different from each other in the circumstances of this euphonic combina- tion. In the first case, the word Ã¡vaÅ›Ä3 is followed by Ã­ti in the text of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ itself which reads Ã¡vaÅ›Ã©ti. But, the PadapÄá¹­ha offers the two padas as: Ã¡vaÅ›Ä3 / Ã­ti /, with the first word ending in the pluta vowel. Regarding this first example, Whitney comments: â€œAll the saá¹ƒhitÄ manuscripts, however, observe the precept of our treatise in making the combi- nation of avaÅ›Ä3 with the succeeding word, and accordingly its protraction, which is assured by this rule and by i.105 (= CA 1.4.14), and which is exhib- ited by the pada-text, entirely disappears in saá¹ƒhitÄ - a strange imperfection of the latter text, and one which, if it did not exhibit itself in all the manuscripts, we should be very loth to introduce, upon the sole authority of this rule of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 699) says: â€œThe more proper reading in b (in AV 12.4.42) would seem to be Ã¡vaÅ›ÄÌ3Ã­ti, but all the saá¹ƒhitÄ- mss. read Ã¡vaÅ›Ã©â€™ti, as in our text, although the pada gives the sign of protrac- tion (3) also after avaÅ›Ä, as it should be. But the PrÄt. (i.97 = CA 1.4.6) re- quires -Å›Ã©â€™ti simply: see the rules i.97 (= CA 1.4.6) and 105 (= CA 1.4.14), and notes to them.â€ Whitneyâ€™s doubts whether this rule should apply to the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha are strengthened by P.6.1.129 (à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡). The rule teaches something

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾249 similar to the present CA rule, except that the word upasthita is interpreted by PataÃ±jali on this rule as à¤…à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤ƒ, â€œthe word iti which does not stem from a Rá¹£i (= Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha),â€ i.e. the word iti which appears in the Pada, Krama, etc. This would suggest that the rule did not apply to the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. However, as Whitney points out, all the manuscripts of the AV exhibit the saá¹ƒhitÄ form Ã¡vaÅ›Ã©ti, and hence we must accept that reading. Interestingly, even the PaippalÄda (17.20.2, Raghuvir edn.) reading agrees with the ÅšaunakÄ«ya reading in this case. Thus, the assumption that the word avaÅ›Ä3 ends in a pluta vowel is not directly based on the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, but on the un- derstanding of the text as exhibited by the author of the AV PadapÄá¹­ha, an un- derstanding which is in close agreement with the precepts of PÄá¹‡ini, cf. P.8.2.97 (à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). Also see Strunk (1983: 67, 81-82, 97). In the second case, the word babhÅ«vÄÌƒ3 ending in the pluta vowel al- ready appears in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and it is not followed by Ã­ti, either in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ or in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Such a combination arises only in the KramapÄá¹­ha : à¤¬à¥’à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤µà¤¶à¤¾ à¤† à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¤¾à¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤(H, N: à¤‡)à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥’à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤ , à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨. à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - (à¤µà¤¿)à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤°à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨- à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥’à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤ , à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤š â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥¨) â€˜à¤¬à¥’à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¤¾à¤ , à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®) à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥€à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥§.à¥ª.à¥­. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.98). A, B, C, D, M, P: Â°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿Â°. A, B: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°- à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿Â°. E, F: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤µà¥‡Â°. K reads Â°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿Â°, and KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsaâ€™s commentary justifies this reading. G: 1.4.7.

250à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª Translation: Consonants, not separated by [intervening] vowels, are termed saá¹ƒyoga â€˜conjunction.â€™ Note: As Whitney notes, the term saá¹ƒyoga â€˜conjunctionâ€™ is more comprehensive than the scope of the term saá¹ƒyukta defined in CA (1.2.9). For the distinction between these conceptions, see Notes on CA (1.2.2) and CA (1.2.9). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤…à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤â€™ (Source?)à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜[à¤¸à¥]à¤«à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤¯à¥Œ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥©.à¥¯, â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§. à¥¬. à¥®.à¥¨), â€˜à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤•â€™ (not found in AV, à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§à¥§.à¥§), â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­. à¥ªà¥¬.à¥¨, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥ªà¥®.à¥¨), â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤ƒà¥’à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¬. à¥©), â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥(H, N: à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥®.à¥§à¥®) à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ (Referring to à¤¯à¤œà¥+à¤¨ ! à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤) à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤…à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤µà¤šà¥à¤š, â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥‡ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ

à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®- à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¦à¤¨à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥à¤¨à¥à¤à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‡à¤–à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ â€˜à¤œà¥à¤â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥«.à¥©) à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¥ à¤†à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ â€˜à¤œà¥à¤à¤ª à¤®à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤šâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤ , à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤•à¥Œà¤®à¥à¤¦à¥€, à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤• à¥§à¥¬à¥¨à¥«), â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥«.à¥ª. à¥§à¥¨à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥€à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡ à¤šà¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ â€˜à¤šà¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤—à¥à¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾251 à¤²à¤¿à¤ªà¤¿à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¤—à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¤—à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤™à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤—à¥à¤™à¥à¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤—à¤™à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤®- à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤• à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ Note: Here, BhÄrgava-BhÄskara displays his expertise in the PÄá¹‡inian system by quoting a number of PÄá¹‡inian rules. Of course, building a PÄá¹‡inian argument to account for the divergent pronunciations of jÃ±a is nothing but an exercise in futility. Also this whole discussion has little relevance to the context of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya rule. à¥§.à¥ª.à¥®. à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤¯à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1.99). A, B (corr), Nb: Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾Â°. G: 1.4.8. Translation: Within the same word, after [a stop], other than the last [member of a stop series, i.e. after a non-nasal stop], its numerically corresponding twin [yama = nasalized version of the stop] is [inserted], before a last [member of a stop series, i.e. nasal stop]. Note: Here, the distinctive notion is that of a different principle of selection for the insertion, i.e. the principle of numerical correspondence (yathÄsaá¹ƒkhya). This is the same principle which is enunciated in P.1.3.10 (à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). The idea is as follows. For the set of four non-last stops in each series of stops, e.g. k, kh, g, and gh, there is a corresponding set of four nasalized twins or yamas, e.g. kÌ, khÌ, gÌ, ghÌ. The insertion of these yamas takes place in accordance with their numerical correspondence, e.g. after k, we can insert only kÌ, and not any other yama. On this rule, Whitney has a long note discussing the notion of yama, and the core of Whitneyâ€™s analysis is as follows: â€œIf, now, we pronounce a t before a following m, as in Ätma, the t, in the first place, suffers abhinidhÄna, losing the explosion which is essential to its full utterance : the organs pass, without intervening unclosure, from the dental contact to the labial contact, by which latter the m is produced, with expulsion of sound through the nose. … But if we utter sound through the nose before transferring the organs from the dental to the labial contact, we give origin to a kind of nasal counterpart to the t, as a transition sound from it to the m. If this is not the yama of the Hindu

252à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª grammarians, I am utterly at a loss to conjecture what the latter sound should be. The theory which recognizes it might be compared with that which, in rule 50 (= CA 1.2.10), above, taught a general assimilation of the former consonant of a group, in its final portion, to the latter; it is still more nearly analogous with the surd which, by ii. 9 (= CA 2.1.9), is inserted between a final nasal and a following sibilant : this arises, like the yama, by an exchange of the emission (the anupradÄna) belonging to the former letter for that belonging to the latter before the transfer of the organs from the one position to the other; and the t thus introduced, for example, between a n and a s has just as good a right to be called the yama or counterpart of the former letter, as has the n inserted after t before m.â€ On the whole, Whitneyâ€™s account is substantially accurate, except that his valuation of the contribution of the Indian phoneticians was not without hesitation. On the other hand, Max MÃœller and Regnier, who held the Indian phoneticians in high esteem, wrongly believed the yama to be a nasal articula- tion preceding the stop. For a review, see: Allen (1953: 75-7). Whitney also mentions the two dominant views on yama found in the Sanskrit phonetic texts: â€œThe ancient commentators themselves seem to have been somewhat in doubt as to how many different yamas there are, whether twenty, one for each of the non-nasal mutes, or a smaller number. The orthodox doctrine of the Rik Pr. seems to be that of twenty : but its commen- tator says that there are only four; one for all the first mutes, one for all the sec- onds, and so on.â€ Rightly calling the second alternative indefensible, Whitney also has an important criticism of the first alternative: â€œPhysically, it would seem necessary that a nasal transition sound between two mutes should be of the nature either of the first or of the second : if the second, and that second a nasal, it would be indistinguishable from it; of the first, it would be identical with the nasal of that series, and so the same for all the mutes of the series.â€ Another question raised by Whitney relates to the possibility of a yama after an aspirated stop: â€œA much more serious difficulty is, that the theory of the yama allows its occurrence between an aspirate mute and a nasal : and we should suppose that the unclosure and brief emission of unintonated breath constituting the aspiration would form an impassable barrier between the two letters, the nasal utterance being unable to precede it, and the position of contact of the former letter to follow it, so that no nasal counterpart to the former letter could be uttered. I see no way of getting over this difficulty, excepting by sup- posing an inaccuracy in the analysis of the Hindu phonetists.â€ As is now shown by Allen (1953: 176-7), the two processes of breath and nasality may overlap, whether partially or wholly, and that this was the case with Sanskrit.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾253 One should also note that Whitney did not admit the possibility of voiced aspi- ration, and that modern phonetics clearly admits voiced aspiration or breathy voice. In spite of some of these valid doubts, Whitney is correct in assuming that the CA seems to have opted for the doctrine of twenty yamas. Both the commentaries seem to support such a view. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°- (à¤¤)à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤¯à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤ª- à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤à¤¨à¥‘(à¤®à¥)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥¦à¥¯.à¥©, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥§à¥§à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤§à¥à¤§à¥à¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not found in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤£à¤¾(Whitney em.: à¤­à¥à¤£à¤¾ ! à¤­à¥à¤­à¥à¤à¤£à¤¾)à¤¤à¤¿â€™à¥¤ Note: The form grÌ¥há¹‡Äti is attested in AV (6.76.4), but cannot have a yama. The form grÌ¥bhá¹‡Äti is not attested in AV. However, we do have the form grÌ¥bhá¹‡Ämi in AV (3.8.6), which, with the insertion of the yama, would read grÌ¥bh+bhÌ+á¹‡Ämi. For Å›radhnÄti which is not attested in AV, Whitney says: â€œthe word most nearly resembling it is Å›rathnÄnaá¸¥ (xiv.1.57), for which it may not impossibly be a false reading of the manuscript.â€ With the insertion of the yama, the form Å›rathnÄnaá¸¥ should read Å›rath+thÌ+nÄnaá¸¥. Whitneyâ€™s guess is probably on the mark, as the VVRI edition notes the variant Å›radhnÄnaá¸¥ in the manuscript K for Å›rathnÄnaá¸¥ in AV (14.1.57). It is possible that our commentary belongs to the tradition represented by the manuscript K recorded in the VVRI edition. Of course, no manuscripts ever record the yamas. à¤­à¤¾.à¤­à¤¾.à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®- à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥Œ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¯à¤®à¤ƒ â€˜à¤…à¤¸à¤¿à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤•à¥à¤à¤¨à¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥­.à¥§), â€˜à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤•à¥à¤à¤®à¤¾à¤®à¥(H, N: à¤•à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤‚)â€™ (â€˜à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤®à¤¾,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥«. à¥¨à¥«-à¥¨à¥¬), â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥à¤à¤à¥ˆà¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥©à¥¦), â€˜à¤…[à¤¾?]à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥«.à¥¬.à¥«.à¥©), â€˜à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤à¤¨à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§), â€˜à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤à¤®à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§.à¥­), â€˜à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¥à¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (not found

254à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª in Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs), â€˜à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¥à¤à¤®à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¬.à¥«), â€˜à¤µà¥ƒ- à¤•à¥à¤•à¥à¤à¤£à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¯à¤®à¤ƒ â€˜à¤šà¤–à¥à¤–à¥à¤à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (not found in Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs), â€˜à¤¯à¤›à¥à¤›à¥à¤à¤à¥â€™ (not found in Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs)…(incomplete manuscript) Note: The manuscripts do not show the yamas in writing. I have in- dicated the yamas with nasalized consonant signs in Devanagari. à¥§.à¥ª.à¥¯. à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ Whitney (1.100). D, F, Ha, J, M, Na, P: à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤‚Â°. O: Â°à¤°à¤¾à¤‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨. A, B: Â°à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¨. Translation: After h, there is [insertion of] a nÄsikya [= hÌ?], [before a nasal stop]. Note: CA (1.1.26: à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾) refers to the sound or sounds called nÄsikya â€˜[pure?] nasal.â€™ See the Note on CA (1.1.26). Whitney ex- presses his doubts: â€œWhat the sound may be which is thus taught to form the step of transition from the aspiration to a following nasal, it is hard to say with confidence. I can only conjecture it to be a brief expulsion of surd breath through the nose, as continuation of the h, before the expulsion of the sonant breath which constitutes the nasal.â€ Whitney suggests that, in a word like brahma : â€œthe Hindu phonetists doubtless regarded the h as belonging with and uttered like the a; and noticing at the same time the utterance, scarcely to be avoided, of at least a part of the h in the position of the m, they took account of it as a separate element, and called it nÄsikya.â€ One of the misconceptions of Whitney was that he could not accept Sanskrit h to be a voiced aspiration, be- cause he did not think such a thing was possible. Thus, the nÄsikya, if it in- volved aspiration, was not a â€˜surdâ€™ aspiration, but voiced nasal aspiration. Such nasal voiced aspirates are attested for a modern IA language like Marathi, e.g. nh (as in tinhÄ«), á¹‡h (as in kaá¹‡haá¹‡e), and, mh (as in tumhÄ«). Also see Allen (1953: 77). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µ- à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤£Â° ] (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾- à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤£Â° ] (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤£Â° ]

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾255 (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤ªà¤¹à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤®Â° ] (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤®Â° ] (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤¨à¥Â° ] (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘â€™ [ !

Â°à¤¹à¥ à¤à¥à¤®Â° ] (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§. à¥§à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: The sound called nÄsikya is represented by the Nagari ligature à¤à¥ in the above notations. The manuscripts do not show the nÄsikya in writing. For details on the cited examples, see the commentary on CA 1.2.18 (à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°- à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤œà¤‚ à¤š). à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦. à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¦à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (1.101). Translation: After an r, and before a spirant followed by a vowel, there is an insertion of a vocalic fraction (svarabhakti), which is [equivalent to] half of a short a, or quarter according to some [authorities]. Note: Calling it a perfectly intelligible theory, Whitney says: â€œThe theory evidently is, that a r cannot be pronounced in immediate combination with any following consonant : there must always be slipped between them a little bit of a transition-vowel, varying in length, according to different authori- ties, from a half to an eighth of a mora, and longer before a sibilant or h, if these be followed in turn by a vowel, than before other consonants; while in quality it coincides with the a.â€ Whitney, however, was not able to discern the reason why the fractional vowel inserted before spirants must be longer than before other con- sonants, though he does note the practice of the AV manuscripts of writing rÌ¥ for r before spirants. Referring to Wackernagel and Debrunner (1896-1954), Vol.I., Â§ 50, Allen (1953: 73) points out that, in such cases, â€œthe metre also occasionally requires the pronunciation of a vowel which is not noted in our texts (e.g. darÅ›ata = 4 syllables).â€ Besides the variation of the length of the in- serted vowel fraction, different texts suggest that the vowel is rÌ¥, a, i, e, or u, cf. Allen (1953: 73).

256à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¦à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°- à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¶à¥‡à¤· à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥ƒà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¸à¤ƒ(Wâ€™s em.:à¤‹à¤¤à¤µà¤ƒ) à¤¬à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¥¤â€™ (source?) Note: The words varsam and tarsam are cited as examples in the MB on P.8.3.59. Referring to the verses cited in the commentary, Whitney says: â€œNext follow several verses, a part of which are of a character which would render their introduction under rule 37 (= CA 1.1.37), above, more approppri- ate, while one line, the second, belongs rather under rule 98 (= CA 1.4.7). Placing the responsibility for the inelegance of these verses upon the com- mentator or the manuscript, Whitney offers the following translation: â€œHalf of what there is in the rÌ¥-vowel different from r is of the same character with the preceding vowel. Of consonants separated by audible sound, the conjunction is destroyed. In the rÌ¥-vowels there is, by express rule, half a mora of r, half a mora is to be recognized as vowel, and that, again, is thus managed : put the parts upon both sides of the short vowel, so as to make out a mora : examples are darÅ›a, vará¹£a, tatha rÌ¥tavaá¸¥, [and] barhiá¸¥ : know this to be the way when a svarabhakti is to be produced.â€ There seems to be an important distinction between the svarabhakti of longer duration and the svarabhakti of the shorter duration. With the svara- bhakti of the longer duration, as the verses here seem to say, a consonant clus- ter is broken apart, by the creation of an additional syllable. On the other hand, as CA 1.4.13, below, shows, the svarabhakti of the shorter duration did not lead to the break-up of a cluster.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾257 à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥§. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (1.102). A, B, D: Avagraha after Â°à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®. Translation: [After r], before another consonant [= non- spirant], [the inserted fractional vowel is equivalent to] a quarter or an eighth [of a short a in duration]. Note: See the Note on the previous rule. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‡ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤®à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤£à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥©à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¨. à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (1.103). P separates this rule from the previous rule by add- ing a daá¹‡á¸a as a correction. Translation: That [i.e. insertion of the shorter fractional vowel of 1/8 or 1/4 mora duration] is itself [called] sphoá¹­ana. Note: There seems to be a difference of opinion between Whitney and others on what this rule means. Whitney does not seem to identify the sphoá¹­ana with the shorter svarabhakti, but only admits that a sphoá¹­ana is of the same duration: â€œ(Trans:) Of the latter value is sphoá¹­ana. (Comment:) That is to say, if I do not misapprehend the meaning of the rule, sphoá¹­ana, like the shorter svarabhakti, has a quarter or an eighth the quantity of a short a : or it may be that the emphatic eva would restrict the reference to the latter value, the eighth, alone.â€ Allen (1953: 74) seems to understand that the svarabhakti of the length of 1/8 a to be the element referred to as sphoá¹­ana. Allen further clarifies: â€œFrom a later passage (= CA 2.1.38: vargaviparyaye sphoá¹­anaá¸¥ pÅ«rveá¹‡a ced virÄmaá¸¥) we learn that this occurs in groups where a stop is followed by an- other of a more back series, especially a velar (e.g. in vaá¹£aá¹­-krÌ¥tam, tad gÄyatre). … This would appear to indicate a type of svarabhakti, whether voiced or voiceless, the infinitesimal duration of which is suggested by the specification of a value 1/8 a, in fact a minimal audible release. The mechanism of the fea-

258à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª ture referred to is perhaps the release of the front closure during the formation but before the completion of the back closure, resulting in the momentary out- flow of an air-stream attenuated by the back constriction.â€ In my view, sphoá¹­ana is just another name for the shorter svarabhakti of the duration of a quarter of or an eighth of an a, and is not different from such a svarabhakti. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤·à¥’à¤Ÿà¥à¤•à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µ(N: à¤µà¥à¤¯)à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¥’à¤œà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥©.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥- à¤¬à¥à¤—à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: On the citation from AV (2.3.1), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 40) says: â€œAvatkÃ¡ (p. avatÂ°kÃ¡m : quoted in the comment to PrÄt. i.103 = CA 1.4.12; ii.38 = CA 2.1.38; iv.25 = CA 4.1.25) is obscure, but is here translated as from the present participle of root av (like ejatkÃ¡, v.23.7 âˆ€cf. abhimÄdyatkÃ¡, ÅšB., viká¹£iá¹‡atkÃ¡, VS.#).â€ à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥©. à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (1.104), C, Hb, I (orig), Nb, O: Â°à¤µà¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š. A, B, D, F, I (corr), J, K, M, P: Â°à¤­à¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š. E, F: Visarga after à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µ. J, M: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚Â°. A, B, D: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹Â°. Ha, Na: Â°à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š. P: Â°à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚Â°. Translation: [With the shorter svarabhakti called sphoá¹­ana, it carries] the accent of the previous syllable [lit. vowel], and there is no dismemberment of the consonant cluster. Note: Whitney takes this rule to mean that all the phonetic insertions taught in this section â€œare to be reckoned as belonging to the preceding vowel, and sharing in its accent; and whereas it might seem that the insertion of the vowel-fragment, and of its kindred sphoá¹­ana, dissolved the conjunction of the consonants between which they were inserted … the contrary is expressly de- clared to be true.â€ He further states: â€œThe Rik Pr. alone, besides our treatise, thinks it necessary to say (vi. 10, r. 35, ccccxi) that the svarabhakti does not dissolve the conjunction : in the VÄj. Pr. it is left to be pointed out by the com- mentator.â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾259 In my opinion, the present rule is restricted to the shorter svarabhakti alias sphoá¹­ana, and does not extend to the cases of longer svarabhakti, where as pointed out by Allen (1953: 73): â€œthe metre also occasionally requires the pro- nunciation of a vowel which is not noted in our texts (e.g. darÅ›ata = 4 sylla- bles).â€ Support for such a restricted interpretation is derived clearly from the CAB, which refers only to the shorter svarabhakti (cf. à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾), and all the examples it cites are identical with the examples for the shorter svarabhakti offered under CA (1.4.11). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾- à¤µà¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ 260à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤ƒ. H, N: place Daá¹‡á¸a after à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿. A, B, D, J, K, M: Â°à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿Â°. The repetition of the passage à¤‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ indicates that this is the end of the AdhyÄya. O places à¤‡à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥ at the very end of the passage, while P omits it. O places a daá¹‡á¸a after à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¾. Translation: There are the following cases of protracted vowels [in the ÅšAV]: AV (4.15.15), (9.6.18), (10.2.28), (11.3. 26), (11.3.27), (12.4.42), and (12.5.50). Why is this listing made? Any instances beyond this [listing] are in excess [i.e. do not belong to the ÅšAV]. The following is also the intrinsic purpose [of the listing], [namely, to point out that] protractions are of various types, specifically, three types: followed by vowels, followed by abhiniá¹£á¹­Äna [= visarjanÄ«ya, á¸¥], and fol- lowed by consonants. Among them, those which are followed by simple vowels are treated as if non-protracted before iti, [e.g. Ã¡vaÅ›Ã©ti, AV (12.4.42), Pada: Ã¡vaÅ›Ä3 / Ã­ti /]. Note: Concerning the variant readings and interpretations for the first passage, see Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 175). On the passage from AV (11.3.27), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 627) has some important remarks: â€œThe pluta- or protracted syllables in this and the next verse are quoted in PrÄt. i.105 (= CA 1.4.14), but nothing is said as to their accentuation, from which it seems most plausible to infer that the protraction made no difference in the ac- cent; and though in the BrÄhmaá¹‡as a protracted syllable is always accented, that is not the invariable rule in the Vedic texts.â€ Lanman (ibid.) also notes the great variety of mss. readings for the passage concerned. Also see Whitneyâ€™s comments on AV 9.6.18 and 10.2.28, and Strunk (1983: 68). The passage after iti plutÄni is treated by Whitney as part of the commentary, and translated as follows: â€œfor what reason is this enumeration made? because any other instance than these is in excess : within these limits the protracted vowel is pointed out by its own meaning (?). Protractions are various; namely, of three kinds: those which affect a syllable ending in a vowel, in visarjanÄ«ya, and in a consonant, respectively; among these, those which affect syllables ending in simple vowels assume their unprotracted form before iti.â€ I have given my own translation above, and I believe it is an improvement over Whitneyâ€™s. Whitney, on this rule, discusses in some detail, problems of accentua- tion of the cited examples. However, in most cases, the accents cannot be de- cided on the basis of either the CA rules or manuscripts. The only case, where

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾261 the CA rule is relevant for the accent of a pluta syllable is AV (4.15.15). For a discussion of the accents of this example, see the Note on CA (1.4.5). Also see Strunk (1983: 90). For the accents of examples from AV (10.2.28) and AV (11.3.26, 27), I have followed the readings of the VVRI edition, rather than those of Roth- Whitney edition. See CA (4.1.28) and the Note on it for further discussion on these examples. A, B, D, M: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥. I: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥§à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥§à¥§à¥¦. O: à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥¥à¥§à¥¯à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿- à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥ªà¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ P: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹- à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ Note: Notice the difference in the number of rules mentioned for this PÄda and the cumulative numbers given for the first AdhyÄya in the colophons of different manuscripts. Not only do the manuscripts H and N list only 13 SÅ«tras for this PÄda, the last SÅ«tra, i.e. 1.4.14 is most probably not considered to be a SÅ«tra by the CAB. On the other hand, the manuscript O says that there are 19 rules in this PÄda. The manuscript C omits this entire last rule and offers the cumulative number of SÅ«tras for this AdhyÄya to be 103. On the other hand, the manuscript I lists the cumulative number of rule for this AdhyÄya to be 110. It not only includes the last passage as part of the Sutra text, it probably counted its separate parts as seven different SÅ«tras. It would seem that this passage is indeed not part of the CAB itself, as it was once thought by Whitney. This must be the case because this passage does not comment on some earlier rule. However, its inclusion in the manuscripts of the CAB indicates that the copyists of this commentary knew that this passage had been admitted as part of the SÅ«tra text, though the CAB does not comment on it.

262à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥§, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥§à¥©à¥¥. ___________________________________

à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§. à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.1). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: [The following rules apply] in [the context of] combining [the separated words given in the PadapÄá¹­ha to form a continuous text, i.e. the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha]. Note: In general, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya literature took for granted the exis- tence of the PadapÄá¹­ha, and assumed that the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha was derived by ex- plicitly combining the separated words given in the PadapÄá¹­ha, following the rules of sandhi. This rule is a general heading (adhikÄra) with its scope extending over the second and the third chapters of the CA. However, as Whitney warns: â€œWe shall see, however, that our treatise does not everywhere strictly limit itself to what concerns the conversion of pada-text into saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨. à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.2). A, B, D: Â°à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹Â°. J, M (corr): Daá¹‡á¸a after Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚. Translation: Word-final stops, except the last [members of the stop-series], are replaced with the [corresponding] thirds [of the series, i.e. voiced aspirate stops], before voiced consonants and vowels. Note: Whitney observes: â€œConsidering that, by i. 6 (= CA 1.1.8), only the first and last of each series of mutes can occur as finals, this rule might have said prathamÄnÄm, â€˜first mutes,â€™ instead of anuttamÄnÄm, â€˜mutes not nasal;â€™ both this and the following rules, however, seem constructed in view of the disputed character of the final non-nasal mute, and of the doctrine of Åšaunaka himself that it is a media, and not a tenuis.â€ One should note that the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 264 PadapÄá¹­ha lists the separated words as ending in the first stops, i.e. voiceless unaspirated stops, e.g. yat / yatra, AV (2.1.1); tasmÄt / vÄá¸¥, AV (3.13.3). However, the present rule is formulated in a generic way. One may see here not only the need to accommodate the doctrine of Åšaunaka, as noticed by Whitney, but also the influence of the generic grammars of Sanskrit of the type represented by PÄá¹‡ini, cf. P.8.4.53 (à¤à¤²à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¶à¥ à¤à¤¶à¤¿), which subjects all non- nasal stops, as well as spirants, to substitution by an appropriate voiced unaspi- rated stop. However, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule applies to internal, as well as external, sandhis, and interestingly does not specify this change explicitly before vowels. In a procedure somewhat reminiscent of Åšaunakaâ€™s view noted above, cf. CA (1.1.10), PÄá¹‡ini, as a generic procedure, changes all word-final non- nasal stops, and spirants, to the appropriate voiced unaspirated stops, cf. P.8.2.39 (à¤à¤²à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡). It is, however, appropriate to note that PÄá¹‡ini is not dealing with word-finals before pause, as is the case with Åšaunakaâ€™s doctrine. We must mention another dilemma raised by this rule. Since the rule refers to ghoá¹£avat â€˜possessed of ghoá¹£a, voicedâ€™ and svara â€˜vowelâ€™ as separate classes, a question is raised whether the term ghoá¹£avat did not include vowels (svara) because vowels do not have the feature of ghoá¹£a, or whether, for some reason, the term ghoá¹£avat was used only for consonants to distinguish voiced consonants from voiceless consonants. If the first alternative is valid, then one could argue for two modes of voicing, one represented by ghoá¹£a, which be- longed only to voiced consonants, and nÄda, which belonged to both the voiced consonants and vowels. On the other hand, some have argued that there is no phonetic distinction between nÄda and ghoá¹£a, and that the term ghoá¹£avat is used to refer to voiced consonants, with no intention of denying the feature of ghoá¹£a to vowels. For the details of this debate, see: Deshpande (1976, 1976a), Cardona (1983, 1986). Also see: Introduction, section 5.11. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¤‚ à¤šà¥’à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾- à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥‡à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¥‘ à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤—à¥à¥’à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥ƒà¥‘à¤·à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¦à¤­à¥‚(H: à¤®à¥‚, N: à¤®à¥à¤µ)à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥(H, N: à¤¤à¥ƒà¤·à¥)à¤¬à¤¤à¥à¤°â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾265 Note: The example à¤¤à¤¦à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤®à¥ cited by the CAB is not found in the Vul- gate of the AV, and Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. It is clear that, in making such claims, Surya Kanta did not consult the original manuscripts, H and N. Other- wise, his so-called genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya examples may have been à¤¤à¤¦à¤®à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¥ (N) or à¤¤à¤¦à¤®à¥‚à¤¤à¤®à¥ (H). Surya Kanta makes no allowance for either the inaccuracies of the copyists, or for the possibility that the commentator may occasionally quote a passage which is not Atharvan. Interestingly, Whitney also reports another example, i.e. à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¬à¤¤à¥à¤° cited by the commentator which does not occur in the AV. However, Surya Kanta does not use that example for raising the same claims. The example à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¬à¤¤à¥à¤° is found in the KV on P.8.2.39 (à¤à¤²à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡). à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©. à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤šà¤¾à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.3). D, I (corr): Â°à¤µà¤¾à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ. Translation: Further, at the end of a word, [before a pause, as in the PadapÄá¹­ha, or at the end of a metrical foot in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, the non-nasal stops] are replaced with [the corre- sponding] voiceless [unaspirated stops]. Note: Whitney comments: â€œThis, in view of i. 6 (= CA 1.1.8), is a superfluous precept, and its introduction is only to be accounted for by the considerations adverted to under the last rule.â€ I do not believe that the rule is superfluous at all. CA (1.1.8) is more of the nature of a listing of what could occur in the word-final position. On the other hand, this rule is an operational rule achieving that result. Since the inputs to this rule are represented by the word anuttamÄnÄm in the previous rule, it represents a theoretically wider pro- cedure replacing all possible word-final non-nasal stops with the correspond- ing voiceless unaspirated stops. The rule is followed by the Saá¹ƒhitÄ and the PadapÄá¹­ha manuscripts for the ÅšAV. PÄá¹‡ini 8.4.56 (à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡) says that the change of word-final non-nasal stops to voiceless stops is optional, or preferable (if we follow Kiparskyâ€™s view, cf. Kiparsky 1979, on the meaning of vÄ in PÄá¹‡ini). The Kiparskyan interpretation of PÄá¹‡ini brings him closer to the view of the CA. However, the traditional commentators view this rule as being simply optional, and this may have influenced the reading in the two CA manuscripts, D, I (corr): Â°à¤µà¤¾à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 266 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤šà¤¾à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤§à¥à¤•à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ªà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®. à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥ª. à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.4). B, D: Â°à¤…à¤‚à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡Â°. Translation: Also, before voiceless [consonants, the word- final non-nasal stops become voiceless]. Note: As with the previous rule, Whitney says: â€œAlso an unnecessary specification; since final surds do not require to become surds before succeed- ing initial surds, but simply remain unchanged.â€ The rule takes a more generic view of the word-final consonants as inputs for this rule, possibly assuming that there are words which, in derivational or recitational terms, may be as- sumed to end in voiced stops. Such a recitational tradition was attributed to Åšaunaka, cf. CA (1.1.10: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ). The rule may be understood as saying that, even if one assumes that the PadapÄá¹­ha could have words ending in non-nasal voiced stops, these must be changed to their voiceless counterparts in sandhi combinations imminent in the Saá¹ƒhitÄ- pÄá¹­ha. Compare P.8.4.55 (à¤–à¤°à¤¿ à¤š). Note that PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule does not distinguish between external versus internal sandhi. The present CA rule, though it applies to the transformation of the PadapÄá¹­ha into Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, may apply to those internal sandhis, where the PadapÄá¹­ha splits the base from the affix, or members of a compound. For example, the word apsu (AV 1.4.4) is split in the PadapÄá¹­ha as ap+su. One wonders if the PadapÄá¹­ha reading could have been ab+su, in accordance with Åšaunakaâ€™s precept, cf. CA (1.1.10). As- suming, such a possibility, the present rule would change the b to p in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. The same sort of dilemma may be perceived in a form like utta- rasmin (AV 1.9.1), which is split up in the PadapÄá¹­ha as ut+tarasmin. A PadapÄá¹­ha which strictly followed the precept of Åšaunaka could have had the reading ud+tarasmin. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤šà¥‡à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤

Note: Whitney makes an important observation: â€œThe PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas are unanimous in this requirement. … PÄá¹‡ini, as has already been noticed (under i.2 = CA 1.1.3), [cf. P.8.4.45: à¤¯à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾], allows either the unaspirated sonant or the nasal before a nasal, while the manuscript usage is almost, if not quite, invariably in favor of the nasal.â€ Whitneyâ€™s view of PÄá¹‡ini may now be revised in view of the interpretation proposed by Kiparsky (1979) that vÄ in PÄá¹‡ini refers to a preferred option. This would suggest that PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s preferred option is more in agreement with the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas and the practice of the manuscripts. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¤§à¥‘à¤™à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¥’ à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯ à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥’à¤£à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤£à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¹à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª.)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤šà¥ˆà¤ƒ,â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥¬.à¥§.)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in AV, cited in KV on P.8.4. 45)à¥¤ Note: As Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 62) points out, the APR (136: à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿) directly refers to our present rule. Translation: Before Å›, á¹£, and s, [the word-final non-nasal stops] become second [members of the series, i.e. voiceless as- pirated stops]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤–à¥(H, N: à¤•à¥)à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤ à¥(H, N: à¤¡à¥)à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¥à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤«à¥(H, N: à¤ªà¥)à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤–à¥(H, N: à¤•à¥)à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤ à¥(H, N: à¤¡à¥)à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¥à¥(N: à¤¤à¥)à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤«à¥(H, N: à¤ªà¥)- à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤–à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤ à¥(H, N: à¤¡à¥)à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¤¥à¥(H, N: à¤¤à¥)à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤«à¥(H, N: à¤ªà¥)à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–(H, N: à¤–à¥à¤¯)à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤•- à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¥à¥à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤ƒ) (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª. à¥©à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Except for the last example offered by the commentary, all the examples are fabricated examples. The same examples are found in the CAB on CA (1.2.9). Also see the Note on CA (1.2.9). Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 28-29, 40) points out that the VPR (4.119: à¤…à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯) is a patent reference to CA (2.1.6). However, rejecting Weberâ€™s claim that the CA is later than the VPR, Surya Kanta says that â€œthe kernel of the VPr. is older than is yet supposed to be.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾269 Such references (to CA) can only show the various recasts each work of this class has undergone.â€ While it is probably the case that the kind of phonetic changes taught in this rule were genuinely part of Åšaunakaâ€™s doctrine, such a doctrine is followed neither by the manuscripts of the AV, nor by the manu- scripts of the CAB. Whitney, on this rule, points out the disagreements be- tween the different PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, but finally says: â€œThe manuscripts of the Atharvan read always the simple surd before the sibilant, and in the printed text we have of course followed their authority rather than that of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ This particular doctrine is not followed by PÄá¹‡ini, but is ascribed by a VÄrttika on P.8.4.48 to a teacher named Pauá¹£karasÄdi (à¤šà¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤°à¤¿ à¤ªà¥Œà¤·à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ). Even while intending to exemplify this rule, the manuscripts of the commentary do not show the change in writing. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥­. à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.7). Translation: After them [i.e. word-final non-nasal stops, the following] h is replaced by the fourth [member of the stop- series, i.e. the voiced aspirated stop], corresponding to the pre- ceding [word-final stop]. Note: As Whitney notes, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas generally follow this rule, but that PÄá¹‡ini (8.4.62: à¤à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥) allows this change optionally. The mss. of both the AV, as well as those of the CAB, almost universally follow the rule. All the examples cited by the commentator are examples of a word- final t, as given in the AV PadapÄá¹­ha, combined with the following h. In all the cases, the PÄá¹‡inians are likely to treat the first member as ending in d, rather than in t, cf. P.8.2.39. However, the CA tradition converts all prepausal non- nasal stops to voiceless unaspirated stops. PÄá¹‡inian commentators offer ex- amples of other word-final non-nasal stops combined with the word-initial h. Macdonell (1916, 1971: 39), offers Vedic examples like sadhryÃ g ghitÄÌ from sadhryÃ k + hitÄÌ, and Ã¡vÄá¸ á¸havyÄÌni from Ã¡vÄá¹­ + havyÄÌni. While the CA rule is a generic rule, the examples offered in the commentary do not exhibit the vari- ety required to justify this generality. It is possible that the rule shows the oc- casional shift of the CA in the direction of the general grammar of Sanskrit. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µ- à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤˜à¤µà¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 270 à¥§à¥¯.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥’ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥’à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿- (H, N: Â°à¤°à¥à¤·Â°)à¤£à¤‚à¥’ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¥‘(H, N: Â°à¤¨à¥€Â°)à¤•à¥‡à¤¶à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬. à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‘ à¤¨à¥‚à¥’(H, N: Â°à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥‚Â°)à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¥à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¥’ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥­à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 60) states that the APR (163) and the CAB on the present rule cite identical examples. However, note that, in this case, the APR cites only the first three examples out of the total of six cited by the CAB. One should also point out that this is not a case of a gaá¹‡a or a complete listing, and the examples are only illustrative in both the texts. Also see APR (p. 110). à¥¨.à¥§.à¥®. à¤Ÿà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¥¤ Whitney (2.8). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction, while O crosses out a daá¹‡á¸a as a correction. Translation: After a [final] á¹­, a [dental] t [is inserted], before an [initial] s. Note: The insertion of t between á¹­ and s facilitates the transition from á¹­ to s. It suggests that after an unreleased á¹­, there is first a shift of the organs to the position of a dental stop, before moving on to the dental spirant. The clo- sure begins at the retroflex position and then shifts, without release to the den- tal position. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤Ÿà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µ- à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’(H, N: à¤¡à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µ)à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯. à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¥’(H, N: à¤¡à¥à¤¸à¥)à¤µà¥€à¤°à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤·à¥‘à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸(H, N: à¤¡à¥à¤¸)à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: The examples offered by the commentators illustrate the juncture of one word with the next, the juncture of a base with an affix, and the juncture of the first member of a compound with the second. In all these cases, the PadapÄá¹­ha splits the components.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾271 Referring to the first example cited above, Whitney and Lanman (AV Transl. Vo.II., p. 508) make some important observations: â€œNo ms. !of oursâˆ€ inserts t between -rÄÌá¹­ and sva- in b !but four of SSPâ€™s do soâˆ€, as required by PrÄt. ii.8 (under which this is one of the passages quoted).â€ Given this condi- tion of the mss., one needs to seriously investigate, whether certain mss. or groups of mss. follow the rules of the CA more consistently, and whether this reflects a somewhat separate transmission. The manuscripts of the CAB, while offering examples for this rule show neither the PadapÄá¹­ha form, nor the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha form, but read a final á¸ followed by an initial Å›, without showing the insertion of t. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¯. à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.9). E, F (orig): à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤®à¤ƒÂ°. I: 10. O adds a daá¹‡á¸a after à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ. Translation: After [final] á¹…, á¹‡, and n, [respectively] the [sounds] k, á¹­, and t [are inserted], before Å›, á¹£, and s. Note: Whitney says: â€œThe form of this rule is a little ambiguous, since we might be left by it to query whether, for instance, after á¹…, was to be inserted k before Å›, á¹­ before á¹£, and t before s, or only k before all the three sibi- lants - in other words, whether the transition-sound should adapt itself to the character of the following or of the preceding letter. The commentator either does not notice, or does not deign to relieve, this difficulty; he offers no expla- nation of the rule, and, in the instances which he cites, the manuscript persis- tently omits to write the transition-sound.â€ While the manuscripts are unclear because of the lack of writing the transition-sound, the commentary does clear one doubt. The one-to-one matching (yathÄsaá¹…khya) does not work across the board. The commentary does clearly indicate that a final á¹… may be followed by Å›, á¹£, and s. The same holds true for final á¹‡ and n. As far as the CA rule is concerned, Whitney also correctly assumes: â€œFor phonetic reasons, however, it cannot be doubted that the latter is determined by the preceding letter, and that after á¹… is to be uttered a k, after á¹‡ a á¹­, and after n a t, before all the sibilants.â€ However, it is not clear whether such an assumption was widely shared by all the different grammatical traditions. For instance, PÄá¹‡ini treats á¹… and á¹‡ differently from n. P.8.3.28 (à¤™à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤•à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤•à¥ à¤¶à¤°à¤¿) says that, after á¹… and á¹‡, optionally, the augments kUK and á¹­UK are respectively inserted, before Å›, á¹£, and Å›. Then P.8.3.30 (à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤š) says that, after n, the augment dhUá¹¬ (dh>t) is optionally inserted before s. Finally,

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 272 P.8.3.31 (à¤¶à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥) says that, after n, the augment tUK is inserted before Å›. None of these rules cover the case of a word final n being followed by an ini- tial á¹£. On the other hand, the CAB clearly offers an attested case of a word-fi- nal n followed by an initial á¹£, e.g. Å›Ä«tÄn+á¹£aá¹­ (AV 8.9.17). The manuscripts of the AV are irregular at best in showing these tran- sitional sounds, and the manuscripts of the CAB do not show them at all. The logic of this phenomenon is elucidated by Whitney as follows: â€œThe insertion of these tenues after the nasals is a purely physical phenomenon, and one which is very natural, and liable to occur in any oneâ€™s pronunciation. There is to be made, in each case, a double transition in utterance: from the so- nant nasal to the surd oral emission, and the former is made an instant earlier than then latter, if the nasal resonance is stopped just before, instead of exactly at the same time with, the transfer of the organs to the position of the sibilant, a tenues of the same position with the nasal becomes audible. It is, as already remarked under i. 99 (= CA 1.4.8), the counterpart of the nasal yama, asserted by the Hindu phonetists to be heard between a mute and following nasal. It is also closely analogous with the conversion of nÅ› into Ã±ch, as will be pointed out below (under rule 17 = CA 2.1.17).â€ The artificial examples cited under this rule by the CAB are comparable in general to examples found in the KV on P.8.3.28-30. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤·- à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥‡(H, N: à¤™à¥à¤¶à¥‡)à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (H, N: Â°à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡) (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¸à¤¾(H, N: Â°à¤™à¥à¤¸à¤¾)à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¤£à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¶à¥‡(H, N: Â°à¤£à¥à¤¶à¥‡)à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¤£à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤·(H, N: Â°à¤£à¥à¤·)à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¤£à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¸à¤¾(H, N: Â°à¤£à¥à¤¸à¤¾)à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤¡à¤¾à¥‘à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥€à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤·(H, N: Â°à¤¨à¥à¤·)à¤¡à¥à¥‘ à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥’(H, N: Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¸)à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤œà¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) points out that this rule is not followed by the Vulgate mss. for the AV. From this, and such other facts, he concludes â€œ(1) that CA records saá¹ƒdhis for the Åšaunaka AV; (2) that these are not observed by the Vulgate mss.; (3) that the Vulgate does not repre- sent the Åšaunaka Å›ÄkhÄ, but some other.â€ Surya Kanta, fully convinced of his own conclusions, does not notice the fact that the sandhis prescribed by the CA

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾273 are not applied by the manuscripts of the CAB to the very examples which are supposed to illustrate those sandhis. Whitney himself has noted this fact many times, and the present edition also makes that amply clear. Thus, if the manu- scripts of the very CA and its commentary fail to apply the sandhis taught by this very text, so could, and probably did, the manuscripts of the very ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV itself. This happened most probably because the ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition itself underwent significant change, as evidenced by the APR. Surya Kanta forgets to notice the significance of the fact that a significant number of manuscripts of the CA also contain the text of the APR, and the manuscript tradition has consistently treated both of these texts as belonging to the ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition. See the manuscripts B, M, P, VR, and V (APR, Introduc- tion, p. 1-3). All these manuscripts have also been used for the present edition of the CA. The manuscripts, as the final colophons show, were copied and meant to be studied by the Brahmins who did not distinguish between the Å›ÄkhÄs of these two texts, and who were all followers of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV. For instance, the final colophon for the Jyotiá¹£agrantha included in the mss. B used by Surya Kanta (ibid, p. 1) says: à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤¶à¤¾à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¤—à¥à¤°à¤‚à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¥. The same manuscript contains the texts of CA and APR, and the whole mss. was meant for the study of a Brahmin named BrÌ¥haspatiji in the PaÃ±coli family from Anahilapurapattana. Descendants of this PaÃ±coli family are followers of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV till this very day, and the last few surviving reciters of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV come from this family. Concerning this rule, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., Intro., p. cxxiv) says: â€œPr. ii.9 ordains that between á¹…, á¹‡, n and Å›, á¹£, s respectively, k, á¹­, t be in all cases introduced; the first two thirds of the rule never have an opportunity to make themselves good, as the text offers no instance of a conjunction of á¹… with Å› or of á¹‡ with á¹£; that f final n with initial s, however, is very frequent, and the t has always been introduced by us. The usage of the mss. is slightly varying [â€˜exceedingly irregular,â€™ says W. in his note to the present rule of CA]: there is not a case perhaps where some one of them does not make the insertion, and perhaps hardly one in which they all do so without variation.â€ On AV 6.51.1, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 319) remarks: â€œThe Atharvan reading, ac- cording to the PrÄt. phonetic rule ii.9 (= CA 2.1.9), ought to be pratyÃ¡á¹…k before a following Å›; but (as explained in the note to that rule) the mss. read simple á¹…, and both printed texts adopt it.â€ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥¦. à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 274 Whitney (2.10). A, B: à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ for à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ. O: à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ for à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ. P: à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤° for à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡. Translation: Before Å›, n is replaced with Ã±. Note: This rule needs to be understood in conjunction with CA (2.1.17: à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯), which changes Å› to ch, after a dental stop. The examples as cited by the commentator show the change of -n+Å›- to -Ã±+ch-. These two rules raise interesting questions as regards the order of their appli- cation. However, such theoretical questions are not discussed by the com- mentary. The dilemmas, however, are transparent. If we apply CA (2.1.10) first, and change the n to Ã±, then we cannot apply CA (2.1.17), because that rule changes Å› to ch after a dental stop, and Ã± is not a dental stop. On the other hand, if we first apply CA (2.1.17), and change Å› to ch after n, then we can no longer apply CA (2.1.10) which changes n to Ã± before Å›, and there is no longer a Å› after n. Also see Note under CA (2.1.17). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯

à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤à¥à¤›à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥’à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¿ à¤·à¤à¥à¤›à¥à¥’à¤•à¥à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥¯)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥§. à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.11). A, B: Â°à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥€Â°. Translation: [The final n changes to Ã±, also] before a voiced [stop] belonging to the c-series. Note: As Whitney points out: â€œThat is to say, before j; since jh, as already noticed, never occurs, and Ã± is never found as initial.â€ The exclusion of voiceless stops c and ch is important, because the final n behaves differently before these sound, cf. devÄn+ca > devÄÌƒÅ›ca / devÄá¹ƒÅ›ca. The manuscripts of the AV do not consistently show this change, and, instead of the expected Ã±, sometimes we find an anusvÄra, or a dental n. For example, on AV (1.33.2), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 33) notes that only about half of the mss. carry out the prescribed sandhi. The Whitney-Roth edition generally has an anusvÄra. S.P. Panditâ€™s edition and the VVRI edition read -an j- without ap- plying this sandhi rule.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾275 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤- à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¥‘(H: à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾)à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§. à¥©à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥ƒà¥’à¤£à¤¹à¤¾à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥®.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥ˆà¥’à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥«. à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ Note: The CAB here lists the first four instances out of a total list of 10 instances found in the APR (138). The examples occur exactly in the same order. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 58) mistakenly cites CA (2.2, from Whitneyâ€™s edition), instead of the present rule. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥¨. à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤£à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.12). Translation: [The final n is changed to] á¹‡ before a [voiced stop] belonging to the á¹­-series. Note: As Whitney points out, no lingual stop is found at the begin- ning of â€œany word in the Atharvan, any more than in the other Vedas, and this rule is as unnecessary as is the inclusion of á¹‡ along with the other nasals in rule 9 of this chapter (= CA 2.1.9), and as is more than one rule or part of a rule in that which is to follow: such specifications are made merely for the sake of a theoretical completeness.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤£- à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€(H, N: à¤°à¥à¤£à¥€)à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€(H, N: à¤°à¥à¤£à¥€)à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ Note: The readings à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ and à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ are based on Whitneyâ€™s conjectures which are clearly preferable to the reading in the manuscripts, which as they stand cannot even illustrate this rule. These are clearly artificial examples, not attested in the known text of the AV. However, with respect to these examples, Surya Kanta does not raise his claim that these instances may have occurred in the genuine text of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 276 The corruptions à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ and à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ in both the mss. for the original à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ and à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ are comparable to the corruption of à¤–à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤¡à¤•à¤¾ to à¤–à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤°à¤—à¤¾ on CA 3.2.27. These corruptions, which seem to change á¸ to r, seem to be indi- cations of the probable Rajasthani origin of the manuscripts, cf. Ernest Bender (1992: 90-91) à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥©. à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.13). A, B, D: Â°à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ. Ha, J, M, N, P: Â°à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ. Translation: Before Å› and l, t is changed to a sound sharing the same point of articulation as the following sound. Note: Whitney points out that the sandhi of t with Å› is not complete without rule CA (2.1.17), which changes Å› to ch after a dental stop. The term parasasthÄna refers to a sound which has the same point of articulation as the following sound. In comparison with other treatises, we know that a final t is changed to c before Å›, and to l before l. The first change is more obvious than the second, because t and l share the same sthÄna â€˜point of articulation,â€™ i.e. both are dental (dantya), and hence it is not clear why this rule should change a t to l before l. Since, t and l are already sasthÄna of each other, the formulation of the rule is basically faulty. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s formulation averts such a difficulty by using the term parasavará¹‡a instead of the term para- sasthÄna, cf. P.8.4.60 (à¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¤¿) with parasavará¹‡aá¸¥ continuing from P.8.4.58. The term sasthÄna simply refers to the sharing of a common point of articulation, while the term savará¹‡a, as defined by P.1.1.9 (à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¥), refers to those sounds which share the same point of articulation (sthÄna) as well as the internal effort (prayatna). While t and l are sasthÄna â€˜having a common point of articulation,â€™ they are not savará¹‡a â€˜having a common point of articulation and internal effort.â€™ PÄá¹‡ini asks us to replace a dental stop, before l, with a sound which is parasavará¹‡a. The only sounds which share the same point of articulation and internal effort with l, are l itself and its nasal variety, i.e. lÌƒ. Thus, a final t is changed to l, and a final n is changed to lÌƒ. Neither the CAB, nor Whitney, show any awareness of these theoretical difficulties. This also raises a significant question about how much of this text is pre-PÄá¹‡inian. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¥’ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤˜à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥- à¤²à¥à¤²à¥à¥‘à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥®.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾277 Note: The manuscripts of the AV, as well as those of the CA, most often do not fully observe this sandhi as it relates to the juncture of t and Å›, and write ch for cch. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥ª. à¤šà¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.14). A, B: à¤šà¤Ÿà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š. Translation: Before the consonants of the c-series and á¹­- series, [a final t is changed to a consonant which shares the same point of articulation as the following consonant]. Note: This rule also shows that the CA makes certain assumptions which are not brought out by the CAB. One such assumption is that out of the possible substitutes, one selects a replacement which is closest to the original in terms of phonetic features. This principle is stated by PÄá¹‡ini in P.1.1.50 (à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ), and CA (1.4.4: à¤†à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ). For example, when a final t is followed by c, we are told that t changes to a consonant which is parasasthÄna â€˜shares the same point of articulation as the following sound.â€™ The sounds i, e, c-series, and Å›, all share the same point of articulation. They are all tÄlavya â€˜palatal.â€™ The principle given in CA (1.4.4) tells us that we replace t with c, and not with some other sound. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤šà¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°(à¤¸)- à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¾à¥’- à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¬à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤šà¤¿à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¡à¥à¤¡à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ Note: The fact that there are no examples attested in the Vulgate of the AV for illustrating a t followed by a retroflex stop is taken by Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39) as a possible indication that the Vulgate is not a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, and that a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension may have contained such examples. On the other hand, I believe that Whitney is probably correct in suggesting that a rule like this is perhaps an indication of this text straying occasionally into the requirements of a general grammar for Sanskrit, and he points to similar examples in the commentaries on P.8.4.40-41

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 278 (à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤ƒ, à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ƒ).
