O combines a portion of this rule with CA 2.1.17, and omits CA 2.1.16: à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€- à¤¯à¤¾à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒà¤¶à¥à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯. Translation: Within the same word, after these [= stops of the c-series, i.e. palatal stops, and the á¹­-series, i.e. retroflex stops], a member of the t-series [i.e. a dental stop] is replaced with a sound which shares the same point of articulation as the previous [palatal or retroflex stop]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤šà¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€- à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‚à¥’à¤¢à¤¾ à¤…à¥‘à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥­. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥‹ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥‚à¥‘à¤¢à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥’ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®. à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney points out that all the cases of this rule illustrated by the commentary fall in the category of internal sandhi which results only if one is interested in the derivation of the word mÅ«á¸ha, and not its relationships with the preceding or the succeeding word, which is the proper area for a PrÄti- Å›Äkhya. The CAB on CA (1.1.2) says: à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤²à¥€à¤¢â€™à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¢à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¢à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°(H, N: Â°à¤¦, Whitney: Â°à¤°)à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤§à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥ªà¥¦)à¥¤ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (cf. â€˜à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥ªà¥§)à¥¤ à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ (cf. â€˜à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥©.à¥§à¥©)à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ (cf. â€˜à¤¢à¥à¤°à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤½à¤£à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤ªà¤¾. à¥¬.à¥©.à¥§à¥§à¥§) à¤µà¥ˆà¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ The word mÅ«á¸ha is derived in the same way, where the root muh is followed by the past participle affix -ta. The CAB, and perhaps the CA, seem to assume a derivational process analogous to the PÄá¹‡inian process cited in the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾279 commentary passage above. The h of the root muh is replaced with á¸h before the affix -ta. Then the present CA rule changes t of -ta, coming after á¸h, to á¸h, giving us the stage muá¸h+á¸ha. The present CA rule does not go beyond this stage. According to PÄá¹‡inian derivation, however, á¸h is deleted before á¸h by P.8.3.13 (à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ), and the preceding vowel is lengthened by P.6.3.111 (à¤¢à¥à¤°à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤½à¤£à¤ƒ). Whitney is, however, correct is saying that such a derivational process does not truly concern a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, a point also made by the CAB on CA (1.1.2). Whitney also suggests: â€œThe only practical application of the precept is one which is not recognized, or at least not illustrated, by the commentator; namely, to those cases in which an initial s followed by a t or th is, by later rules (ii. 90 = CA 2.4.10 etc.), converted to á¹£ : the following dental then be- comes by this rule a lingual.â€ While the change indicated by Whitney does in- deed take place in forms like anuá¹£á¹­hita, it cannot take place by the present CA rule, because the present CA rule strictly applies to a dental stop which follows a palatal or a retroflex stop, and not something that follows any palatal or retro- flex sound. The change indicated by Whitney does, however, take place by the following CA rule, i.e. CA (2.1.16). In any case, this rule, along with several successive rules, illustrates the relatively less common process of regressive assimilation. Generally, Sanskrit shows progressive assimilation. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥¬. à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.16). F, I: Â°à¤°à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾Â°. O omits this rule. Translation: After an á¹£, even in a different word [i.e. even across a word-boundary], [a dental stop is replaced with a sound which has the same point of articulation as the preceding á¹£]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤…à¤ªà¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨- à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«. à¥§à¥«.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤£à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤·à¤£à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ,â€™ à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥­.à¥¨. à¥§à¥«.à¥§, à¤•à¤¾à¤ à¤•à¤¸à¤‚. à¥ªà¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: Whitney says that the example á¹£aá¹£á¹­iá¸¥ properly â€˜belongs under the preceding rule.â€™ This is not quite true. The preceding rule, as pointed out earlier, applies only to dental stops which follow palatal or retroflex stops, and

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 280 not which follow palatal or retroflex sounds across the board. In any case, an example like á¹£aá¹£á¹­iá¸¥ constitutes an example of internal sandhi, which concerns the process of word-derivation, which strictly speaking is not the concern of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. However, as Whitney indicates on the preceding rule, one can think of a â€˜word-internalâ€™ application for this rule, where the initial s of a root is changed to á¹£ because of the preceding vowel across the word-boundary. The dental stop following such an á¹£ then changes to a retroflex stop, e.g. anu+ sthita > anu+á¹£thita > anu+á¹£á¹­hita. Numerous examples of this kind can be found in the text of the Atharvan. The example á¹£aá¹‡á¹‡avatiá¸¥ is offered in the KV on P. 8.4.42 (à¤¨ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿà¥‹à¤°- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥), to illustrate the VÄrttika: à¤…à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¤¨à¤—à¤°à¥€à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥. Since the example á¹£aá¹‡á¹‡avatiá¸¥ is not attested in the AV, what would be a proper AV example? In this case, Whitney rightly points out: â€œThe precept was evidently only intended for such combinations as bahiá¹£ á¹­e (i.3.1), in which, by the rules contained in the fourth section of this chapter, an original final s becomes lingualized, and the following t is assimilated to it.â€ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥­. à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.17). A, B (corr), D, J: à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: After a member of the t-series [i.e. a dental stop], Å› is replaced with ch. Note: This rule works in conjunction with rules 2.1.10 and 2.1.13 above. See Notes on those rules for problems regarding the mutual relations between these rules as formulated. Whitney also points out: â€œThis rule, taken in connection with rules 10 (= CA 2.1.10) and 13 (= CA 2.1.13), above, de- termines the form to be assumed by the combinations t+Å› and n+Å›. Exception may fairly be taken, however, to the method in which the change is taught. By the other rules referred to, t and n are to become c and Ã± before Å›: and if those rules are first applied, there will be no dental mutes for Å› to follow; while, if the present rule be first applied, the others are rendered wholly or in part superflu- ous, by the non-occurrence of Å› after t and n. In the case of t there comes in the still farther difficulty that rule 6 of this chapter (= CA 2.1.6) has converted it into th, so that a part of rule 13 is thereby also rendered incapable to applica- tion. These are incongruencies such as the authors of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas are very seldom guilty of. What is the intention of our treatise is, indeed, sufficiently clear.â€ The kind of problems pointed out by Whitney in the application of CA rules have been handled with far greater sophistication in the PÄá¹‡inian system

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾281 with devices like a) sthÄnivadbhÄva â€˜treating a substitute as if it had some of the same properties as the original,â€™ b) rule ordering and well-defined proce- dures for conflict-resolution and priority, and c) treating a rule or it result as if it is not in effect for some other rules (asiddha). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥à¤›à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥©à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤à¥à¤›à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚- à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥’à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¿ à¤·à¤à¥à¤›à¥à¥’à¤•à¥à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®. à¥ª.à¥«à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: Whitney points out: â€œThe commentator cites examples only of the combination of n and Å›. … As an example illustrative of the other part of the rule, we may take ÄrÄc charavyÄá¸¥ (i.19.1).â€ Whitney further points out that the manuscripts â€œwith hardly an excep- tion, write simply ch, instead of cch.â€ While this observation is beyond doubt, Whitney draws some debatable conclusions: â€œThis orthography (i.e. ch, rather than cch) is also, to my apprehension, a truer representation of the actual pho- netic result of combining t with Å›. That these sounds fuse together into a ch is very strong evidence that the utterance of the Sanskrit surd palatals did not dif- fer materially from that of our ch (in church etc.); and I conceive that the con- stant duplication of the ch and jh (wherever the latter occurs) between two vowels is to be looked upon simply as an indication of the heaviness of those consonants, and of their effect to make the preceding vowel long by position.â€ I think Whitney seems to overlook the fact that the representation cch is not a mere orthographic representation, but that the processes of syllabication would require that the initial c be part of the previous syllable, with the next syllable beginning with ch. Such a syllabic division was obligatory in Sanskrit, espe- cially, if the previous syllable had a short vowel. In NIA languages like Hindi and Marathi, however, we can have a ch preceded by a short vowel forming a light syllable in words like bichÄnÄ > bi-chÄ-nÄ. In Sanskrit, there is no reason to believe that ch was always a heavy consonant. After long vowels and sen- tence-initially, one has no reason to assume that ch must be a heavy consonant. Assuming the compound nature of ch, Whitney says: â€œThe conversion of nÅ› into Ã±ch, on the supposition of the compound nature of the palatal, as made up of a mute and a sibilant element, would be almost precisely analogous with that of ns into nts, as taught in rule 9, above, and would be readily and simply explainable as a phonetic process.â€ While there is indeed some com- monality between these two cases, one must note that the Sanskrit tradition

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 282 treated ch as a single sound, while ts was always treated as a consonant cluster. In the cluster ts, after the initial closure for t, one has the continuant s. On the other hand, ch is unlike n+c+Å›, in that ch has aspiration as part of it release, but does not have the continuant feature of Å›. Such a distinction allows ts to be split in a syllabic division as -t+s-. Such a division is not available for ch. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥®. à¤²à¥‹à¤ª à¤‰à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.18). Ha, Na: à¤‰à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒÂ°. J, M, Hb, Nb, P: à¤‰à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒÂ°. E, F: à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹à¤¦à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒÂ°. A, B: à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒÂ°. O: à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹à¤¦à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚à¤­à¥‹à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤‰à¤¦ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤- à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¥’ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¥à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘à¤ªà¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘à¤ªà¤¯à¥’ à¤¸à¥€- à¤¦à¥‘à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the form utthuá¸¥ in AV (7.52.2), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 422) remarks: â€œSSP. strangely reads, with the comm. and the majority of his authorities, and with part of ours (P.?O.R.), ut sthur in c, against both general grammar and the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya (ii.18; its commentary quotes this passage as an illustration of the rule).â€ In all the cases of ut+sthÄ cited by the commentary, the PadapÄá¹­ha clearly retains the s of sthÄ. However, as Whitney points out: â€œWherever, however, the preposition receives the accent, and enters into a more intimate combination with the root, as in the participle Ãºtthita, the pada-text (by iv. 62 = CA 4.2.16) does not separate the compound, or restore the original s, but reads the same form which appears in saá¹ƒhitÄ. Of this kind is also the only example of the root stambh combined with the prepo- sition ud which our text presents, viz. satyeno â€™ttabhitÄ (xiv.1.1), where the pada reads ÃºttabhitÄ, and not Ãºt-stabhitÄ.â€ Also compare this rule with P.8.4.61 (à¤‰à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯). The CA rule is closer to PÄá¹‡ini as compared to other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, as Whitney points out: â€œThe VÄj. Pr. (iv. 95) notices the loss of s from the root stambh, but, as Weber remarks with surprise, omits all mention of sthÄ. The Taitt. Pr. (v. 14) includes these cases in a more general rule, that s is dropped when preceded by ud and followed by a consonant.â€ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥§à¥¯. à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.19).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾283 Translation: R [is deleted] before r. Note: As Whitney notes: â€œThe r which is thus dropped must itself, of course, be the product of euphonic processes taught elsewhere (ii. 42, 43 = CA 2.2.3-4). The protraction of a preceding short vowel when an r is thus dropped is prescribed in a later rule (iii. 20 = CA 3.1.20).â€ However, the CA rules must be clearly contrasted with PÄá¹‡inian rules P.8.3.13 (à¤¢à¥‹ à¤¢à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ) and P.6.3. 111 (à¤¢à¥à¤°à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤½à¤£à¤ƒ), which prescribe additionally a deletion of a á¸h before á¸h, and the lengthening of the preceding vowel. The CAB on CA (1.1.2) knows these PÄá¹‡inian rules, and the same commentary on CA (2.1.15), if not CA (2.1.15) itself, seems to presuppose such rules. See Notes on CA (1.1.2) and CA (2.1.15). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤°à¤¦à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤šà¥€(à¤ƒ) à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (not in known Vedic texts, quoted in the KV on P.1.3. 14)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘ à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥’à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¥‚ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤ Note: The example à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ cited by the CAB is not found in the Vulgate of the AV and is actually not found in the known Vedic literature. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. However, the fact that it occurs in the KV may perhaps mean that it could have been taken by our commentary from a gram- matical source like the KV. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦. à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.20). Translation: After a last member [of a stop-series, i.e. a nasal stop], and before a non-last [member of a stop-series, i.e. non-nasal stop], a non-last [member of a stop-series, i.e. a non- nasal stop, is deleted].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 284 Note: This rule is interesting in that it does not seem to apply to the transformation of the words given in the PadapÄá¹­ha to their Saá¹ƒhitÄ versions, or vice versa, and hence it does not fit a strict definition of the purpose of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. To make sense of the inclusion of such rules, one may perhaps propose that the CA is trying to clearly distinguish its recitational practice from the norms of generic Sanskrit, and from other traditions, cf. Whitney: â€œNeither of the other known PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas teaches the same omission, or even notices it as prescribed by any authority.â€ Concerning the practice taught by this rule, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol. I., Intro., p. cxxv) says: â€œAbbreviation of the consonant-groups: as in paá¹…kti and the like. – By ii.20 (= CA 2.1.20) a non- nasal mute coming in the course of word-formation between a nasal and a non- nasal is dropped: so paá¹…ti; chintam and rundhi in stead of [paá¹…kti], chinttam and runddhi; etc. The manuscripts observe this rule quite consistently, although not without exceptions; and it has been uniformly followed in the edition. At xii.1.40, anuprayuá¹…ktÄm iaccidental exception; and here, for once, the mss. happen to agree in retaining the k. !Cthe Hibernicisms strenâ€™th, lenâ€™th, etc.âˆ€â€ Note that the comments enclosed between the L-brackets â€˜!â€™ and â€˜âˆ€â€™ are added by Lanman. On the other hand, the VVRI edition does not follow this rule, and maintains the k/g in its readings. This rule also needs to be contrasted with CA (2.1.9: à¤™à¤£à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤·à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥), which prescribes: â€œAfter [final] á¹…, á¹‡, and n, [respectively] the [sounds] k, á¹­, and t [are inserted], before Å›, á¹£, and s.â€ While CA (2.1.9) has parallels elsewhere, the present rule does not. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤™à¥à¤¤à¤¿(H, N: à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿)- à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤°â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤¤à¤‚à¥’(H, N: à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚) à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤­à¤™à¥à¤§à¤¿à¥’ (H, N: à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥©. à¥§à¥©)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤ƒ(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤ƒ)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‹) à¤µà¤¾à¥’ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤°)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥’(H, N: à¤ªà¥à¤¸)à¤°à¤¸à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤¸à¤§à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤‚à¥‘ à¤®à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¤®à¥‘ à¤à¤¨à¥’à¤®à¤ªà¥‘ à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤®à¤ƒ(H: à¤§à¥à¤¸à¤ƒ, N: à¤§à¤¾à¤ƒ)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾285 Note: The deletion taught by this rule is not practiced by the mss. of the CAB. The consonant groups as assumed in the counter-examples are not seen either in the manuscripts of the AV, nor in those of the CAB. Also the counter-examples are not chosen with proper care in that several of them con- tain multiple violations of the conditions at a time, rather than illustrating strictly the single condition referred to by the query à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥. I: 20. Translation: After a vowel, word-final y and v [are deleted]. Note: As Whitney points out: â€œThis rule applies, on the one hand, to the y and v of the syllables ay, av, Äy, Äv (the latter, however, being excepted by the following rule), into which, by iii. 40 (= CA 3.2.17), e, o, ai, and au are converted before a vowel; and, on the other hand, to the y into which, by ii. 41 (= CA 2.2.2), visarjanÄ«ya theoretically passes before an initial vowel.â€ I object to the word â€˜theoreticallyâ€™ used by Whitney. While it is true that the CA seems to demand unconditional deletion of a y derived from a visarjanÄ«ya, and, there- fore, this y becomes a seemingly theoretical entity, other schools were not so categorical about this deletion, and hence this y could appear in the final result, cf. KV on P.8.3.19 (à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯) says: à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤µà¤£à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿. Also contrast the fact that such a deletion takes place, according to PÄá¹‡ini, before aÅš, i.e. vowels and voiced consonants. The CA rule is a statement of unconditional deletion. In any case, this procedure was widely disputed, and Whitney records the wide spectrum of views in the traditional phonetic literature concerning these disputes. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤• à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¥‡ à¤µà¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥®. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯ à¤‰à¤¦à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥’à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¥’ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤‰à¥‘ à¤à¥’à¤µ à¤®à¥‘à¤¹à¤¾à¤¯à¥’à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤†à¤ªà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾287 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤—à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥Œ à¤—à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¨ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤·à¥à¥‘à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚à¥’ à¤—à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥Œâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥’à¤µà¥‡- à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¤¹à¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney says: â€œOther like cases, as gavÄÅ›ir and gaviá¹£, occur in the twentieth book of the text, but with that book the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya has nothing to do.â€ APR (155), which seems to be referring to our CA rule, also teaches that in gaviá¹£á¹­au and gaveá¹£aá¹‡aá¸¥ the v is not elided. Surya Kanta makes a case that making such a rule which can apply to the Saá¹ƒhitÄ text was originally not the function of the APR, which was originally supposed to describe only the peculiarities of the Pada text, and that such rules were added later to it. On the other hand, he argues that the CA was from the very beginning a treatise deal- ing with the conversion of the Padas into Saá¹ƒhitÄ, and that a rule such as the present one is more genuinely suited to it. See: APR, Introduction, pp. 25-26. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª. à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.24). A, B, D: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚Â°. O: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚Â°. Translation: According to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, there is a weak ar- ticulation [of the word-final y and v discussed in the earlier rules], as regards the feature of contact [between the articulator and the point of articulation]. Note: As Whitneyâ€™s survey of the various texts shows, the doctrine ascribed to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana here is offered as an option by most texts, and is occa- sionally ascribed to other scholars like VÄtsapra. P.8.3.18 (à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•- à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯) ascribes the same view to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, but uses a slightly different term: laghuprayatnataraá¸¥ â€œrelatively weaker articultory effort.â€ PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.19 (à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯) ascribes the deletion of final y and v to ÅšÄkalya. By default, it would seem that these sounds were neither deleted nor weakened, but were pronounced with the normal force in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s own school. This gives us a wide range of pronunciation for final y and v across the various dialects of Sanskrit. What is noteworthy, however, is that the view of deletion, which is ascribed by PÄá¹‡ini expressly to ÅšÄkalya, is the default view in CA. While it does care, for some reason, to record the view of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, it does not care to record the view of normal pronunciation of y and v. It should be noted that there is a close relationship of the CA tradition to the views expressed by

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 288 ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, cf. BhÄrgava-BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA (1.1.11-12) and the Notes on these rules. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨- à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤†à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥¤ â€˜à¤• à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¥‡ à¤µà¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥®. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯ à¤‰à¤¦à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥’à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¥’ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤‰à¥‘ à¤à¥’à¤µ à¤®à¥‘à¤¹à¤¾à¤¯à¥’à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾ à¤†à¤ªà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥«. à¤ªà¥à¤®à¥‹ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤½à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.25). E, F: à¤ªà¥‚à¤ for à¤ªà¥à¤‚. J, M: Â°à¤¯à¥‹ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤‚Â°. O: Â°à¤ªà¥‚à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾Â°. Translation: Before a voiceless stop not followed by a spi- rant, the m of pum is changed to a visarjanÄ«ya [i.e. á¸¥], except in puá¹ƒÅ›ca etc. Note: Whitneyâ€™s frustration with the rule and the commentary is manifest in his comments: â€œThis is a rule very hard to get along with. In the first place, it is altogether unnecessary and uncalled for, since of all the words to which it is intended to apply, but a single one, puá¹ƒÅ›calÄ«, is found in the Atharvan text, and that one is written by the pada-text precisely as in saá¹ƒhitÄ, and so requires no explanation from the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ Besides the fact that the rule seems to step into the un-PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyan ter- ritory of general grammatical derivation, the condition apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u creates a number of problems. The first problem is that the form puá¹ƒÅ›ca already seems to show the operation of the rule. If so, then what is being excluded by saying apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u? The CAB offers puá¹ƒÅ›cora as a counter-example. However, as Whitney agonizes: â€œBut puá¹ƒÅ›cora, â€˜he-thief,â€™ is as regular an instance of the application of the rule as puá¹ƒskÄmÄ or puá¹ƒÅ›calÄ«; nor does it seem possible to find in apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u itself any form which constitutes an exception to the pre- vious specifications. I can only conjecture that the reading is corrupt, and was corrupt before the commentator set himself at work upon it, and that his expla- nation was as unintelligible to himself as it is to us. The specification may have been intended for such words as puá¹ƒkhyÄna, which constitutes an actual exception to the rule, and it is cited as such in BÃ¶htlingkâ€™s note to PÄá¹‡ini viii.3.6, as from the SiddhÄnta-KaumudÄ«.â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾289 It is now quite clear that apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u is an ancient corruption. It is shared by all the manuscripts, and, as Whitney correctly assumes, it must have been there already when the author of the CAB attempted to explain the word. Whitneyâ€™s comment quoted above, led me to look for a possible emendation. Having looked at the shapes of the letters kh and c in Gupta and pre-Gupta scripts, it seems very likely that these two letters were confused, and a possible apuá¹ƒkhÄdiá¹£u was misread as apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u. The expression apuá¹ƒkhÄdiá¹£u would not only exclude puá¹ƒkhyÄna cited by Whitney, but also the relatively earlier expression puá¹ƒkha, which is traditionally etymologized as pum+kha [< pumÄá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ khanati, pum+khan+á¸Œa, etymology offered in Åšabdakalpadruma, Vol. 3, p. 163]. Another possible reading is apuá¹ƒká¹£Ädiá¹£u, which wouexclude cases like puá¹ƒká¹£Ä«raá¸¥ and puá¹ƒká¹£uraá¸¥. However, these examples are already taken care of by the exclusion anÅ«á¹£mapare, and one would not need a separate exclu- sion to be stated. Therefore, the reading apuá¹ƒkhÄdiá¹£u seems to be a better emendation. Another word which fits in the same category as puá¹ƒkha is puá¹ƒkheá¹­a, which is analyzed by Roth-BÃ¶htlingk (PW, Vol. 4, p. 752) as puá¹ƒs+khe â€™á¹­a, and explained as: â€œein mÃ¤nnlicher Planet, (ref:) Ind. St. 2,258, N.â€ Indeed the word puá¹ƒkha is at least as old as the epics, cf. BÃ¶htlingk, PW, Vol. 4, p. 752, and, even though it is unattested in Vedic literature, it could have been on the mind of the author of the CA as an exception to the rule. It is also attested in VarÄhopaniá¹£ad (2.82, Yogopaniá¹£adaá¸¥, p. 482). However, this is a late Upaniá¹£ad, and the verse containing this word is in the meter Vasanta- tilakÄ, a late classical meter. Whitney rightly suspects that the reading apuá¹ƒÅ›cÄdiá¹£u was corrupted from some now-unknown original before this commentary was written. On the other hand, his comment that this whole rule is probably an interpolation, because the word visarjanÄ«ya is repeated again in the following rule, is not jus- tified, since Whitneyâ€™s reading of CA 2.1.26: à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿- à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ is not supported by a single manuscript. By mistake, Whitney has taken the elaboration in the commentary to be the text of the rule. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤®à¥‹ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤²à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤· à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 290 texts)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‹à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ Note: Except for one, all the examples cited by the commentator are unattested in the AV. Many of these examples are found in the KV on P.8.3.6 (à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤–à¤¯à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‡). The example puá¹ƒká¹£Äraá¸¥ may be a corruption of puá¹ƒká¹£Ä«ra which occurs in the KV on P.8.3.6. For puá¹ƒyÄnam and puá¹ƒÅ›coraá¸¥, the Pe- tersburg Lexicon finds the only known attestations in the CAB on the present rule. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¬. à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.26): à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ. A, B, C, D, E, F, J, M, Na, O: Â°à¤šà¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥Â°. P: Â°à¤šà¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥Â°. Translation: Before voiceless [stops] of the c-series, á¹­-series, and t-series [i.e. palatal, retroflex, or dental stops], [not fol- lowed by a spirant], the [final] n [is changed to a visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥]. Note: As Whitney points out, this rule is uniformly applied by the manuscripts of the ÅšAV. Whitneyâ€™s further contribution lies in pointing out that the doctrine proposed by this rule amounts to an insertion of a sibilant, and the n is subsequently replaced by the nasalization of the preceding vowel. Whitney offers a historical explanation: â€œIt is sufficiently evident that this in- sertion of a sibilant after a final n before a surd mute is no proper phonetical process: the combination of the nasal and following non-nasal is perfectly natu- ral and easy without the aid of a transition sound, nor can any physical expla- nation be given of the thrusting in between them of a sibilant, which only en- cumbers the conjunction. … The historical rather than phonetical origin of the r which is appended (see rule 29 = CA 2.1.29, below) to a few accusatives plu- ral in the Vedic language before a vowel has been long since pointed out by Bopp; and a kindred explanation of the conversion of Än into ÄnÌ before a vowel (see rule 27 = CA 2.1.27, below) was added by him in his Comparative Grammar. He has refrained from tracing the insertion of a sibilant before c and t to the same cause, doubtless, because of the numerous instances in which the insertion is made after a word which is not entitled by origin to a final s. But

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾291 nothing is more natural than that an insertion originally organic, but of which the true character was forgotten, and which had come to seem merely euphonic, should considerably extend its sphere of occurrence, and should be by degrees, and more and more, applied to cases to which it did not historically belong. Now a very large majority of the words ending in n are accusatives plural and nominatives singular, to both of which cases comparative grammar clearly shows that a final s belongs as case-ending; and I can entertain no doubt that the whole phenomenon of the insertion of the sibilant arose from its preserva- tion in these forms, and from the inorganic extension of the same mode of combination, by analogy, to the much smaller classes of vocative, locative, and verbal forms.â€ I have quoted Whitneyâ€™s explanation in full, because it is an explanation which has been subsequently accepted without any challenge. In his footnote (1862: 86-87), Whitney offers statistical information pertaining to the occurrence of this type of sandhi. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤Ÿà¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®- à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥ƒà¥’à¤¹à¤¨à¥ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¥‘à¤£à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (H, N: à¤£à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ)(à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥«à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥ˆà¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¤¾ à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ Note: Most of the examples, not attested in the AV, are found in the KV on P.8.3.7 (à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥). Again we must note that Surya Kanta does not suggest that these examples are from the so-called now lost genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. It is absolutely unconscionable that the commentator does not offer a single example from the text of the Atharvan to illustrate this phenomenon, which is by no means rare in the Atharvan text. By citing the examples which he does, he shows how deeply influenced he is by the tradition of PÄá¹‡inian grammar. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥­. à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.27). E (orig), F (orig): à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾Â°. P: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤ªÂ°.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 292 Translation: In words like upabaddha [i.e. upabaddhÄn], [the final n], preceded by Ä, [is changed to a visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥], before a vowel. Note: While the previous rule survives in the classical language, the present rule is applicable only to Vedic language. Here, the visarjanÄ«ya is eventually replaced with y by CA (2.2.2), and by CA (2.1.21), this y is deleted. The other change taking place is the compensatory nasalization of the preceding vowel by CA (1.3.6). Thus, the sequence upabaddhÄn+iha is changed in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha to upabaddhÄÌƒ iha. In the classical usage, this would remain upa- baddhÄniha. It is not immediately obvious why the sandhi of devÄn+ca result- ing in devÄá¹ƒÅ›ca should retain the historical dimension down to the classical usage, while the combination upabaddhÄn+iti should lose that historical dimen- sion. As Whitney points out, â€œAll the cases in which this loss of a final n occurs are accusatives plural or nominatives singular, which originally pos- sessed a final s after the n, and the loss of the n before the sibilant, with ac- companying nasalization of the preceding vowel, and then the disappearance of the sibilant itself, as in other cases after Ä and before a vowel, are unquestiona- bly the cause of the sandhi as it finally presents itself.â€ The interesting thing is that there is no synchronic generalization of this rule to all cases with final -Än followed by a vowel, but the phenomenon is limited to a set of defined cases. For example, yÄtumÄn+ayam in AV (1.7.4) does not change to yÄtumÄÌƒ ayam. Whitney himself notes: â€œThe loss of the n with nasalization of the vowel is evidently an old-style sandhi, going out of use, and no longer appearing except sporadically. It is interesting, as regards this sandhi and that taught in the pre- ceding rule - which have both … the same historical origin - to note the rela- tions of the Rik and the Atharvan usage to one another and to the practice of the classical Sanskrit. The insertion of the s, which has become a necessary proceeding under the modern euphonic rules, is almost universal in the Athar- van, and comparatively rare in the Rik: the conversion of the n into anusvÄra, of which the general Sanskrit grammar knows nothing, is only infrequently observed in the Atharvan, while it is made in the Rik with but few exceptions.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¥‘à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¹à¤¾ à¤µà¥‘à¤¹â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤¾à¥’à¤¸ à¤‡à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤ à¤…à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾293 à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤ à¤…à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¤¸à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¤ªà¤¥à¤¾à¤à¥’ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: There is a slight error when Whitney says that the commentator cites five instances. The commentary cites only four instances. However, Whitney collects a complete list of such cases in the text of AV. The gaá¹‡a referred to in this CA rule is fully spelled out by the APR (196), and out of a total of 76 instances listed by the APR, the CAB cites the first four in the same order. This, in spite of Surya Kantaâ€™s view to the contrary, indicates a very close connection between the CAB and the APR. One should also note that Whitneyâ€™s listing does not completely match the listing of the gaá¹‡a as found in the APR, and the differences between these listings need to be further explored. All the instances listed under APR (196) are covered by Whitneyâ€™s listing, but Whitneyâ€™s listing contains substantially more instances. Below, I am listing those cases which are listed as showing a case of this rule, which are listed by Whitney, but are not found in the listing under APR (196): 1.19.3; 4.19.5; 4.19.7; 5.23.8; 6.15.1-2; 6.54.3; 6.69.2; 7.57.1; 7.65.1; 9.1.19; 10.3.14; 10.3.15; 11.9.22; 11.9.24; 13.2.5; 13.2.18; 13.2.21; 13.2.29; 14.1.45; 14.1.55; 14.2.10; 18.2.13; 18.2.18. Whitney also lists the following instances from the 19th and the 20th KÄá¹‡á¸a of the AV, which are completely left out of consideration by the APR (196): 19.6.8; 19.13.8; 19.26.3; 19.32.7; 19.36.4; 19.50.4; 19.59.2; 20.127.7; 20.128.4; 20.128.5; 20.128.8; 20.136.15. One needs to study all these instances indi- vidually. However, at first glance, it seems plausible that the scope of the ap- plication of this rule went on increasing even after the gaá¹‡a was fully listed by the APR. Such an increasing scope for this application is indeed puzzling, es- pecially since it is not represented in the classical language. One possible rea- son for it may be sought in the generally accepted RÌ¥gvedic influence on the AV tradition. As Whitney points out, this rule is applied in the â€œRik with but few exceptions,â€ the RÌ¥gvedic influence may have led the AV tradition in the direc- tion opposite to that of the classical language. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥®. à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.28). A, B, D, P: Â°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤‚Â°. E, F: Â°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤à¤½Â°. Hb, Nb: à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥Â°. O: Â°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿Â°.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 294 Translation: In the sequence vrÌ¥ká¹£Än vanÄni, [the final n changes to a visarjanÄ«ya] before v. Note: The rule specifically mentions the phrase vrÌ¥ká¹£Än vanÄni to re- strict this change to this instance. However, as Whitney points out: â€œThe counter-examples [e.g. vrÌ¥ká¹£Än vÄtaá¸¥ and vrÌ¥ká¹£Än vayÄá¸¥ cited by the CAB], however, are fabricated: no such passages occur in the Atharvan. Nor is the citation of vanÄni in the rule necessary, although excusable enough: a v follows vrÌ¥ká¹£Än in no other passage of the text, except in xii.1.51, where it is separated from it by an avasÄna, and so exercises upon it no euphonic influence.â€ In the example above, the n is changed to a visarjanÄ«ya, which is subsequently de- leted, and the preceding vowel is nasalized. This is also a type of sandhi which is not attested in the classical language. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤¿à¥’ à¤¸à¤‚ à¤šà¥‘à¤°â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥«. à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥‡(H, N: à¤®à¥ˆ)à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤®à¤¾ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯. à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤« à¤‹à¤¤à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¶à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.29): Â°à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾295 (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‹ à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥’à¤£à¥€à¤à¤°à¥’à¤­à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥§.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¥‘à¤¯à¥‚à¤à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¤ à¤¬à¥‹à¥‘à¤§à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: The gaá¹‡a referred to in this CA rule has been fully listed by the APR (197), and out of a total of eight instances listed therein, the CAB quotes the first three in the same order. On rule CA (2.1.26 = Whitney 2.26), Whitney offers a â€˜complete list of exceptionsâ€™ in a footnote. The APR (198) follows a different strategy. In- stead of formulating a gaá¹‡a of exceptions, it lists cases where the final n is pre- ceded by a short vowel and followed by t, where the n changes to a visarjanÄ«ya. After providing a listing of such cases, the APR says: à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾. This makes it difficult to directly compare Whitneyâ€™s data with those offered by the APR.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 296 Regarding the expression à¤¸à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥, Whitney (AV Transl, Vol. I., p. 11) points out the ambiguity involved in the form of the citation: â€œThe word (tam or tÄá¹ƒ) and its predecessor are quoted in the PrÄt. (ii.30 = CA 2.1.30), … but the form of the quotation (samairayantÄdÄ«nÄm) prevents our seeing whether its authors read tÄÌm or tÃ¡m; the comm. gives tÄm.â€ à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥§. à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.31). H, J, M, Na, P: Â°à¤¸à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ. A, B: à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡Â°. Translation: [A final] m, before a stop, is changed to a con- sonant which has the same point of articulation as the following [stop]. Note: In conjunction with CA (1.4.4: à¤†à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ), this rule changes the final m to a nasal consonant of the same point of articulation as the follow- ing stop. The CAB on CA (1.4.4) cites our present rule as an example where the principle of maximal featural proximity enunciated in CA (1.4.4) must ap- ply. Thus, the present rule changes the word-final m to á¹…, Ã±, á¹‡, n, or m, de- pending upon which stop follows m. We should note that PÄá¹‡ini allows the change of m to an anusvÄra and its maintenance before any consonant as an option to its change to a nasal homorganic with the following stop. PÄá¹‡ini also allows the change of m to nasal á»¹, á¹½, or lÌƒ, before y, v, and l. CA (2.1.35) makes allowance for only lÌƒ. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹(H, N: à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾- à¤¨à¥‹) à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¤¾à¥‘à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤µà¤¹à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¥‘à¤à¥à¤œà¥€à¥’à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¯- à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥«. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥’à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¬.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤¨à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥ˆà¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘ à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¾à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥«)à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ(H, N: à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ)à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥­.à¥«)à¥¤

E, F, Nb: No Visarga after à¤²à¥‹à¤ª. Translation: Before semi-vowels and spirants, [the word- final m is] deleted. Note: After deleting the m before semi-vowels and spirants, the pre- vious vowel is nasalized by CA (1.3.5: à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ). The CA procedure differs from PÄá¹‡ini in that PÄá¹‡ini allows the change of m to na- sal á»¹, á¹½, or lÌƒ, before y, v, and l. The CA (2.1.35) makes allowance for only lÌƒ. Before any consonant, PÄá¹‡ini also allows the maintenance of an anusvÄra. The anusvÄra is left out of consideration by the CA in favor of the nasalized vowel. Whitney on this rule surveys the variegated practice of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤°à¤à¥’ à¤µà¤°à¥à¥‘à¤£à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤§à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥©à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥ƒà¥‘à¤œà¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¤ à¤¶à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥©.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¥’à¤·(H,

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 298 N: à¤)à¤¤à¤ à¤¹à¥’à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤­à¥‚à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¸à¤¿ à¤¸à¤ à¤¸à¤®à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney is undoubtedly right in saying that this deletion of m carries with it the nasalization of the preceding vowel. The commentary cites only one counter-example: pratikÄmyaá¸¥ (AV 2.36.8). Whitney points out: â€œInstances of m before r in like position would not be hard to give - e.g. tÄmradhÅ«mrÄá¸¥ (x.2.11) - but it is found before l only in root syllables, as in malimlucam (viii.6.2), and before v only in the case which forms the subject of rule 37 (= CA 2.1.37), below.â€ Whitney also appropriately points out that â€œthis rule and the next concern mat- ters with which the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya properly has no concern,â€ because they deal with internal sandhis which are not altered during the transformations between the PadapÄá¹­ha and the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾299 à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥ª. à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.34). Translation: Also, n [is deleted before sibilants within a given word]. Note: This rule, like the previous rule, also deals with what may be strictly called an internal sandhi, which one would encounter only in the deri- vation of a given word, rather than in transformations between the PadapÄá¹­ha and the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. In that sense, as Whitney points out, these rules exceed the strictly defined scope of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. Interestingly, these rules provide us some insight into the grammatical derivations of words as understood by the CA. For instance, this rule assumes that a form like paruÌƒá¹£i is derived from parÅ«ná¹£i, while the previous rule assumes that a form like vÄ©Å›ati is derived from vimÅ›ati. For instance, in the derivation of the form paruÌƒá¹£i, PÄá¹‡ini starts with parus+i. Then, P.7.1.72 (à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤²à¤šà¤ƒ) prescribes the augment nUM, which goes after the u of parus, leading to paruns+i. The CA seems to assume a somewhat similar process. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥‚à¤

à¥‘à¤·à¤¿à¥’ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¥‚à¥‘à¤·à¤¿à¥’ à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¬.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹(N: à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾) à¤¹à¥’à¤µà¥€à¤à¤·à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ à¤Šà¤·à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥Œà¤¦à¥€à¥’ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿ à¤•à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: Again the manuscripts show merely the anusvÄra, where one would expect to find a nasalized vowel. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥«. à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.35). A, B, D, J: Â°à¤­à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹Â° for Â°à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹Â°. Translation: Both [i.e. m and n] are changed to a nasal lÌƒ before an l. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 300 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥®. à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¤¿à¥’(H, N: à¤¤à¥€)- à¤®à¤¾à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥€à¥’à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤²à¥à¤à¤²à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥®.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the citation from AV (18.4.5), Whitney (AV Transl. Translation: [The m] of sam is not [deleted] before [the r of the root] rÄj. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¡à¥‡à¤•à¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿ à¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤œà¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬. à¥©à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¥’ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¥‘à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤¤ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ(H, N: à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥) à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¥‘à¤§à¤¿ à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤¤ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ Note: A possible counter-example to this rule may be the form saá¹ƒ- [sÃ£?]rÄdhayantaá¸¥ in AV (3.30.5). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾301 à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥­. à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤š à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.37). A, B (corr), K, P: à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡. B (orig), D, M: Â°à¤šà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡. J: Â°à¤šà¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡. Translation: Also before v resulting from a sandhi, [the m is not deleted]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­- à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹à¥‘ à¤†à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬. à¥«à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: Here, the sequence sam v ÄsnÄ is derived by the change of u to v before the following Ä. The Mss H adds Å«á¹ƒ iti at the end. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥®. à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤šà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.38). A, B, D, K, P(corr): place Daá¹‡á¸a after à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ, and treat the rest as a separate SÅ«tra. Ha, Na: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ. Translation: [In a stop+stop combination], in the reverse order of the stop-series [i.e. reverse of the normal order: k- series, c-series, á¹­-series, t-series, and the p-series], there is an insertion of a sphoá¹­ana [i.e. a vocalic particle of one-eighth mora length, between the stops], if the first [stop of the combination] occurs at the end [of a pada]. Note: The term sphoá¹­ana has been discussed at length in the Note to CA (1.4.12: à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ). Referring to sphoá¹­ana, Allen (1953: 74) says: â€œThis would appear to indicate a type of svarabhakti, whether voiced or voiceless, the infinitesimal duration of which is suggested by the specification of a value 1/8 a, in fact a minimal audible release. The mechanism of the feature referred to is perhaps the release of the front closure during the formation but before the completion of the back closure, resulting in the momentary outflow of an air- stream attenuated by the back constriction.â€ I agree with Whitney that the term viparyaya refers to not just â€˜differ- ence of the series,â€™ but to their reverse order, i.e. where a stop is followed by another stop belonging to a series pronounced farther back on the oral track.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 302 All the instances offered by the commentary fit this pattern: á¹­+k, t+k, b+k, and d+g. Whitney says: â€œThat the Hindu theory allows sphoá¹­ana in the combina- tion of the phrase only in the case two mutes meet in the inverse order of the vargas to which they belong has something of arbitrariness in it, yet is not without foundation; for it may be noted, I think, that it is perceptibly harder to change from a contact farther forward in the mouth to one farther back, than to make a like transfer in the contrary direction, without allowing any intervening escape of breath or sound: and the order of the vargas follows the advance in the mouth of the place of formation.â€ Allenâ€™s explanation given above is not very different from Whitneyâ€™s. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤šà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤·à¤Ÿà¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¬. à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¥’à¤œà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«. à¥¨à¥©.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¬à¥à¤—à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤—à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥ à¤•à¥‹ à¤…à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥‡à¥’à¤£à¥‹- à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤—à¤¾à¥‘ à¤‡à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥€ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤—à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Referring to the citation of AV (1.27.3), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 28) says that SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s reading is udgÄs for adgÄs as given by the CAB, and that neither word is quotable from elsewhere. For Whitneyâ€™s comment on avatkÃ¡m, see the Note on CA (1.4.12). Whitney criticizes the interpretation of the term pÅ«rveá¹‡a assumed by the CAB. For the commentary, the term pÅ«rva â€˜previous,â€™ seems to mean non- final, i.e. non-nasal. The term pÅ«rva simply refers to the earlier member in a consonant-cluster. The commentary seems to exclude the combinations of nasals with non-nasals from the occurrence of sphoá¹­ana. Whitney suggests that these must be included, and offers the following examples: keÅ›Än+ khÄdantaá¸¥ (AV 5.19.3), vidvÄn+gandharvaá¸¥ (AV 2.1.2), and devÄn+ghrÌ¥tavatÄ (AV 3.10.11). Whitney supports his interpretation by pointing out that â€œthe VÄj. Pr. makes no such exception of the nasals.â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾303 à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥¯. à¤¨ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.39). A, B, D, M: à¤¨ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ … à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥¥. P also divides the rule in the same way. Ha, Na: Â°à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°. I: 39. Translation: There is [no insertion of a sphoá¹­ana] when a stop of the á¹­-series is followed by a stop of the c-series. How- ever, here there is a prolongation of time [needed to pronounce the cluster], and that [prolongation] is called kará¹£aá¹‡a [i.e. â€˜drag- gingâ€™]. Note: The term kará¹£aá¹‡a is not met with in the phonetic literature elsewhere. Whitney remarks: â€œIt is easy to see the physical ground of this ex- ception to the rule prescribing sphoá¹­ana. The same close relationship with re- spect to place of utterance which causes the final palatal to pass often into a lin- gual instead of reverting to the guttural out of which it originally grew, causes the lingual, in coming before the palatal, to virtually double it only. The trans- fer of position of the organs is too slight and easy to necessitate the emission of an intervening sound.â€ Also see Allen (1953: 74-75). Perhaps, the CA needs an interpretation different from the one offered by Whitney. The extension of duration (kÄlaviprakará¹£a) in this case is explainable by referring to the fact that the retroflex stops require the curling of oneâ€™s tongue and touching the top of the oral cavity with the underside of the tip of the tongue. On the other hand, the pronunciation of the palatal stops requires touching the tÄlu by the middle of the tongue. Making a switch from the one to the other obviously involves a major rearrangement of the articulatory organs. The reason that there is no sphoá¹­ana is that there is no discontinuity of the contact of the tongue-tip moving from the retroflex to palatal position, and hence no intermediate release of breath. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤Ÿà¥ à¤šà¥‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤Ÿà¥ à¤šà¥‘ à¤®à¥‡ à¤·à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥«.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¤¡à¥ à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 304 à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ C, E, F, H, N: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. A, B, D, M, P: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. I, J: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. O: à¤š. à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥©à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ ____________________________________

à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§. à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.40). A, B, D, Ha, J, M, Na, P: Â°à¤¸à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹Â°. O: Â°à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¥‡. Translation: The visarjanÄ«ya [= á¸¥], before a voiceless [con- sonant], is changed to a [maximally similar consonant] which has the same point of articulation as the following [voiceless consonant]. Note: This rule clearly works in conjunction with CA (1.4.4: à¤†à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ) in ensuring that of all possible sounds which share the same point of arti- culation as the following voiceless consonant, only the consonant which is maximally similar with a visarjanÄ«ya will be substituted. The CAB on CA (1.4.4) cites the present rule as an illustration for the use of the general princi- ple of finding a substitute which is maximally similar to the original. For in- stance, in a case like yaá¸¥+ca, the possible substitutes include all the sounds which share the same point of articulation as c, i.e. i-vowels, e, c-series, and Å›. Of all these possible substitutes, CA (1.4.4) will permit only Å› to replace á¸¥ in the above example, because Å› is maximally similar to á¸¥, i.e. it is voiceless and a spirant. Thus, the above rule predicts that the á¸¥ becomes a jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya, i.e. á¸«, before k, and kh; it becomes Å› before c, ch, and Å›; it becomes á¹£ before á¹­, á¹­h, and á¹£; it becomes s before t, th, and s; and it becomes upadhmÄnÄ«ya, i.e. áº–, before p, and ph. Whitney notes that â€œThe theory of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya, however, is not at all the practice of the manuscripts, and the latter, rather than the former, has been followed by us in the printed text.â€ Other editions of the AV also follow the same practice. Whitney points out that none of the AV manuscripts distin- guish the jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya and the upadhmÄnÄ«ya from the visarjanÄ«ya, and approv- ingly he says: â€œas we cannot but think, with much reason: since the division of this indistinct and indefinite sound into three different kinds of indefiniteness savors strongly of an over-refinement of analysis.â€ On the one hand, Whitneyâ€™s discussion is suggestive of the distinction of phonemic versus allo- phonic sounds as it developed later in linguistics. On the other hand, it is also indicative of the emphasis he put on the written versus oral comprehension of

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 306 the text of the AV, and the fact that the texts like CA were not aimed at de- scribing the practice of writing, but at the accurate pronunciation of the Vedic texts. The best Vedic recitation even today distinguishes between these three sounds, though they are not represented in the manuscripts. For a critique of Whitneyâ€™s views, see: Allen (1953: 50). While Whitney concentrated primarily on the written evidence, Allen (1953: 51) offers a historical understanding which bridges the early descrip- tions of pronunciation and the later practice of writing: â€œIn later, though still ancient, times there appears to have been a tendency for -á¸¥ to extend its usage to contexts other than in pausa. The earliest of these extensions was to the po- sition before the initial fricatives Å›-, á¹£-, s-, where it replaced the homorganic final -Å›, -á¹£, -s (indraÅ› Å›Å«raá¸¥ > indraá¸¥ Å›Å«raá¸¥, etc.). This practice was then ex- tended to the position before the velar and labial voiceless stops: in connexion with this innovation we find mentioned the names of Ä€gniveÅ›ya, VÄlmÄ«ki, ÅšÄkalya, and the MÄdhyandina school, whilst the ancient grammarian ÅšÄkaá¹­Ä- yana is quoted as holding to the more conservative practice. These changes have been generally accepted so far as the writing of Sanskrit is concerned, and A.H. Fry in his article â€˜A Phonemic Interpretation of Visargaâ€™ has suggested that the spread of -á¸¥ was due to the writers of Classical Sanskrit â€˜operating with a phonemic orthographyâ€™. Though the term â€˜orthographyâ€™ once again begs the vexed question of writing, it is possible that this extension had a phonological rather than a phonetic basis.â€ A history of the actual recitational practice is difficult to reconstruct, though occasionally one does come across reciters who exhibit clear differences between the pronunciation of these sounds. Therefore, conclusions based solely on manuscript material are not an appropriate reflection of the recitational practice. Whitney provides a detailed survey of the views of different PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas in his comments. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¥’à¤•à¥‹à¥’à¤·à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤šà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤·à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·- à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¤²à¥à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥à¤œà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤œà¥‡ à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¥’ à¤ªà¤¸à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥’à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤œà¤¯à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥ªà¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’à¤¯à¥’-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾307 à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¥’à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¥’ à¤œà¤—à¥‘à¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤–à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥¨à¥©)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥®à¥¯.- à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‘(H: à¤£à¤¾, N: à¤£à¥‹)à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¥’- à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥(H, N: à¤¸à¥à¤¥)à¤¨à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥®.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‹à¥’(H, N: à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‹)à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: Whitney rightly says: â€œbefore k and kh it (= visarjanÄ«ya) be- comes jihvÄmÅ«lÄ«ya, and, before p and ph, upadhmÄnÄ«ya – these last two spi- rants being, as already noticed, clearly implied in this rule, although nowhere referred to by name as belonging to the scheme of spoken sounds recognized by the treatise.â€ The mss. do not orthographically distinguish these two sounds from the visarjanÄ«ya. Referring to this rule, Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39) says: â€œThe prescription is unmistakable, and must have been carried out by the ÅšaunakÄ«yas. This is not followed by the Vulgate mss., which, instead, drop the visarjanÄ«ya altogether before a sibilant followed by a surd or sonant mute, a usage sanctioned by the APr. 80. Compare VyÄsaÅ›iká¹£Ä 156 for this against TPr. 9.1., which is ignored by the TS. mss.; thus indicating a hopeless mixture of Å›ÄkhÄ variations.â€ Here Surya Kanta is again looking for homogeneous and authentic Å›ÄkhÄ manuscripts. However, the kind of change which is advocated by the CA perhaps became so outdated by the time the AV was committed to writing, that even the ÅšaunakÄ«yas may have disregarded the explicit prescription of their own tradition under the pressure of the more cur- rent practice of writing Sanskrit. For such a possible historical development, see: Allen (1953: 51). This possibility cannot be easily discounted. By Surya Kantaâ€™s own admission, the APR represents a somewhat later formulation as compared to CA, and it may have impacted the writing of the AV even in the ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition. The example à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¤à¥‡, which is not attested in a Vedic text, is found in the KV on P.8.2.41 (à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ƒ). It is interesting to note that Surya Kanta does not suggest that this instance belonged to the so-called genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya re- cension of the AV which is now supposedly lost. For a discussion of related textual problems, see Lanman (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 976): â€œThe rationale of the corruption is not hard to see: the hiatus between c and d being once covered by the fusion of the final of jambhaya with the ÄÌ of ÄÌ stenam, nothing was easier than to see a form jambhayÄs in the first part of the combination, and then to substitute tÃ©na for the vastly less

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 308 common stenÃ¡m or for the meaningless tenÃ¡m (which might be read out of the combination: see PrÄt. ii. 40, note); the exigency of the meter occasioned by the blunder with jambhayÄs then made the insertion of tÃ¡m easy. With the Berlin solution of the corruption, the meter is in perfect order.â€ For AV (19.47.8), Whitney-Roth read à¤œà¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤‚ (from assumed jambhaya Ä stenam), while the VVRI edition reads à¤œà¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤‚, with the PadapÄá¹­ha: à¤œà¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤®à¥. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥¨. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.41). C: Â°à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ. Translation: Before a vowel, [a visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥] is changed to y. Note: Whitney says: â€œIt is very hard to say whether the conversion into y is a matter of grammatical theory only, or whether it gives account of an actual process of phonetic transition.â€ For a fuller discussion of this issue, see the Note on CA (2.1.21). Re- ferring to the former, which was the only reading accessible to Whitney, he says: â€œperhaps the reading is corrupt, and va Äpaá¸¥ (iii.13.7) or na Äpaá¸¥ (xii.1.30) is the passage intended.â€ Now the manuscript N has provided the proper reading sarva Äpaá¸¥ which is attested in AV (16.4.6). à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥©. à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.42).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾309 Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥], preceded by a nÄmin [i.e. a vowel other than a and Ä], is changed to r, [before a vowel]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¥‘à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥­.à¥§à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥’à¤®à¤¿- à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜Â°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤¹à¤‚ à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤µà¥’ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤µà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥©.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥’à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥§.à¥®)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥ª. à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.43). A, B, D: Â°à¤¤à¥€Â°. Translation: Also, before a voiced [consonant, the visarja- nÄ«ya, preceded by a vowel other than a and Ä, is changed to r]. Note: This rule, in conjunction with the preceding rule, raises some questions about the meaning of the term ghoá¹£avat, and why the vowels are not covered by this term. These same questions are also raised by the usage of this term in other rules. For a discussion, see the Note on CA (1.1.5), and Introduction, section 5.11. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€- à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡- à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¥’à¤—à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥«.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¥’à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ƒà¥‘à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤®à¥’à¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¥‹à¥’ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¥‘à¤°à¤¸à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ Note: On the preceding rule, and its commentary, Whitney says: â€œThere is here another lacuna in the manuscript: immediately upon the citation tair amitrÄá¸¥ follow tasyÄ agnir vatsaá¸¥ and the other illustrations of the conver- sion of visarjanÄ«ya preceded by an alterant vowel into r before a sonant conso- nant, and then follow the words ghoá¹£avati ca, before the rule Ävaá¸¥ etc. It is evident that the copyist has leaped over the rule ghoá¹£avati ca, together with its own paraphrase, the final repetition of the preceding rule, and perhaps some of the illustrative citations belonging to one or both of them. There is no reason

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 310 whatever to suppose that anything more than this is omitted, or that any rule is lost altogether.â€ Fortunately, this lacuna is fully made up by the second manu- script, N, now available to me. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥«. à¤†à¤µà¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¤°à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.44). A, D, Hab, O, P: Â°à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤°Â°. A, B, D: Â°à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ. Nb, Hb: à¤†à¤µà¤·à¥à¤•Â°. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a at the end of this rule as a correction. Translation: [Also, the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of] Ävaá¸¥, kaá¸¥, akaá¸¥, ca vi vaá¸¥, and abibhaá¸¥ [is changed to r, before a vowel or a voiced consonant], when [these] are not pronominal [expres- sions]. Note: As Whitney points out, â€œIn this and the following rules, as far as the 49th (= CA 2.2.10) inclusive, are treated the words whose final visar- janÄ«ya represents an original r, and not s, and in which, accordingly, the r is liable to reappear before a sonant initial, even though a or Ä precede.â€ One should note that the CA itself does not have a notion of an â€˜original r.â€™ The starting point of the rule for the CA is not some abstract derivational or lexical sequence, but the expression as found in the PadapÄá¹­ha, i.e. a word as it would appear before pause. The recitational tradition converted the so-called â€˜origi- nalâ€™ r to a visarjanÄ«ya before pause, and then this visarjanÄ«ya became the start- ing point for our rule. For instance, the CA does not have a rule parallel to P.8.3.15 (à¤–à¤°à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ) which says: â€œBefore a voiceless consonant (= khaR) or a pause (avasÄna), an r is replaced with a visarjanÄ«ya.â€ The CA rule takes off from where P.8.3.15 leaves a derivation. Whitney also points out that there is some built-in â€˜superfluity.â€™ The commentary says that some instances are cited along with a few associated words to avoid generalization and to limit the listing to these specific cases. Whitney says that the final condition added to the rule, i.e. exclusion of pro- nominal usages achieves the same purpose, and, therefore, there is â€˜super- fluity.â€™ In all the examples cited by the commentary, except AV (6.81.3), the visarjanÄ«ya is not followed by either a vowel or a voiced consonant in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. Thus, where would one see the change of visarjanÄ«ya to r? The commentary offers examples of repetition (parihÄra) of the word concerned with an interposed iti. This creates an occasion for the change of visarjanÄ«ya to r before iti. Concerning this cited repetition, Whitney makes a very significant

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾311 observation: â€œIt will be observed that the commentator repeats each word to which the rule applies with iti interposed, except in the last case, where the r appears in saá¹ƒhitÄ. This is in accordance with the usage of the pada-text of the Rigveda, but not with that of the Atharvan, which in no single instance per- forms parihÄra of a word ending in a riphita visarjanÄ«ya; and we must accord- ingly regard the repetitions as taken from the krama-text, which would give such a form to the words in question, as standing at the end of a line.â€ He also points to the deviant behavior of the 20th KÄá¹‡á¸a: â€œExcepting in the twentieth book, whose pada-text is shown by this and other peculiarities to be merely a putting together of extracts from that of the Rik.â€ The fact that the CA does not note the deviant behavior of the 20th KÄá¹‡á¸a probably indicates that the 20th KÄá¹‡á¸a was added to the AV after the formation of the CA. The examples cited by the commentary are mostly found among the examples on APR (141). The CA rule lists instances which show this phenomenon neither in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, nor in the PadapÄá¹­ha, but only in the KramapÄá¹­ha. [However, we have prÄtar iti in the PadapÄá¹­ha for RV 4.35.7a]. This is nowhere clearly stated in the rule or in the commentary, but is an inference of Whitney. Un- fortunately, I have not been able to confirm this practice with modern-day re- citers of the AV, none of whom could recite the Krama. I have now found a few manuscripts of the KramapÄá¹­ha and Jaá¹­ÄpÄá¹­ha for the ÅšAV, but unfortunately not for the sections containing these instances. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤š à¤µà¤¿ à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤†à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¤šà¥‹à¥‘ à¤µà¥‡à¥’à¤¨ à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤†à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤†à¤µà¤ƒ à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥’(H, N: à¤¤à¥€) à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¹ à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‘à¤µà¥‡ à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤•à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¤‚à¥’ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤‹à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤…à¤•à¤°à¤¿- à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿ à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’ à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¥’- à¤®à¤¸à¥‘à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’ à¤µà¤¿ à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤š à¤µà¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‘à¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¬à¤¿à¥‘à¤­à¥’à¤°à¤¦à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥®à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸- à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¤¿à¤°à¥‘à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¥’ à¤…à¤¤à¥ƒà¥‘à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¯à¥’à¤¦à¤¾ à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®
