à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾313 à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ [? no place for parihÄra for ahÄá¸¥ in AV 7.53.3)à¥¤ à¤…à¤œà¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¤¾à¥’ à¤…à¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦.à¥­)à¥¤ Note: Whitney suggests an alternative formulation for this rule: â€œAn equivalent and, one would think, preferable form for this rule would have been harater ahÄá¸¥, â€˜ahÄá¸¥ when coming from the root har (hrÌ¥).â€ Whitneyâ€™s sugges- tion has the merit of brevity. The commentary of [pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a, on AV (6. 103.2-3, and 7.53.3) paraphrases the form ÄhÄá¸¥ with root hrÌ¥, and AV (13.1.5) refers back to the form ÄhÄá¸¥ in (13.1.4) with Ä ahÄrá¹£Ä«t. Thus, all the three ex- amples are from the root hrÌ¥ (harati). With the examples cited for this rule, it is clear that the rule applies to a few cases in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha such as AV (6.103.2, 3) and (7.53.3); and that there is a counter-example from the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, i.e. AV (2.10.7). The in- stance in AV (13.1.4) must be assumed as a case of KramapÄá¹­ha. Referring to the passage â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¹ à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ in the CAB, Whitney makes an impor- tant observation: â€œiha rÄá¹£á¹­ram Ä â€™hÄá¸¥ (xiii.1.4: the commentator, or the copyist, omits to add ahÄr ity ahÄá¸¥), and agniá¹£ á¹­ad Ä â€™hÄá¸¥ (vii.53.3: here is added ahÄr ity ahÄá¸¥, but it is out of place, the word not standing in pausa; perhaps the parihÄra has slipped away from its proper place after the preceding citation to this: but then the word following ahÄá¸¥ should also have been quoted in the last passage, and it should read agniá¹£ á¹­ad Ä â€™hÄr nirrÌ¥teá¸¥).â€ The kind of ill-arrange- ment of the text of the commentary referred to by Whitney must have taken place at a relatively early period, since it is shared by both the available manu- scripts, H and N. Referring to AV (2.10.7), Whitney says: â€œThe comment to PrÄt. ii.46 (= CA 2.2.7) quotes ahÄs in this verse as not ahÄr, i.e. as from hÄ, not hrÌ¥â€ (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 52). The commentary of [pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a also paraphrases ahÄá¸¥ in this passage with ahÄsÄ«á¸¥ atyÄká¹£Ä«á¸¥. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥®. à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.47), C, Hbc, N: Â°à¤°à¥ŒÂ°. Other mss. read Â°à¤°à¥‹Â°. A, B, D: Â°à¤¤à¥ˆÂ°. A, B: Â°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 314 Translation: [Also, the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥], belonging to a vocative singular of [a noun] which has a dual form ending in - rau, [is changed to r, before a vowel or a voiced consonant]. Note: Concerning the formulation of this rule, Whitney makes an important observation: â€œHere, as in more than one other instance, our treatise shows a greater readiness than the others to avail itself of the help of grammati- cal categories in constructing its rules: all the other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas laboriously rehearse in detail, one by one, the words which are here disposed of as a class, in one brief rule.â€ The procedure is also to be contrasted with PÄá¹‡ini. For PÄá¹‡ini, it is not the case that one takes the forms of words as they would ap- pear before pause, and then combine them by removing the pause. Certain forms may lexically or derivationally end in r. Such r-final forms may then be followed either by pause or by other words beginning with vowels or conso- nants. P.8.3.15 (à¤–à¤°à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ) says that a final r is changed to a visar- janÄ«ya before voiceless consonants, or before pause. Thus, by exclusion, it is left unchanged before vowels and voiced consonants. Thus, PÄá¹‡ini neither needs, nor has, a rule which changes the word-final (pre-pausal) visarjanÄ«ya to r in some cases, after removal of that pause. The construction of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ- pÄá¹­ha from the PadapÄá¹­ha essentially amounts to the removal of pause between the separated items. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤š- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©. à¥­à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¥‡à¥‘ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤§à¥‡à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥¬à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤šà¥‘à¤®à¥‡à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯. à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¥’(H, N: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾) à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤° à¤Šà¥’à¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤µà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥­.à¥¯)à¥¤ à¤°à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¥‡à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¸à¥Œ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Note: The example(s) à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿ and à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿ are not found in the Vul- gate of the ÅšAV. Whitney rightly points out that à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿ belongs properly under

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾315 the next rule. Whitney first makes a suggestion: â€œbut possibly the three phrases form a single passage together, and are a genuine citation from some other text.â€ Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40), carrying Whitneyâ€™s sug- gestion forward, construes these three to be part of a single passage suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. In any case, there is no trace of these in any known Vedic text. One finds several instances of à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ in AV, e.g. AV (7.17.1-3), and it is possible that the commentator created the example à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿ from such associations. An actual instance à¤§à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤ƒ is found in AV (7.18.1). à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥¯. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.48). Note: Whitney observes: â€œThe other treatises exclude the noun Ã¡nta by defining the accent of antÃ¡á¸¥, and the Rik Pr. treats svÃ¡á¸¥ in the same way – a method which renders necessary considerable additional limitation and expla- nation.â€ For the PÄá¹‡inian procedure, see the Note on CA (2.2.8). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¥‡ à¤œà¥à¥‘à¤¹à¥à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥’à¤°à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤­à¤—à¤‚à¥‘ à¤ªà¤·à¤£à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¨à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥à¥‘à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µ[ï†„]à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥‘ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤…à¤°à¥‘à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥‘à¤—à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤—à¥à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤½à¤…à¤—à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤½à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®, à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ ! â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥‘à¤—à¥à¤°à¤ƒà¥’ à¤¸à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥®à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 316 Note: Whitneyâ€™s text for AV (2.5.2) does not show the change of n to á¹‡. However, he says (AV Transl. ÅšÅšS. svÃ r á¹‡Ã¡; and the mss. vary between the two; our edition reads the former with the majority of our mss.; SSP. has the latter, with the majority of his.â€ à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.49). Ha, Na: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤š. I: 10. P(orig): à¤§à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š. P(corr): à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š. Translation: Also, [the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of the word svaá¸¥, in the combination] svará¹£Äá¸¥ (< svaá¸¥+sÄá¸¥). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤·à¤®à¥‘à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨.à¥®)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥’à¤¸à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤¸à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ Note: The commentary points out that the full expression svará¹£Äá¸¥ is mentioned to indicate that the change of á¸¥ of svaá¸¥ to r takes place here in spite of the fact that the following consonant is a voiceless spirant. The previous rules make this change only before vowels and voiced consonants. Then, the commentary says that this change takes place only in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. Whitney notes that this implies that the above change does not take place in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Since the PadapÄá¹­ha actually separates the components svaá¸¥ and sÄá¸¥ from each other, the item svaá¸¥ is in fact followed by a pause, rather than by sÄá¸¥. Therefore, Whitney comments: â€œThis last is rather a gratuitous piece of information.â€ Actually, the commentary is quoting not the PadapÄá¹­ha, but the parihÄra or repetition of a final word interposed with iti as it appears in the KramapÄá¹­ha. In the KramapÄá¹­ha, the second time the word appears, its compo- nents are separated from each other, but not when it appears the first time. However, even in the first occurrence, changes like s>á¹£ are restored, cf. CA (4.3.6: à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥) and the commentary CAB on this rule. Thus, in the parihÄra for svará¹£Äá¸¥, we do not get svará¹£Äá¸¥ in either repetition. The first time the word is given, svaá¸¥ is not separated from sÄá¸¥, and yet á¸¥ is not changed to r, nor is s changed to á¹£. Thus, the comment of the CAB seems to have a proper place, and need not be discarded following Whitney. This instance of Krama is now attested from AV 20.11.4 in the BORI ms. 133/1879-80, folio 6.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾317 Another point one should note is that the term saá¹ƒhitÄ in the commen- tary is used in the sense of Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, rather than its normal later meaning of sandhi or absence of separation. In the parihÄra, the word is first given as svaá¸¥sÄá¸¥. Here, by classical standards, we have an occasion for sandhi, since there is no separation of components. However, this is not the same thing as the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥§. à¤…à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤¸à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.50). Ha, Na: no Repha. The mss. H reads à¤¸à¤ªà¤¹à¥‹, which Whitney reported as à¤¸à¤®à¤¹à¥‹ without even noting the actual mss. reading. Now the mss. N provides a much more acceptable reading à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¹à¥‹. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 318 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤°à¤¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥«à¥«)à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤°à¥‚à¤ª à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤œà¥ˆ.à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾. à¥¨.à¥¨à¥§à¥¦; à¥¨à¥§à¥©)à¥¤ à¤°à¥‚à¤ª à¥¤ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¥‹à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¥’ à¤¨à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¥‹à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥‘à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¬.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤°à¤¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤° à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¤¥- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤® à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (not in knownVedic texts)à¥¤ Note: Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39-40) says that the com- bination of Ã¡has with rÅ«pÃ¡ and rathaá¹ƒtarÃ¡ does not occur in the Vulgate of the AV, and suggests that a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya version of the AV probably contained such examples. I believe, Whitney was correct in his suggestion: â€œIt is a very suspicious circumstance that a vÄrttika to a rule of PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s (viii.2.68, ahno ruvidhau rÅ«parÄtrirathantareá¹£Å«pasaá¹ƒkhyÄnaá¹ƒ kartavyam) mentions the same three exceptions which our rule gives: and it is very probable that our treatise in this case, as in several others, has constructed its rule so as to include all the cases noted as occurring in general usage; and hence, that the two phrases quoted are not necessarily to be regarded as having constituted a part of the Atharvan text for which the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya was composed.â€ This is a far more realistic explanation. Whitney did not suggest that these were merely â€œslips of memory on the part of the CA-writer,â€ as alleged by Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39). The reading as cited by Surya Kanta (p. 40), i.e. Â°sÄma gÄyati, is not supported either by Whitney, or by mss. H and N. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥©. à¤Šà¤§à¥‹à¤½à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤­à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.52). P: à¤Šà¤§à¥à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹Â°. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correc- tion. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of [the words] Å«dhaá¸¥, amnaá¸¥, and bhuvaá¸¥ [is not changed to r]. Notes: Whitney observes: â€œThis rule is utterly idle in our treatise, since no precept has been given which should in any way require or authorize the conversion into r of the final of these words. The original form of Å«dhas,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾319 however, is Å«dhar, as is clearly shown by the comparison of the kindred lan- guages, …, and by its treatment in the Rig-Veda; and the Rik. Pr. … Neither of the other treatises takes notice of it or of either of the words here associated with it. All three, however, are noted by PÄá¹‡ini (viii.2.70, 71), as words which may or may not, in Vedic use, change their final into r.â€ The svarÄdi-gaá¹‡a mentioned in P.1.1.37 (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤®à¥), as given in BÃ¶htlingk (1887: 144), includes bhuvar, amnas, and amnar. While Whitney is absolutely correct in saying that there is no rule in the CA to authorize the change of á¸¥ of these words into r, the very existence of the present rule, combined with the information given by PÄá¹‡ini, would make it understandable that this matter did weigh on the mind of the author of the CA. It seems that this rule may have been intended to distinguish the ÅšAV recita- tional tradition from the traditions of the other Vedas. In the larger context of other traditions, the author of the CA assumes a possibility of the visarjanÄ«ya in these words being changed to r, perhaps unwittingly, and the present rule sim- ply wards off such a possibility. Clearly, the inherited texts of the AV, i.e. the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha and the PadapÄá¹­ha do not show a case of the visarjanÄ«ya of any of these words changing to r. Perhaps, the author of the CA was really concerned with such a change happening in cases of parihÄra in the KramapÄá¹­ha, such as would be occasioned for the word Å«dhas in AV (8.10.12), where the word oc- curs at the end of the line: à¤—à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤­à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‚à¤§à¤ƒà¥‘. With the present rule, the author of the CA perhaps wanted to ensure the parihÄra as à¤Šà¤§ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤§à¤ƒ, rather than as à¤Šà¤§à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤§à¤ƒ. If the tradition of the AV was coming under an increasing influence of the RV tradition, then such a fear may be understandable. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤Šà¤§à¤¸à¥, à¤…à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥, à¤­à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œ- à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹ à¤…à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’ à¤Šà¤§à¥‹à¥’ à¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¥’à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥§à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¥à¥’ à¤¸à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥«à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥‘ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Surya Kanta says that the example à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¥à¥’ à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘ as a passage cited by the CAB is not found in the Vulgate of the AV, and he (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that this may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the Vulgate is not the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. Here again it is obvious that he has confused Whitneyâ€™s statements. Whitney says that the example à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¥à¥’ à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘ is found in

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 320 the commentaries on PÄá¹‡ini (8.2.70, 71), and that the CAB gives à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¥à¥’ à¤¸à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘, which is not found in the AV. Now the new critical edition of the KV (Osmania University edn., Vol. 2, p. 927), based on mss. evidence gives exactly the same example as given by our commentary, and it refers it to RV 10.50.4, which is the same reference given for à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥‘à¤·à¥à¥’ à¤­à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘ by Surya Kanta. The text of RV 10.50.4 unambiguously reads savaneá¹£u and not bhuvaneá¹£u as cited by Surya Kanta. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª. à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.53). J, M, O: à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹Â°. Translation: [A visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥], preceded by a, is changed to u, before a. Note: This rule works in conjunction with other rules. After the visa- rjanÄ«ya is changed to u, this u is combined with the preceding a to yield an o by CA (3.2.22: à¤‰à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£ à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ), and then the following a is combined with the pre- ceding o to yield an o by CA (3.2.30: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰(H, N: à¤“, W: à¤‰)à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥‡à¥‘à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥­.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥‡à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: The CAB, or perhaps the copyists, render the rule incorrectly by stating that the visarjanÄ«ya changes to o. That would have led to the word- ing of the original rule to be akÄropadhasya+okÄraá¸¥+akÄre > akÄropadhasyau- kÄro â€™kÄre. This is not supported by any manuscript. Without noting the devi- ant explanation of the CAB, Whitney correctly translates: â€œvisarjanÄ«ya be- comes u.â€ In fact, he cites the commentary as: akÄropadhasya visarjanÄ«yasyo â€™kÄro bhavati. However, this is a reading corrected by Whitney. The original reading of both the manuscripts is given above in the text. The commentary of KrÌ¥á¹£á¹‡adÄsa on this rule (= PS 267) also correctly interprets this rule: à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤. About the text of the rule as given by the manuscript H, Whitney comments: â€œThis rule is much mutilated by the copyist, both in its first state- ment (akÄro â€™kÄre) and in its final repetition (akÄropadhasyokÄre), so that its true form is only restorable from the commentatorâ€™s paraphrase. … Evidently

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾321 the triple recurrence of the syllables kÄro, kÄro, kÄre bothered the copyistâ€™s weak head, and he stumbled from the one to the other of them in an utterly helpless manner.â€ It is to Whitneyâ€™s credit that, in spite of the mutilated text in the manuscript H, he correctly guessed the proper wording of this rule, which is now fully confirmed by the second manuscript, N. Evidently, the copyist for the second manuscript did not have what Whitney called a â€œweak head,â€ and he was not bothered by the triple recurrence of the syllables kÄro, kÄro, and kÄre. On the whole, the manuscript N presents a better state of the text of the com- mentary and the rules. It is also chronologically slightly earlier than the manu- script H. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥«. à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.54). Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, preceded by a, is changed to u], also before a voiced [consonant]. Note: This rule works in conjunction with CA (3.2.22: à¤‰à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£ à¤“à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ), which combines a and u into an o. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸- à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤‹à¥’à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥‹à¥‘ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥®.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤ªà¤¤à¥’ à¤¬à¥€à¤œà¥‘à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¬. à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.55). A, B, D, M, P: à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹Â°. Hb, Nb: Â°à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤ƒ. Translation: [A visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] preceded by Ä, is deleted [before a voiced consonant]. Note: As Whitney notes, â€œthe case of Äá¸¥ before a vowel was included in ii. 41 (= CA 2.2.2: svare yakÄraá¸¥).â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥’à¤®à¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤µà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¦.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 322 à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¥€à¤°à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¤•à¥‘à¤¶à¤¤à¤‚à¥’ à¤¤à¤¾ à¤œà¥’à¤¨à¤¤à¤¾à¥’ à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥®.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­. à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¥€à¤‚ à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.56). J, M: Â°à¤µà¤‚à¤¦à¤¹à¤¨à¥‡à¤µÂ°. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, is also deleted in the ex- pressions] Å›epahará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m [< Å›epaá¸¥+hará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m] and vandane â€™va [< vandanaá¸¥+iva]. Note: By normal rules of sandhi, the first combination would have given us Å›epohará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m and vandana[#]iva. Referring to the first of these two cases, Whitney says: â€œThe former is a striking case of arbitrariness in etymologizing on the part of the authors of the pada-text, for there is neither necessity nor plausibility in treating the com- pound as if made up of Å›epas and hará¹£aá¹‡a: the former member is evidently Å›epa, which in the Atharvan is much the more common of the two forms of this word.â€ On another occasion, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p.149) further adds: â€œThe pada-reading of the last word is Å›epaá¸¥-hará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m, and PrÄt ii.56 (= CA 2.2.17) prescribes the loss of the visarga of Å›epaá¸¥ in saá¹ƒhitÄ; the comment to PrÄt. iv.75(74?) (= CA 4.3.2) gives the reading thus: Å›epohará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m iti Å›epaá¸¥- hará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m; and one of our pada-mss. presents it in the same form, adding kramakÄle â€˜this is the krama-readingâ€™; and the comm. has Å›epoha-; but Ppp., Å›epahará¹£iá¹‡Ä«. As Å›Ã©pa is as genuine and old a form as Å›Ã©pas, there seems to be no good reason for the peculiar treatment of the compound.â€ Whitney is clearly misguided in view of the fact that his own Index Verborum cites (p. 294) no other occurrence for Å›epa- than the expression Å›epahará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m. On the other hand, it lists nine occurrences of Å›epas. This is also confirmed by A Grammatical Word-Index to Atharvaveda, VVRI, 1963. Thus, there is good justification for the treatment given to Å›epahará¹£aá¹‡Ä«m by the present rule. Referring to the second case, he says: â€œAs for the other case, of elision of the visarjanÄ«ya before iva and contraction of the two vowels into a diph- thong, it is equally surprising to find this one singled out to be so written, from among the many in the text which are to be so read.â€ Whitneyâ€™s more general comments are as follows: â€œFor the contraction of a final syllable, ending either in an original s or m, with the following parti-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾323 cle of comparison iva, so that the two together form but two syllables, is the rule rather than the exception in the Atharva-Veda. Out of 59 instances in the text, in which a final aá¸¥ occurs before iva, there are only 13 in which the metre shows the sandhi to be regular: in 46 cases we are to read e â€™va; am iva is con- tracted in the same manner 25 times out of 40; Äá¸¥ iva, only 4 times out of 19; im iva, 3 times out of 5; iá¸¥ iva, 7 times out of 10; uá¸¥ iva, 6 times, or in every instance the text contains; um iva, only once out of 3 times: and there are single sporadic cases of a similar elision after the terminations eá¸¥, Äu, Än, ad, ud, which would pass without notice, as mere irregularities of metre, were it not for their analogy with the others I have mentioned, but which, considering these latter, are worth adverting to, as illustrations of the same general ten- dency.â€ A primary fact Whitney fails to mention is that the rules in the CA are not given to account for those cases where modern scholars restore the irregu- lar meter to its regularity by assuming that the â€˜originalâ€™ text read differently from what has been transmitted to us. The CA rules are not restorative in this sense, but descriptive of the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha and the PadapÄá¹­ha as they were re- ceived at that time. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¥€à¤‚ à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œ- à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤‚(H, N: à¤§à¥€à¤‚) à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¥’à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¥€à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! à¤¶à¥‡à¥’à¤ªà¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¥€à¤®à¥, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¤ƒà¤½à¤‡à¤µ, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥§à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¥‹à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¥€à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¥€à¤®à¥â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨ à¤‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤µâ€™ à¥¤ Note: The VVRI edition of the AV cites the PadapÄá¹­ha for AV (7.120.2 = W: 7.115.2) as à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¤¾à¤½à¤‡à¤µ, and offers the variant à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¤ƒà¤½à¤‡à¤µ in the footnotes. One should also note that the commentary of [Pseudo]-SÄyaá¹‡a adopts the first of these readings (cf. à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾ à¤²à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ), and shows no awareness of the reading as assumed by the CA. In this connection, it may also be noted that, as far as my reading of [Pseudo]-SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary goes, he shows no knowledge of the CA. This may also be explained by the fact that no manuscript of the CA has been found to the south of Maharashtra, and that it is likely that {Pseudo]-SÄyaá¹‡a may have had no access to this text. Whitney points to a case which he believes the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya should have taken care of. This is the expression yaká¹£modhÄm in AV (9.8.9). Whitney

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾325 Note: The syntax of this rule seems strange, especially coming after the previous rule. Normally, one would have expected the force of na in the previous rule to continue into this rule. Whitney notes an important point that â€œin all these cases, it will be noticed, the lopa of the visarjanÄ«ya is made in the pada-text, as well as in saá¹ƒhitÄ, as is directed in a later rule (iv. 100 = CA 4.3.29: dÄ«rghÄyutvÄyÄdÄ«nÄá¹ƒ ca).â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¥‘ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°- à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¥’ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¤¦à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§. à¥ªà¥«, à¥«à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney correctly assumes that in the first two examples, there is an actual substitution of the stems Äyu and caká¹£u, for the stems Äyus and caká¹£us. However, he has some hesitation in assuming a similar substitution of the stem barhi for barhis in the last example. The gaá¹‡a referred to in this rule of the CA has been fully listed in the APR (200). The CAB cites the first three instances of this gaá¹‡a, which con- tains a total of 10 instances. à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¥¥à¥«à¥¯à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§. à¤¦à¥à¤° à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.60). Ha, Na: Â°à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤‚à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of duá¸¥ [< dur] is changed to u, before dÄÅ›a, and [the d] following [á¸¥] is changed to a retroflex [á¸]. Note: It is assumed that after duá¸¥+dÄÅ›a is changed to duu+á¸ÄÅ›a, the two u vowels coalesce into a long Å«, yielding the formation dÅ«á¸ÄÅ›a. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¦à¥‚à¥’à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡à¥’ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¦à¥à¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡à¥‘â€™ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - â€˜à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¦à¤­à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡(H, N: à¤¯à¥‡)à¤·à¥ à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ (missing: â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¤£à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡.à¤–à¤¿à¤². à¥ª.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¤¡à¤­à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV, â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¥’à¤³à¤­à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‚à¤¢à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤ªà¥‘(H, N: à¤µ) à¤¦à¥‚à¥’à¤¢à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘ à¤œà¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¯à¥ª.à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: The commentary brings up an important issue by saying this change occurs only in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. We must interpret à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ as referring specifically to the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, and not referring to the generic sandhi or the lack of a pause in between the recited items. Thus, the PadapÄá¹­ha reading duá¸¥ / dÄÅ›e does not occasion this rule, because the components are separated by a short pause. However, in the parihÄra of the KramapÄá¹­ha, the word is first repeated with its components combined. Then it is followed by iti, followed by the repetition of the word broken into its components. In the first repetition, one would expect the normal sandhi rules to apply. Thus, we

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾327 have duá¸¥+dÄÅ›a changing to durdÄÅ›a. However, since this is not the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha, the present rule does not apply. The same important distinction between sandhi versus Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha is found in several other cases, e.g. CA (2.2.17). It should be noted that the CA appropriately limits itself to the forma- tion dÅ«á¸ÄÅ›a which is attested in the AV. However, the more generalized for- mulation appearing in the commentary extends the same procedure to other formations occurring elsewhere. Also note that while the generalized formula- tion includes dÅ«á¹‡ÄÅ›a, Whitney points out that â€œthe Atharvan has duá¸¥-naÅ›a (v.11.6), but treats it according to the regular methods of combination, making durá¹‡aÅ›a in saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ Thus, the generalized formulation, introduced with apara Äha, seems to take care of dÅ«á¹‡ÄÅ›a, which is not an Atharvan expression, and fails to take care of durá¹‡aÅ›a which is an Atharvan expression. Thus, the VÄrttika-like passage cited by the commentary offers a glimpse into an unknown [non-Atharvan?] grammatical text. Compare the VÄrttika (à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¦à¤­à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥) on P.6.3.109, which is expanded by PataÃ±jali to: à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¦à¤­- à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥¨. à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.61). Translation: Before Å›un, [the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of duá¸¥] is changed to t. Note: This rule helps the transition of the PadapÄá¹­ha reading duá¸¥ / Å›unÄ to the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha reading ducchunÄ. The initial duá¸¥+Å›unÄ is changed to dut+Å›unÄ by this rule. Then, with the application of CA (2.1.13: à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤²à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ) and CA (2.1.17: à¤¤à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯), we finally get ducchunÄ. Since the forms ducchunÄm and ducchunÄ are not analyzed into their components in the PadapÄá¹­ha, Whitney believes that this rule is â€œproperly su- perfluous, and we have a right to wonder that it was introduced into our trea- tise.â€ The same sentiment is echoed by Surya Kanta (APR, p. 142). In my opinion, this rule, like several others, indicates that the author of the CA occa- sionally goes into grammatical analysis beyond the limits of the PadapÄá¹­ha, rather than this rule being a later addition to the text. All the manuscripts have the rule and the oldest commentary comments on it, and hence, if the rule is a â€˜laterâ€™ addition, it must have taken place very early.

328à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© There is good reason why the PadapÄá¹­ha does not break this word down into its components. Its etymology is elusive. SÄyaá¹‡a on RV (1.116.21) paraphrases the word with duá¹£á¹­asukha = duá¸¥khasya kartÄ, and says that the word suna refers to happiness. However, this word is not independently attested. SkandasvÄmin paraphrases the word with durbhiká¹£a. Surya Kanta (1981: 343) derives it as dut+Å›una, but then also seems to link it with the root du â€˜burn.â€™ He quotes a paraphrase as duá¹£á¹­acitta for this word occurring in TS (iv.6.6.7). The denominative verb ducchunÄyase in RV (7.55.3) is paraphrased by SÄyaá¹‡a with bÄdhase, while ducchunÄyate in VS (xix. 33) is paraphrased with daridraá¹ƒ karoti. Thus, this word would qualify for not being split into its components in the PadapÄá¹­ha, because of the confusion concerning its components, cf. sandeha in CA (4.2.5: à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥). On the other hand, the present CA rule represents an humble effort to suggest an etymology for the word. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¥’ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥­.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¹à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¯.à¥®)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©. à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤•à¤ªà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.62). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾329 (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥­.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘à¤•à¥‡à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒà¥‘à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒà¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¾à¤®à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤ƒà¤ªà¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: The last counter-example, i.e. AV (12.3.39), cited by the com- mentary is not directly accounted for by the CA rule. Its very presence in the commentary suggests that either the commentator is adding something that the author of the SÅ«tras unintentionally left out, or that there was a change in the oral tradition, and that the commentator was faced with an instance which did not occur in the text as known to the author of the SÅ«tras. This instance is in- deed listed in the APR (201) as an exception, and it is clear that the CAB has recorded this exception from the APR. Whitney suggests another possibility that sequences of repeated words like paraá¸¥+paraá¸¥ were perhaps not treated as compounds by the author of the SÅ«tras and hence he did not feel the need to make provision for this instance. On the other hand, it is clear that the com- mentator considers this an instance of compounding, and hence feels that he must explicitly exclude this instance from the operation of the rule. In any case, there is change in the tradition, either linguistic, theoretical, or both. Since this last instance has been explicitly accounted for by the APR (201, p. 120), it is clear that the CAB and the APR are following the same tradition, which is slightly different from the one reflected in the CA. Also see the Note on CA (4.1.62). This rule is cited in a slightly abbreviated form in APR (201, See: APR, Introduction, p. 20). However, identical examples are found under APR (201) and in the CAB on the present rule. As far as the prescription for sadyaá¸¥krÄ«á¸¥ is concerned, we should note that the later uniform usage of the derivative sÄdyaskra indicates that the prohi- bition on the change of Visarga to s in this form was not generally followed. SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s reading is sadyaskrÄ«á¸¥. On pÄ«basphÄkam, Whitney says: â€œI would remark that its treatment by the pada-text, and its citation under this rule, seem to depend upon a false ety- mology, in as much as its final member is plainly not phÄka, but sphÄka, a word allied with sphÄna and sphÄti, repeatedly met with elsewhere.â€ On the same word in AV (4.7.3), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 155) says: â€œIn b, all our mss. (as also the comment on PrÄt. ii.62 = CA 2.3.3) read pÄ«basphÄkÃ¡m (p. pÄ«baá¸¥-phÄkÃ¡m, which the comment just quoted ratifies), as our edition

330à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© reads; SPP., on the other hand, prints pÄ«baspÄkÃ¡m (comm. pÄ«vaspÄkam, ex- plained as â€˜fat-cookingâ€™) and declares this to be the unanimous reading of his authorities: this discordance of testimony is quite unexplainable. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of] niá¸¥, duá¸¥, Äviá¸¥, and haviá¸¥ [becomes s before k and p], even where there is no com- pounding. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¹à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤¸- à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥’(H, N: à¤·à¥à¤Ÿ)à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚à¥’ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥‘à¤°à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ(H: à¤µà¤ƒ, N: à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ)â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥à¤·à¥à¤µ à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿â€™ (variant for AV 12.4. 29c)à¥¤ à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥’à¤°à¥€à¤£à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¥‘à¤°à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¤¾à¤¶à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney says: â€œThe particle duá¸¥ never appears in the Atharvan text except as compounded with other words, but it would seem from this rule that the compounds which it forms are not entitled to the name samÄsa.â€ However, with respect to any cited form, a conclusion whether it is or it is not a case of compound (samÄsa) cannot be automatically be drawn, because the condition stated in the rule, â€˜even when there is no compounding,â€™ allows for

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾331 examples of compounds, as well as non-compounds. In general, words like niá¸¥ are not viewed as being compounded with finite verbs, but are viewed as being compounded with verbal nouns. A somewhat similar distinction seems to hold in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s system, cf. P.8.4.14 (à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯) and P.7.1.37 (à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥). All the AV mss. used by Whitney retain the visarjanÄ«ya in à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥‘à¤®à¥ (AV 12.2.16, 42) and à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¥‘à¤¥à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ (AV 16.7.6), and so does Whitneyâ€™s edition. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 38) suggests that here we have the non- ÅšaunakÄ«ya readings preserved in the mss. Concerning the passage à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ which is not attested in the AV, Surya Kanta (ibid, p. 40) makes a sug- gestion that it may have occurred in the genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension, and that the currently available AV text is not genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya. Somehow, he does not raise the same claim about the example duá¹£pÄ«tam cited by the commentary which is also not attested in the AV. The example duá¹£pÄ«tam is cited by the KV on PÄá¹‡ini (8.3.41: à¤‡à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯), and it is likely that our commentator cited it from such a source. To illustrate the condition à¤…à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿, the commen- tator seems to have found examples of mostly finite verbs with the associated words like nir. However, when it came to dur, it would seem that he was hard- pressed to find examples of such finite verbs. Thus, he was forced to come up with examples of non-finite forms, out of which one is attested in the AV, and the other the commentator found in commentaries on PÄá¹‡ini. One need not posit for this a so-called lost genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya text of the AV. The exception introduced by the commentary with the words à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ is important. This exception is not directly accounted for by the CA rule, nor has it been accounted for in the APR. This makes one suspect that the text of the AV as known to the author of the commentary was perhaps slightly differ- ent as compared to the text as known to the authors of the CA and the APR. Whitneyâ€™s edition of the AV follows the statement in the commentary, but it is not clear whether the manuscripts of the AV follow this prescription. The VVRI edition also seems to follow the prescription as given in the commen- tary. Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 698) suggests another possibility for à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿. For AV (12.4.29c), some mss. read à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿, while others read à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤·à¥à¤µ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿. Whitney says: â€œThe translation implies in b the reading krÌ¥á¹‡ute instead of krÌ¥á¹‡uá¹£va, although the former is found only in O.p.m.D.T. âˆ€Three of SSPâ€™s pada-mss. have krÌ¥á¹‡ute.# The comm. to PrÄt. ii.63 quotes Äviá¹£ krÌ¥á¹‡ute rÅ«pÄá¹‡i, which is not found in the text unless here.â€ Thus there is no reason to say that this passage is not at all found in the AV. The simplest assumption would be that the CAB knew this reading for AV

332à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 12.4.29c. The only other known Vedic text which uses à¤†à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥‡ is JaiminÄ«ya- BrÄhmaá¹‡a (3.96), but here it does not co-occur with rÅ«pÄá¹‡i. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥«. à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.64). Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of] triá¸¥ [is changed to s, before k and p]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¥’à¤²à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥à¤°- (à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒ?)à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥¬. à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¤°à¤‚à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.65). Translation: [A visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] except that of kará¹‡ayoá¸¥, [is changed to s], before the words kuru, karam, karat, krÌ¥á¹‡otu, krÌ¥ti, and krÌ¥dhi. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤•à¥à¤°à¥ à¤•à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥ƒà¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’ à¤¨à¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤¬à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤®à¥’à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥®)à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸ à¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥â€™ (Whitney: â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¤¸à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¥‘à¤¤à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿- à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤­à¥‡à¤·à¥’à¤œà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤£à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥’- à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‘à¤¸à¤¿à¥’ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾333 à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤§à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¦.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‡à¤®à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤·à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤…à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¥à¥à¥’à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‘à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤§à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥ªà¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney says: â€œThe cases to which this rule is meant to apply are of very different frequency of occurrence, and the rule itself is of very dif- ferent degrees of accuracy as concerns the forms mentioned. … Not much can be said in praise of the way in which this rule is constructed.â€ While Whitneyâ€™s frustration is understandable, one must also deal with the fact that he is comparing the text of the AV as we know it today with the rules of the CA which were formulated more than two thousands years ago, and we must make allowance for change in the transmitted text, before assigning blame to the author of the CA. This rule is especially a good example for illustrating the possibility of such changes occurring in the transmitted text. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 41) brings up a very interesting difference between the CA and the APR. The CAB says that the change of visarjanÄ«ya to á¹£ before krÌ¥á¹‡otu occurs only in three cases listed there. On the other hand, the APR (148) refers to the same three passages and says: à¤•à¥ƒà¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨. Surya Kanta points out that the Vulgate mss. follow the APR, and not the CA prescription, and retain the visarjanÄ«ya in these cases. This, to Surya Kanta, implies that the Vulgate is not a ÅšaunakÄ«ya text. While not denying the facts pointed out by Surya Kanta, one can think in terms of possible change within the same tradition over a period of time. Such a change could have occurred even between the period of CA and that of the CAB. It is indeed conceivable that the CA did not think of the kind of limitations sug- gested by the CAB, but that the CAB is making a reference to a changed situation. If such a possibility is granted, one can then think of further change reflected in the APR. Does the APR project a reverse situation, i.e. that there could be an s for the visarjanÄ«ya before krÌ¥á¹‡otu in all other instances, except these three? Or does it say that in the three cases, where the CAB prescribed the change, no such change occurs, and in these cases, we get a visarjanÄ«ya, as we get it elsewhere before krÌ¥á¹‡otu. One would have to accept the second alter- native, in view of the testimony of the manuscripts. Whitney says: â€œIn all these (= three) passages, however, the manuscripts read, without dissent, visarjanÄ«ya before the k. … Other instances in which krÌ¥á¹‡otu has an unaltered visarjanÄ«ya before it are tolerably numerous. … They are vi.40.1, 2; 53.3; 73.3; 83.1; 104.3; vii.32.1; 33.1; 51.1; 91.1; viii.8.4; ix.2.7; 4.2; xi.1.6; xii.1.1, 43.â€ In all these

334à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© cases, the VVRI edition records a visarjanÄ«ya before krÌ¥á¹‡otu, and there are no manuscript varients recorded. Thus, instead of simply talking about two differ- ent recensions represented by these two texts, one could make a better case for a possible historical change within the same tradition: 1) CA - Unconditional change of visarjanÄ«ya to s before krÌ¥á¹‡otu. 2) CAB - This change occurs only in three instances. 3) APR - The above change does not occur in any instances. Surya Kantaâ€™s conceptions are based on several assumptions. The first is that the oral (or even written) textual traditions, once codified by some scholar-sage, were essentially immutable. The second assumption is that the CAB actually forms part of the text of the original CA, and hence the examples and everything else seen in the CAB was somehow identical with the expec- tations of the original CA. In my opinion, both of these assumptions are seri- ously questionable. The general direction of possible change in the language is further supported by the following observations of W.S. Allen (1053: 51): â€œIn later, though still ancient, times there appears to have been a tendency for -á¸¥ to extend its usage to contexts other than in pausa. The earliest of these exten- sions was to the position before the initial fricatives Å›-, á¹£-, s-, where it replaced the homorganic final -Å›, -á¹£, -s (indraÅ› Å›Å«raá¸¥ > indraá¸¥ Å›Å«raá¸¥, &c.). This practice was then extended to the position before the velar and labial voiceless stops: in connexion with this innovation we find mentioned the names of Ä€gniveÅ›ya, VÄlmÄ«ki, ÅšÄkalya, and the MÄdhyandina school, whilst the ancient grammarian ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana is quoted as holding to the more conservative practice.â€ Allen also refers to A.H. Fryâ€™s view that â€œthe spread of -á¸¥ was due to the writers of Clas- sical Sanskrit operating with a phonemic orthography.â€ On the inclusion of krÌ¥ti in this rule, Whitney remarks: â€œThe next word, krÌ¥ti, is one which, for a double reason, has no right to a place in the rule: in the first place, it occurs nowhere except in compounds; and secondly, it converts into a sibilant only the preceding visarjanÄ«ya of niá¸¥ and haviá¸¥, and so would be sufficiently provided for by rule 63 (= CA 2.3.4), even if not adjudged to fall under rule 62 (= CA 2.3.3).â€ On à¤®à¥’à¤£à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥‹à¤¤à¥ in AV (10.6.31), Whitney and Lanman (AV Transl. Vol. II., p. 588) point out: â€œAccording to PrÄt. ii.65 (= CA 2.3.6), we ought to read maá¹‡Ã­á¹£ krÌ¥- ; âˆ€this is the reading of three of SPPâ€™s mss., but of none of Wâ€™s so far as noted: both texts give maá¹‡Ã­á¸¥#.â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾335 à¥¨.à¥©.à¥­. à¤¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.66). O: Â°à¤®à¥à¤¹Â°. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of] tataá¸¥ [is changed to s], before the word pari followed by the word brahma. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥’ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤£à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§. à¥§à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥®à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitney points out: â€œA similar case, in which the suffix taá¸¥ be- comes tas before pari, is à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ (iv.10.4 and vii.45.1); the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya takes no notice of it, if it be not intended to be included in the gaá¹‡a with which the section concludes (ii. 80 = CA 2.3.21).â€ This gaá¹‡a, as we now know, is fully listed under APR (203, p. 121-2), and contains 12 instances. Yet, interestingly enough, it does not contain the instance cited above by Whitney, i.e. à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘. However, that instance could be taken care of by the next rule, i.e. CA (2.3.8). The example is listed neither among the positive cases for changing the visarjanÄ«ya to s, nor among exceptions to APR (202, p. 120-1). My under- standing of the APR lists under this rule (i.e. APR 202) is that the list of posi- tive examples is merely illustrative, while the list of exceptions is a complete list. Since à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ does not appear in the list of exceptions, it could have been most likely a case of the positive change of visarjanÄ«ya to s. The fact that there are no manuscript varients listed for this instance by any of the editions of the AV also probably points in the same direction. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥®. à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.67). Translation: Also, [the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of an ablative form [is changed to an s, before pari], except in aá¹…gebhyaá¸¥ pari etc. Note: Whitney points out: â€œThe Rik Pr. (iv. 15) and VÄj. Pr. (iii. 30) give the additional specification that the pari must be at the end of a pÄda, or before a pause, and the addition of that restriction to our own rule would have

336à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© made it accurate, and obviated the necessity of the gaá¹‡a.â€ Whitney records, in a footnote, the instances and the counter-instances for this rule. Since the APR (202, pp. 120-1) also contains similar lists of instances and counter-instances, it is well worth comparing Whitneyâ€™s listing with the APR listing. Whitneyâ€™s list of positive instances matches with the one given under APR (202), except that Whitney also adds AV (xix.39.1, 5), and, he, for some reason, does not think of adding à¤¸à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ (AV iv.10.4 and vii.45.1) to this list. The lists of exceptions, have important mismatches: Whitneyâ€™s list of exceptions includes 10.7.25, 13.1.26, besides several instances from the l9th KÄá¹‡á¸a, which are not included in the APR list. On the other hand, the APR list of exceptions in- cludes 3.6.1, 6.89.1, 1.27.1, 4.33.6, and 9.5.6. These cases are not included in Whitneyâ€™s list of exceptions. Thus, there are major discrepancies, suggesting the possibility of changes in the textual transmission of the ÅšAV after the com- pletion of the APR. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‹à¥‘(H, N: à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹) à¤¹à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥©à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¯.à¥¯; à¥«.à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¥’ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤®- à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤šà¤°à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: In a footnote on p. 109, Whitney details instances and counter- instances for this rule. Surya Kanta wishes to use the examples cited by the commentary and the CA rule itself to argue that the CA and the APR belong to two different recensions of the AV. He points out (APR, Introduction, pp. 40- 1) that the APR (202) prescribes the same operation as the present rule in CA, but in the APR the gaá¹‡a list of exceptions begins with à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¥’à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¬.à¥§), the second exception listed being à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤šà¤°à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥«). Why should the list of exceptions in the CA begin with the second example in the APR list? Surya Kanta argues: â€œEither CA has omitted pÃºmÄn puá¹ƒsÃ¡á¸¥, or APR has added it afterwards. In any case the result is unmistakable. While the APR negatives satva in the passage, CA seems to imply it, thus showing that the two schools are different.â€ Surya Kanta also forgets to point out that the first positive example of such a change offered by the commentary, i.e. à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‹à¥‘ à¤¹à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ is absent from the list of examples provided by the APR (202). This example is from the 19th KÄá¹‡á¸a of the AV, and both the CA and the APR

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾337 rarely cite from anything beyond the first 18 KÄá¹‡á¸as. It is possible that this is a later addition to the text of the commentary. One more possibility omitted by Surya Kanta from consideration is that the pronunciation may have changed in the period between the CA and the APR, making it necessary for the latter to list or omit a passage. Such a change could have occurred within the same school. See the Note on the previous rule for a discussion of the example sin- dhutas pari (AV, iv.10.4 and vii.45.1). à¥¨.à¥©.à¥¯. à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤šà¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.68). 340à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© of s as the final of only iá¸ÄyÄs before pada seems a strong indication that this verse (= AV 6.63.4) was not a part of the AV text as recognized by the PrÄt.â€ On the present rule, Whitney says: â€œThat the rule is not so framed as to include also the closely analogous case iá¸as pade (vi.63.4), the only other one in the text where an original final sibilant is preserved before pada, gives reason to suspect that the verse containing it was not in the commentatorâ€™s Atharvan: a suspicion which is supported by the peculiar mode of occurrence of the verse, at the end of hymn with the subject of which it has nothing to do. It looks as if it had been thrust in at the end of vi.63, because in the Rik text (x. 191) it pre- ceded the verses of which vi.64 is composed.â€ There are some curious facts which must be mentioned. The text of the commentary repeats à¤‡à¤¡à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ after citing the actual AV example à¤‡à¤¡à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤¦à¤®à¥, before proceeding to ask the question à¤‡à¤¡à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥. This is highly un- usual, and one wonders whether this was a misreading for an intended original à¤‡à¤¡à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡. Such a suspicion is strengthened by the fact that the APR (203, p. 121) actually lists the case à¤‡à¤¡à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡. However, it is of course possible that the example was not part of the AV known to the CA and the CAB, and was incorporated in it by the time of APR. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥ª. à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.73), A, B, D, H, J, K, M, N, and P read à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤¿. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of the word pituá¸¥ [is changed to s] before the forms of pitrÌ¥. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¥’ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥’ à¤¸ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨. à¥§.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¥‘à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯. à¥§à¥«)à¥¤ Note: Whitneyâ€™s manuscript, our H, contained only the first example, and Whitney recorded the second one in his notes: â€œa similar phrase is found once more in the text (at ix.9.15)â€. This second example is now found in the manuscript N. Whitney further says: â€œOn the other hand, we have three cases in the eighteenth book (xviii.2.49; 3.46, 59) in which pituá¸¥ stands before pitaraá¸¥, and,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾341 by the unanimous authority of the manuscripts, maintains its visarjanÄ«ya. We must suppose either that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya and its commentator overlooked these passages, or that they did not stand in the text contemplated by them, or that they stood there with the reading pituá¹£ pitaraá¸¥.â€ In all these cases, the VVRI edition also offers a reading with the visarjanÄ«ya, and does not cite any manu- script varients in favor of its change to á¹£. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 38) argues that such violations by the Vulgate text of the AV of the rules of the CA should be interpreted to mean that the Vulgate is not the ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV, and that the CA must be referring to a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension which we do not possess today. It is curious to note that while the CAB does not explicitly note any ex- ceptions, the APR (147, p. 101) lists à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¤ƒà¥‘ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤°à¥‹à¥’ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¤¾à¤ƒ, AV (xviii.2.49; 3.46, 59) as an exception to the change of á¸¥ to s. Since neither the CA nor the CAB show any awareness of this exception, and since the APR explicitly lists it as an exception, the most likely conclusion is that the text of the AV as known to the CA and the CAB did not have this exception, but that the exception had developed prior to the listings made by the APR. Referring to the mss. variants regarding this phrase in AV (9.9.15), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., 554) says: â€œSome of our mss. (P.s.m.O.K.T.) read pitÃºá¸¥ p- in d; we had the phrase once before, at ii.1.2, and the combination falls under PrÄt. ii.73 (= CA 2.3.14).â€ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥«. à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.74). Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of the word dyauá¸¥ [is] also [changed to s, before a form of pitrÌ¥]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¯à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥ˆà¥’à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥ à¤…à¥‘à¤§à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥â€™ (H, N:â€˜à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤§- à¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥,â€™) (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the Vulgate mss. for AV (6.4.3), Whitney says: â€œAll mss., but one, retain visarjanÄ«ya.â€ All manuscripts, except I and H, give dyauá¹£ in AV 3.9.1 and so does Whitneyâ€™s edition. However, later Whitney

342à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 98) says â€œSSP. reads in b dyÄÃºá¸¥ p-, which is doubtless preferable to our dyÄÃºá¹£ p-; it is read by the majority of his mss. and by part of ours (H.I.K); Ppp. also has it.â€ At AV (3.23.6, and 8.7.2), almost all mss. re- tain the visarjanÄ«ya, and so does Whitneyâ€™s edition. On the reading in this verse, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 128) reports: â€œThe first half verse is found again later, as viii.7.2.c,d; in both places, part of the mss. read dyÄÃºá¹£ p- (here only our O., with half of SPPâ€™s); and that appears to be required by PrÄt. ii-74 (= CA 2.3.15), although the looser relation of the two words favors in a case like this the reading dyÄÃºá¸¥, which both editions present.â€ Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p.38) refers to this situation and argues that the Vulgate of the AV is not ÅšaunakÄ«ya, but that there is a mixture of the ÅšaunakÄ«ya readings at times in the existing mss. The example AV (6.4.3) is cited as example 21 under APR (28b, p. 27) with á¹£, rather than with the visarjanÄ«ya. The tenden- cies in the manuscripts of the AV, in this case, seem to show a further shift away from á¹£. Such a change is clearly more in the direction of the tendencies reflected in the classical language. See: Allen (1953: 51). The example à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥ à¤…à¥‘à¤§à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥ has no place here. The examples à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥ˆà¥’à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒà¥‘ (AV 6.4.3) and à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥ à¤…à¥‘à¤§à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥ (AV 5.22.2) are cited consecutively under APR (53, p. 43), and it is possible that the copyist for the CAB, who may also have copied the APR, confused the citations. This is the best explanation for why these two otherwise unrelated examples might have been juxtaposed in the manuscripts of the CAB. The confusion must have been fairly old to have been found in both the manuscripts H and N. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥¬. à¤†à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.75), D, H, J, M, N, and P: à¤†à¤¯à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡. Other mss: à¤†à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of the word Äyuá¸¥ [is changed to s], before prathama. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤¯à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¥’à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: On this rule, Whitney says that all the AV mss. without dissent read visarjanÄ«ya whereas the CA rule expects á¹£ in the example cited by the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾343 commentator. In this case, in his edition of the AV, Whitney disregards the unanimous authority of the mss. and follows the CA. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 38) refers to this situation and says that Whitneyâ€™s decision is arbitrary. However, note that the APR does not record these cases as excep- tions to the change of visarjanÄ«ya to s, and the best guess is that the APR knew these cases with the change. In Surya Kantaâ€™s opinion, the AV mss. in this case represent a non- ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. On the cited example, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 216) says: â€œOur edition combines ÄÌyuá¹£ pr-, because required by PrÄt. ii.75 (= CA 2.3.16); but the mss., except one of SPPâ€™s have ÄÌyuá¸¥ pr-, which SPP. retains.â€ Here too, the manuscripts of the AV seem to indicate a progression toward the maintenance of the visarjanÄ«ya, cf. Allen (1953: 51). In this case, the shift away from the change of visarjanÄ«ya > s > á¹£, may have begun after the completion of the APR. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥­. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤®à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (2.76). Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, of the word Äyuá¸¥ is changed to s] before pra, when it is followed by a form of the verb muá¹£ or jÄ«v. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤®à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤†à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾ à¤¨à¥’ à¤†à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤®à¥‹à¥‘à¤·à¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤œà¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¸à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ªà¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤°â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥ªà¥«)à¥¤ Note: Whitney points out that all the mss. for AV (8.2.17 and 18.2.3) read Äyuá¸¥, and he accepts this reading in his edition. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p.38) points out how arbitrary Whitneyâ€™s decisions generally are, and that the manuscripts represent a non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. The ÅšaunakÄ«ya readings as defined by the CA are not always available in the existing AV manuscripts. Regarding AV (18.2.3), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 832) himself says: â€œThe PrÄt. (ii. 76 = CA 2.3.17) distinctly requires ÄÌyuá¹£ prÃ¡ to be read in d, but of our mss. only O.s.m. (in margin) gives it; nearly half of SPPâ€™s saá¹ƒhitÄ-mss., however, have it, and it ought to be received as the true AV. text,

344à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© though both editions read ÄÌyuá¸¥.â€ A case such as this suggests that one needs to carefully investigate the groupings of the manuscripts to detect slightly divergent traditions of the transmission of the AV, and see if they are consistent in following or not following the rules of the CA. On the whole, it still seems that there is a general movement away from the change of visarja- nÄ«ya > s, a direction discussed by Allen (1953: 51). Since the APR (147, p. 101) explicitly lists AV (12.2.45) as an ex- ception to the change of visarjanÄ«ya to s, as listed here by the CAB, one may assume that the APR knew other instances as involving this change, and the wholesale movement in the direction away from this change and toward the maintenance of the visarjanÄ«ya can be dated after the APR. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥®. à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (2.77), Ha, J, K, Na: à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ. Other mss: à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ. Translation: [The visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥,] of paridhiá¸¥ [is changed to s] before patÄti. Note: Whitney notes: â€œThe manuscripts are unanimous in supporting the reading prescribed by the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya.â€ However, note that the VVRI edi- tion notes the PaippalÄda variant as à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿. The example cited by the commentary is not listed among exceptions to the change of visarjanÄ«ya to s by the APR, and one may assume that the APR knew this case as involving this change. Why the manuscript tradition should maintain this change, when in other cases it moves in the direction of keeping the visarjanÄ«ya needs to be explored. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¥’ à¤¸à¥‹ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥‘à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥¨,à¥©)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥§à¥¯. à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (2.78). Note: Whitney has an important comment: â€œThe pada-text regards manaspÄpa as a compound, writing it manaá¸¥-pÄpa. The accentuation does not help to settle the question, and the sense is nearly as good one way as the other.â€ One may point out that the commentary of [pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a on AV (6.45.1) treats the expressions pÄpa and manaá¸¥ as separate vocatives, rather than as parts of a compound, though the manuscripts of the PadapÄá¹­ha, without exception, treat this expression as a compound. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤®à¤¨ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥‡à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥©.à¥¨à¥§. à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.80). 346à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© Translation: Also, [the visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, occurring at the end of the first item is changed to s before the second item] in [sequences] such as rÄyaspoá¹£am. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤°à¤¾à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¿à¥‘à¤¶à¤¾à¥’à¤šà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥­)à¥¤ Note: The wording of the commentary creates an impression that the Gaá¹‡a is simply poá¹£Ädi. However, comparing such lists is a very difficult task, as Whitney notes: â€œUnfortunately, it is impossible to tell what is the teaching of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya with regard to any such cases; we do not even know how accu- rately it or its commentators had noticed and noted the instances which their text contained. There is no apparent reason why the single cases noted in rules 66, 72, 77, 78, 79 should not have been left to go into the gaá¹‡a, if a gaá¹‡a was to be established, and neither the accuracy nor the method of the treatise, in dealing with this class of phenomena, is worthy of unqualified condemnation.â€ Even with the addition of the APR to our understanding of the AV tradition, things have not changed completely. à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¥¥à¥®à¥¦à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ.
