à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾347 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¥¥à¥®à¥¦à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ __________________________________

à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§. à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.81). Translation: Here [i.e. in the context of the section beginning with CA (2.3.3: samÄse sakÄraá¸¥ kapayor …) teaching the change of a visarjanÄ«ya, i.e. á¸¥, to s], s is changed to á¹£, if preceded by a nÄmin [i.e. any vowel other than a and Ä]. Note: The change of s to á¹£ taught by this rule is already apparent in the examples of a number of previous rules, e.g. CA (2.3.4-6; 14-8; 21). Its scope also extends to rules which follow, e.g. CA (2.4.3-6). The commentary CAB continues the words à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ into these following rules. As Whitney points out, this rule applies â€œwhether the s to which the rules relate is original, or comes from visarjanÄ«ya.â€ In the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, this phenomenon is generally referred to by the term nati â€œbending [= retroflexion],â€ and the vowels which condition this change are called nÄmin â€œbender [= retroflexing vowel].â€ Whitney translates the term nÄmin as â€œalterant vowel.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥ - â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤•à¤ªà¤¯à¥‹- à¤°à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤…â€™ (à¤š.à¤†. à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨. à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.82). C, E, F, I, O: Â°à¤¡à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯. B, D, J, N: Â°à¤¦à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯. Translation: [The s] of the root saá¸¥, when transformed to sÄá¹­, [is changed to á¹£]. Note: From the examples given by the commentary, we understand that the condition nÄmyupadhasya is not relevant for this rule, and that the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾349 change of s to á¹£ takes place, even when the form sÄá¹­ is not preceded by a nÄmin vowel, a vowel other than a and Ä. If sÄá¸bhÅ«tasya in the CA rule is intended to prevent the application of this rule to the form prasahanam, and if prasahanam is not attested in Vedic literature, then it is clear that like PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.56 (saheá¸¥ sÄá¸aá¸¥ saá¸¥), the CA too, consciously or unconsciously, could not dispense with the contemporary lan- guage while framing its rules. Whitney points out, â€œThat sÄá¸bhÅ«ta means â€˜when it becomes sÄá¹­,â€™ and not â€˜when it becomes sÄh,â€™ appears from the instances amitrasÄha and sÄtrÄsÄha (see under iii.23 = CA 3.1.23), in which, although the vowel of the root is lengthened, the sibilant remains unaltered.â€ Whitney also objects to the rule itself, and its location in the text: â€œThere is no real necessity for any such rule as this, since all the words to which the commentary regards it as relating have precisely the same form in pada as in saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ A positive way of putting the same thing may be to say that this rule, like many others, shows progress of linguistic analysis beyond the stage represented in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The rule is a close parallel to PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.56 As for its location, Whitney says: â€œBut there is a graver objection to the rule than its dispensability: it is quite out of place where it stands. In the first place, it treats of an initial s, while the treatise otherwise puts off such cases until after all those of a final s are disposed of; and, much worse, it interrupts the anuvrÌ¥tti of nÄmyupadhasya, which must necessarily take place from rule 81 (= CA 2.4.1) to those that follow; since, in the majority of the cases which it concerns, the sibilant is preceded by long Ä. Either there is here an unusual de- gree of awkwardness and inconsistency of method on the part of the author of the treatise, or the rule is an interpolation.â€ Since the rule is found in all the manuscripts, and since the CAB comments on it, the chance of this rule being an interpolation is drastically reduced. The question of the location of the rule, however, cannot be easily solved. The problem has been resolved in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar in an interesting way: P.8.3.55 (à¤…à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) states the general conditions: â€œ[in the follow- ing rules], the words â€˜of the non-word-finalâ€™ and â€˜cerebralâ€™ [should be continued].â€ Then comes the rule P.8.3.56 (à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤ƒ): â€œThe s of the root sah, transformed into sÄá¹­, [is changed to a cerebral á¹£].â€ Then comes the rule P.8.3.57 (à¤‡à¤£à¥à¤•à¥‹à¤ƒ): â€œafter the sounds [included in the shortforms] iá¹† and kU.â€ The term iá¹† refers to the sounds i, u, rÌ¥, lÌ¥, e, o, ai, au, h, y, v, r, and l. Among other things, this list includes all the nÄmin vowels referred to in CA (2.4.1). The term kU refers to the consonants k, kh, g, gh, and á¹…. Thus, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s system has taken care to place the condition iá¹‡koá¸¥ after P.8.3.56, and avoid the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 350 problem of this condition becoming vacuous in this rule. I now doubt the traditional view that the CA follows PÄá¹‡ini. A large portion of the CA probably predates PÄá¹‡ini, or follows pre-PÄá¹‡inian traditions, and PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s formulations seem to improve upon the inadequacies of this or a similar older tradition. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.à¤ªà¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨à¥¦.à¥©à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’- à¤·à¤¾à¤¡à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¡à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¹à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ Note: The examples listed by the CAB are found in APR (p. 146). à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥©. à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (2.83). Translation: Before a t-initial taddhita affix, [the s, preceded by a vowel other than a and Ä, is changed to á¹£]. Note: As Whitney notes, none of the other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas give â€œa grammatical definition of the phenomenon, like that of our treatise.â€ Taddhita affixes are affixes added to nominal stems to derive secondary nominal stems. This rule, unlike the previous rule, has a proper application within the normal scope of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. For instance, à¤µà¤ªà¥à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥‡ in AV (5.5.6) is represented as vapuá¸¥-tame in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Based on such examples, we know that the author of the AV PadapÄá¹­ha did separate certain affixes from their bases, af- fixes which were explicitly called taddhita by PÄá¹‡ini and the CA. Compare PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule P.8.3.101 (à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡), which has an additional condition hrasvÄt â€œafter a short vowel,â€ to prevent from this change applying after long vowels. The CA version can dispense with such a condition, because it is primarily concerned with examples as they appear in the ÅšAV, and not with Sanskrit at large. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾351 â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV, à¤‹.à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥©à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (â€˜à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‘à¤®à¥‡,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥«. à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤•à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«. à¥¨à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ Note: Most of the unattested examples quoted in the CAB are found in the KV on P.8.3.101 (à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡). à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥ª. à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.84). Translation: [The s, preceded by a vowel other than a and Ä, is changed to an á¹£], before [t-initial] allomorphs [lit. â€˜substi- tutesâ€™] of yuá¹£mat, except in passages such as tais tvam. Note: The relevant allomorphs of yuá¹£mat in this context are tvam, tvÄ, and te, as well as tubhyam and tava not included by Whitney. In a footnote, Whitney lists all cases of this phenomenon he found in the text of the ÅšAV. However, he does not list the gaá¹‡a, which forms the exceptions: â€œThis gaá¹‡a I have not thought it worth while to take the trouble to fill up, deeming it of more interest to give the complete list of the cases in which the change of the sibilant did, rather than of those in which it did not, take place. The former are, I be- lieve, the more numerous of the two classes.â€ Methodologically, of course, Whitneyâ€™s procedure is exactly opposite of the one chosen by the CA. Also note that the gaá¹‡a referred to in the above CA rule is fully listed in the APR (204). The APR lists a total of 18 instances in this gaá¹‡a, and the CAB cites the first three instances exactly in the same order. The examples listed in this gaá¹‡a also include instances of tubhyam and tava, indicating that our present rule did indeed cover these forms as well. There are other significant differences between the listings of Whitney and the listing given by the APR. Whitney lists à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¥’ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¥‘ (AV 7.74.3) as a positive case of change, while the list of exceptions to this change in the APR (p. 122) includes this example, indicating that the APR knew this instance without cerebralization.

Also compare P.8.3.103 (à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ƒà¤·à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¥). The condition à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¥ â€œwithin a metrical footâ€ in PÄá¹‡ini eliminates certain instances, which the APR (p. 122) had to explicitly list as exceptions, e.g. à¤…à¤¦à¥‘à¤¬à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥‘ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤µà¥‡- à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹, AV (17.1.9). E, F, I, O, P(corr): Â°à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¾Â°. Translation: [The s, preceded by a vowel other than a and Ä, is changed to á¹£] also before tat, tÄn agre etc. Note: Whitney says that the relevant forms of tat covered by this rule â€œare tam, tat, and tÄn.â€ If tÄn is thus included by the generic reference to tat, then what is the point of listing â€˜tÄn agre etcâ€™? Normally, such phrasal citations are meant to limit a given generalization to the instances with the whole phrases. If we thus take this reference to à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ as limiting this change to those instances of tÄn which are followed by agre, then some cases in the AV pose a dilemma, e.g. à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥, AV (18.2.28). The CA, perhaps, knew this case without cerebralization, and that the present text represents an analogical extension of cerebralization. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾353 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‹à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥§. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‹â€™ (Whitney: à¤¨à¥‹) (â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥’à¤¨à¥‹à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥­. à¥©; â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤°à¥‘à¤®à¥,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤­à¥‘à¤œâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¨. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤•à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤°à¥€(à¤®à¥)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: The CAB additionally offers a few examples which do not strictly come under the purview of the present rule. The manuscripts actually read duá¹£á¹­aro, while Whitney reports duá¹£á¹­ano, and then comments: â€œThe word duá¹£á¹­ara (vi.4.1) would seem to come properly under it, but its treatment by the pada-texts (it is written dustara, not duá¸¥-tara) indicates, I should think, that the Hindus regarded it as an irregular compound of duá¸¥ and stara, from the root star (strÌ¥); hence it would fall under the next rule, or else under rule 98 (= CA 2.4.18).â€ The manuscript reading duá¹£á¹­aro looks like a conflation of duá¹£á¹­ano and duá¹£á¹­aram. The most likely intended form must be à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥’à¤¨à¥‹à¥’ (AV 4.7.3), which is split by the PadapÄá¹­ha as à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥‹à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¦à¥à¤ƒà¤½à¤¤à¤¨à¥‹. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¬. à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.86). I have accepted Whitneyâ€™s reading against all the mss, because each manuscript contains numerous errors. H, Nb: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µÂ°. A, B, D, E, F, O: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥. Na: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µÂ°. I: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥. C: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥. J, M: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥. P: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥. Translation: Before strÌ¥ta, sva, and forms of the root svap, [the s, preceded by a vowel other than a or Ä, is changed to á¹£]. Note: The manuscripts of the CA, and also of the AV, do not reflect the predicted double sibilant in these forms, but the forms are read with a single cerebral á¹£. The printed editions follow the manuscripts in this respect. However, in the examples, as intended by the rule and the commentary, one must assume that, after a final s has been changed to á¹£, by this rule, before one of these forms, the initial s of these forms further undergoes cerebraliza- tion. Whitney here notices a gap in the coverage of sandhi rules in the CA. He points out that the rule as literally interpreted would yield the â€˜barbarous and impossible formsâ€™ like aniá¹£strÌ¥taá¸¥, niá¹£svÄ, and duá¹£svapnyam, and that there is

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 354 no express prescription to change the s of the roots to á¹£ due to its conjunction with an á¹£. PÄá¹‡ini 8.4.41 (á¹£á¹­unÄ á¹£á¹­uá¸¥) expressly takes care of such a situation. However, as Whitney correctly states: â€œ… we are compelled to look upon aniá¹£á¹£á¹­rÌ¥taá¸¥, niá¹£á¹£vÄ, and duá¹£á¹£vapnyam as the forms which the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in- tends to sanction.â€ Also, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 370) remarks: â€œThe proper readings in (AV 6.121.1) c are (see note to PrÄt. ii.86 = CA 2.4.6) duá¹£á¹£vÃ¡pnyam and nÃ­á¹£á¹£va, which the mss. almost without exception abbreviate to duá¹£vap- and nÃ­á¹£va, just as they abbreviate dattvÄ to datvÄ, or, in 2 a, rÃ¡jjvÄm to rÃ¡jvÄm. SPP. here gives in his saá¹ƒhitÄ-text nÃ­ á¹£va, with all his authorities; our text has nÃ­á¸¥ á¹£va, with only one of ours (O.): doubtless the true metrical form is nÃ­á¹£ á¹£uvÄ â€™smÃ¡t.â€ In AV (7.82.3) etc., the CA rule enjoins double á¹£á¹£, which is not seen in any mss. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39) says that the mss. drop the á¹£ according to the APR 80. Surya Kanta argues that the mss. thus represent a non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya tradition. However, it may be that even the ÅšaunakÄ«yas disregarded their own precepts, when it came to writing down the text of their tradition, under the pressure of the contemporary practice of writing Sanskrit, where the writing of such double á¹£á¹£ is hardly ever practiced. Thus, one needs to make a distinction between the original ÅšaunakÄ«ya precepts, and what later happened to the transmitted text under the pressure of the latter- day practice of Sanskrit orthography, and perhaps, pronunciation. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (?, Whitney: â€˜à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥®à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥¬. à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥§.à¥§; à¥­.à¥®à¥©.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: Referring to aniá¸¥-strÌ¥taá¸¥ in AV (7.82.3), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 449) remarks: â€œAll the pada-mss. read at the end Ã¡niá¸¥-strÌ¥taá¸¥, and this is required by PrÄt. ii.86 (= CA 2.4.6); but SPP. alters to Ã¡ni-strÌ¥taá¸¥ – which, to be sure, better suits the sense. The RV. pada-text also has (viii.33.9) Ã¡niá¸¥- strÌ¥taá¸¥; TS. (and by inference MS., as the editor reports nothing), Ã¡niá¹£á¹­rÌ¥taá¸¥, un- changed.â€ à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥­. à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ Whitney (2.87). A, B, D, P: split the rule after Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ. H, J, M, N, O: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯. P(orig): à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ for à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾355 Translation: The [initial] s of a suffix [is changed to á¹£] after a vowel other than a and Ä, k, or r. Note: There is a shift beginning with this rule to the change of an initial s. The conditioning sounds belong to a different morpheme, and hence we should note that the change takes place across a morpheme-boundary. Ele- ments across such morpheme-boundaries are occasionally split by the Pada- pÄá¹­ha, but not always so. In all the three examples cited here, the PadapÄá¹­ha does not split the constituents. The comparable rules in PÄá¹‡ini are P.8.3.57 (à¤‡à¤£à¥à¤•à¥‹à¤ƒ) and P.8.3.59 (à¤†à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ). While the present CA rule refers to k, rather than ka-varga, cf. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s kU in P.8.3.57, the CAB renders it as kavarga, possibly under the in- fluence of the PÄá¹‡inian rules. Or perhaps, as Whitney suggests: â€œHe explains ka in the rule by kavargÄt, â€˜after a guttural,â€™ probably in view of the require- ments of some authorities (see under ii. 6 = CA 2.1.6) that the k should be- come kh before the sibilant.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤«à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¥‘à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥‘à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¯à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¥’ à¤­à¥ƒà¤—à¥à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥ª. à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤·à¤®à¥‡à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: Rules such as this one indicate that a transition from the origi- nal purposes of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya and Åšiká¹£Ä literature to those of a general grammar of Sanskrit has already begun. This rule deals with a kind of juncture which is not separated even in the PadapÄá¹­ha, and hence one would not be ex- pected to make this sandhi in the process of combining the Padas to derive the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. This juncture is purely internal. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥®. à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¥‚à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.88). Translation: [The change of s to á¹£ also takes place in the form] straiá¹£Å«yam [< strai+sÅ«yam]. Note: Whitney comments: â€œWhy, among the words mentioned in iv.83 (= CA 4.3.11), it should be singled out to be made thus the subject of a

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 356 special rule, is not at all clear. The position of the rule, too, thrust in between the two closely related rules 87 (= CA 2.4.7) and 89 (= CA 2.4.9), and dis- turbing their connection, is in a high degree awkward, and calculated to inspire suspicion of an interpolation.â€ Since all the manuscripts contain this rule in this very position, this rule must have been a very ancient interpolation, if in- deed it is an interpolation. In any case, the instance accounted for in this rule is of an exceptional character. It is not covered by à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ in CA (2.4.7), because the s of sÅ«ya does not belong to an affix. Similarly, it is not covered by rules like CA (2.4.10), because sÅ«yam is not preceded by an upasarga. This form would probably be derived by P.8.3.106 (à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥), which is a nebulous rule saying that, according to some teachers, in Vedic texts, an s, preceded by an appropri- ate conditioning sound belonging to the preceding word, is cerebralized. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¥‚à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¥‚à¥‘à¤¯à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¯. à¤¨à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.89). Translation: Even when the [intervening] n has been deleted, [the initial s of an affix, preceded by an appropriate conditioning sound, cf. CA (2.4.7), is changed to cerebral á¹£]. Note: As Whitney notes, the rule â€œis intended to apply to such cases as yajuÌƒá¹£i, havÄ«Ìƒá¹£i, where, by ii. 34 (= CA 2.1.34), there has been a loss of n be- fore the ending si, accompanied, by i.67 (= CA 1.3.5), with nasalization of the preceding vowel, when the ending itself is converted into á¹£i after the alterant vowel, although the latter is nasal.â€ It is to be contrasted to PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.58 (à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿). P.8.3.58, in part, says that the s of the following affix changes to á¹£, if preceded by an appropriate conditioning sound, in spite of the intervention of sounds like nUM (> anusvÄra). Since the anusvÄra is consid- ered to be a consonantal nasal sound, PÄá¹‡ini thinks of its intervention in exam- ples like yajÅ«á¹ƒá¹£i. For the CA, which does not have the conception of an anusvÄra, the n is deleted, and the preceding vowel is nasalized. Therefore, it speaks of â€œeven after the deletion of the intervening n.â€ Another point brought up this rule is the conception of the deletion as held by the CA. One may pos- sibly infer that, according to the CA, a deletion may be considered to be like a

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾357 positive zero, whose intervention may block the operation of a rule like CA (2.4.7). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥‚à¤‚à¥‘à¤·à¤¿à¥’ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤œà¥à¥‘à¤¾à¥‚à¤‚à¤·à¤¿à¥’ à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¬.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¹à¥’à¤µà¥€à¤à¤·à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ Note: On this rule, Whitney says: â€œThis rule attaches itself immedi- ately and closely to rule 87 (= CA 2.4.7), from which it has been blunderingly separated by the intrusion of rule 88 (= CA 2.4.8).â€ On the basis of the con- tents of the rule, one feels like agreeing with Whitney. Note that the parallel rules in PÄá¹‡ini, i.e. P.8.3.57 (à¤‡à¤£à¥à¤•à¥‹à¤ƒ), P.8.3.58 (à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿), and P.8.3.59 (à¤†à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ), are consecutive rules. However, rule CA (2.4.8) must have been a very early intrusion, since it is uniformly supported by all the manuscripts as well as by the oldest commentary, i.e. the CAB. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦. à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.90). A, B, D: Â°à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾Â°. !: 10. Translation: After [an appropriate conditioning sound, cf. CA (2.4.7), at the end of a] preverb (= upasarga), [the initial s] of a verb root [is changed to á¹£]. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 358 à¥®)à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤§à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥ à¤¸à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¤¿â€™ à¥¤ Note: The counter examples à¤¦à¤§à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¤¿ and à¤®à¤§à¥ à¤¸à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¤¿ are found in the KV on P. 8.3.65 (à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥Œà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤­à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨à¤¯à¤¸à¥‡à¤§à¤¸à¤¿à¤šà¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤µ- à¤à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤®à¥). à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥§. à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.91). No such rule in A and B. Translation: [The initial s of a verb-root is changed to á¹£] after [an appropriate conditioning sound, cf. CA (2.4.7), in] the reduplication. Note: For all the examples cited by the commentator, the PadapÄá¹­ha offers the dental s unchanged, e.g. suá¹£Å«data : susÅ«data, siá¹£yade : sisyade. It is not, however, clear how one would avoid double retroflexion in a case like à¤…à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡, AV (5.5.9). Why would rule CA (2.4.10) not apply to this example to change the s of the reduplication to á¹£, as it does in the form à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ? The answer may lie in the way the PadapÄá¹­ha treats these forms. The form à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤µ- à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ in AV (1.2.3) is represented as pari-sasvajÄnÄá¸¥ in the PadapÄá¹­ha, indicat- ing this as a case of compounding. On the other hand, à¤…à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡ in AV (5.5.9) is represented as abhi / sisyade in the PadapÄá¹­ha, indicating that these are treated as two separate padas, and hence abhi is not an upasarga. In this context, abhi is a preposition (karmapravacanÄ«ya) connected with the accusa- tive vrÌ¥ká¹£Än. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤·à¤¦à¤¤à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥«.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤† à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥‡â€™ (only in N, not found in Vedic texts)à¥¤ â€˜à¤† à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¬; à¥«.à¥¨à¥­.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¤¾à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¥’à¤µà¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾359 à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¨. à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¤¿à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (2.92). Translation: [The s of the roots] sthÄ, sah, and sic, [is changed to á¹£ after an appropriate conditioning sound, cf. CA (2.4.7), in the upasarga], even when there is an intervening [past-tense marker] a. Note: There is an interesting theoretical issue concerning the applica- tion of this rule which has not been brought out either by the CAB or by Whitney. For example, in the example abhyaá¹£á¹­hÄm, the components are abhi+a+sthÄm. On the face of it, the rule assumes that the change of s to á¹£ takes place before the i of abhi is changed to y. CA (2.4.7: à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¥‡- à¤«à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯) does not include the sound y among the conditioning sounds for this change, while the category of nÄmin includes the sound i. On the other hand, the conditioning sounds for this change, as listed in P.8.3.57 (à¤‡à¤£à¥à¤•à¥‹à¤ƒ), in- clude y, besides i, in the abbreviation iá¹†, cf. PadamaÃ±jarÄ« on P.8.3.63 (à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥ à¤¸à¤¿- à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¡à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿) says: à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ … à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥‡à¤µ à¤¯à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥, à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¯à¤£à¤¿ à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡- à¤µà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥. Thus, PÄá¹‡ini can afford to make the change of s to á¹£, either be- fore or after changing abhi to abhy. On the other hand, the CA seems to expect us to make change of s to á¹£, before changing abhi to abhy. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¤¿à¤šà¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½- à¤ªà¤¿ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‘- à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤‚à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥«.à¥©à¥¬; à¥§à¥¬.à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‘- à¤·à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤·à¤¿à¥‘à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript H presents the first sentence simply as: à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¤¿à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney rightly felt that this was mutilated and incomplete, and he restored the sentence as: à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¤¿à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾- à¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ While this is not exactly identical with the text as now found in the second manuscript, N, it is very close to it, and we must admire Whitneyâ€™s acumen in restoring the missing text. For the examples cited by the commentary, the PadapÄá¹­ha and the printed editions offer different treatment. The example abhyaá¹£á¹­hÄm in AV

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 360 (10.5.36) is represented in the PadapÄá¹­ha as two words: abhi / asthÄm. The VVRI edition reads vyasahanta in AV (3.10.12), while it notes the manuscript variant vyaá¹£ahanta. The PadapÄá¹­ha splits it as: vi / asahanta. The form abhyaá¹£icyanta in AV (14.1.36) is represented in the PadapÄá¹­ha as: abhi- asicyanta. All the three forms are given with cerebrals in the Whitney-Roth edition. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥©. à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.93). Translation: Even with the intervention of a reduplication, [the s] of sthÄ [is changed to á¹£, after an appropriate conditioning sound, cf. CA (2.4.7), in the preverb (upasarga)]. Note: In the examples cited by the commentary, the PadapÄá¹­ha restores the â€˜originalâ€™ dental sibilant, e.g. vi taá¹£á¹­hire : vi / tasthire. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¤ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‘à¤µà¥‹ à¤µà¤¿ à¤¤à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‘ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥’à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚à¥’ à¤µà¤¿ à¤¤à¥‘à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‡(H: à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¿à¤°à¥‡)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: Whitneyâ€™s text for AV (9.10.19) does not show the application of this rule, but reads: vi tasthe. Whitney says that this was given erroneously and that there is manuscript evidence to support the reading vi taá¹£á¹­he. This reading is also supported by the VVRI edition, AV (9.15.19 = W: 9.10.19). Whitney further points out: â€œWe have in two other passages (ix.9.2, xiv.2.9) adhi tasthuá¸¥ (not taá¹£á¹­huá¸¥); this apparently constitutes an exception to the rule which has escaped the notice both of the treatise and of the commenta- tor : possibly, however, the adhi is not in these passages regarded as standing in the relation of upasarga to the root sthÄ, since it does, in fact, belong rather, in a prepositional relation, to preceding ablative cases, than to the verbal form as its prefix : and this is the more clearly indicated by its retaining its independ- ent accent before the accented verb.â€ The VVRI edition agrees with Whitneyâ€™s reading, and cites no manuscript variants. It is just not clear what ablative cases Whitney is referring to in the cited examples. The preposition (à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤š- à¤¨à¥€à¤¯) adhi in both instances seems to echo the locatives in the context: à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾

P: Â°à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤¨à¥‡. Translation: [The initial s of sthÄ is changed to á¹£] after parama etc., but not after ÄpÄke. Note: The CAB does not explicitly continue the word sthaá¸¥ from the previous rule, though all the examples it cites are examples of the root sthÄ, and it makes eminent sense to continue the word into this rule. It may be noted that all the examples of the paramÄdi gaá¹‡a listed under APR (205, pp. 122-3) in- volve the element stha. There are two instances included here which actually involve the superlative affix -iá¹£á¹­ha, but seem to have been evidently wrongly etymologized as involving stha, i.e. Å›reá¹£á¹­ha and prathiá¹£á¹­ha. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 362 were made, the need for stating such exceptions diminished. One needs ex- ceptions stated, only when one does not have full lists of instances, and has only generic rules. Whitney also points out agniá¹£vÄttaá¸¥, AV (18.3.44: Pada: agni-svÄttaá¸¥), which he says should have been included in this rule: â€œWe can hardly suppose that it was intentionally omitted here, to be included in the gaá¹‡a of rule 98 [= CA 2.4.18], below: either it must have been overlooked by the maker of the treatise, or the verse which contains it was not in his Atharvaveda : that it was, however, contained in the text recognized by the commentator, is shown by the fact that he several times (under i.80 = CA 1.3.18; i.84 = CA 1.3.22; and ii.34 = CA 2.1.34) cites the phrase atto havÄ«á¹ƒá¹£i, which forms part of its second line.â€ Whitneyâ€™s inference may not be so cogent, especially because the par- allel rule in PÄá¹‡ini, i.e. P.8.3.82, also excludes the consideration of this form. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 364 Note: PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.107 (à¤¸à¥à¤à¤ƒ) is identical with CA (2.4.17). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾365 â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¥’à¤·à¥‡à¥’à¤§à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥®.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤˜à¥à¥’à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥­. à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Referring to the expression tryÄdi, Whitney says: â€œHere is an- other of those convenient gaá¹‡as, set as a catch-all for whatever cases may not have been otherwise provided for, and rendering it impossible for us to ascer- tain the precise degree of accuracy with which the authors of the treatise ex- amined and excerpted their text.â€ Now, the gaá¹‡a referred to in this CA rule is fully listed in APR (206). It contains a total of 16 instances, out of which the CAB quotes the first three instances exactly in the same order. Also see the Note under CA 2.4.16. Whitney further says: â€œHe (= commentator) also, in his paraphrase, limits the application of the rule to cases of this character, in which an alterant vowel at the end of the first member of a compound comes before an initial s of the following member.â€ The commentator simply says à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ, and makes no explicit reference to the nÄmin vowels at the end of these words. It is, true, however, that all the cited examples fit Whitneyâ€™s description. But the examples listed in this gaá¹‡a under APR (206, pp. 123-4) are not examples of compounds. They contain a number of phrasal sequences, e.g. à¤¨à¤¿ à¤· à¤¹à¥€à¥‘à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥, AV (8.4.10). Whitney offers a number of cases which might potentially become members of this class. Whitneyâ€™s listing overlaps with the listing of this gaá¹‡a, as found under APR (206, pp. 123-4). As noted above, the gaá¹‡a under APR (206) contains several phrasal sequences, while Whitneyâ€™s listing includes only compound expressions. The APR gaá¹‡a contains the following compound expressions, not covered by Whitneyâ€™s listing: gaviá¹£á¹­hiram (4.29.5), viá¹£Äsahiá¸¥ (1.29.6), abhimÄtiá¹£Ähaá¸¥ (4.32.4), and agniá¹£vÄttÄá¸¥ (18.3.44). On the other hand, Whitney lists the following compounds, which are not listed under APR (206): suá¹£á¹­uti (6.1.3), suá¹£Å«man (7.46.2), anuá¹£á¹­up (8.9.14), triá¹£á¹­up (8.9.14), traiá¹£á¹­ubha (9.10.1), and diviá¹£á¹­ambhaá¸¥ (19.32.7). à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¯. à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.99). Translation: After a word ending in short rÌ¥, [the initial s] of the root sad [is changed to á¹£].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 366 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥‹à¥’à¤¤à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥ƒà¥’- à¤·à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¤¦à¥‘à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥¬à¥­)à¥¤ Note: Whitney adds: â€œTo these may be added pitrÌ¥á¹£ad (xiv.2.33 : p. pitrÌ¥-sad); and in nÄrá¹£ada (4.19.2 : p. nÄrsada) is also implied nrÌ¥á¹£ad.â€ à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¦. à¤¬à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿à¤ªà¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (2.100). F: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š. I: Â°à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¥€à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š. J, M, P(corr): Â°à¤ªà¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¥Â°. I: 20. Translation: [The s of the root sad is changed to á¹£] also after barhi, pathi, apsu, divi, and prÌ¥thivi. Note: Whitney comments: â€œWe have reason to be surprised that the root sad is treated in this manner, being made the subject of these two separate rules. If the compounds into which it enters as final member are to be excepted from the general gaá¹‡a of rule 98 (= CA 2.4.18), we should expect to find it directed that the s of sad should always be lingualized after an alterant vowel, as is actually the case. Not only is there, by the method adopted, a loss of that brevity which treatises of the sÅ«tra class are wont to aim at almost as their chief object, but there is also a loss of completeness : the only remaining compound of sad of this class, suá¹£ad (e.g. ii.36.4), is left out, to be provided for in the general gaá¹‡a. Or is it possible that su is regarded as falling under rule 90 (= CA 2.4.10), as if a proper upasarga or preposition? If so, the forms into which it enters would be sufficiently provided for; since, excepting in the cases noted in the later rule (102 = CA 2.4.22 etc.), it always lingualizes the initial s of a root, while it has no effect upon that of a preposition or adverb, as in susaha (vi.64.3 : p. su-saha) and the numerous compounds in which it is followed by sam, as susaá¹ƒrabdha.â€ There is no exactly parallel rule or rules in PÄá¹‡ini which deals specifically with the formations involving the root sad. We may note that no forms of sad are noted in the gaá¹‡a under APR (206), which is probably the same gaá¹‡a as referred to by the term tryÄdi in CA (2.4.18). Whitneyâ€™s discussion regarding the status of su needs an extensive consideration. For a parallel discussion, see the KV on P.8.3.88 (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) and P.8.3.98 (à¤¸à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š).

Note: It is understood from the context that the rule applies only to those forms of the verb as, where the initial a is deleted, and the forms become s-initial. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤ªà¥‹à¥’ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥«. à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¿ à¤·à¥à¤ â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥¦.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥à¤šà¥‹à¥’ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: What is the source of this exception referred to in the passage à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥à¤šà¥‹à¥’ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ in the CAB? APR? This could be a case of the author of the CA inadvertently forgetting to mention an exception, or a case of textual change. In this case, the manuscripts of the AV do follow this excep- tion, and Whitney as well as the VVRI edition read à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥à¤šà¥‹à¥’ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘. Referring to the preceding section, Whitney makes the following gen- eral comments: â€œBut there are still left in the Atharvan text a few instances of the same conversion, which can hardly be regarded as included in any of the preceding rules, since they are analogous with none of the other cases there treated of: unless something has been lost from this final section of the chapter

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 368

  • of which there are no indications - the treatise-makers and their commentator must lie under the imputation of having been careless enough to overlook them. The passages referred to are as follows: à¤†à¤¦à¥à¥‘ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¥’à¤¨à¤®à¥ (iv.3.4), à¤¤à¤®à¥à¥‘ à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¹à¤¿à¥’ (vi.1.2), à¤¨à¤¿ à¤· à¤¹à¥€à¥‘à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥ (viii.4.10), and à¤šà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘ (xviii.1.33). There would be little plausibil- ity in a claim that the verses containing these passages were not included in the Atharvaveda accepted by the school to which the treatise belonged, or that the readings of the school were different.â€ Now we find that the last two of the examples are mentioned in the tryÄdi gaá¹‡a, which is referred to in CA (2.4.18), and is extensively listed under APR (206, pp. 123-4). Besides this, Whitneyâ€™s assumption that the CAB was expected to give complete lists of all examples and counter-examples found in the text of the ÅšAV is baseless. Even in the APR, it appears that lists of posi- tive examples are not complete catalogues, while the lists of exceptions are so. In contrast, the CAB is almost always illustrative, rather than exhaustive. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¨. à¤¨ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (2.102). Ha, Na: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¤¿Â°. J, M: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿Â°. E (corr): Â°à¤®à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿Â° for Â°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿Â°. F (corr): omits à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿. Translation: Not, [however, the s] of the roots srÌ¥p, srÌ¥j, sprÌ¥Å›, sphÅ«rj, svrÌ¥, and smrÌ¥. Note: Whitney makes the following comment: â€œThis is evidently a rule of kindred sphere with rule 106 (= CA 2.4.26), below, and the two might well enough have been combined into one, which should teach that a root con- taining a r, either semivowel or vowel, was not liable to the changes prescribed in this section.â€ However, from the behavior of the treatise, one may infer that the CA does not intend to cover the consonantal and the vocalic r under a common generalization. This suspicion is further strengthened by the separate mention of rÌ¥ and r in one and the same rule, e.g. CA (3.4.1: à¤‹à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¨à¥‹ à¤£à¤ƒ). PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.110 (à¤¨ à¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿à¤¸à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) also separately refers to roots containing consonantal and vocalic r. Whitney further says: â€œAs so stated, it would require the notice of but a single exception, vi á¹£phurat (vi.56.1 and x.4.8). As the rules now stand, they are slightly inexact, for in neither of them are included anusphuram (i.2.3), atisara (v.8.2 etc.), and pratisara (e.g. ii.11.2), although other forms of the root sar are contemplated in rule 106 (= CA 2.4.26).â€ Again, we now find that the instances of atisara (v.8.2 etc.), and prati- sara (e.g. ii.11.2) are listed in the gosanyÄdi gaá¹‡a referred to in the next rule,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾369 CA (2.4.23), and fully listed under APR (147f, p. 101). As for anusphuram (1.2.3) mentioned by Whitney as an exception to cerebralization, the VVRI edition notes several manuscripts which have the reading anuá¹£phuram. Fur- ther, the absence of anusphuram in the gosanyÄdi gaá¹‡a listed exhaustively under APR (147f, p. 101) may be taken as an indication that the APR also knew the form as anuá¹£phuram, rather than as anusphuram. On the other hand, P.8.3.76 (à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ) says that after nir, ni, and vi, the s of sphurati and sphulati is optionally (or â€˜preferablyâ€™ a la Kiparsky) changed to á¹£. The tra- dition understands this rule in such a way, that without this rule, there would be no cerebral á¹£ in any forms of these roots: à¤à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤®à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, NyÄsa on KV on P.8.3.76. This would predict the form anusphuram. One could conceivably argue that a more original AV form anuá¹£phuram was reduced to anusphuram under the pressure of the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°- à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¨à¥â€™ (not in AV, à¤µà¤¾.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥§.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¥‘à¤·à¥’à¤­à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¬.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (?, Whitney: perhaps a corrupted reading for â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤ƒà¥‘,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥©.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‚à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¥à¤‹à¥’à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‘ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¥‡à¤¥à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤œà¤¯à¥‘à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥­)à¥¤ Note: The instances cited by the commentary, not traced to the AV, are found in the KV on P.8.3.108 (à¤¨ à¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿à¤¸à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). For example, the gosanyÄdigaá¹‡a as listed under APR (147f, p. 101) also includes the examples adhi skanda (5.25.8) and abhi skandam (5.14.11), while the CA provides the next rule to take care of these examples, as if they were not included in the gosayÄdigaá¹‡a. à¥¨.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥ª. à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (2.104). Translation: [The s] of the root skand, after adhi and abhi, [is not changed to á¹£]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤§à¤¿ à¤…à¤­à¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿- à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¦ à¤µà¥€à¥’à¤¡(Whitney: à¤°)à¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥«.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿à¥’ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¥‘à¤¦à¤‚ à¤®à¥ƒà¥’à¤—à¥€à¤µà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥ª.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¤•à¥‘à¤¶à¤¤à¤‚à¥’ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¯.à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: The VVRI edition accepts the reading vÄ«rayasva for AV (5.25. 8), but notes the manuscript variant vÄ«á¸ayasva. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾371 mentatorâ€™s grammatical system derives skandha, â€˜shoulder,â€™ from the root skand. An actual example of the kind he seeks to give is pariá¹£kanda (xv.2.1 etc.).â€ Whitneyâ€™s suspicion that, for the commentator, the word skandha in viá¹£kandha may have been derived from the root skand finds support in [pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™ commentary on the word viá¹£kandham in AV (1.16.3): à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥‹à¤·à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‡ à¤˜à¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ â€˜à¤µà¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤°à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾. à¥®.à¥©.à¥­à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤§à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ. We should note that on pariá¹£kanda, the VVRI edition notes that a sub- stantial number of manuscripts have the reading pariskanda. Apparently, the northwestern form was cerebralized, while the central and the eastern form was non-cerebralized, according to PÄá¹‡ini, cf. Hb: à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š. I: à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š. Translation: [The s] followed by r [is not changed to á¹£].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¨, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥ª 372 Note: Rules CA (2.4.22) and the present rule together provide a large class of exceptions to the roots whose initial s changes to á¹£ after an appropriate conditioning sound. The common factor shared by these roots is that they contain, after their initial s, either a vocalic or a consonantal r. A similar grouping of roots resistant to cerebralization is found in PÄá¹‡ini 8.3.110 (à¤¨ à¤°à¤ªà¤°- à¤¸à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¶à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥). Translation: [There is no cerebralization of s in] abhi syÄma prÌ¥tanyataá¸¥. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤® à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¯à¤®à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤® à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­. à¥¯à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤®à¤¾ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒà¥’ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¤à¥‘à¤¨à¤¾ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤®â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: For the citation from AV (7.93.1), all the mss., except W, used by Whitney read á¹£yÄma and this reading, violating the present rule in the CA, is chosen by Whitney in his edition. Later Whitney changed his mind. He (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 456) remarks: â€œMost of the saá¹ƒhitÄ-mss. give á¹£yÄma (our W.O., and two fifths of SPPâ€™s authorities, sy-), and both printed texts read it; but the PrÄt. On AV (13.1.22), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 714) points out that â€œM.p.m. âˆ€and SPPâ€™s C.# read at end syÄma; the passage is quoted as an instance of -á¹£y- in the comm. to PrÄt. ii. 107 (= CA 2.4.27).â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾373 With respect to the variation in AV (7.93.1), it is more likely that the situation as seen in the majority of the manuscripts represents an analogical spread of retroflexion in later times. It is non-ÅšaunakÄ«ya only in the sense that it does not represent the situation as codified by the CA. However, one must not preclude the possibility of change within the ÅšaunakÄ«ya oral tradition, as is done by Surya Kanta. The VVRI edition offers the reading à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤® à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒ for AV (7.98.1 = W: 7.93.1), but notes the reading à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤® à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¤ƒ as a manuscript variant. It would probably be reasonable to assume that there was further spread of retroflexion after the period of the CA, and such a spread accounts for the retroflexion seen in such instances. Secondly, this rule again brings into sharp focus the possibility that the gaá¹‡as such as the gosanyÄdigaá¹‡a referred to in CA (2.4.23) and APR (147f, p. 101-2) may have had different composition in the two traditions. While the instance abhi syÄma prÌ¥tanyataá¸¥ appears in the list of the gosanyÄdigaá¹‡a in the APR, its separate treatment by the CA may indicate that the gosanyÄdigaá¹‡a as conceived by the CA was a smaller collection of exceptions. For another similar case, see the Note on CA (2.4.23). à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¥¥à¥§à¥¦à¥¬à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ. I: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾- à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥ªà¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤•à¥Œà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥à¥¨à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥§à¥¦à¥­ à¥¥ à¤à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¥¨à¥§à¥­. P: à¥¥à¥ªà¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¥¥à¥§à¥¦à¥¬à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¥¥ ___________________________________

à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥©.à¥§.à¥§. à¤¸à¤¹à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.1). Translation: Before [a form of] the root sah, ending in Äá¹­, [the preceding vowel] becomes long. Note: As Whitney notes, the qualification Äá¸-anta â€˜ending in Äá¹­â€™ in this rule achieves the same goal as achieved by the qualification sÄá¸bhÅ«tasya in CA (2.4.2). Whitney says: â€œIt would not do to say â€˜before sah when it be- comes sÄh,â€™ because of the words amitrasÄha and abhimÄtiá¹£Äha, in which, though the vowel of the root is lengthened, the preceding final remains un- changed.â€ Whitney also notes: â€œThis rule also belongs in the category of the supererogatory, since in none of the words to which it relates does the pada- text afford a different reading from that of the saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ A more positive way of interpreting this rule may be to say that it marks a stage of grammatical analysis beyond the stage reached by the PadapÄá¹­ha, and hence, even though it does not relate to the conversion of the padas into saá¹ƒhitÄ, it shows us the progression of the grammatical science, cf. P.8.3.56 (à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤ƒ). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤¹à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤†à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥’- à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¥’à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥ª.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦. à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤¡à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤†à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¹à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in Vedic texts)à¥¤ Note: While prÄá¹£Äá¹­ is not attested in the ÅšAV as we know it, it is listed in the APR (p. 146), along with the other examples cited by the CAB.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾375 à¥©.à¥§.à¥¨. à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¦à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤šà¤•à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.2). Translation: [The final a of] aá¹£á¹­a [is lengthened] before pada, yoga, paká¹£a, pará¹‡a, daá¹ƒá¹£á¹­ra, and cakra. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·- à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¦à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤šà¤•à¥à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤ªà¥‘à¤¦à¥€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¯.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤ªà¥‘à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥©.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‹à¥’à¤—à¥ˆà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¯à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤®à¥â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾- à¤šà¥‘à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’ à¤¨à¤µà¥‘à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤šà¥‘à¤•à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney remarks that â€œthe rule, moreover, is an unnecessary one, since the pada-text everywhere offers the same reading with the saá¹ƒhitÄ, as is expressly directed by a later rule.â€ Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39) suggests that combinations of aá¹£á¹­Ã¡ with pará¹‡Ã¡ and dÃ¡á¹ƒá¹£á¹­ra, which are not attested in the Vulgate of the AV, may have existed in a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV. I tend to think that these are indications of the CA occa- sionally straying into provisions for a general grammar of Sanskrit. However, in this case, it should be noted that these examples are not found in the KV on P.6.3.125 (à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥). The word aá¹£á¹­Ädaá¹ƒá¹£á¹­raá¸¥ is found in Ä€Å›valÄyana- Åšrauta-SÅ«tra (12.99.9) and Ä€pastamba-Åšrauta-SÅ«tra (24.8.6), but not in the earlier Vedic texts. The fact that the rule of the CA includes daá¹ƒá¹£á¹­ra, though it is evidently a late usage, shows that the author of the CA was already leaning toward a general grammar of Sanskrit. à¥©.à¥§.à¥©. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (3.3). B, J: Â°à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°Â°. E, F, I, O, P(orig): à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡. M: à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤µÂ°. Translation: Before the root vyadh, when it does not end in any affix, [the preceding vowel is lengthened].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 376 Note: In the examples of this rule, the PadapÄá¹­ha is identical with the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha reading, and hence we need to look at this rule as an advance of grammatical analysis beyond the stage represented by the PadapÄá¹­ha. The rule asserts that in a formation like Å›vÄ-vit < Å›vÄ-vidh < Å›vÄ-vyadh, the root vyadh is apratyaya â€˜does not end in an affix.â€™ However, it is clear that here it is a verbal noun. The CA deals with a root-noun as a root without an affix. This needs to be contrasted with PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s procedure which adds an affix such as KvIP, where ultimately each component of this affix is deleted, leaving behind a Ã˜-affix. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule which provides lengthening in such cases explicitly refers to the Ã˜-affix KvI, i.e. P.6.3.116 (à¤¨à¤¹à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤·à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤•à¥à¤µà¥Œ). PataÃ±jali, however, uses the term apratyaya to refer to such zero-affixes like KvIP, see: MB and PradÄ«pa on P.1.1.6 with reference to pipaá¹­hÄ«á¸¥. On the expression marmÄvidham, AV (11.10.26), [pseudo]-SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary offers a PÄá¹‡inian derivation by adding the affix KvIP to the root vyadh. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤§à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ [à¤…]à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾[à¤¨à¥]à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥©.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥ƒà¥’à¤¦à¥’à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥§à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (only in N, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¥’ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: The three examples cited by the CAB are listed under APR (p. 146) in the same order. à¥©.à¥§.à¥ª. à¤‰à¤ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.4). Hb, Nb: à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿Â°. After this rule, A, B, D, J, M add: à¤Šà¤‚à¤‡à¤¸à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ. C, E, F, H, I, and N: no such rule. Translation: In [the sequences] idam Å« á¹£u etc., the particle u (= uÃ±) [is lengthened]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤® à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¦à¥‚à¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‚à¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¥€à¤®à¥‚à¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬.à¥¨)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾377 â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯ à¤Šà¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤· à¤Šà¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥©à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‚à¥’ à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥®à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Evidently, Whitney is listing some missing instances: â€œthe other cased afforded by the text are pary Å« á¹£u (vi.6.4), and para Å« te (xviii.3.7).â€ Of these two, the first one is actually found in the text of the CAB, and Whitney just missed it. It is found in both the manuscripts, one of which, i.e. H, was available to Whitney. About the second example, i.e. para Å« te (xviii.3.7), Whitney com- ments: â€œWere it not for this last case, the rule of our treatise might have been constructed like that of the VÄj. Pr., which says (iii.109) that u before su is lengthened.â€ The gaá¹‡a referred to in this CA rule is fully spelled out in APR (207a) and the examples listed there occur exactly in the same order as in the CAB. The example which is added by Whitney and which is not given by our commentary here is the last example in the APR list. It is not clear why the CAB did not list this example. It could be an example of omission, or it may represent a change in usage. Compare this rule with PÄá¹‡ini 6.3.134 (à¤‡à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤à¤¿), which has slightly wider coverage, but represents a generalization of the type demanded by Whitney in his comments cited above. à¥©.à¥§.à¥«. à¤“à¤·à¤§à¥‡à¤°à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.5). Translation: [The final i] of the word oá¹£adhi [is lengthened] before [case endings] other than the first five [i.e. nominative sg., du., pl., and accusative sg., and du.]. Note: Whitney translates the condition apaÃ±capadyÄm as â€˜except in the strong cases,â€™ and then assumes that this condition leaves everything else open, including a situation where oá¹£adhi occurs as the first member of a com- pound, and is followed by the second member. With such a wider interpretation, he comments: â€œSince the rule does not restrict itself to forms of declension, it is guilty of an oversight in taking no account of the compound oá¹£adhija (x.4.23 : p. oá¹£adhi-ja) as a farther exception. In the only other compounds which the text affords - viz. oá¹£adhÄ«saá¹ƒÅ›ita (x.5.32 : p. oá¹£adhi- saá¹ƒÅ›ita), and oá¹£adhÄ«mant (xix.17.6; 18.6) - the rule of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya is observed.â€

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 378 The closely similar rule in PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s grammar, i.e. P.6.3.132 (à¤“à¤·à¤§à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥), clearly seems to restrict this lengthening before a case ending, other than the nominative, and it seems likely that the CA rule also applies be- fore case endings alone, and not to the situations of compounds. If so, how would one deal with the examples of compounds brought up by Whitney? The APR may provide some assistance in this direction. The example oá¹£adhÄ«- saá¹ƒÅ›ita is included in a gaá¹‡a of compound expressions showing similar lengthening of the final vowel of the first member, cf. APR (208, pp. 125-6). Though, it is true that there is no specific CA rule which would take care of this lengthening. On the other hand, the text of the PadapÄá¹­ha, as given by the VVRI edition reads: oá¹£adhÄ«-saá¹ƒÅ›itaá¸¥. This is different from the pada-reading cited by Whitney. But, if this reading is somehow valid, then this may not have been viewed as a case of lengthening at all, since the long vowel was al- ready there in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The instance oá¹£adhÄ«mant is clearly taken care of by CA (3.1.17: à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¥Œ). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤“à¤·à¤§à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤…à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€(H, N: à¤§à¤¿)à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥¦.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¹à¥’ à¤®à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚à¥’ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥©à¥®.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript H mostly writes à¥ for à¤“. à¥©.à¥§.à¥¬. à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¤§à¥€à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.6). O: à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤‚à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¤‚. Translation: [The i of the word oá¹£adhi is also lengthened in the word oá¹£adhÄ«m only in the phrase] jÄ«vantÄ«m oá¹£adhÄ«m. Note: PÄá¹‡ini 6.3.132 (à¤“à¤·à¤§à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥) prescribes lengthen- ing of oá¹£adhi before all non-nominative case-endings, and hence à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¤§à¥€à¤®à¥ would be a normal formation in that system, while à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤–à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤·à¤§à¤¿à¤®à¥ would be an exceptional case. The situation is reverse with the CA formations.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾379 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥€à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤®à¥‹à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€à¤®à¥’à¤¹à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥¬; à¥­.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹- à¤£à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤®à¤¾ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤–à¥‘à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¶à¥‡à¤ªà¥’à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¥€à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: [Pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a reads oá¹£adhÄ«m in AV (3.18.1), but oá¹£adhim in AV (4.4.1). Could this be taken as an indication that [Pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a was not familiar with the rules of the CA, which he fails to quote even once in his entire commentary? à¥©.à¥§.à¥­. à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.7). Translation: [The vowel a in the root sah in the form] sÄá¸ha [is lengthened]. Note: Whitney comments: â€œThe rule is one of the most utterly super- fluous presented by our treatise, which, of course, has nothing to do with the mode of formation of such words. Moreover, if it was inclined to do a work of supererogation as regards them, it should not have omitted to notice also rÅ«á¸hvÄ, rÅ«á¸ha, mÅ«á¸ha, gÅ«á¸ha, and other like forms which the text contains. Probably the reason why this particular one was noticed, and not the others, is that the regular form, according to the rules of the general grammar, is soá¸ha.â€ Whitneyâ€™s last comment is the correct reason. PÄá¹‡ini too provides special treatment only for this form, and not the other ones, which are derived by the normal rules of his grammar. The normal rule, i.e. P.6.3.112 (à¤¸à¤¹à¤¿à¤µà¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¥‹à¤¦à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯), changes the a of the root sah to o to derive the form soá¸ha. However, the next rule, i.e. P.6.3.113 (à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¥à¤¯à¥ˆ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤®à¥‡), admits as nipÄtanas exceptional forms like sÄá¸ha for the Vedic language (nigame). For some reason, sÄá¸heti in P.6.3.113, is analyzed by the KÄÅ›ikÄvrÌ¥tti as à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿, rather than as à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿, and the commentary takes sÄá¸hÄ to be a nominative form of sÄá¸hrÌ¥- : à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤šà¤¿ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥. However, it does not cite any example for it. The SK on this rule of- fers the example sÄá¸·hÄ (= sÄá¸hÄ). But, interestingly, the commentary Subo- dhinÄ« says that the rule should also be applicable to the past participle sÄá¸ha : à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤·à¤¾à¤³à¥à¤¹à¥‹ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡ à¤µà¥ƒà¤·à¤­à¤ƒ à¥¤â€™ In general, the PÄá¹‡inian commentators show little familiarity with the AV tradition.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 380 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤¢à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤šà¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤¢à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥©à¥¦.à¥¯)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥§.à¥®. à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.8). Translation: [The final i] of rÄtri is diversely [lengthened]. Note: Whitney takes the author of the CA to the woodshed: â€œThis is rather a discreditable confession on the part of our treatise, whose business it is to settle authoritatively the reading of its school in all cases admitting of any doubt, that it does not feel equal to dealing with the irregularities of the word in question. Nothing like it has hitherto met us, but we shall find several in- stances in that which follows.â€ It is understandable that a similar appeal to di- versity and irregularity of Vedic usage is found in PÄá¹‡ini 4.1.31 (à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¥Œ). However, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s appeal is more acceptable, since he aimed at describing the diversity of Sanskrit at large. On the other hand, we do indeed expect a more exact accounting from a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya text. The use of bahulam in this and other rules again indicates occasional leanings of the author of the CA in the direction of a general grammar of Sanskrit. This is also apparent from Whitneyâ€™s comment: â€œIt is also a very unnecessary acknowledgment; for, in the first place, there was no such rule as this absolutely called for, since the pada- text everywhere reads all the forms of rÄtri like the saá¹ƒhitÄ.â€ To look a little deeper into the wording of the rule, one may point out that the genitive rÄtreá¸¥ suggests that, for the author of the CA, as for PÄá¹‡ini - cf. P.4.1.31 -, the basic stem form was rÄtri, and not rÄtrÄ«, and the CA rule may be taken literally to indicate the deemed deviant character of this word, a stem in short i, occasionally providing forms in the text of the AV unpredictably (bahulam) as if it were a stem in long Ä«. However, I agree with Whitneyâ€™s criti- cism that we should expect from a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya a more exact account. For some reason, the APR also does not take account of the diverse behavior of rÄtri. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¥‘(H, N: à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿)à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¥‘à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¥‘- à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¥‘à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤·à¥â€™ à¥¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾381 à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¨ à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤‚à¥’ à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«. à¥§à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: Whitneyâ€™s text for AV (18.1.10) reads rÄtrÄ«bhiá¸¥. The manu- scripts H and N both read rÄtribhiá¸¥. However, considering the later comment in the commentary, i.e. à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¨ à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿, I suspect that the reading in- tended by the commentator must have been rÄtrÄ«bhiá¸¥. This reading is also sup- ported by the VVRI edition. à¥©.à¥§.à¥¯. à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤°à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.9). Translation: [The final a] of viÅ›va is [diversely lengthened] before nara, vasu, and mitra. Note: Whitney points out that the examples brought together here are heterogeneous. The word viÅ›vÄnara is not broken up in the PadapÄá¹­ha into its components. On the other hand, viÅ›vÄvasu of the Saá¹ƒhitÄ is represented as viÅ›va-vasu in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The word viÅ›vÄmitra is unchanged in the PadapÄá¹­ha, while the word viÅ›vamitrÄá¸¥ in AV (18.3.63, 4.54) is analyzed in the PadapÄá¹­ha as viÅ›va-mitrÄá¸¥. Whitney also argues that it is difficult to justify the continuity of the word bahulam into this rule from the previous rule. However, his arguments against the continuity of bahulam are not strong. Compare PÄá¹‡ini 6.3.128 (à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥‹à¤ƒ), 6.3.129 (à¤¨à¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥), and 6.3.130 (à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤šà¤°à¥à¤·à¥Œ). PÄá¹‡ini makes a semantic distinction between viÅ›vÄnara vs viÅ›vanara, and viÅ›vÄ- mitra vs viÅ›vamitra. The lengthened forms are names, while non-lengthened forms are descriptions. For example, on viÅ›vamitrÄá¸¥ in AV (18.3.63), the commentary of [pseudo-]SÄyaá¹‡a renders it as à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ, and not as mem- bers of ViÅ›vÄmitraâ€™s clan. Also see Whitneyâ€™s note on this verse (AV Trans- lation, Vol.II., p. 866). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤°à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‘à¤°à¥‡ à¤…à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¤(H, N: à¤¤à¥)â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥’ à¤œà¤®à¥‘à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤®à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤šà¤¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥¬à¥©; à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥ª)à¥¤

We should also note that the exception is followed by all the editions of the AV and is supported by the manuscripts. Whitney (AV Transl. Translation: Before varta etc., [the final vowel of the pre- ceding item is lengthened]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’- à¤µà¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥‘à¤­à¥€à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§. à¥©à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: Whitney, reading only from the manuscript H, believed that the paraphrase of this rule had some missing words, which, if restored, would read: à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿. However, the second manu- script, N, does not support this wording. The gaá¹‡a referred to in this rule is fully listed in APR (207b). It contains a listing of 21 instances. The CAB quotes the first two instances from this list. It may have also contained the cases listed under APR (208). APR (207b, p. 124): à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ, and the 21 cases listed under this rule take care of the cases of the nÄmin vowel of an upasarga being length- ened before varta etc. However, Whitney lists a whole host of expressions where the preceding is not an upasarga, nor does it necessarily end in a nÄmin vowel, and yet one finds lengthening. Many of these cases are found listed

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 384 under the next rule of the APR, i.e. APR (208, p. 125-6). One may assume that, contrary to Whitneyâ€™s expectation, the present CA rule had a general ap- plication, not restricted to upasargas ending in a nÄmin vowel, and that it may have intended to encompass the examples covered by the two consecutive rules of the APR, i.e. APR (207b, and 208). I would just like to note in passing, that the lists of examples offered by Whitney do not completely match the ones found under APR (207b, and 208), and the discrepancies need to be individually investigated. They may possibly indicate changes in the transmitted text of the AV. à¥©.à¥§.à¥§à¥©. à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.13). Translation: The a of a reduplication is diversely [length- ened]. Note: The word bahulam in the rule seems to be there to take care of examples like sasahe cited by the commentator. It may be noted that the APR (209, p. 126) reads à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¿. It is a somewhat strange formulation in that one would expect a text like the APR to be concerned with the language of chandas alone, and, therefore, one sees no purpose in the use of chandasi, except to indicate that the forms where this kind of lengthening does not take place are more like the non-chandas language. The gaá¹‡a listed under this rule cites examples of lengthening alone. The APR rule is also not restricted to the vowel a of the reduplication. The rule contains no such restriction, and the gaá¹‡a contains the example jÄ«hÄ«á¸a, the only case of non-a vowel. This example is taken care of by the next rule of the CA. Whitney draws our attention to the forms rÅ«rupaá¸¥ (iv.7.5), rÄ«riá¹£aá¸¥ (v.3.8), and Å›Å«Å›ucaá¸¥ (xviii.2.4), and says: â€œThe PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya may intend to include these forms in the gaá¹‡a of rule 21 (= CA 3.1.21), below, but they would much more properly have been provided for in the present rule.â€ Indeed, the nÄrakÄdigaá¹‡a referred to in CA (3.1.21), and as fully elaborated under APR (212, p. 129) contains the first two examples cited by Whitney. However, it is not clear why these examples were not covered by APR (209). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¾à¥’à¤§à¥ƒà¥’à¤·à¥à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤§à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾385 à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤§à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥€à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¯.à¥§à¥©)à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥’ [à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘] à¤¸à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨ à¤¸à¥‘à¤¸à¤¹à¥‡à¥’ à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥‘à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ Note: Whitney (AV Transl.
