Translation: After final e and o, the word-initial a [ becomes one] with the preceding [vowel]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥(H: à¤•à¥à¤°)à¤µà¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥©. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¥‘à¤£à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤°- à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: The reading te â€™kravan of H led Whitney to suggest an emen- dation to te â€™krÌ¥á¹‡van, which â€œalso is not to be found in the Atharvan.â€ The manuscript N offers a better reading: te â€™bruvan. The example te â€™vadan is cited in the KV on P.6.1.115 (à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦- à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¥‡). However, this instance is also traceable to RV (10.109.1), and hence we cannot be sure if the KV is citing this passage from the AV. This rule is in part comparable to APR (99). We should note that all the examples in the CAB are found in the same order as examples 68-71 on APR (100). While admitting that this is an â€œexceedingly common sandhi,â€ Whitney observes: â€œThe physical explanation of this combination is exceedingly diffi-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾421 cult.â€ Perhaps, one may suggest that as one moves from e or o to the conso- nant after the word initial a, one inevitably goes from a more open sound to a point of a relative oral constriction. If a is itself a close (saá¹ƒvrÌ¥ta) sound, then it is just like a point in the normal transition from an open sound to a constriction. For other detailed explanations, see: Allen (1962: pp. 39ff) and Cardona (1987). à¥©.à¥¨.à¥©à¥§. à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (3.54). I: 31. O: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ. Translation: Sometimes, [the word-initial a] remains un- changed. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜(H, N: à¤°à¥à¤š)à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¡à¥‹(H, N: à¤¡à¥‡) à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤ Note: One may note that these exceptions are not specifically taken care of by the APR, except that the APR (100) refers to a nebulous rule: à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤‚ à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¿. The present CA rule is comparable to P.6.1.115 (à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¥‡) and the following rules. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 40) suggests that the example à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤°à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¿à¤¡à¥‡ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° which is not attested in the Vulgate of the AV, possibly belongs to the now lost genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension of the AV. Whitney cites the ex- ample as à¤¸à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤°à¥à¤šà¤®à¥, while both the manuscripts offer the reading à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤šà¤®à¥. The reading à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤šà¤®à¤¿à¤¡à¥‡ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° is obviously a corruption for à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¡à¥‹ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘ (AV 18.1.43). This shows the fallacy of Surya Kantaâ€™s hypothesis. à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. E, F: à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. A, B, D, J, M: à¥¥à¥¨à¥¥ à¤› à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. I: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. O: à¤š. à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¥à¥©à¥§à¥¥ P: à¥¥à¥¨ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ ____________________________

à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥©.à¥©.à¥§. à¤·à¤¡à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤²à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¢à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Translations: The authorities [lit. makers of definitions] recognize only six types of circumflex (svarita) accent. Of these, [in the order in which they are explained], each preceding one is harder [than the succeeding one, and] the succeeding one is softer [than the preceding one]. Note: Whitney (p. 154) cites the five verses beginning with this verse as belonging to the commentary in the mss H. However, these verses are found in all the mss. which provide only the text of the CA. Since the CAB does not comment on these verses, it is possible that at one time they belonged to that commentary itself, but were incorporated later into the text of the CA. Whitney (1880: 162) says: â€œThe passage introductory to the third section of this chapter and which, in the edition, I treated as a part of the commentary, is found in B., as if belonging to the text. That it belongs to the text, however, as an original and proper part of it, is by no means to be believed; it is, rather (along with the two similar passages to be noted later), the interpolation of some reworker. This is evidenced both by its own character and by the fact that the comment takes no notice of it; it did not belong to the treatise which the commentator took in hand to explain.â€ There is also a strong possibility, as suggested by Whitney, that these passages may be interpolations of a later period. However, since these verses are found in all manuscripts, including those that call themselves Kautsa-VyÄkaraá¹‡a, this incorporation must have taken place at a reasonably early time. Therefore, I have decided to treat these verses as part of the text of the CA as it can be reconstructed on the basis of our manuscripts. A, B, D: à¤·à¤¡à¥‡à¤š. E, F, I, O: à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿Â°. Surya Kanta (APR, Intro., p. 61) makes a far looser claim for incorporation of all sorts of portions of the commentary into what he styles the older CA: â€œA deeper analysis of CCA (= CAB) should suggest that the portion now styled as comment, is, in reality, nothing but relics of the older CA., that the metrical portions betokened by Whitney as citations from some ancient authority are mutilated parts of the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾423 older CA., and that longer metrical portions thrown into Additional Notes by the editor are definitely so. They are so, all the more, because in all the mss. of the CA., they are read as part of the SÅ«tra-text; they must, accordingly, be rein- stated to their proper position.â€ Not all the verses cited in the CAB are treated by the other manuscripts as belonging to the SÅ«tra-text, and one must make a careful distinction between these two classes of verses. The fact that certain verses are treated by most manuscripts as being part of the SÅ«tra-text does not by itself prove that they must be part of the original CA. They could very well be ancient interpolations into the SÅ«tra-text from the commentary. It is also true that the later text-tradition did treat them as being part of the SÅ«tra-text. As Whitney points out: â€œPrecisely what is meant by â€˜sharpâ€™ (tÄ«ká¹£á¹‡a) and â€˜hardâ€™ (drÌ¥á¸ha) on the one hand, and â€˜softâ€™ (mrÌ¥du) on the other, is not very clear: but that the proper circumflex, which arises upon the combination into a single syllable of an original acute and an original grave element, is more strongly marked and distinct in its quality of double pitch than that circumflex which is only enclitic, need not be doubted.â€ Some light is shed on this question by the possibility that different kinds of svaritas represent different levels of musical pitch. S. Varma (1929: 156), referring to PÄriÅ›iká¹£Ä, informs us that the types jÄtya, abhinihita, and ká¹£aipra are pronounced with niá¹£Äda, or the 7th note on the Indian musical scale. The types tairovyaÃ±jana and pÄdavrÌ¥tta are pronounced with dhaivata, or the 6th note. The types praÅ›liá¹£á¹­a and pratihata are pronounced with paÃ±cama, or the 5th note. On the whole, one may conclude that higher musical pitch is referred to by the terms â€˜sharpâ€™ or â€˜hard,â€™ and the lower musical pitch is referred to by the term â€˜soft.â€™ This distinction is still common in the Indian classical music till today, where the term tÄ«vra â€˜sharpâ€™ refers to higher pitch, and the term komala â€˜delicate, softâ€™ refers to lower pitch. The order of the types of svarita given by the present CA verse does not completely match the one given by the PÄriÅ›iká¹£Ä, but one does notice some shared features, and this indeed seems to be the intended difference between the various types of svarita. Unfortunately, the reciters of the ÅšAV I met in India were not able to demonstrate these differences in their recitation, and it would seem that these distinctions have been lost in the recitation of the AV. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨.à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤­à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤²à¤®à¥ à¥¥

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 424 Whitney (p. 154). A, B: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹Â°. E, F, I, J, M: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹Â°. Whitney: Â°à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‰à¤­à¥Œ. A, B, D: Â°à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šÂ°. J, M, P: Â°à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦- à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šÂ°. H, N: Â°à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤¤Â°. O: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: Abhinihita, PrÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a, and both JÄtya and Ká¹£ipra, as well as TairovyaÃ±jana and PÄdavrÌ¥tta, - this is the group of svarita [varieties]. Note: The order of the different types of svaritas given in this verse, and assumed in all the first four verses of this section is directly correlated to the order in which these types are defined in the rules that follow, i.e. abhini- hita (3.3.6), praÅ›liá¹£á¹­a (3.3.7), jÄtya (3.3.8), ká¹£aipra (3.3.9-12), tairovyaÃ±jana (3.3.13), and pÄdavrÌ¥tta (3.3.14). This matching shows that the verses are inte- grally related to the rules that follow. The verses present the notions of relative hardness and softness of these types, but do not define their exact nature, while the later rules define the exact circumstances of each type, without going into the question of their relative hardness. However, both the sections assume the same order of presentation of these types, and hence are clearly complementary to each other. à¥©.à¥©.à¥©.à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤­à¥Œ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 154). A, B, E, F, I, J, M: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ŸÂ°. I: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ŸÂ°. H, N: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿Â°. M: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥Œ for Svara=. O: Â°à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: The abhinihita is the sharpest of all. [Softer] than that is said to be the prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a. Softer than that is the next pair of accents, i.e. jÄtya and ká¹£ipra. Note: The verse is found in the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä (verse 82), Åšiká¹£Ä- saá¹ƒgraha, p. 470. à¥©.à¥©.à¥ª.à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨ à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤¤à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¬à¤²à¤¾à¤¬à¤²à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 154). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾425 Translation: Softer than those is said to be the accent called tairovyaÃ±jana. The pÄdavrÌ¥tta is softer [than that]. Such are the relative strengths and weaknesses of the svarita varieties. Note: This verse is also found in the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä (verse 83), Åšiká¹£Ä- saá¹ƒgraha, p. 470. à¥©.à¥©.à¥«. à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹ - à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 154). E, F, I, O: à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹. O: Â°à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒÂ°. D, E, F, J, M, O: Â°à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤°à¥‹Â° for Â°à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹Â°. O, P: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ. Translation: Another [phonetician] says: â€œTairovyaÃ±jana and PÄdavrÌ¥tta are of similar utterance.â€ [In a svarita], the first [por- tion] is high-pitched (udÄtta). The following [portion] is low- pitched (anudÄtta). A svarita is a combination of these two. Note: The tag phrase apara Äha clearly indicates that this was in all probability originally not part of the text of the CA, but that of a commentary. However, the entire passage is found in all the CA-text-only manuscripts. One may also note the curious fact that the text of the Vará¹‡apaá¹­ala, a PariÅ›iá¹£á¹­a of the AV, contains verses introduced with the phrase à¤…à¤ªà¤° à¤†à¤¹, and the verses along with the tag phrase are cited in the CAB. See the commentary and the Note on CA (1.1.28: à¤°à¥‡à¤«à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿). Whitney had assigned the entire preceding portion to the commentary. However, regarding à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ, à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ, à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ he said: â€œI am not al- together confident that this is not the first rule of the section, since, as we shall see, the two rules which follow are defective in form, and need some such predecessor. Considering, however, the faulty construction of the whole sec- tion, the limited applicability of the words in question as an adhikÄra or heading for that which follows, their inconsistency with rule 66 (= CA 3.3.17) below, and the absence of the paraphrase and repetition which ought to follow them, if they are a rule, I have not ventured to regard them as a part of the treatise; they are more probably an addition of the commentator, intended to supply the de- ficiency of the next two rules.â€ As I pointed out in my Note on CA (3.3.1), Whitney was not willing to accept this initial portion as part of the text of the CA even after the discovery of a second manuscript of the CA which contained this portion. Now it is clear that each and every manuscript of the CA contains

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 426 this initial portion, and we have to accept it as part of the text of the CA. How- ever, it could have been a very early addition, which remained somewhat unas- similated even up to the composition of the CAB. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¬. à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.55). Ha, Na: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¥ŒÂ°. A, B: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥ŒÂ°. E, F, I, O: Â°à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: [Where] the final e or o [are merged with] the following a [resulting into e and o respectively], that [svarita] is [called] abhinihita. Note: The commentary adds significant information which is not ex- plicit in the rule itself. The commentator specifies that it is a combination of the final high-pitched e or o with the following low-pitched a. This general infor- mation is derived from the immediately preceding rule, CA (3.3.5). This rule is an exception to CA (3.3.17: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ), which prescribes that a combination of a high-pitched vowel with a non-high-pitched vowel, resulting in a single substitute for both (ekÄdeÅ›a), is high-pitched. Whitney criticizes the CA : â€œthe treatise nowhere informs us under what circumstances a circumflex accent arises in connection with the meeting of a final e or o and an initial a, or even that it arises at all.â€ Indeed the treatise, CA (3.2.30: à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯), teaches the single substitute in such cases. The present section, headed by CA (3.3.5) tells us that, under certain circumstances, such combina- tions become svaritas, and the present rule tells us that this specific combina- tion of a high-pitched e or o with the following low-pitched a becomes a spe- cific type of svarita, i.e. abhinihita. Whitney believes that the CA should have combined all this with the fact that such a svarita combination is an exception to CA (3.3.17), and the fact that the author of the CA has not done so leads Whitney to say: â€œWe can hardly avoid supposing that the constructors of this part of the treatise have not been skillful enough, or careful enough, to combine the two subjects of the section in such a manner as to give completeness to both.â€ There is indeed an internal logic to the presentation of the CA rules, including the initial verses of this section, which Whitney misses. For details, see the Note on CA (3.3.2). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾427 â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥­.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥(H: à¤•à¥à¤°)à¤µà¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤¤à¥ˆ.à¤¸à¤‚. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤¦à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¥‘à¤£à¤ƒà¥’ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥‹à¥‘à¤½à¤°à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: The example te â€™bruvan, TS (2.5.1.3) is cited as an example of abhinihata in the commentary VaidikÄbharaá¹‡a on TPR (20.10). We should note that all the examples in the CAB, including the unattested te â€™bruvan, are found in the same order as examples 68-71 on APR (100). The same exam- ples are cited in the CAB on CA 3.2.30. Whitney notes that in parataá¸¥ akÄram â€˜with a followingâ€™ the commen- tator treats the word akÄram as a neuter nominative. A nominative with parataá¸¥, in the sense of â€˜with x followingâ€™ or â€˜x is on the other side,â€™ is not un- common in Sanskrit, cf. yaá¸¥ and parataá¸¥ in à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤ƒ, BhagavadgÄ«tÄ (3.42d). What is uncommon is the neuter gender of the word akÄra. The MB also uses the word vará¹‡a in both masculine and neuter genders. à¥©.à¥©.à¥­. à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.56). D, E, F, H, I (corr), J, M (corr), N, P: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ. Translation: [The svarita arising out of a combination] of two short i vowels is [called] prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a. Note: While a combination of any two i vowels, long or short, results in a long Ä« vowel, not all such resulting long Ä« vowels are evidently eligible for the title of prÄÅ›liÅ›á¹­a. The second constraint, as explained by the commentary, and evidently implied in this case by the continuing force of CA (3.3.5), is that of these two short i vowels being combined, the first one is originally high- pitched, and the second one is originally low-pitched. Thus, this rule also becomes an exception to CA (3.3.17) which says that a combination of a high- pitched vowel with a non-high-pitched vowel, resulting in a single substitute, becomes high-pitched. Whitney finds that if the first high-pitched vowel is a long Ä« and the following low-pitched vowel is a short i, â€œit is very natural that, as the more powerful element, it should assimilate the weaker grave vowel, and make the whole compound accute.â€ But the reverse situation is more problematic. â€œThe cases in which a long unaccented Ä«, on the other hand, is preceded by a short accented Ã­, are exceedingly rare. … We should, however, expect that in such a

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 428 compound, especially the circumflex would not fail to appear; for if, in the fu- sion of Ã­ and i, the grave accent of the second element is represented in the ac- centuation of the resulting vowel, by so much the more, should this be the case in the fusion of Ã­ + i, where the second element is the stronger. The teachings of the accentual theory are so obvious and explicit upon this point that it is hardly possible to avoid the conclusion that the Hindu grammarians, in estab- lishing their system, overlooked or disregarded the combination Ã­+Ä«, on account of its rarity, and that the accent of the cases later noted was made to conform to the rule, instead of the rule being amended to fit the cases.â€ Perhaps, Whitney has been a bit too impatient. First, there is no glob- ally accepted accentual theory, which predicts results for each Vedic school, and, as Whitney himself notes, the different schools disagree on the scope and nature of prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a svarita. Given the fact that the prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a ranks the second highest in hardness or sharpness of musical pitch, it seems natural that what the early AV reciters were looking for in a prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a is the musical height of the high portion of the prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a, rather than the prominence of the low-pitched part, as Whitney seems to imply above. There are major differences on the scope of prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a among the various phonetic and grammatical authorities, and Whitney has eminently surveyed these different views in his comments on the present rule. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹(à¤ƒ) à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿- à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥€à¥’[ï†…]à¤¦à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥§à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥€à¥’[ï†…]à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¥’à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤‚à¥‘ à¤¨à¥‹à¥’ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‘à¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥­.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾- à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¥€à¥‘à¤µà¥’ à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® ! ) â€˜à¤…à¤¤à¥€à¥’à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤‡à¤µâ€™ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ(H: à¤‡à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ, Whitney: à¤ˆÂ°) à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤œà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (source?) â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€à¥‘à¤µ à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¨à¥¬.à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€à¥‘à¤µà¥’ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¯à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ (à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® !) â€˜à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€à¥‘à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¦à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¤¿ à¤‡à¥‘à¤µâ€™ à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾429 Note: Whitney (1862: 159) translates the end portion of the com- mentary beginning with atÄ«va : â€œin the passage Ã¡tÄ« â€™va yÃ¡á¸¥ (ii.12.6) - where the krama-text would read Ã¡tÄ« â€™vÃ©â€™ty Ã¡ti-iva - the circumflex of the Ä« is tairovyaÃ±jana (see rule 62 = CA 3.3.13). When an Ä« is the result of praÅ›leá¹£a, the former ele- ment being acute and latter grave, the result of praÅ›leá¹£a is always made circum- flex. No other circumflex accent is declared to arise from the sandhi. Instances are divR_i_macron_grave â€™va cÃ¡ká¹£uá¸¥ (vii.26.7), divR_i_macron_grave â€™va jyÃ³tiá¸¥ (vi.92.3), where the krama-text reads divR_i_macron_grave â€™vÃ© â€™ti divÃ­-iva.â€ He is not sure of his interpretation, and thinks that â€œits significance is evidently of the smallest.â€ The first point to make, which apparently escaped Whitneyâ€™s attention, is that there is a verse cited here. Secondly, the manuscript N offers the read- ing ikÄrayoá¸¥ which fits the meter better and is probably the original reading. Third, the cited verse offers a context for CA (3.3.5) to be brought down to bear on the interpretation of the present rule of the CA, indicating that CA (3.3.5) is in all likelihood a genuine part of the CA. Finally, the verse adds support to the (3.3.7) itself, in reinforcing the view that, in the AV tradition of recitation, the prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a svarita was limited to the combination resulting from Ã­+i. Finally, it says that it is always pronounced as a svarita, indicating that it is no longer a prosodically variable syllable, but always remains svarita. The last quarter of the verse still remains enigmatic to me. à¥©.à¥©.à¥®. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.57). A, B, D: Â°à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿Â°. J: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾Â°. O reads à¤¸à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ for à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚. P: Â°à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µÂ°. Translation: A svarita, which follows a consonant cluster ending in y or v, - a consonant cluster which is either preceded by an unaccented vowel, or is not preceded by any vowel - is [called] jÄtya. Note: The term jÄtya indicates that this particular variety of svarita is an integral part of a word, it is born with it. It is lexical, rather than born out of discourse or prosody. Whitney notes: â€œno syllable in Sanskrit has an inde- pendent circumflex accent except as it results from the conversion of an origi- nal accented Ã­ or Ãº (short or long) into its corresponding semivowel y or v.â€ The important thing to note, however, is that it arises â€œin connection with the combination of syllables into words, rather than of words into a sentence.â€ Thus, the jÄtya svarita arises as part of derivation of a word, or as a result of internal sandhi, rather than as a result of an external sandhi (= ká¹£aipra svarita).

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 430 Whitney complains: â€œThe definition or description of the jÄtya circum- flex given by our treatise is after all imperfect, since it fails properly to distin- guish the jÄtya from the ká¹£aipra. Such ká¹£aipra accents as are instanced by abhy Ã rcata (vii.82.1), nv Ã¨tÃ©na (v.6.5), and the like, answer in every particular to the defined character of the jÄtya. The word pade, â€˜in an independent or un- combined word,â€™ or something equivalent, needs to be added to the rule.â€ Whitneyâ€™s problem lies in confusing his understanding of the historical evolution of Sanskrit and its derivational morphology with the assumptions made by the authors of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. The CA rules 3.3.8 and 3.3.9, defin- ing the jÄtya and ká¹£aipra varieties make a very important and subtle distinction. CA (3.3.8) speaks of jÄtya as a svarita coming after a consonant cluster ending in y or v, and makes no reference to y and v being results of sandhi, or being substitutes for some â€˜originalâ€™ Ã­ or Ãº, like Whitney. Ideally, the PratiÅ›Äkhya is not interested in internal word-derivation, and, therefore, the morph+morph sandhi, or internal sandhi, is of no value to it, unless it somehow participates in pada <> samhitÄ transformations. Therefore, the results of the so-called internal sandhi are not treated by the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya as results of any transformation, but as given facts. In contrast with CA (3.3.8), the wording of CA (3.3.9), defining the ká¹£aipra svarita, clearly makes a reference to sandhi- transformation - antaá¸¥sthÄpatti - of Ã­ and Ãº into y and v before unaccented vowels. By such a transformative process, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya refers only to exter- nal sandhi. In a word like kvÃ , the modern linguist may see a derivational process from kÃº+a. However, the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya does not call this process antaá¸¥sthÄpatti - transformation of vowels into semivowels. It takes the form kvÃ  for granted, and this is what makes this type of svarita a jÄtya svarita â€˜born with the word.â€™ Thus, Whitneyâ€™s criticisms of the formulation of these rules shows a certain lack of comprehension of the assumptions made by the CA, which can be easily recovered from the wording of the rules. Thus, the CA can clearly separate the jÄtya variety from the ká¹£aipra variety. While the CAB does not make these assumptions explicit, it offers the correct examples for the jÄtya and the ká¹£aipra varieties. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤®à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤šà¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤œà¥’-

It may be noted that somehow the jÄtya svarita is the most basic svarita of all the types. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¯. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.58). Translation: When, [in external sandhi], a high-pitched vowel is transformed into a semi-vowel, before a low-pitched vowel, the resulting svarita is [called] ká¹£aipra. Note: For a clear distinction between the jÄtya and ká¹£aipra varieties, and the assumptions made by the CA rules, see the Note on CA (3.3.9). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤šà¤¤â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥®à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥€à¥’à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤™à¥à¤—à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ Note: The KV on P.6.1.77 (à¤‡à¤•à¥‹ à¤¯à¤£à¤šà¤¿) cites the example kartrartham. à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥¦. à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.59). Translation: Even within the same word, in the first five case-forms [i.e. nominative sg., du., and pl., and accusative sg., and du., when a high-pitched vowel is transformed into a semi- vowel, before a low-pitched vowel, the resulting svarita is called ká¹£aipra]. Note: Whitney comments: â€œNot one of the other treatises offers any- thing corresponding; they would all, apparently, class as jÄtya the circumflex

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 432 accents here treated of, not distinguishing them from the others which occur within the limits of a word, or in the uncombined text. The rules, however, are not without some interest, as showing that the authors of our text appreciated the entire analogy which the circumflex accents with which they deal have with the ordinary ká¹£aipra. Thus nadyÃ s is equivalent to nadÄ«Ì.as, as nadyÃ sti would be to nadÄ«Ì asti, while nadyÄÌi, nadyÄÌs represent nadÄ«-ÄÌi, nadÄ«-ÄÌs; the terminations of the strong cases showing no trace of that tendency which is exhibited by the other case-endings to draw away upon themselves the accent of the final vowel of the theme: compare tudÃ¡ntam, tudÃ¡ntau, tudÃ¡ntas, with tudatÄÌ, tudatÃ³s, tu- datÃ¡s.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒà¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¥’ï†… à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‘ à¤¸à¥à¤¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¥’à¤²à¥à¤¯ï†„à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥¯. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¦à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯ï†„à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¥‘à¤·à¥‡ à¤¹à¥’à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¯.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¦à¥‘à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬. à¥§à¥©à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¦à¥€ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤š à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤° à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (source?) The reading in H is even more corrupt: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¦à¥€ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾. If Surya Kanta has reconstructed the correct reading for this APR rule, then, assuming that a similar confusion may have taken place with our verse quoted in the CAB, the verse could be partially restored as: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤š à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤° à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ Surya Kanta (APR, Notes, p. 24) offers the following interpretations for some of the words which appear in APR (57): â€œantodÄttÄdÄ«ni = antodÄttaá¸¥ (Ä«Ì+am) Ädir yeá¹£Äá¹ƒ tÄni. yÄt = through y letter (Ä«Ì+a = yÃ ), vilÄ«á¸hÄ«Ì+am= vilÄ«á¸hÃ­- am=yÃ .â€ With all this partial restoration, the verse still remains metrically irregular.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾433 I propose an alternative interpretation of the verse, as it now reads in the text given above: â€˜à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¦à¥€ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤š à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤° à¤‰à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ â€œ[For] feminine stems ending in Ä«Ì and Å«Ì, in accordance with the rule [= nyÄyÄt], and [for the feminine stems ending in] short nÄmin [i.e. Ã­ and Ãº] which also [occasionally] behave like [the feminine stems in Ä«Ì and Å«Ì], in weak cases [= apaÃ±capadyÄm], the high-pitched vowel is pronounced. [In strong cases = paÃ±capadyÄm, by contrast], a ká¹£aipra svarita is pronounced.â€ I suspect that the word nadÄ« in the verse is used in its PÄá¹‡inian technical meaning, i.e. a feminine stem ending either in Ä« or Å«, cf. P.1.4.3 (à¤¯à¥‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¤¨à¤¦à¥€). Here, the verse seems to refer to antodÄttÄ nadÄ«, â€œfeminine stems ending in Ä«Ì and Å«Ì.â€ I admit that this interpretation also requires a good deal of â€œconstructive imagination,â€ and I would welcome a better proposal. à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥§. à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ Whitney (3.60): à¤Šà¤•à¤¾à¤°Â°. P: à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤šÂ°. Translation: [When a final] Ãº [and Å«Ì are transformed into v before a low-pitched vowel], in all cases [i.e. strong as well as weak cases, the low-pitched vowel is pronounced as a ká¹£aipra svarita]. Note: The major confusion regarding this rule is whether it should read ukÄrasya as all the manuscripts have it, or as Å«kÄrasya as Whitney emends it, or something still different. Whitney says: â€œThe manuscript reads in this rule ukÄrasya, â€˜if the final is u,â€™ but the facts seem to require the amendment to Å«, and the method of writing of our copyist is too careless to make his authority of much weight against it.â€ Part of APR (57, p. 48) also reads ukÄrasya sarvatra and is clearly a related rule. Surya Kanta (APR, Notes, p. 24) says â€œbetter Å«kÄrasyaâ€ and refers to the present CA rule, without realizing that Whitney gave the reading Å«kÄrasya, while his manuscript actually read ukÄrasya. The dilemma arises because if the rule is ukÄrasya, it will cover only the examples in short u, while Å«kÄrasya, as suggested by Whitney and Surya Kanta, will cover only the examples in long Å«. Among the examples cited by the CAB, the stems tanÅ«, camÅ«, and vadhÅ« end in long Å«. the other hand, the CAB cites a number of exceptions, and among these exceptions, two stems, i.e. prÌ¥dÄku and urvÄru, end in short u, while Å›vaÅ›rÅ« ends in long Å«. Somehow,

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 434 Whitney does not notice that two of these exceptions have stems ending in short u, as he clearly acknowledges in his Index Verborum. If the rule is read Å«kÄrasya, then the exceptions with stems in short u do not make any sense. On the other hand, if the rule is read ukÄrasya, as justified by the manuscripts, the positive examples with stems in long Å« do not make any sense. Perhaps, what one needs is the reading uvará¹‡asya, which no manuscript supports. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤- à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§. à¥©à¥©.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥’[ï†…]â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¥‘à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’à¤®à¥à¤µà¥‹à¥’- [ï†…]à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥§à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤§à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥’ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¦à¤¾à¥’à¤•à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆâ€™ (H, N: à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤°à¤ƒ, Whitney: â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆâ€™)(à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥ª)à¥¤ Note: Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 60-61) points out that the APR (57b) shares with the CAB even the corrupt reading Å›vaÅ›uraá¸¥ for the re- quired Å›vaÅ›rvai. This is explainable by referring to the fact that a large number of the mss. of the APR and the CA are found in the same bundles, are copied by and meant for the same person. However, in this case, the two texts do not cite all identical examples. Under à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿, the CAB cites the first four ex- amples out of the five listed by the APR. In this case, even the phrase à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ª- à¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ is shared with the APR (57b). It should also be pointed out that while the examples cited as exceptions to the rule are mostly identical in both the texts, the positive examples are not so identical. What this perhaps indicates is that one should not assume that the CAB directly copied its examples from the APR. Most probably, there existed a list of gaá¹‡as, like the Gaá¹‡apÄá¹­ha of the PÄá¹‡inian tradition, which was used by both. However, where the examples were only illustrative, and not part of a closed gaá¹‡a, the two texts cited in- dependent illustrations. There is no indication in the CA rule of there being exceptions to this rule. However, the CAB and the APR both share the same list of exceptions. Thus, it is conceivable that the original rules did not envi- sion any such exceptions, and that the commentary reflects a changed state of the Atharvan text. After listing the exceptions cited by the CAB, Whitney adds: â€œto which is to be added vadhvÄÌi (xiv.2.9, 73).â€ The gaá¹‡a as listed in the APR already

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾435 contains this instance. Then Whitney observes: â€œAll these exceptional forms, it will be remarked, have a heavy ending, while those which exhibit the circum- flex accent the ending is light in every instance but one (tanvÄÌ€m).â€ Whitneyâ€™s additional exceptions: â€œThe words bÄhvÃ³s (e.g. vii.56.6) and Å«rvÃ³s (xix.60.2) are instances - and, if my search has been thorough, the only ones which the text presents - of like forms from themes in u, which are not to be regarded as contemplated by the rule.â€ à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥¨. à¤“à¤£à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (3.61). Translation: [The svarita] which is separated [from the pre- ceding high-pitched vowel] by consonants is called tairo- vyaÃ±jana. Note: Whitney observes: â€œThere is here a notable change of subject and of implication. We have passed without any warning, from considering the necessary or independent circumflex to treating of that which is enclitic only, arising, according to following rules (rules 67-70 = CA 3.3.18-21), in an unaccented syllable, which is preceded by an acute, and not again immediately followed by an acute or circumflex.â€ Whitney discusses other subdivisions of this type as prescribed by other texts, e.g. tairovirÄma, in which the preceding high-pitched vowel belongs to the first member of a compound-word,

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 436 separated in the PadapÄá¹­ha by an avagraha, or a brief pause, for example prajÄÌ- vat, where the unaccented a of vat is prosodically changed to a svarita. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥‹à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥ª. à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.63). Translation: Where there is a hiatus [between the preceding high-pitched vowel and the following low-pitched vowel, the resulting svarita for the low-pitched vowel is called] pÄdavrÌ¥tta. Note: Whitney notes that the RPR calls this type vaivrÌ¥tta, â€˜arising in connection with a hiatus,â€™ and further observes: â€œThe term pÄdavrÌ¥tta is evi- dently a mutilated substitute for pÄdavivrÌ¥tta or pÄdavaivrÌ¥tta, â€˜arising in connec- tion with a hiatus between two words.â€™â€ Whitneyâ€™s footnote further clarifies: â€œThe definition of the Taitt. Pr. (xx.6) brings out this derivation more distinctly than our own; we read there pada-vivrÌ¥ttyÄm pÄdavrÌ¥ttaá¸¥.â€ The important point clarified by the TPR definition is that this type of svarita has to do with a hiatus between two padas â€˜words,â€™ rather than between two pÄdas â€˜metrical feet.â€™ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¥’à¤¸à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤°à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¯à¤‚à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¥’ à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‰à¥‘ à¤šà¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥«.à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript N has a lacuna. After the word svayaá¹ƒkrÌ¥tÄ, the manuscript resumes with the end portion of the commentary on CA 3.3.24. à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥«. à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.64). Translation: With the separation [of members of compound- words by a brief pause, the accents of the separated parts re- main] of the same pattern [as before the separation].

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾437 Note: The recitational tradition, in the context of the PadapÄá¹­ha, thus distinguishes between a longer pause between the words which produces pro- sodically discontinuous segments and the brief pause (avagraha) between members of compound-words which does not produce prosodically discon- tinuous segments. Of the several possible interpretations of this rule, Whitney prefers this wider interpretation: â€œNotwithstanding an avagraha, the accent of a following syllable remains just what it would be were there no such pause; a hiatus conditioning a pÄdavrÌ¥tta, and the intervention of consonants a tairo- vyaÃ±jana.â€ Whitney points out that such a wider interpretation â€œis supported by the authority of the Rik. Pr., which lays down the general principle (iii.15, r.23, ccx) that where syllables are separated by avagraha, there accentuation is the same as if they were connected with one another according to the rules of sandhi.â€ The CAB, on the other hand, seems to prefer a narrower interpretation, applying only to those cases of avagraha, where a hiatus is created by splitting the vowels apart due to an avagraha, which had been merged by sandhi in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha. Such a narrow interpretation is indicated by the kind of exam- ples cited by the commentary. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¥’à¤½à¤…à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯, à¤µà¥’à¤¶à¤¾à¤½à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥§.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥’à¤œà¥à¤à¤½- à¤‹à¤¤à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤½à¤“à¥‘à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¤½à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥à¤·à¤¾â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥§.à¥©, à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤½- à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥à¤·à¤¾â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥€à¥’à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤½à¤…à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¥à¤·à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ Note: Whitney notes that the nominative dÄ«rghÃ¡-Äyuá¸¥ is found at AV (xiv.2.2, 63). à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥¬. à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤£à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤µà¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (3.65). E, F, I (corr), M (corr): Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ŸÂ°. A, D, J: à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ … à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤£à¥Â°. O, P: à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ. O: Â°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: Of [the four types of svarita, i.e.] abhinihita, prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a, jÄtya, and ká¹£aipra, followed by a high-pitched or cir- cumflex, a quarter-mora quantity is made to fall [below the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 438 normal level of low-pitch accent], and that [phenomenon] is called vikampita â€˜oscillationâ€™ by the wise. Note: Whitney has a very long discussion on this rule, and to do full justice to it would need a dissertation by itself. To respond to his main thrust, Whitney seems to look at the entire discussion of the accents in the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas as a matter of grammatical theory, rather than as facts of a recita- tional tradition. Referring to Hindu grammar, Whitney says: â€œWhether the Hindu grammar is much the gainer by this intense elaboration of the accentual theory may fairly be questioned: whether, indeed, it has not lost more than it has gained by the exaggeration, and even the distortion, in more than one par- ticular, of the natural inflections of the voice. To me, I must acknowledge, it seems clear that those ancient grammarians might better have contented them- selves with pointing out in each word the principal accent and its character, leaving the proclitic and enclitic accents, the claimed involuntary accompani- ments of the other, to take care of themselves; or, if they could not leave them unnoticed, at least stating them in a brief and general way, as matters of nice phonetic theory, without placing them on a level with the independent accents, and drawing our a complete scheme of rules for their occurrence.â€ In his com- ments, Whitney seems to foreshadow the distinction between phonetic versus phonemic, which developed in later times, and seems to feel that the function of the authors of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas was, or should have been, closely similar to that of the modern grammarians of Sanskrit. Here, he completely misses the main point of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. They are, first and foremost, description of recita- tional practice, rather than that of some abstract theory. Consider the distinc- tion between pratijÃ±Ä â€˜doctrineâ€™ and vrÌ¥tti â€˜recitational practiceâ€™ drawn by CA in 1.1.1. The second point missed by Whitney is that the accent as understood by the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, and as observed in the recitational practice, is already fully musical, and hence, in theory as well as in practice, afforded a far wider latitude of up and down pitch movement, as compared to accent in natural speech. The statements at the beginning of this pÄda of the CA, indicate that the various types of svarita rank differently in terms of the sharpness of the musical note reached in their utterance. Thus, the notion of phonological redundancy of all this phonetic or recitational detail is a peculiarly western theoretical problem, and shows a lack of comprehension of the function of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. Within the description of the CA it makes eminent sense why a feeling of vibration or kampa would be created only for some varieties of svarita than for others. The rising portion of the different varieties of svarita rises to differ- ent musical heights, and the first four varieties, i.e. abhinihita, prÄÅ›liá¹£á¹­a, jÄtya,

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾439 and ká¹£aipra rise higher than tairovyaÃ±jana and pÄdavrÌ¥tta. Then, before a high- pitched udÄtta or a svarita, with its initial rising element, the falling segment of these four varieties of svarita the normal level of anudÄtta. From this lower than the low position, the pitch then rises again to the high of the fol- lowing udÄtta, or to the higher than high of the following svarita. This natu- rally creates a feeling of vibrating or swinging up and down the musical scale. NighÄta Normal Levels—– K A M P A —– NighÄta Svarita High Svarita UdÄtta High Svarita Svarita AnudÄtta UdÄtta Different manuscripts have different methods of marking accents, cf. Witzel (1974) for a comprehensive discussion. The printed editions have generally opted for the method used in the RÌ¥gveda. For the notation of kampa, Whitney points out: â€œA svarita immediately preceding an udÄtta cannot receive simply the usual svarita sign, lest the following syllable be deemed a pracaya instead of udÄtta. The method followed in such a case by the Rik is to append to the circumflexed vowel a figure 1 or 3 - 1 if the vowel be short, 3 if it be long - and to attach to this figure the signs of both svarita and of anudÄtta.â€ In the text of the commentary below, I have placed these figures in square brack- ets, since they do not appear in the manuscripts of the commentary, but are provided from the printed text of the AV. Whitney has additionally given a plausible explanation for the origin of this notation, cf. Whitney (1862: 169). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾- à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤£à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹(H: à¤¤à¤¾) à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤µà¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹à¥’[ï†…]à¤­à¤¿-

Identical with P.8.2.5. Translation: [As a general principle], the single replacement for a high-pitched vowel [combined with a non-high-pitched vowel] is high-pitched. Note: This is a general rule, and has a few exceptions, i.e. CA (3.3.6- 7): The vowels Ã© and Ã³, when they absorb the following a, become Ã¨ and Ã², and Ã­+i become R_i_macron_grave. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤§à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¹à¤¿à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¥à¤·à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤œà¥à¥’à¤·à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¯à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¹à¤¿à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤†à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¹à¤¿à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥’à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¹à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¥’-à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¹à¤¿à¥’â€™, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µà¥‘ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤…à¤µà¥‘ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥’à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤¤à¥’ à¥¤ à¤† à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¤à¥’,â€™ à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥©à¥­)à¥¤ Note: All the examples cited here by the CAB are cited in the same order under APR (8).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾441 à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥®. à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (3.67). J: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚Â°. Translation: A low-pitched vowel, following a high-pitched [syllable], becomes circumflexed. Note: The svarita or the circumflex accent defined here is the enclitic svarita. As Whitney points out, â€œit is, as we have seen above (rules 62, 63 = CA 3.3.13-4), subdivided into the two kinds called tairovyaÃ±jana and pÄda- vrÌ¥tta, according as one or more consonants, or only a hiatus, intervene between the acute vowel and its successor.â€ It is to be noted here that the first element of a svarita was, for many of its varieties, higher than the normal height of an udÄtta, while the anudÄtta pre- ceding an udÄtta remained anudÄtta according to CA (3.3.21), or became lower than the normal low according to PÄá¹‡ini, cf. P.1.2.40 (à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ). The printed editions of the AV follow the PÄá¹‡inian or the RÌ¥gvedic method of marking the sannatara. Thus, the two most noticeable peaks of musical notes during the recitation were the higher than the high of the svarita and the lower than the low of the sannatara. Otherwise, for the recitational purposes, the in- termediate high and low levels represented by the normal udÄtta and the normal anudÄtta actually collapsed into a single level, as indicated by CA (3.3.22) which says that the anudÄtta syllable after a svarita has the same pitch as that of the udÄtta. Thus, the historical values of udÄtta and anudÄtta collapsed into an unmarked pitch level. The initial high of the svarita moved up from this level, and the lower-than-low of sannatara moved down from this level. Thus, from a purely recitational point of view, the historical udÄtta could not be distin- guished from the anudÄtta. This clearly indicates the nature of the recitational tradition. Burrow (1955: 114) remarks: â€œAccording to the usual system, that adopted in the RÌ¥gveda for instance, the principle is to mark the syllable pre- ceding the udÄtta, the sannatara, with a subscript line, and the dependent svarita following the udÄtta by a vertical stroke above. The udÄtta itself is left un- marked. … The modern recitation of the RÌ¥gveda follows the notational system to the extent of pronouncing the sannatara lowest and the svarita highest musi- cally of syllables and ignoring the udÄtta altogether. This is a secondary devel- opment although it may be old, and at variance with the teachings of PÄá¹‡ini which are in complete agreement with the findings of comparative philology.â€ It is clear that PÄá¹‡ini, who specifically defines the occasion for sannatara, knew that it was pronounced lower than the normal anudÄtta. Similarly, the CA, as

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 442 discussed above, knew that many varieties of svarita rose above the normal level of udÄtta, and their falling levels went below the normal level of anudÄtta. Similarly, the CA clearly says that the anudÄttas, which follow an udÄtta or a svarita have the same Å›ruti â€˜auditory qualityâ€™ as the udÄtta. This is a clear proof of the unmarked udÄtta and unmarked anudÄtta having fallen together to a common unmarked middle pitch level. While, I agree with Burrow that this is a secondary development, it is indeed very old. To the extent it is true to the recitational practice, one need not follow Burrow (ibid, p. 113) in calling the notational system as â€œunnecessarily complicated.â€ Strictly speaking, according to the CA description, the first part of the dependent svarita is not higher than udÄtta, and the anudÄtta before an udÄtta or a svarita remains an anudÄtta, and does not become sannatara, the marking system adopted by many manuscripts, and by all the printed editions, shows the svarita with a vertical line, and the anudÄtta before an udÄtta or a svarita with a subscript line. These markings hint at the RÌ¥gveda-like recitation of the AV. The AV reciters I have heard do not distinguish the AV recitation from the RV recitation in these respects. Thus, there may indeed be a strong RV influence on the AV recitational tradi- tion, driving it somewhat farther away from the description of the accents as given in the CA. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥©.à¥§à¥¯. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (3.68). A, B: à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤ªà¤¿Â°. Translation: Even with the separation [of words from each other by pauses in the PadapÄá¹­ha], within the same word, [an anudÄtta syllable following an udÄtta syllable is circumflexed]. Note: As Whitney notes: â€œBy their adhikÄra (ii.1 = CA 2.1.1), all rules in the second and third chapters should apply only to the saá¹ƒhitÄ, or combined text; hence it must here be specifically taught that in pada, as well as in saá¹ƒhitÄ, the syllable following an acute is enclitically circumflex, if the latter be in the same word with the former, and so not separated from it by a pause or avasÄna.â€ The pauses between the separated words of the PadapÄá¹­ha create dis- continuous segments, and yet, as the present rule indicates, within each word unit, the same prosodic rules apply. This contrasts with the next rule, where an

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾443 avagraha, or a brief pause separating members of compound-words, does not create prosodically discontinuous segments as far as accentuation is concerned. In Whitneyâ€™s words: â€œAlthough, in the pada-text, the pause which separates each independent word from the one following it breaks the continuity of accentual influence, so that a final acute of the one does not render circumflex the initial grave of the other, yet the lesser pause of the avagraha, which holds apart the two members of a compound word, causes no such interruption; on the contrary, an acute at the end of the former member calls forth the circumflexed utterance in the first syllable of the latter member.â€ In my view, it is not anything in the phonetic nature of the pauses that causes this behavioral difference. As we are told by CA (3.3.35), all these different pauses are of one mora duration, and hence, as durations of silence, they are identical with each other. It must be theoretical assumptions made by the authors of the PadapÄá¹­ha that cause this difference. In one case, one is separating words from each other, in the other, only components of compound-words. The authors of the PadapÄá¹­ha have assumed that the first kind of separation creates independent units, while the second kind creates dependent units. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¦. à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (3.69). Translation: Also, when there is a separation [with avagraha, a brief pause, of the members of compound-words, an anudÄtta syllable following an udÄtta syllable is circumflexed]. Note: See the Note on the previous rule for a distinction between separation of words by avasÄnas and separation of members of compounds by avagrahas. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤š à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤¸à¤‚à¥‘à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤¯à¥‘à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤¶à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 444 â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤¦à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¢à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤­à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤½à¤¹à¥à¥‘à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥­à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ Note: All these examples occur exactly in the same order as examples 13-18 under APR (31b, p. 34). This shows that both the texts are drawing upon identical lists of examples. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥§. à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.70). Ha: Â°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¤°à¤‚Â°. O: à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒÂ°. Translation: However, [a low-pitched (anudÄtta) syllable], followed by a high-pitched (udÄtta) or a circumflex (svarita) syllable, is not [circumflexed]. Note: As Whitney explains: â€œA syllable originally grave remains grave before a following udÄtta or svarita, even though preceded by an udÄtta, and hence, by the last rules, regularly entitled to the enclitic circumflex.â€ Whitneyâ€™s theoretical conclusion is as follows: â€œThe proclitic accent thus ap- pears, in the estimation of the Hindu phonetists, to be more powerful than the enclitic, and the law which requires the voice to plant itself upon a low pitch in order to rise to the tone of acute or independent circumflex to be more invio- lable than that which prescribes a falling tone in the next syllable after an acute.â€ While according to the rule of the CA, such a syllable remains merely anudÄtta, according to the RV notation used by many manuscripts and by the printed editions, such a syllable is marked with a horizontal subscript. In PÄá¹‡inian terms, such a syllable becomes sannatara, with pitch lower than the low of the anudÄtta. The post-CA tradition of the AV reciters seems to have moved more in the direction of the RV in this respect. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¨à¥’ à¤†à¤ªà¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¬.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‹ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤œà¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤¸à¥à¤µï†„à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥«.à¥¨)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾445 à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¨. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (3.71): Â°à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤Â°. Translation: A low-pitched [syllable], after a circumflex, as- sumes the high-pitch [of the udÄtta]. Note: Whitney says: â€œAll the other treatises (R. Pr. iii. 11, r. 18, ccv; V. Pr. iv. 138, 139; T. Pr. xxi. 10) lay down the same principle, stating also distinctly what must be regarded as implied in our precept, that not only the single grave syllable which immediately follows the circumflex receives the acute utterance, but those also which may succeed it, until, by rule 74 (= CA 3.3.25), the proximity of an acute or circumflex causes the voice to sink to the proper anudÄtta tone.â€ The significance of this rule cannot be overstated. This shows that the accentual system of the Vedic texts as they were being recited was already on its way to major collapsing of levels, and this collapse is further indicated by the traditional RV notation, also used for many AV manuscripts and all the AV editions, supports this collapsing of udÄtta and the syllables described in the present rule. Most other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas refer to this syllable by the term pracaya, which is sometimes used as a name for a distinct accent. PÄá¹‡ini 1.2.39 (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) provides that all low-pitched vowels after a circumflex are pronounced with ekaÅ›ruti â€˜monotone.â€™ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤[à¤®à¥] à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤- à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥€à¥‘à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¨. à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤µà¥€à¥‘ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥©. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (3.72). Translation: Even when separation [of words from each other occurs in the PadapÄá¹­ha], within the same word, [an anudÄtta syllable after a svarita syllable is pronounced like an udÄtta].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 446 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥- à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤à¤½à¥€à¤—à¥‚à¤²à¤¾à¥‘à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥©.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥’à¤•à¤¾à¤Ÿà¤¿à¥‘à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥®)à¥¤ Note: The commentary cites these examples without specifically tell- ing us that these are to be understood as PadapÄá¹­ha citations, which is what they must be in order to illustrate this rule. Translation: Also, when there is a separation [e.g. of the members of a compound-word with an avagraha â€˜brief pause,â€™ an anudÄtta â€˜low-pitchedâ€™ syllable after a svarita â€˜circumflexâ€™ syllable is pronounced like an udÄtta â€˜high-pitchedâ€™ syllable]. Note: Whitney comments: â€œThat is to say, again, the avagraha, or pause of division, does not interfere with the influence of the circumflex, any more than (by rule 69 = CA 3.3.20) with that of an acute, upon the following unaccented syllables.â€ See the Notes on CA 3.3.19-20. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾- à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¯.à¥§à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ƒà¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ Note: The manuscript N resumes with the word aÅ›manvatÄ«. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥«. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (3.74). A, B: Â°à¤¨à¤‚à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°Â°. F, O: Â°à¤¨à¤‚à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚. Translation: Before a circumflex or a high-pitched syllable, the immediately preceding [low-pitched] syllable remains low- pitched.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾447 Note: In the system of accents as laid out by the CA, this is the only kind of syllable which remains truly anudÄtta after all the prosodic changes are made. The anudÄtta after an udÄtta turns into a svarita. The anudÄtta after a svarita turns into an udÄttaÅ›ruti â€˜syllable sounding like an udÄtta.â€™ Thus, the only anudÄtta which is left unaltered in this system is the one prescribed by this rule. However, we should note that the PÄá¹‡inian system, cf. P.1.2.40 (à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤- à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ), treats exactly the same syllable as a sannatara syllable, i.e. syllable with a note lower than the normal level of anudÄtta. The RV notation used to mark the accents for the AV in printed editions and many manuscripts seems to treat this syllable more like a sannatara, if indeed this is the implica- tion of the horizontal line below the syllable. For further discussion, see the Notes on CA (3.3.18, 21, 22). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤…à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°- à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥‘à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥‡à¥’ à¤•à¥à¤µà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥®. à¥ªà¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¦à¥‡à¥‘à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¤à¥’ à¤¯à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤®à¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¤ªà¥’ à¤¯à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¬. à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 174) quotes this as part of the commentary. H, I, N con- nect this with the following rule. Translation: Consonants have no accents. Note: The SÅ«tras beginning with CA 3.3.26 are simply listed in the manuscripts H and N, and may have either been part of the commentary itself, or may be an early interpolation. Here they are treated as SÅ«tras because they are found in all the SÅ«tra-only manuscripts. à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥­. à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 174) quotes this as part of the commentary. E, F, P: Â°à¤¤à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ. H, I, N: connect this rule with the previous one. Translation: Ä€nyatareya says that [consonants] do have ac- cents.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥©, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥© 448 Note: For a discussion of accent-bearing consonants, see: Allen (1953: 83). à¥©.à¥©.à¥¨à¥®. à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 174) quotes this as part of the commentary. A, B, D, J, M, P: à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. The CAB on CA (1.4.2: à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¥) cites the rules CA (3.3.31-34) as SÅ«tras to illustrate the use of the term aká¹£ara. Thus, it would seem that this commentary treats these as part of the text of the CA. However, the absence of any comments on these SÅ«tras is perhaps an indication of their lack of full incorporation into the text of the CA. Such a situation is perhaps to be explained by an assumption that these were relatively recent interpolations into the text of the CA, and that the author of the CAB had ambivalent feelings about these rules. For further details, see the Note on CA (1.4.2). Translation: Of a syllable being circumflexed, which part is it that is circumflexed?

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾449 Note: Whitney (1862: 174) cannot locate any context for this whole discussion: â€œIn the absence of any illustrations, I am at a loss to see to what kind of combinations this question and its answers are to be understood as ap- plying.â€ It would seem that it was commonplace to think of a svarita as being composed of two portions. It is also my guess that the verb svaryate is proba- bly used in the sense of â€˜markedly raised,â€™ and that it was this raising the initial part of the svarita that was the most noticeable part of a svarita for the Indian phoneticians and Veda reciters. For further discussion, see the Note on the BhÄrgava-BhÄskara-VrÌ¥tti on CA (1.1.16). à¥©.à¥©.à¥©à¥¨. à¤…à¤°à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‹ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 174) quotes this as part of the commentary. B, D: à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‹Â°. H, N: à¤ªà¤¦à¥Œ for à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‹. Most mss. read à¤°à¥à¤¹ for à¤¹à¥à¤°. Translation: Some say that [the first] half of a short vowel, and the [first] quarter of a long vowel [is circumflexed]. Note: The doctrine here generally agrees the one stated in CA (1.1.17) that the first half-mora of a svarita is high-pitched. This naturally gives the first quarter of the long svarita vowel as being high-pitched. However, this general view leads to the recitation of each svarita vowel as having two distinct accents for their initial and final portions. While this is the standard view shared by most authorities, a minority opposition is voiced in the next rule by ÅšÄá¹…kha- mitri. à¥©.à¥©.à¥©à¥©. à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (p. 174) quotes this as part of the commentary. Translation: ÅšÄá¹…khamitri says that the entire [syllable is cir- cumflexed]. Note: This rule and the next represent ÅšÄá¹…khamitriâ€™s argument against having a svarita vowel with two parts, and he apparently proposed that the entire syllable be pronounced with a raised pitch with no falling portion. ÅšÄá¹…khamitri is a lone voice in Sanskrit phonetics, as no one else is known to have expressed the same view.

Whitney, H: Â°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤µÂ°. C, N: Â°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤µÂ°. A, B: Â°à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤µÂ°. Translation: [The pause] at the end of a half-verse, at the end of a word [in the PadapÄá¹­ha, before the next word], the ava- graha, [e.g., the pause between the separated members of a compound-word in the PadapÄá¹­ha], and for the hiatus [in the Saá¹ƒhitÄpÄá¹­ha] is of one mora duration. Note: This is a very important rule. It is important to note that the various pauses are phonetically identical, i.e. they are all stretches of silence for the duration of one mora. However, they have different theoretical and re- citational consequences. See the Note on CA (3.3.19). à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H, N: à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ.
