à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾485 The reading found in most mss., i.e. sasaheÂ° makes no sense in this context, and probably represents the confusion of susaha and sasahe, enhanced by the presence in the AV of the form sasahe (AV 1.16.3; 2.5.3). However, this is a verb form with reduplication, and does not illustrate anything in the present context. The examples naghÄriá¹£ÄÌm (AV 8.2.6, 7.6) and sÃºsaha (AV 6.64.3) are intended to illustrate the rule given in the previous verse. Normally, nÃ¡ is an accented particle, but it loses its accent in the first example. Similarly, sahÃ¡ is normally accented on the last syllable. However, it loses its accent in the compound-expression sÃºsaha. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥¦ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤šà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¤à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥‹ [à¤¸à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥Œ?] à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 261) quotes this as part of the commentary. See the Note below. Translation: [Continuing the previous topic of compounding of sahÃ¡]: And, where the change [of sahÃ¡] to sa is taught, an accented word is compounded with the unaccented [sa]. The illustrations are sahÃ¡sÅ«ktavÄkaá¸¥, sÄÌntardeÅ›Äá¸¥, and Å›atakrato. Note: I have translated the first part of the verse, assuming the emen- dation sabhÄvo referring to the change of sahÃ¡ to sa. In my opinion, the manu- script readings codÄttaá¹ƒ svabhÄvo and codÄttam abhÄvo are corruptions for codÄttaá¹ƒ sabhÄvo, because the copyists could not understand the word sabhÄvo, and replaced it with the more familiar words, which actually make no sense in the context. The examples sahÃ¡sÅ«ktavÄkaá¸¥ (AV 7.97.6) and sÄÌntardeÅ›Äá¸¥ (AV 9.5. 37) illustrate the two types of combinations. In the first combination, the accented word sahÃ¡ is combined with the unaccented sÅ«ktavÄkaá¸¥. In the sec- ond combination, the unaccented sa is combined with the accented Ã¡ntardeÅ›Äá¸¥, cf. PadapÄá¹­ha : sa-Ã¡ntardeÅ›Äá¸¥. As for the example Å›atakrato (AV 14.1.41), Whitney (1862: 263) comments: â€œÅ›atakrato is also added, but apparently only by a blunder; or rather, the reading is probably false and corrupt, as the metre helps to show.â€ All the manuscripts have this reading, and yet the reading makes no sense in this context. I would like to suggest that Å›atakrato is an an- cient error of a copyist for sakrÌ¥Ìtau (AV 11.1.10) which is analyzed by the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 486 PadapÄá¹­ha as sa-krÌ¥Ìtau, a compound of an accented word with the unaccented sa for sahÃ¡. This copyistâ€™s error must be truly ancient to get into all the available manuscripts. This may indicate that ultimately all our existing manuscripts go back to a common source which had this error. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥§.à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤½à¤§à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 262) quotes this as part of the commentary. A, B, D, P: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿Â°. Other mss. read: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡. Whitneyâ€™s emendation: à¤…à¤¨à¥- à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡Â°, Â°à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ. C, E, F, I, O: in a different location. J: no such verse. I have adopted Whitneyâ€™s emendation over the manuscripts. The reading à¤…à¤¨à¥- à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ probably developed due to the scribal confusion with à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ in the next verse. The prevalence of this confusion in most manuscripts also hints at its presence in the archetype from which probably all our surviving manuscripts are derived. For a similar phenomenon, see my Note on the preceding verse. Translation: Where there is an unaccented pre-verb [= gati] in between the preceding and the following [pre-verbs], both of which have their natural accent [udÄtta], the first of these is iso- lated [in the PadapÄá¹­ha as a separate word], for example: pÃºruá¹£Ã© â€™dhi samÄÌhite (AV 10.7.15). Note: In the example cited by the verse, there are three pre-verbs [gati, upasarga], such that the first and the third are udÄtta, while the second one is unaccented, i.e. Ã¡dhi+sam+ÄÌ. The verse says that in such a sequence, the first preverb is isolated in the PadapÄá¹­ha as an independent word, namely that it is not treated as part of a compound. This is confirmed by the PadapÄá¹­ha. Here, one may say that Ã¡dhi is syntactically related to pÃºruá¹£e, rather than with samÄÌhite, and, hence, to use the PÄá¹‡inian terminology, it is a true preposition (karmapravacanÄ«ya), rather than a preverb (upasarga). Both categories are sub- sumed under the wider category of gati in the PÄá¹‡inian grammar, as is appar- ently the case with these verses. The phrase pÃºruá¹£Ã© â€™dhi samÄÌhitÄá¸¥ appears in the same verse. The grammatical theory as expressed in the verse pays atten- tion only to the sequence of accented or unaccented items, but does not seem to pay much attention to the syntactic component.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾487 à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥¨.à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 262) quotes this as part of the commentary. B, D, M: à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¨à¥ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾Â°. E, F, J: à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾Â°. C: no such verse. O, P: à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹- à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿Â°. Others: à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¿. The meter requires a hiatus: à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤‚. Translation: Where an accented [pre-verb, particle, gati] is followed by a pre-verb, and where the following word is unac- cented, in such a case, the first [pre-verb, particle, gati] is iso- lated [in the PadapÄá¹­ha as a separate word], for example: sÃ¡á¹ƒ sÃºbhÅ«tyÄ (AV 3.14.1). Note: Whitney (1862: 263) describes this verse as: â€œwhere two ac- cented prepositions precede an unaccented noun, the former of them is to be made independent.â€ The PadapÄá¹­ha for the example reads: sÃ¡m / sÃº-bhÅ«tyÄ /. The verse does not clearly say that both the pre-verbs must be accented. How- ever, given that the noun is said to be unaccented, this makes the compounded pre-verb an accented item. We should note that, the logic of this verse is not entirely clear. The actual practice of the AV PadapÄá¹­ha, which is also corroborated by 54 exam- ples listed under APR (10, pp. 9-11), seems to provide a somewhat generalized rule. When an accented or unaccented verbal noun (krÌ¥danta) is preceded by two upasargas, with the first one being an accented upasarga / karmaprava- canÄ«ya, it is isolated as a separate word in the PadapÄá¹­ha. For instance, Ã¡pa dur- matÃ­m (AV 14.2.6). Here, dur is unaccented, matÃ­m is accented, and yet the PadapÄá¹­ha isolates Ã¡pa as an independent word. There are a large number of examples of this kind. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥©.à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 262) quotes this as part of the commentary. E, F, O: à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹- à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‡Â°. Whitney: Â°à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡Â°. F, M: Â°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿Â°. E, F, I, O: Â°à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. Others: à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. C: no such verse. Translation: Where both the first and the second [upasargas] are naturally accented (udÄtta), in such cases, after isolating the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 488 initial accented items [as independent words in the PadapÄá¹­ha], all the items are separated. Note: On this verse, Whitney (1862: 263) remarks: â€œVerse 11 has no example, and, although easily enough translated, its meaning is to me obscure.â€ To begin to make sense of this verse, we need to properly interpret the term ÄdyudÄtta. On the one hand, the term ÄdyudÄtta understood as â€˜an item with its initial syllable with the udÄtta accent,â€™ distinguishes between accented and unaccented preverbs, and then distinguishes between those which are accented on the first syllable, and the ones which are accented on the last syllable. Such a distinction is possible only with polysyllabic upasargas. CA (4.1.19-21) below tell us that all the twenty upasargas are naturally accented. Out of the eleven polysyllabic upasargas, abhÃ­ is the only one which is accented on the final syllable. All the others are accented on the first syllable. If the verse above, as translated here, is to be meaningful, it refers to a difference of behavior between abhÃ­ and the rest of the upasargas. I have not been able to detect any clear behavioral difference. Therefore, I have chosen to interpret the term ÄdyudÄttÄni in the verse to refer to â€˜initial accented items.â€™ If this meaning is accepted, then we can find examples to illustrate this verse. As far as I can see, all the 57 examples listed under APR (13c, pp. 12-14) would fall into this category. Here, typically, an unaccented verb is preceded by two accented upasargas, and the PadapÄá¹­ha isolates all of these as separate words. For example: Ãºpa prÄÌgÄt (AV 1.28.1), PadapÄá¹­ha : Ãºpa / prÃ¡ / agÄt /. I should note here that over half the mss. read à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ instead of à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. I have chosen the latter reading, and I admit, along with Whitney, that I cannot make any sense of the former. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥ª.à¤¨à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤š à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥ˆà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 261) quotes this as part of the commentary. E, F, I, O: à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¤à¥‡Â°. A, B, D, P: Â°à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥ˆÂ°. C: no such verse. P: à¤¨à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¤à¥‡Â°. O: Â°à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥Â°. H: à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚. Others: à¤¸à¤‚à¤¬à¤‚à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚. Translation: Verbs are not compounded [with each other], nor is a verb and a noun compound [with each other]. How-

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾489 ever, a semantically related noun is compounded with a noun or with a pre-verb (upasarga). Note: The reading sambandhÄrtham, as supported by most manuscripts, and by Whitney (1862: 262), would literally mean: â€˜for the sake of relationship.â€™ However, taking a hint from the reading à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ in H, I have chosen to amend the text to à¤¸à¤‚à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚. The word sambaddhÄrtha as an equivalent to samartha is found in the MB on P.2.1.1 (Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., p. 365): à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ. Also relevant in the context is the fact that the APR (3, p. 3) is identical with P.2.1.1 (à¤¸à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ), and that the APR often brings up the notion that no compounding takes places between items which are asamartha, cf. APR (13b, p. 12). I suspect that the present verse is making a similar statement. The statement à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ of this verse is comparable to APR (13b, p. 12): à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¥. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥«.à¤¨ à¤¯à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤•à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¨ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 262) quotes this as part of the commentary. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾491 other accents, for example: saá¹ƒsrÄvyÃ¨á¹‡a (AV 1.15.1), durar- maá¹‡yÃ á¸¥ (AV 16.2.1), and ÄcÄryÃ á¸¥ (AV 11.5.3). Note: Given the fact that the reading svaritÄdibhiá¸¥ is supported by all mss., it can either mean â€˜svarita etc.â€™ or â€˜those which begin with a svarita sylla- ble.â€™ Since the second meaning does not seem to be even remotely applicable, we must accept the first meaning. Whitney (1862: 263) takes this to mean â€˜however accented,â€™ and then says that the verse â€œillustrates only their compo- sition with a circumflexed word.â€ All the three illustrations demonstrate the same type, i.e. compounding of an unaccented prepositional item with the fol- lowing word with a svarita accent. How about the compounding of an unac- cented prepositional item with words with udÄtta or anudÄtta accents? If our understanding of the verse is correct, this should be possible. We can find a large number of instances where an unaccented preposi- tional item is compounded with the following word with an udÄtta syllable, e.g. sumatÃ­m (AV 4.25.6). However, it is not easy to find an unaccented preposi- tional item compounded with an unaccented (sarvÄnudÄtta) word. The only cases I can locate in the text of the AV are those where a previous compound becomes completely unaccented through further embedding, e.g. rÌ¥tÃ¡prajÄtÄ (AV 1.11.1), where the segment prajÄtÄ becomes completely unaccented because of its further compounding with rÌ¥tÃ¡. Otherwise, the word would be accented as prÃ¡jÄtÄ (AV 1.34.1). The AV mss. read durarmaá¹‡ya (AV 15.2.1). However, Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 795) remarks: â€œThe translation implies the change of durar- maá¹‡yÃ s to duradmanyÃ s, as proposed by the Pet. Lexx. (add TB. iii.3.99 as a reference for duradmanÄ«Ì). The reading of the mss. is, however, assured by its quotation in the PrÄt., and three times in the KÄuÅ›.â€ à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§à¥¯.à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¿à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿à¤¸à¥‚à¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤­à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ Whitney (p. 262) quotes this as part of the commentary. P: Â°à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¤ƒ … à¤¸à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥€ … à¤µà¤·à¤¡à¥à¤¡à¥à¤²à¤¾ … à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤²à¤²à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°Â°. H: Â°à¤µà¤·à¤¡à¥à¤—à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤²à¤¾Â°. This is probably the most corrupt passage in this entire text. Translation: The following items, [though not listed as upa- sargas], behave like upasargas, and their accents are as recited: Ã¡ccha, Ã¡ram, Ã¡stam, hÃ¡sta, lÄá¹…gÅ«lam, tirÃ¡á¸¥, purÃ¡á¸¥, pÃºnaá¸¥, nava, Å›yetÄ«Ì, vÄtÄ«Ì, phalÄ«, hÃ­á¹ƒ, srÃºk, vÃ¡á¹£aá¹­, ululÄ , kakajÄÌ, svÄÌhÄ, svadhÄÌ, Å›rat, svÃ r, alalÄ. Note: Whitney (1862) took great pains to make sense of this passage, for which he had only one manuscript. We shall begin by noting his comments (1862: 263-4): â€œFinally, the last verse (or prose passage) attempts to give a list of those words which are treated as if they were prepositions, although prop- erly belonging to what it includes and what it omits. A part of the forms which it contains are in frequent use, and familiarly known as bearing marked analo- gies with the prepositions proper. Such are achÄ, tiraá¸¥, puraá¸¥, punaá¸¥, hiá¹…, prÄduá¸¥, and Å›rat. Others, as aram and astam, are more remotely connected with the same class. Vaá¹£aá¹­, svÄhÄ, and vÄtÄ« are in the Atharvan compounded only with kÄra and krÌ¥ta, and hardly in such a manner as should require their inclusion in the list. SvadhÄ and sruk form no other compounds than svadhÄ- kÄra and srukkÄra (ix.6.22); phalÄ« forms phalÄ«karaá¹‡a (xi.3.6); kakajÄ forms kakajÄkrÌ¥ta (xi.10.25). Namas enters into namaskÄra, namaskrÌ¥ta, and namas- krÌ¥tya (vii.102.1), which last affords actually good ground for special treatment, as does hastagrÌ¥hya (e.g. v.14.4), on account of which hasta is ranked with the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 494 others. For lÄá¹…gÅ«la, ká¹£itÄ«, and ulÄ, I can find nothing at all in the Atharvan : there is room in the case of the two last, and especially of the third, to suspect corrupted readings. What may be hidden in svaralalÄ, I have not been able to discover, nor how the last word in the extract, which apparently has to do with the accent of the words treated of, is to be amended into intelligibility.â€ With the new set of manuscripts at our disposal, and with further thought on the listed items, I think it is now possible to advance beyond Whitneyâ€™s difficulties. We shall look at the listed items individually:

  1. Ãccha. For example: Ã¡cchÄ vada (AV 3.20.2). Compare P.1.4.69 (à¤…à¤šà¥à¤› à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥), which treats Ã¡ccha as a gati.
  2. Ãram (= Ã¡lam). For example: Ã¡raá¹…krÌ¥tam (AV 12.1.22). Compare P.1.4.64 (à¤­à¥‚à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤²à¤®à¥), which treats Ã¡lam as a gati.
  3. Ãstam. For example: astameá¹£yatÃ© (AV 17.1.23). Compare P.1.4.68 (à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š), which treats Ã¡stam as a gati.
  4. HÃ¡sta. For example: hastagrÌ¥Ìhya (AV 5.14.4). Compare P.1.4.77 (à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤ªà¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥‡), which treats haste as a gati. The mss. reading hasto is probably a corruption of haste, as it is found in P.1.4.77.
  5. LÄá¹…gÅ«lam. The word lÄá¹…gÅ«la is attested in the PaippalÄda AV (9.8.1) in the expression lÄá¹…gÅ«la-grÌ¥hya, which is directly comparable with hasta-grÌ¥Ìhya (AV 5.14.4). Such an occurrence accounts for its being listed as an upasarga-vrÌ¥tti item. In my view, this is the best explanation. However, I would like to mention two further possibilities. A possible reading is uluá¹…gulam. All manuscripts have the reading hastolÄá¹…gÅ«laá¹ƒ, which Whitney amended to hastalÄá¹…gÅ«lam. This did not ac- count for the o in hasto. My guess is that hastoluá¹…gulaá¹ƒ could be analyzed as hasta+uluá¹…gulaá¹ƒ. Here, the word uluá¹…gulam is in all probability a portion of the name of the Apsaras mentioned in PaippalÄda AV (15.19.1-12: à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥à¤²à¥à¤™à¥- à¤—à¥à¤²à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤°à¤‚ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ). With the final agentive affix -uka, the formation uluá¹…gulukÄ looks like a derivation from a denominative verb uluá¹…gulati, from the sound-imitation uluá¹…gula-. Such sound-imitations, especially in com- bination with verbs like krÌ¥ are called gati, cf. ulalÄ and alalÄ below. The word uluá¹…gulukÄ has been provided with a somewhat unclear folk-etymology in PaippalÄda AV (15.18.6: à¤‰à¤²à¤®à¤¾à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤—à¤¶à¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤ƒ). I would also like to mention one more possibility. A reading such as hastolÅ«galuá¹ƒ may contain three words: hasta, ulÅ«, and galuá¹ƒ. Here, the word ulÅ« could be the first member of the word ulÅ«Ìkhala (AV 9.6.15) which is left unanalyzed by the PadapÄá¹­ha. The next item galuá¹ƒ may be the first portion of the expression galuntÃ¡á¸¥ (AV 6.83.3). This expression is not split by the

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾495 PadapÄá¹­ha. However, SÄyaá¹‡a explains this expression as: à¤—à¤¡à¥‚à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¤¡à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥ à¤‰à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤”à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥. There is a strong possibility that nÃ¡va, in the sense of â€˜newly, recently,â€™ may have been treated as a gati in an instance like navagÃ¡t (AV 3.10.4), which is split by the PadapÄá¹­ha as nava-gÃ¡t. Also see: Wackernagel, Altindische Grammatik, Vol. II., Pt. Boisacq 2, 236.â€ All the manuscripts read punará¹‡avaá¸¥. It is easy to see how the combination in the list of punar+nava may have been identified by the copyists with the AV word punará¹‡avaá¸¥ (AV 8.1.20). Against his manuscript, and now against all manuscripts, Whitney amended the text to read punará¹‡amaá¸¥. NÃ¡mas is attested in AV. For example: namaskÄrÃ©á¹‡a (AV 4.39.9). The word namaá¸¥ is included in the sÄká¹£ÄtprabhrÌ¥tÄ«ni list of items treat as gati in combination with the root krÌ¥, cf. ÅšyetÄ«Ì. This reading is supported by mss. E, F, I, and O, and probably is the source of the reading ká¹£itÄ« in H. The item syetÄ« as a cvi-form appears in combination with the verb krÌ¥ in the TaittirÄ«ya-Saá¹ƒhitÄ (5.5.8: Å›yaitÃ©na Å›yetÄ«Ì akuruta … Å›yaitÃ©na Å›yetÄ«Ì kurute). This form, along with mithunÄ«, is mentioned in TPR (x.18: à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥€ à¤®à¤¿à¤¥à¥à¤¨à¥€). While the AV does not have the usage of Å›yetÄ«Ì+krÌ¥, the word Å›yaita is attested in AV (15.2.4). The similarity of the formations Å›yetÄ«Ì+krÌ¥ with vÄtÄ«+krÌ¥ below is inescapable. I would like to mention sani as another possibility, though not a very strong one. In the form saniá¹£yadÄÌá¸¥ (AV 19.2.1), the portion sani is actually part of reduplication of the root in the intensive form. However, several manu- scripts of the PadapÄá¹­ha place an avagraha between sani and syadÄÌá¸¥, suggest- ing that somebody at sometime may have looked at sani as a first member of a compound-expression, cf. Whitney, Index Verborum to AV, p. 304, and the

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 496 VVRI edition, Part IV, Fasc. I., p. 1790. Whitney (AV Translation, Vol. II., p. 899) says: â€œOur saniá¹£yadÄÌs in c is an emendation, and called for !see Skt. Gram. Â§ 1148. 4. k., near the endâˆ€; all the mss., and SPP., accent saniá¹£yÃ¡dÄs. … The pada-mss. make the absurd division saniÂ°syÃ¡dÄá¸¥.â€ While Whitneyâ€™s view may be historically correct, there is no reason to reject out of hand the strong possibility that some traditions analyzed the word differently. This is especially so in view of the different accentuation for the word found in the manuscripts. The combination sani-vÄtÄ« in the list was easily misunderstood and changed to sinÄ«vÄlÄ« by some copyists. 11. VÄtÄ«Ì. For example: vÄtÄ«ÌkrÌ¥tasya (AV 6.109.3). Such forms are in- cluded under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). 12. PhalÄ«. For example: phalÄ«kÃ¡raá¹‡Äá¸¥ (AV 11.3.6). The item phalÄ«- krÌ¥tya is listed by the KV under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). 13. HÃ­á¹ƒ. For example: hiá¹…kÄrÃ¡á¸¥ (AV 11.7.5). Compare the items hum, ghum etc. which are listed among nipÄtas under P.1.4.57 (à¤šà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡), cf. the KV on P.1.4.57. As imitations of sounds, these are covered as gatis under P.1.4.62 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥). 14. SrÃºk. For example: srukkÄrÃ©á¹‡a (AV 9.6.22). This expression ap- pears in the same verse which has the more familiar expression vaá¹£aá¹­kÄrÃ©á¹‡a, and the items listed next in our list is vÃ¡á¹£aá¹­. 15. VÃ¡á¹£aá¹­. For example: vaá¹£aá¹­kÄrÃ©á¹‡a (AV 9.6.22). The item vÃ¡á¹£aá¹­ is listed as a gati in the Å«ryÄdigaá¹‡a in P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š), cf. the KV on P.1.4.61. 16. UlulÄ . This is my suggested emendation. The mss. readings vary: uá¸ulÄ, gudurulÄ, ulÄ. The form ululÄ is made likely by the fact that AV (3.19.6) has the expression ghÃ³á¹£Ä ululÃ¡yaá¸¥. SÄyaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary has the reading ullulayÃ¡á¸¥, which he explains as à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤²à¥à¤²à¥à¤²à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾ à¤˜à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ. If ululu or ullulu is a sound-imitation, then to combine it with a verb like krÌ¥ in the sense of making that sound, P.1.4.62 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥), the sound-imitation is given the designation gati. Also P.5.4.57 (à¤…à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤œà¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¥) prescribes the affix á¸Äc to be added to a sound-imitation like ululu to turn it into ululÄ before it is compounded with a verb like karoti. In fact, the expressions ululÄkuru and ululÄkrÌ¥taá¸¥ are attested in PaippalÄda AV (5.34.2, and 2.55.5). Thus, we can confidently have the form ululÄ eligible for inclusion in the present list. Compare the other included sound-imitation alalÄ. 17. KakajÄÌ. For instance: kakajÄÌkrÌ¥tÄ (AV 11.10.25). This belongs to the same type of gatis listed under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). 18. SvÄÌhÄ. For example: svÄhÄkÄrÃ¡m (AV 15.14.8). The item svÄÌhÄ is listed as a gati under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾497 19. SvadhÄÌ. For example: svadhÄkÄrÃ¡m (AV 15.14.7). The item svadhÄÌ is listed as a gati under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). 20. ÅšrÃ¡t. For example: Å›raddhÃ©yam (AV 4.30.4). The item Å›rÃ¡t is listed as a gati under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). 21. SvÃ r. For example: svargÃ¡á¸¥ (AV 9.5.16) analyzed by the PadapÄá¹­ha as svaá¸¥-gÃ¡á¸¥. P.1.1.37 (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤®à¥) includes svar among in- declinables. 22. AlalÄ. There is no example for alalÄ in AV. However, alalÄ is found compounded in the following usage: alalÄbhÃ¡vantÄ«á¸¥ (RV 4.18.6) â€˜mak- ing the sound alalÄ,â€™ cf. SÄyaá¹‡a: à¤…à¤²à¤²à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤‚à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ.. Such compounding be covered by P.1.4.62 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥), giving the status of gati to the sound-imitation alalÄ. This solves the puzzle of svaralalÄ which Whitney was unable to solve. It also shows that this list is not restricted to items from the AV, but includes items from other textual traditions. Whitney further comments: â€œThere are two words which we especially miss in this list of upasargavrÌ¥ttÄ«ni, and can hardly believe to have been origi- nally absent from it: they are antaá¸¥ and Äviá¸¥ : I cannot, however, find by emen- dation any place for them in the text as it stands.â€ It is difficult to say why these words are not included in the list. These are examples of gatis in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition. The word antaá¸¥ as a gati is covered by P.1.4.65 (à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°- à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡), and Ävis as a gati is covered under P.1.4.61 (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤¾à¤šà¤¶à¥à¤š). Perhaps another enumeration ascribed to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana did include the particle antar. Referring to ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyanaâ€™s view, the BrÌ¥haddevatÄ (2.95) says: à¤…à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ Finally, I believe that this entire initial portion probably represents a very ancient incorporation into the text of the original CA. However, since all manuscripts of the CA, except C, contain them, I believe that the text of the CA, as it can be reconstructed on the basis of the manuscripts, must incorpo- rate these passages. Clearly, the archetype of all our manuscripts must have had this portion. However, it is most likely that they were incorporated into the text of the CA after the CAB. While the CAB itself probably did not know these verses as part of the text of the CA, and therefore did not comment on them, the copyists of the manuscripts of the CAB definitely knew them, and they did incorporate these uncommented verses in their manuscripts. Also see the note on the colophon for this PÄda for a serious disagreement on the num- ber of rules in this PÄda. A possible hint is provided by BhÄrgava-BhÄskara for the importance of the views of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana to the later followers of ÅšaunakÄ«ya AV, that, while

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 498 professing themselves to be followers of Åšaunaka, they often disregarded Åšaunakaâ€™s precepts in preference to those of ÅšÄkaá¹­Äyana, cf. BhÄrgava- BhÄskaraâ€™s commentary on CA (1.1.10): à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥- à¤¸à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥. The presence of such a large extract supposedly from a work of ÅšÄka- á¹­Äyana, or a work from his tradition, may be an indication of such influence on the CA tradition. Also see CA 4.1.52, and the CAB on that rule. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥©. à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤— à¤†à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.1). A, B, C: Â°à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°Â°. D: à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤— à¤†à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. O: Â°à¤†à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨Â°. Translation: A pre-verb (upasarga) is compounded with an accented verb. Note: In the situation envisioned by this rule, the pre-verb (upasarga) is unaccented and the verb is accented. Whitney says: â€œThis is the well-known usage of all the Vedic pada-texts, at least so far as they have been brought to general knowledge. With a true appreciation of the slightness of the bond which connects a verb with its prefix, the constructors of the disjoined text have ordinarily treated the two as independent words: unless, indeed, by laws of accentuation of the sentence, the usually enclitic verb retains its accent and becomes proclitic; and then the two are written together as a compound.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤— à¤†à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¸à¤®- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§.à¥§, à¤ªà¤¦ * â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¤­à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¯.à¥©, à¤ªà¤¦ * â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤…à¤­à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤‚à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°- à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥«.à¥©, à¤ªà¤¦ * â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤µà¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿)à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—- à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤§à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥­. à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤®à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤¦à¥’à¤§à¤¿à¥’à¤°à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥®. à¥«)à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤½à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤²à¤¾à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤¯à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥­.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: This rule is comparable to part of APR (12a). However, the ex- amples listed under APR (12a) are not identical with the examples cited here by

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾499 the CAB. Since the positive examples of the rules do not form a closed gaá¹‡a, one can guess that there was no standard list of such examples. The distinction between samÄsa and non-samÄsa manifests itself in the PadapÄá¹­ha, where an upasarga combined as a samÄsa with the verb form is separated in the PadapÄá¹­ha by an Avagraha. On the other hand, an upasarga which is not combined as a samÄsa with the verb is separated from that verb in the PadapÄá¹­ha as a separate word. The commentary makes an interesting observation. It refers to two classes of items, the upasargas and the upasargavrÌ¥ttis â€˜words which behave like upasargas, but are not upasargas.â€™ Items like puras have been categorized as upasargavrÌ¥tti in CA (4.1.22). As discussed in the note on that rule, it is not clear whether the author of the CAB was familiar with the verses at the begin- ning of this PÄda. It is also likely that it was the CAB that cited the entire pas- sage in the beginning, and then, for some reason, it was incorporated into the text of the CA. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª. à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤•à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (4.2). Translation: When there is more than one pre-verb [preceding the verb], they are [all] compounded even with an unaccented verb. Note: It may be noted that CA (4.1.5-6) formulate this rule in a somewhat different way, and it seems most likely that they were not part of the â€˜originalâ€™ CA, but were extracted from a different grammatical tradition and added to the text of the CA at some point. As Whitney points out: â€œIf more prepositions than one are compounded with an unaccented verb, only one of them, the one next the verb, is accented, the others becoming proclitic. In such a case, the constructors of the pada-text have very properly combined all with the verb, instead of simply putting the prepositions together, since it is not the relation of the former to the latter preposition that costs the former its accent, but rather their common relation to the verb : we have not a compound preposition, but a duplicate verbal com- pound. A later rule (rule 7 = CA 4.1.29, below) teaches us that in such a com- bination the first of the prepositions is separated by avagraha from the rest.â€ The rule seems to leave open the possibility, not discussed by Whitney, that a multiplicity of pre-verbs may be compounded with an accented verb as

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 500 well. However, all the examples offered here are examples of unaccented verbs. See the Notes on CA (4.1.5-6). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤• à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ƒ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤†à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤…à¤µà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥«à¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥§.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤†à¤šà¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤·à¥à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥§.à¥©à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤½à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨(H: à¤£)à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤šà¥à¤›à¥’à¤½à¤†à¤µà¥‘à¤¦à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥©à¥®.à¥©, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥©à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿à¥’à¤½- à¤¹à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤£à¥‹à¤¤â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥©.à¥©à¥­)à¥¤ Note: On the citation from AV (18.4.50), Whitney (AV Transl. Translation: [However], meaningless prepositional items, prepositional items syntactically linked with nouns (karma- pravacanÄ«ya), and those which are related in some other way, are separated [ from the verb in the PadapÄá¹­ha as independent uncompounded words], as in examples such as: abhÃ­ / vÃ­ / tanu (AV 1.1.3). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤à¥’à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¥à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤§à¥’à¤¯à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥ª. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¥‘ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾501 Note: The CAB lists here the first four instances out of a total list of fifty-seven instances found in the APR (13). The instances are cited exactly in the same order. The CA rule is itself identical with, and perhaps is a quotation in, APR (13c). The notion that certain prepositional items are anarthaka in certain contexts is also seen in P.1.4.93 (à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥€ à¤…à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¥Œ). The KV on this rule says that the items adhi and pari are given the designation karmapravacanÄ«ya, when not bearing any meaning, in order to prevent the designations gati and upasarga : à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¬à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. Our rule here, and the commentary on it, seem to differentiate between the categories anarthaka and karmapravacanÄ«ya. Neither the CAB nor the APR explain as to which exam- ples are offered to illustrate which type. However, a related discussion of some of these issues is found under APR (3, p. 4): â€˜à¤ªà¤·à¤¾ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥’à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤µà¤¯à¤¤à¥à¥’ à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥«à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥? à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤·à¤¾ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥‘à¤—à¤®à¥â€™ - à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤½à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤†à¤½à¤­à¥‘à¤—à¤®à¥ (à¥ª.à¥¨à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤ à¤†à¤­à¥‘à¤—à¤®à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤­à¤—à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¥‘à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¥’à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡â€™ - à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¥‘à¤½à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤¹à¥’à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ (à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ ? à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (1862: 186) says: â€œThe term anyayukta probably means â€˜be- longing to another verb,â€™ but such cases are quite rare in the text : an instance of the kind intended is perhaps nÃ­á¸¥ stuvÄnÃ¡sya pÄtaya (i.8.3), where the prepo- sition niá¸¥ belongs to the verb pÄtaya, and not the intervening participle, to which it would otherwise be attached, with loss of its own accent. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s karmapravacanÄ«ya is comprehensive enough to include all the cases to which our rules apply.â€ A similar example of anyayukta is offered by the APR passage cited above, e.g. AV (18.2.54), where pra is not compounded with vidvÄn, since pra is semantically related to cyÄvayatu, rather than to vidvÄn. To this extent, Whitneyâ€™s understanding seems to be correct. However, Whitney is not correct in suggesting that cases like these would be subsumed under PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s notion of karmapravacanÄ«ya. As I have pointed out above, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s notion of karmapravacanÄ«ya, subsumes the in- stances of anarthaka, cf. P.1.4.93. However, there is no reason to believe that

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 502 instances of anyayukta would be covered under his notion of karmapravcanÄ«ya. The compounding of anyayukta items would be prevented by the general con- vention set by P.2.1.1 (à¤¸à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ), which lays down the rule that processes like compounding take place only for the items which are semantically and syntactically related to each other. Interestingly, the APR (3), which is identi- cal with P.2.1.1, has the same import, and the APR specifically prohibits com- pounding because of the lack of sÄmarthya â€˜semantic/syntactic relationship,â€™ cf. APR (13b, p. 12): à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¥ Commenting on the present rule, Whitney exerts to bring together a large collection of instances for â€œthis and the two following rules, since they evidently form a single class, and are only formally distinct from one another.â€ Now that we have access to Surya Kantaâ€™s APR, we can be certain that these two gaá¹‡as were treated as distinct gaá¹‡as, and they are listed separately in that text. The examples offered by the CAB appear to be the first few citations of the long lists found in the APR. Further, the APR brings out some crucial dif- ferences which are not overtly mentioned by the CA, or the CAB. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¬. à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.4). O: Â°à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾Â°. Translation: In abhi vipaÅ›yÄmi etc., the first [prepositional item is separated as an independent word]. Note: Whitney says that, in these instances, â€œa preposition retaining its accent and independence before another preposition which is itself made proclitic and combined with a following accented verb.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤…à¤­à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤®à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¨à¥‘à¤¸à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤œà¤™à¥à¤—à¥‘à¤¹à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¯.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾503 Note: The CAB lists here the first four instances out of a total of seven listed in the APR (12c). The passages occur exactly in the same order as found in the APR. The APR rule (12c) says: â€œWhen an accented verb is pre- ceded by two prepositions, separated (from the second preposition+verb) are such items as are used without significance, or as karmapravacanÄ«yas, or con- nected with something else.â€ While the CA rule simply makes a reference to a list, the APR (12c) provides a more detailed description, and a reasoning. It still leaves a logical possibility open that an accented verb could be com- pounded with two pre-verbs, which are not anarthaka, karmapravacanÄ«ya, or anyayukta. Translation: [There is separation of the pre-verb from the verbs] ÄÅ›Ä«Ì3á¸¥ (AV 11.3.26) and babhÅ«vÄÌƒÌ3, because the pro- longed [i.e. pluta, vowel of the verbs] is [already] effected (siddha). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤†à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¬à¤­à¥‚à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤“à¥’à¤¦à¥’à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥¤ à¤†à¥’à¤¶à¥€[à¥©]à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¥§à¥§.à¥©.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤† à¥¤ à¤¬à¥’à¤­à¥‚à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¤à¥©â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥®)à¥¤ Note: On this rule, Whitney says: â€œThat is to say, if I do not misap- prehend the meaning of the rule, owing to the recognition of the final syllable of each word as a protracted one. To what end the precept is given, unless the words referred to (x.2.28 and xi.3.26, 27) have an irregular accent on the pro- tracted syllable, I do not see. If accented, they would have a right, by the first rule of this chapter (= CA 4.1.23), to combination with the preceding preposi- tion; but, the present rule virtually says, they are seen to lose this right upon a recognition of the fact that the accented vowel is protracted, and that its accent is therefore of an anomalous character. It has been already noticed (under i. 105 = CA 1.4.14) that a part of our manuscripts accent babhÅ«vÄÌƒÌ3 in the latter of the two passages referred to : not one gives an accent to ÄÅ›Ä«3á¸¥, in either case of its occurrence.â€ The VVRI edition goes with the majority of the manuscripts and gives the accent of babhÅ«vÄÌƒÌ3 as antodÄtta, while it notes the unaccented reading given by the Whitney-Roth edition in the footnote. Also in prÃ¡ ÄÅ›Ä«Ì3á¸¥ (AV 11.3.26, 27), the VVRI edition gives the accented reading. In view of the fact that P.8. 2.97 (à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥) which sanctions the pluta vowel also ensures the udÄtta

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾505 accent for the pluta vowel, this reading seems appropriate. In contrast with this, the non-pluta reading for prÃ¡ ÄÅ›Ä«á¸¥ in AV (11.3.28) is unaccented, and, as the PadapÄá¹­ha shows, the accented preverb prÃ¡ is compounded with the unaccented ÄÅ›Ä«á¸¥ in AV (11.3.28). On the other hand, in AV (11.3.26, 27), the accented preverb prÃ¡ is not compounded with the accented pluta form ÄÅ›Ä«Ì3á¸¥. It is in the process of becoming pluta that the vowel also becomes ac- cented. PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rules for pluta and its accent are in the section beginning with P.8.2.82 (à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ), and the convention set by P.8.2.1 (à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥) says that, for rules preceding P.8.2.1, the results of rules coming afterwards are treated as if not effected (asiddha), and that even among the rules which follow P.8.2.1, any given rule does not recognize the following rules and their results. The words siddha and asiddha are crucial in this context, and perhaps the CA is alluding to some such distinction. The CA seems to be saying that, in the context of compounding with the pre-verb, the accent of the pluta vowel is to be treated as a fully valid result. In both the examples cited under this rule, the pre-verbs are accented, as well as the verbs, and hence there is no compounding. The PadapÄá¹­ha generally does not have a compound-expression with two udÄtta syllables in it. This is probably what goes against the compounding in the present case, and this is also probably why the rule uses à¤ªà¥à¤²à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ as a reason. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯. à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (4.7). B, D, J, M: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ. I: 48. The numbering in I indi- cates that the earlier verses were considered to be part of the text of the CA. Perhaps, the verses were broken down into multiple rules in some text-tradi- tions. Translation: [In the PadapÄá¹­ha], there is separation with an avagraha [i.e. pause marking the separation of a member of a compound-expression, as contrasted with virÄma or a pause marking the separation of independent words,] of the first [of the many preverbs from the rest, which are left joined to the verb]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤£ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤½à¤…à¤µà¥ˆà¥‘à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥«à¥©, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤…à¤µà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¬.à¥«à¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 506 à¥§à¥§.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤†à¤šà¤¿à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤·à¥à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¸à¤‚à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤¹à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§. à¥§.à¥©à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤½à¤¸à¤‚à¥’à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥ª.à¥«à¥¦)à¥¤ Note: Whitney observes: â€œThe avagraha, or pause of separation between the two parts of a compound word, is defined by two of the PrÄti- Å›Äkhyas (as has been already remarked, in the note following iii. 74 = CA 3.3.25) as having the length of a mora. From here to the end of section II (rule 72 = CA 4.2.26), the treatise is occupied with rules for its employment or omission. And, in the first place, with however many propositions a verbal form may be compounded, it is always the first of them that is separated from the rest of the compound by avagraha.â€ Rule CA (3.3.35: à¤‹à¤—à¤°à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤šà¤ªà¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒ- à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤ƒ), also says that the avagraha is of one mora duration, but so is the pause between words (padÄnta). See Notes on CA (3.3.19) and CA (3.3.35). Another general principle is that irrespective of the number of members a compound-expression may have, there is only one avagraha. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥¦. à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.8). I: 49. P combines this with the following rule. Translation: In the expression yÄtumÄvat, [the former mem- ber, i.e. yÄtu, is separated from the rest of the members with an avagraha]. Note: Whitney says: â€œIt comes in rather awkwardly here, as only prepositions have been contemplated, thus far in the chapter, as former con- stituents of compounds.â€ However, it is clear that, as an exceptional item, it had to be taken care of somewhere. The assumption seems to be that the word has three members, i.e. yÄtu-mÄ-vat. However, in the PadapÄá¹­ha, only the first item is separated with an avagraha. The CAB also cites another view that -mÄvat is a single affix having the same meaning as -mat. The word yÄtumÄvat appears several times in the RV (1.36.20; 7.1.5; 7.104.23; and 8.49.20), where the PadapÄá¹­ha follows the same division as pre- scribed by our rule. However, perhaps through oversight, Surya Kanta (1981: 546) cites this expression divided as yÄtumÄÌ+vat.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾507 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤½à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥©)à¥¤ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤µ- à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹ à¤®à¤¤à¥(H: à¤¨à¥)à¤ªà¥‹ à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¤®(H: Â°à¤¤à¥à¤¯)à¤ƒ (?)à¥¤ à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥§. à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (4.9). I: 50. Translation: Separation [of the members] by avagraha [takes place in the PadapÄá¹­ha] also for a compound. Note: Whitney says: â€œThe ca in the rule evidently continues the impli- cation simply of avagraha from rule 7 (= CA 4.1.29), and the connection of the text casts upon yÄtumÄvat the suspicion of being an interpolation.â€ While one feels like agreeing with Whitney, one must note that all manuscripts contain the rule yÄtumÄvat, and, therefore, if this is an interpolation, it must be a very an- cient interpolation, certainly predating the composition of the CAB. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤š à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤ªà¥‘à¤½- à¤¹à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥§.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤½à¤§à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥‚à¤°à¤¿à¥‘à¤½- à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥­.à¥¬à¥¨.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥¨. à¤‰à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¥¤ Whitney (4.10). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: When [a pre-existing compound is expanded with a] newly added [member], the latter [i.e. newly added member, is separated with an avagraha, and not the members of the old compound].

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 508 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤¾ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾à¤½à¤ªà¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾-à¤ªà¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤½à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥¬.à¥§à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: As Whitney explains: â€œThe word prajÄ is itself divisible as a compound - thus, pra-jÄ (e.g. vii.35.3); upon farther adding pati, the former division is given up in favor of that between the old compound and its added member, and we have prajÄ-pati (e.g. ii.34.4); and a similar addition and re- moval of the pause of separation gives us prajÄpati-srÌ¥á¹£á¹­aá¸¥ : while we might have, did the words occur, the yet farther change prajÄpatisrÌ¥á¹£á¹­aá¸¥-iva, or prajÄpatisrÌ¥á¹£á¹­i-bhiá¸¥, and prajÄpatisrÌ¥á¹£á¹­ibhiá¸¥-iva. In no compound is the separation by avagraha made at more than one point, and it is always the member last ap- pended which is entitled to separation.â€ This rule presents a very important observation as regards the division of compounds. It implicitly recognizes that certain compounds are already in use and are fully entrenched in the language, and then other members are added to them. Thus, one should not assume that a compound with three members, e.g. ABC, could be split in all sorts of possible ways. One must take into account which members are entrenched in the usage. Otherwise, one could possibly argue that pra has been added to a prior compound jÄpati. This is unacceptable, because no expression like jÄpati is in use. On the other hand, the expression prajÄ is in use. Thus, the practice of separating compounds by avagraha provides us significant insight into how the ancient grammarians looked at the relation of the linguistic usage and the grammatical theory. Com- pare P.2.1.4 (à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¾), which, with the continuation of sup from P.2.1.2, lays down the general principle that, at a time, only one noun is compounded with another noun. Thus, generally, a multi-member compound must be succes- sively built through incorporation of prior compounds. This general discus- sion is also taken up by the VÄrttikas (25 ff.) on P.2.1.1, MB (Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., pp. 372-3. For a detailed discussion, see: S.J. Joshi (1968: 168-208). It may be noted that the grammarians did not bother themselves with the ques- tion of avagraha, and that dimension was left for the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥©. à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (4.11). A, B, D, H, M: à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤š.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾509 Translation: Also in the expression suprÄvyÄ (AV 4.30.6), [the last member is separated with an avagraha]. Note: As Whitney says: â€œIn the word specified the last member is separated from the rest of the compound, and not the first, as would be more in accordance with the general analogies of the system of separation.â€ Normally, with a verbal noun with two preverbs, the first preverb is separated with an avagraha, cf. CA 4.1.7 and the Note on this rule. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤¾ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤½à¤…à¥’à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤œà¥‘à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤µà¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ [à¤¸à¥]à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥ˆà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: For the expression á¹­ÄÅ›abdaá¸¥ in the verse, Whitney proposes the emendation yaÅ›abdaá¸¥. However, the expression á¹­Ä here refers to the instru- mental singular affix in the PÄá¹‡inian tradition, cf. PÄá¹‡ini 4.1.2. Thus, this tra- dition looks at the word suprÄvyÄ as a feminine instrumental singular from the base suprÄvÄ«. Whitney mistakenly interprets the verse as suggesting a deriva- tion with the desiderative suffix yÄ, but then says: â€œSuch an explanation, of course, would be futile, being sufficiently disproved by the accent alone.â€ As is clear, the verse does not propose such an interpretation in the first place. SÄyaá¹‡a offers the reading suprÄvye, perhaps under the influence of RV (10.125.2). The same reading is recorded by some AV manuscripts as noted in the VVRI edition. This perhaps shows the increasing influence from the RV tradition upon that of the AV in the post-CA period. For further dis- cussion of the RV and the AV readings, see Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 201). Also note that the RV PadapÄá¹­ha separates members of this word in the same way as taught by this rule, and it may be that the exceptional character of this division is influenced by the RV tradition. The word suprÄvÄ« appears several times in the RV (1.34.4, 1.60.1, 1.83.1, 2.13.9, and 4.26.5), and in each case the word is split as supra-avÄ« in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The word duá¹£prÄvÄ« also appears in RV (4.25.6) and it is split in an analogous way in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The word prÄvÄ« also appears in the RV (4.9.2), where the PadapÄá¹­ha splits its as pra-avÄ«.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 510 The exceptional division of the word in the PadapÄá¹­ha may imply that, somehow, the words su and dus were not deemed by the author of the PadapÄá¹­ha as modifying the whole compound prÄvÄ«, but just the portion pra in it. This is analogous to the use of the adverb â€˜veryâ€™ in English in a phrase like a very good person. Here, very goes with good, rather than with person. However, the presence of the compound prÄvÄ«, and the absence of just supra or duá¹£pra made it seem like, the normal avagraha may have been like su-prÄvÄ« or duá¸¥-prÄvÄ«. Since this was not the case, a separate rule to note the exception had to be given. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥ª. à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¥¤ Whitney (4.12). I: Â°à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤¯à¥‡Â°. O: Â°à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£Â°. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: When [the new compounding is with an indi- visible item], the old [member is separated with an avagraha]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·- à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¥‡ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤—à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¤½à¤¸à¥‚à¥‘à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¯à¥­.à¥¬, VVRI edn.: à¥­. à¥§à¥¦à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤½à¤…à¥‘à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥«.à¥©à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¤(H: à¤¸à¥‚)à¤¤à¥à¤° … à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Here, the assumption seems to be that the original compound- ing in the form suká¹£etriyÄ is with su+ká¹£etri, to which the new member yÄ is added. However, this new member yÄ being inseparable, the separation with an avagraha is carried out with the old member su. This is the same logic with the example sugÄtuyÄ. CA (4.1.52) and the CAB on it specify that the separa- tion with yÄ occurs only in five forms, and nowhere else. See the CAB on CA (4.1.52):

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾511 à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤…à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥à¤¨(H: à¤ªà¥à¤¤)à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤½à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥’à¤½à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥­.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥’(H: à¤ªà¥à¤¤)à¤½à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤§à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Thus, while we agree with Whitney that yÄ is not a universally aniá¹…gya affix, he fails to take due notice of the fact that it is divisible only in the five forms cited above, and nowhere else. This is what makes the two cited cases su-ká¹£etriyÄ and su-gÄtuyÄ proper examples. However, the situation with the three additional examples offered by the CAB is different. Why are the compounds sÄÌntardeÅ›Äá¸¥, sahÃ¡sÅ«ktavÄkaá¸¥, and suprajÄÌá¸¥ offered as examples of this rule? The CAB seems to assume that the original compound is sÄntar, which is then connected to an indivisible deÅ›a. Similarly, it seems to assume that sahasÅ«kta is an original compound, which is subsequently compounded with an indivisible vÄkaá¸¥. Finally, it assumes that supra is the original compound, which is subsequently compounded with an indivisible ja. Such assumptions are difficult to comprehend. We must agree with Whitney: â€œI do not see how this statement can be accepted as a correct one; for, of the compounds consisting of more than two members, the last is even more often separated from the first two than the first from the last two.â€ My own guess is that the original CA rule applies appropriately to su- ká¹£etriyÄÌ and su-gÄtuyÄÌ. However, the CAB has mixed up several unrelated rules and their examples. The first two examples are not there in the text of the cited verses, and the verses seem to refer to a slightly different doctrine: â€œWhere there are two possible places for separation, an earlier one and a later one, the separation takes place with the earlier one. This is illustrated by su- ká¹£etriyÄÌ, sÃ¡-antardeÅ›Äá¸¥, and su-prajÄÌá¸¥.â€ This doctrine has nothing to do with the present rule, and thus the confusion. Here, the words pÅ«rva and para are used in spacial sense, rather than in temporal order in which the compound develops. The disparate nature of these examples is also indicated by the fact that the APR accounts for them in diverse ways. APR (122, p. 83) reads: à¤¸à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡- à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤£. There is separation of the upasarga su with an avagraha. As ex- amples are offered su-ká¹£etriyÄÌ and su-gÄtuyÄÌ from AV (4.33.2). One suspects that su-prajÄÌá¸¥ (AV 4.11.3) would be accounted for by the same rule. The ex- ample sÃ¡-antardeÅ›Äá¸¥ (AV 9.5.37) is accounted for under APR (128-129, p. 90) which says that sÃ¡-, the reduced form of sahÃ¡, is separated with an avagraha. Also see CA (4.1.10) for a different explanation for sahÃ¡-sÅ«ktavÄkaá¸¥ and sÃ¡-

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 512 antardeÅ›Äá¸¥. The only reason the CAB was able to bring all these examples to- gether is that in all these the separation with an avagraha takes place with the first item. This surface similarity, in addition to the word pÅ«rveá¹‡a in the CA rule and in the cited verse, seems to have led the CAB to bring all these examples together. They could all come together under the rule as phrased in the cited verse, but not under the rule as phrased in CA (4.1.34). à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥«. à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤§à¤¾ à¥¤ Whitney (4.13). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this as a correction. Also, referring to the added rule in the commentary, Whitney says: â€œvyatyayasvaÅ›raddÄ«rghebhyo dhÄpratyaye na avagraho bhavati; â€˜the suffix dhÄ does not suffer separation after … (?), sva, Å›rat, and a long vowel.â€™ The words svadhÄ and Å›raddhÄ, into which the root dhÄ enters as last member, are here referred to, and perhaps godhÄ (iv.3.6); but to what the first item in the enu- meration refers, I have not succeeded in discovering.â€ The first word, by adding a visarga after it, is nothing but the word vyatyayaá¸¥, which also appears in PataÃ±jaliâ€™s MB (on P.1.4.9, Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., p. 315, etc.) in the sense

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾513 of transposition or deviation. Thus, the cited rule seems to be saying that, in deviation from the normal CA rule, the item dhÄ is not separated after sva, Å›rat, and a long vowel. The words Å›raddhÄ and svadhÄ are not analyzed by the PadapÄá¹­ha. However, this really cannot be an exception to the normal CA rule, since the present CA rule applies only if dhÄ is a taddhita affix. Clearly svadhÄ and Å›raddhÄ are not taddhita formations, but derived from the root dhÄ. For dhÄ coming after a long vowel, Whitney suggests â€œperhaps godhÄ (iv.3.6).â€ A genuine taddhita formation with a long vowel before dhÄ is the word tredhÄÌ (AV 1.12.1) which is not divided by the PadapÄá¹­ha with an avagraha, cf. CA (4.2.20). à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥¬. à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.14). Translation: Also the affix trÄ, when it ends in Ä, [is sepa- rated with an avagraha]. Note: The qualification ÄkÄrÄnte is to distinguish trÄ from the affix tra. While the former is separated with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha, the latter is not. Whitney makes an important observation: â€œDoubtless it is the character of the forms to which tra is attached, as being pronominal roots, that prevents its separation from them, rather than anything in the suffix itself. The ablative suffix tas is not separated, even when it follows a word having an independent status in the language, as in abhitas.â€ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¥’à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¥’à¤£à¥à¥’à¤¹à¤¿à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¥¤ à¤µà¥’(H: à¤®)à¤¨à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ à¤†à¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‘ à¤¦à¥‡à¥’à¤µà¤¾ à¤…à¥’à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’ à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤£à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥­. à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¥¤ Whitney (4.15). à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 514 Translation: The affix thÄ [is separated with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] when [added after a word] of more than one syllable. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¥’à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’à¤•à¥à¤·à¥’à¤¤à¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥§à¥¦.à¥¨à¥¬, VVRI edn.: à¥¯.à¥§à¥«.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¤½à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¸[à¤ƒ] à¥¤ à¤®à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¥’à¤¤à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥®.à¥­, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥§.à¥§à¥¦.à¥­)à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤§à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥¨à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney observes: â€œHere, again, it is evidently not the length of the words to which the suffix is appended, as monosyllables or polysyllables, that determines its separability, but the character of the former as pronominal roots and of the latter as nominal themes.â€ A crucial example to test Whitneyâ€™s assessment might be a word like sarvathÄ. However, it does not appear in the ÅšAV. It appears in PaippalÄda AV (9.10.5), but I have not been able to con- sult the PadapÄá¹­ha for PAV. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥®. à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (4.16). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: Also [the comparative and the superlative af- fixes] -tara and -tama [are separated with an avagraha]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥‹à¤ƒà¥‘ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¥’ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤½à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤½à¤¤à¥’à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¤¿à¥’ à¥¤ à¤“à¤·à¥‘à¤§à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥«.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¥’ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥’à¤¶à¤ƒà¤½à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¯.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¨à¥ƒà¥’à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’à¥¤ à¤­à¤—à¥‘à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤½à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥¯.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’- à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥ª.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥’à¤¤à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥®. à¥¨à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ (à¤¨?) à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾515 â€˜à¤•à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒâ€™à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤¤à¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥€ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥Œ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¥(H: à¤‰) à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥€ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (source?) à¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¥‹ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤—à¥‹(H: à¤—à¥Œ)à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¥’à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¥‘à¤¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¥‚à¤¢à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹ à¤§à¤¾(?) à¤¤à¤®à¥‹à¤½(H: à¤®à¤¾)à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸(H: à¤¸à¥‹à¤®)à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ (?)à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Referring to the counter-examples aÅ›vatarÃ¡sya (AV 4.4.8) and aÅ›vataryÃ á¸¥ (AV 8.8.22), Whitney comments: â€œThe citation of these words in this manner, as if they were excluded by the very form of the rule itself from falling under its operation, suggests as the true reading and interpretation of the rule taratamapoá¸¥, â€˜tara and tama when unaccented,â€™ giving to the indicatory letter p the same force which it has as appended to the same suffixes by PÄá¹‡ini (e.g. v.3.55, 57). My copy of the manuscript, indeed, gives m everywhere taratamayoá¸¥; but, considering the small difference between y and p when hast- ily formed, I cannot be confident that the Hindu scribe did not mean to write the latter.â€ Now that we have a large number of manuscripts, Whitneyâ€™s ex- pectation is not supported. My guess is that the commentator, in asking the question à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥, means to suggest that by juxtaposing the affixes tara and tama in this fashion, the rule naturally makes it clear that these words refer to comparative and superlative affixes, and not to just any homophonic affixes. Such an infer- ence excludes aÅ›vatarÃ¡sya etc., since the affix -tara in this example does not have the meaning of the comparative affix. Then, the commentator takes up the question as to why there is no separation in the forms katarÃ¡ and katamÃ¡, yatarÃ¡ and yatamÃ¡. This is answered by saying that these are not the affixes -tara and -tama, but a different set of affixes, i.e. -atara and -atama. The verse cited after this says that when an affix like -atara is added, only the initial consonant of the base remains, the rest is deleted, i.e. yat+atara > y+atara > yatara.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 516 Commenting on this discussion, Whitney remarks: â€œThis distinction of the suffixes as applied to pronominal roots from those applied to other themes is evidently artificial and false. The difference is that the roots themselves are not, like derivative themes, detachable from the suffixes appended to them - as we have seen to be the case under the two preceding rules.â€ Whitney does not note that the commentator is following a standard method, also found in PÄá¹‡i- nian grammar, where these special suffixes are given with a special marker á¸Œ, i.e. á¸ŒataraC and á¸ŒatamaC, and by the force of this marker á¸Œ, the final portion of the base beginning with its final vowel (= á¹¬I) is deleted, cf. P.5.3.92 (à¤•à¤¿à¤‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¡à¤¤à¤°à¤šà¥) and P.5.3.93 (à¤µà¤¾ à¤¬à¤¹à¥‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¡à¤¤à¤®à¤šà¥), P.6.4.143 (à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤ƒ). Thus, PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s procedure is exactly the same as that given by the CAB. Whitney also misses a major distinction. While the comparative and superlative affixes are unaccented affixes, marked with P by PÄá¹‡ini, i.e. -taraP and -tamaP, the affixes in forms like katarÃ¡ and katamÃ¡ are accented affixes, marked with the marker C by PÄá¹‡ini, i.e. á¸ŒataraC and á¸ŒatamaC. Thus, Whitney is not accurate in saying that the distinction of the suffixes as applied to pronominal roots from those applied to other themes is evidently artificial and false. It is a real difference recognized by both PÄá¹‡ini and the CAB. The last verse cited by the commentator refers to words in the sa- mudrÄdigaá¹‡a referred to in CA (4.2.8) and fully listed in APR (217c, examples 59ff). Words in the samudrÄdigaá¹‡a are not separated by an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha. The APR (p. 155) lists gÃ³tamaá¸¥, katarÃ¡á¸¥, katamÃ¡á¸¥, yatarÄÌ, yata- mÃ¡á¸¥, aÅ›vatarÃ¡sya, and aÅ›vataryÃ á¸¥ in the samudÄdi gaá¹‡a, and the verse cited by the CAB seems to make a reference to it. However, a substantial portion of the verse remains unintelligible, unless d is read as: tasmÄn neá¹…gati gotamaá¸¥. As the VVRI edition of the AV shows, a number of manuscripts sup- port the reading gautamam for AV (4.29.6). The manuscript H may have de- rived this reading from this tradition. However, looking at the context of the discussion, the reading intended by the CAB must be gotamam. The verse in the commentary points out that the affix -tama in the word gÃ³tama is not in the superlative sense (anatiÅ›Äyane), and therefore it is not analyzed in the PadapÄá¹­ha. For a discussion of the example AV (1.34.4), see the note on CA (2.1. 5). à¥ª.à¥§.à¥©à¥¯. à¤®à¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (4.17). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾517 Translation: Before the affix matU, [the base is separated in the PadapÄá¹­ha with an avagraha]. P.5.2.94 (à¤¤à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥). à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤®à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤§à¥à¥‘à¤½à¤®à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥‹à¤½à¤®à¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥©.à¥¬à¥§)à¥¤ à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥¦. à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (4.18). Translation: Also before a v-initial [taddhita affix, the base is separated with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤ƒà¥’ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤®à¥’à¤¯à¤ƒà¥’ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¿à¥’ à¥¤ à¤•à¥’à¤£à¥à¤µà¥’à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¥’à¤®à¥’- à¤¦à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤…. à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥©à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‹à¥’à¤¤à¤½à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥©à¥¬.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤½à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§, à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¬à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤à¥à¤œà¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤µà¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥‡à¥’à¤¶à¥’à¤½à¤µ[à¤¾]à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬. à¥¨à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (?)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®à¥â€™(H: à¤µà¤¸) (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¥’à¤½à¤µà¥’à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥¬.à¥¨à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥‚à¥‘à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯)à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤ƒ(H: à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹) à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¥‹ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¥’à¤µà¤¯à¤ƒà¥‘ à¥¤ (H: à¤¹à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ) à¤µà¤¿à¤½à¤¬à¥‘à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤­à¥’à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥«.à¥¯)à¥¤ â€˜à¤†à¤®à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥€â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‡à¤–à¤²à¤¾à¤µà¥€â€™ à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥‡à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¥€â€™ à¥¤ Note: Referring to the examples mÄÌrta-vatsam, Ä-vayÃ¡m, and vÄÌdhÅ«- yam, Whitney says: â€œHe must have been nodding when he added the last three words, of which the third has no suffix beginning with v, and the two others

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 518 are not formed by suffixes, but by composition.â€ Also see Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 498). As for mÄÌrtavatsam, it is clear that there is no taddhita affix beginning with v, though clearly the word is a secondary taddhita forma- tion from an original mrÌ¥tavatsa. Contrast with Ä-vayÃ¡m (AV 8.6.26), the indi- visible example ÄÌvayaá¸¥ (AV 6.16.2). Both of these are specifically mentioned in the APR (217g, p. 158) precisely in the same context. Thus, the examples of the CAB are appropriate as far as their divisibility is concerned, though their grammatical characterizations are not always accurate. Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 255) notes that â€œthe pada-text does not divide druvÃ¡yaá¸¥, but the case is quoted in the comment to PrÄt. iv.18 (= CA 4.1.40) as an exceptional one, vaya being regarded as a suffix added to dru.â€ However, we should note that the expression druvÃ¡yaá¸¥ is not listed by the APR in its samudrÄdi-gaá¹‡a, a list of indivisible words, and hence there is room to speculate whether it was divisible for the APR. Referring to two more examples in the commentary, Whitney says: â€œIt is curious that both Ä-vayam and mÄrta-vatsam are quoted in the commentary to PrÄt. iv.18 (= CA 4.1.40), as if their second member were a taddhita beginning with v.â€ To recognize that the APR and the CAB are genetically linked, we should note that the unattested examples ÄmayÄvÄ«, mekhalÄvÄ«, medhÄvÄ« quoted by the CAB are also found in APR (p. 156) which lists words whose members are inseparable. The CAB tries to cover these examples with an exception rule, while the APR tries to cover these examples by incorporating them in the samudrÄdigaá¹‡a, a list of indivisible words. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥§. à¤¶à¤¸à¤¿ à¤µà¥€à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.19). I: 60. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: Also before the affix Å›as, in the distributive meaning, [the base is separated with an avagraha in the Pada- pÄá¹­ha]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¶à¤¸à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤µà¥€à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤½à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¥’à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤à¥’à¤¨à¥’à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤§à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥’à¤½à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤°à¥‡à¥’à¤œà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤½à¤•à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤½à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤µà¥€à¤ªà¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¥’à¤¶à¤ƒâ€™

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾519 (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥®à¥¨.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤•à¥€à¥’à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥­. à¥«)à¥¤ Note: Whitney remarks with respect to the counter-examples in the CAB : â€œcases which it was very unnecessary to cite, since their suffix, if they have one, is Å›a, not Å›as.â€ However, one may point out that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya may be looking at a more basic surface level, where the expressions end in Å›aá¸¥. The citation kÄ«nÄÌÅ›Äá¸¥ is probably suggestive of the singular form kÄ«nÄÅ›aá¸¥ which ends in Å›aá¸¥. It may be noted that the APR (p. 139) mentions aá¹…kuÅ›Ã¡á¸¥ in its samu- drÄdigaá¹‡a, a list of indivisible words, but not kÄ«nÄÌÅ›Äá¸¥. This leaves open a possibility that the APR knew kÄ«nÄÌÅ›Äá¸¥ as a divisible word. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥ªà¥¨. à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (4.20). E, F, I, O: à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤¯à¥‡. A, B, C, D: à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤¿à¤²à¤¿. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: Also before the affix tÄtiL, [the base is sepa- rated with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha]. Note: PÄá¹‡iniâ€™s rule 4.4.142 (à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¥) prescribes the affix tÄtiL, and interestingly, the CA seems to cite this affix along with its marker L, which indicates that the syllable preceding the suffix is udÄtta, cf.
