Translation: In the expressions vasudhÄtara and sahasra- sÄtama, [separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha is made] after vasu and sahasra respectively. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾- à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥­.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤½à¥’à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤­à¥’à¤µà¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥®.à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤·à¤·à¥à¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ à¤µà¤¸à¥‚à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¥’à¤¸à¥à¥’à¤½à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‘à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾543 â€˜à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¾(H: à¤¸à¤¨à¤¿, Whitney: à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¾)à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤•à¥ƒà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤·à¤·à¥à¤ à¥€à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Whitney says: â€œIt is not without reason that the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya takes note of these cases; for, since the suffixes tara and tama are separable (by iv. 16 = CA 4.1.38), and are plainly the last added members, the words they form should read, in pada, vasudhÄ-tara and sahasrasÄ-tama.â€ Whitney understands the commentary as offering the first alternative that the word vasudhÄÌtaraá¸¥ as â€œthe plural of vasu-dhÄtar.â€ If indeed such were the case, there would be nothing exceptional about the separation of this com- pound as vasu-dhÄtaraá¸¥. Whitney responds to this interpretation: â€œIt would be, in fact, in its Atharvan connection, much more easily interpretable in this man- ner, but that the accent speaks strongly for the other mode of derivation.â€ It is, however, not certain from the wording of the commentary that it is proposing a derivation from vasudhÄtrÌ¥-. The commentary simply says that it is a genitive compound. However, the cited verse relates this notion of a genitive com- pound with the explanation: dhÄ+taraá¸¥, then vasÅ«naá¹ƒ dhÄ+taraá¸¥. The commentary gives as the second alternative, the derivation vasudhÄ+tara. The first part vasudhÄ is explained as vasÅ«ni vÄ dadhÄti, an agentive root-noun. Whitney was not able to interpret the verse properly, since he mis- understood it as saying â€œafter sÄ and dhÄ (?), as krÌ¥t -endings.â€ The verse says that the words sÄ and dhÄ are krÌ¥dantas, i.e. these words end in krÌ¥t-affixes, and not that they are themselves krÌ¥t endings. Then the taddhita affixes -tara and - tama are added after these krÌ¥danta formations, yielding dhÄtaraá¸¥ and sÄtamaá¸¥. The words vasu and sahasra are then compounded with these in genitive Tat- puruá¹£as. The tradition thus looks at the words dhÄ and sÄ as agentive root- nouns, with zero-affixes such as VIC or VIá¹¬, which turn a root into an agen- tive noun. For the PÄá¹‡inian derivation of sÄ in sahasrasÄÌtamÄ, see: à¤·à¤£à¥ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¥¤ â€˜à¤œà¤¨- à¤¸à¤¨à¤–à¤¨à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤—à¤®à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥©.à¥¨.à¥¬à¥­) à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥¬.à¥ª.à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤†à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤ªà¥ à¥¤, SÄyaá¹‡a on AV (3.28.4). For example, the word viÅ›vapÄ is explained as: à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‡ â€˜à¤ªà¤¾ à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡â€™ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€˜à¤†à¤¤à¥‹à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ …â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥©.à¥¨.à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤‚ à¤¬à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ â€˜à¤†à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¥à¤µ- à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤šâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥©.à¥¨.à¥­à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¿ â€˜à¤†à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¥ …â€™

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥§ 544 à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¥, à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ â€˜à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¾.à¥©.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¤ƒ, Tattva- bodhinÄ« on SK on P.6.3.110, p. 56. The traditional explanation for vasudhÄ would be similar. For AV (3.28.4), Whitney records a different accent for the word à¤¸à¥’à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‘- à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤¾. This variant is noted by the VVRI edition, but I have followed the reading as recorded by the VVRI edition. Whitney (AV Transl. Vol.I., p. 135) says: â€œAll the manuscripts agree in giving the false accent sahÃ¡srasÄtamÄ in b; it should be sahasra-sÄÌtamÄ — or to rectify the meter, simply -sÄÌ.â€ The VVRI edition, without specifying the reason, seems to have followed Whitneyâ€™s sug- gested change in giving the reading sahasrasÄÌtamÄ, though it notes the original manuscript reading (= mÅ«lakoÅ›a) sahÃ¡sra-sÄtamÄ as a variant. à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¬à¥®. à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.46). E, F, I, O: Â°à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡. Translation: [In the expression] subhiá¹£aktama, [there is separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] before [the affix] -tama. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¥‘à¤·à¤•à¥à¤½à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™(à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥¨à¥ª.à¥¨)à¥¤ à¤¶à¥‹à¤­à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¤•à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¤•à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¤œà¤¾ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤‚à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹[à¤ƒ] à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Whitney translates the cited verse as: â€œhere su is compounded with the masculine bhiá¹£aj, and tama is farther appended : separation by ava- graha is made of the latter.â€ Whitney criticizes the formulation of this rule: â€œI can see no reason at all for any such rule as this : the case specified is simply one in which the sepa- ration by avagraha takes place normally, according to the general rules, and a score more of precisely similar cases might easily be quoted from the Atharvan text: instances are bhÃ¡gavat-tama (ii.9.2) and bhÃ¡gavat-tara (iv.13.6), sphÄtimat- tama (iii.24.6), mrÌ¥tÃ¡manaá¸¥-tara (vi.18.2), and vrÌ¥trahÃ¡n-tama (vii.110.1).â€

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾545 Whitneyâ€™s criticism is not justified in view of the fact that the expres- sion bhiá¹£Ã¡k-tarÄá¸¥, without the initial su, is attested in AV (19.2.3), leading one to think of the possibility of first having the expression bhiá¹£ak-tama and then compounding it with su. In such a case, the juncture of su with bhiá¹£aktama being the most recent juncture, the avagraha would fall between su and bhiá¹£aktama. Such an understanding of this compound is further strengthened by the fact that the expression bhiá¹£Ã¡ktamam without su also appears in bhiá¹£Ã¡ktamaá¹ƒ tvÄ bhiá¹£Ã¡jÄá¹ƒ Å›rÌ¥á¹‡omi (RV 2.33.4), which is comparable to bhiá¹£Ã¡jÄá¹ƒ sÃºbhiá¹£ak- tamÄá¸¥ (AV 6In contrast with this, the expression subhiá¹£aj by itself is not attested in the Vedic Saá¹ƒhitÄs. The CA rule is most likely based on such an understanding of the com- pound, and then stating the exceptional behavior of the avagraha. On the other hand, the cited verse normalizes the avagraha by suggesting that su is com- pounded with bhiá¹£ak, and that tama is added to subhiá¹£ak. On such an under- standing of the derivation, the avagraha becomes normal, and does not require a special rule. à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ H: à¥¥à¥ªà¥­à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ. E, F: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. A, B, C, D, J, M, P: à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. I: à¥¥à¥¯à¥®à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. O: à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¯ à¥¥. Notice the difference between the number of rules for this PÄda given by H (47), I (98), and O (99). This is an indication of two textual traditions, one with the initial verses, and the one without. However, the majority of the manuscripts supports inclusion of these verses in the text of the CA. One may conjecture that the inclusion of the verses was explicitly done first by the manuscripts of the KautsavyÄkaraá¹‡a, as evidenced by the number of rules recorded in I and O. However, the verses are physically present in all the manuscripts, even though not counted in the number of rules, cf. H (47). Thus, they must have been pre- sent in the archetype reconstructible on the basis of the existing manuscripts. However, given the abnormal length of this PÄda, it seems unlikely that the ini- tial portion was part of the â€˜originalâ€™ CA. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¥¥à¥ªà¥­à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ _________________________________

à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§. à¤¨ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.47). B, D: Â°à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡. J, M, P(orig): à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚Â°. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: After [words ending in] t and s, there is no [separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] before [an affix] in the sense of [the affix] matU [i.e. a possessive affix]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¨ à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¥‘â€™(H adds: à¤®à¥) (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤—à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¬.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¨à¥â€™(à¤ªà¤¦, H: à¤¤à¥) (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦à¥ª.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤œà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ, à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥¬à¥¦.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥«)à¥¤ â€˜à¤Šà¤°à¥à¤œà¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¯à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥§à¥¦. à¥§)à¥¤ Note: While the commentary does not provide counter-examples, Whitney provides them: Äsan-vat (AV vi.12.2), asthan-vantam (AV ix.9.4), and brahmaá¹‡-vatÄ«m (AV vi.108.2). These expressions are split with an ava- graha in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Whitney points out: â€œThe only consonants other than t and s which are found to occur before the suffix vant are n and á¹‡, which allow separation. … The rule is an exception under rule 17 (= CA 4.1.39) above.â€ It is also an exception to CA (4.1.40). The expression matvartha implies that matU was looked as a proto- typical possessive affix. Indeed, the possessive affix vat is derived by PÄá¹‡ini by changing the m of matUP, cf. P.8.2.9 (à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤§à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾547 à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¨. à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤¤à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (4.48). Ha: Â°à¤®à¤¤à¥Œ. Hc, J, M, P: Â°à¤µà¤‚à¤¤à¥Œ. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: After yat, tat, and etat, [there is no separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha], before vatU. Note: While prohibiting the separation of vat, the rule informs us that forms like yÄvat are derived by adding the affix vat to yat etc., cf. P.5.2.39 (à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥). This rule is an exception to CA (4.1.40). PÄá¹‡ini 6.3.91 (à¤† à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ) prescribes the replacement of the final sound of a pronoun with Ä before the affixes drÌ¥k, drÌ¥Å›, and vatU, e.g. yad+vat > ya+Ä+vat > yÄvat. However, there were other grammarians who prescribed the affix á¸ŒÄvatU, which led to the deletion of the final portion of the pronoun beginning with the final vowel, yad+á¸ŒÄvatU > y+á¸ŒÄvatU > y+Ävat > yÄvat, cf. VÄrttika : à¤¡à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ …, on P.5.2.39. Referring to this VÄrttika, the TattvabodhinÄ« points out: à¤‡à¤¹ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¡à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¥‡, on SK on P.5.2.39, p. 298. The CA procedure is more like that of PÄá¹‡ini. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¤à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤š à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¥’ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤­à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤½à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤®à¤¿â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥©à¥©)à¥¤ à¤¯(H: à¤¾à¤µ)à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤(H: à¤¾à¤µ)à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥’à¤®à¥à¤½à¤à¤¤à¥à¥‘à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¨.à¥«)à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥’à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¥‘à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥§.à¥®)à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤½à¤µà¤¤à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤ªà¤¾à¥’à¤·à¥à¤ à¤½à¤µà¥‘à¤¤à¥â€™ (H: à¤…à¤ªà¤¾à¤½à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¤¤à¥) (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥¨à¥¯)à¥¤ Note: The reason for prohibition here seems to be sandeha â€˜doubtâ€™ as to the exact shape of the base, after which the separation is to take effect, cf. CA 4.2.5 (à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥) below. Referring to the counter-examples cited by the CAB, Whitney remarks that these are â€œhardly called for.â€ I assume Whitney means that the rule is so obvious, there is no need for counter-examples, and not that there is anything

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 548 wrong with these counter-examples. The avagraha in the counter-examples is effected by CA 4.1.40 (à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤š). The present rule is an exception to that rule. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥©. à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (4.49). Translation: Also, [no separation of members with an ava- graha takes place] in a copulative compound of divinity-names. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤šà¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥«.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¯à¥‚â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¥’à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤°à¥à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥Œâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤¶à¤°à¥à¤µà¥Œâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥¨à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤°à¥à¤œà¥’à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¦.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¬)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤·à¥‹à¤®à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥®.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤®à¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¥à¥‘à¤£à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥ª.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥«à¥®.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¥‘à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥®.à¥ª.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¹ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯(Whitney adds: à¤¦à¤¿?) à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ (H: à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥, W: à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥) à¤ªà¤¦à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤·à¥‹à¤®à¥Œ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥®.à¥¨) à¤¨à¤¿(H: à¤¤à¤¿)à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶[à¤¨à¤®à¥] à¥¥ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½- à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¾à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’(H: à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾, W: à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾)à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥©.à¥¨) à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¯.à¥¯.à¥§à¥¨) à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¹(à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¹?) à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¨ à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾549 à¤†à¤¨à¤™à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ (à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥¬) à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨(H: à¤¤, W: à¤¨) à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿(H: à¤¨)à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥(?) à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Referring to the cited verses, Whitney says: â€œA number of verses follow in the commentary, in the usual corrupt condition of the text : devatÄnÄm iha dvandve dÄ«rghatvaá¹ƒ yati drÌ¥Å›yate : aniá¹…gyaá¹ƒ tat padaá¹ƒ vÄcyam agnÄ«á¹£omau nidarÅ›anam : thus much is clear, and is a virtual repetition of our rule, but with a restriction to cases in which a long vowel appears at the end of the first member of the compound, which requires a specification farther on of the single exception indravÄyÅ«; what follows is more obscure, and I have not been able, with what time I have given to it, to restore the text to an intelligible form.â€ I think we can now make better sense of most, if not all, of these verses. The second verse says that, if, as stated in the first verse, a deva- tÄdvandva that has a long vowel is not divisible, then how come the compound devÄsurÄÌá¸¥ (AV 6.141.3) is divisible in the PadapÄá¹­ha as deva-asurÄÌá¸¥? Here, the long vowel is due to the merger of the two words, and not due to lengthening of the final vowel of deva. This is similar to the compound satyÄnrÌ¥tÃ© (AV 1.33.2), which is divisible in the PadapÄá¹­ha as satya-anrÌ¥tÃ©. On the face of it, the line discussing the expression brÃ¡hma prajÄÌpatiá¸¥ (AV 19.9.12) is unclear. It seems to say that this is never separated. How- ever, the available PadapÄá¹­ha reads: brÃ¡hma / prajÄÌ-patiá¸¥. However, note that KÄtyÄyana in his VÄrttika : à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š on P.6.3.25 (à¤†à¤¨à¤™à¥ à¤‹à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡) says that in the dvandva compound brahmaprajÄpatÄ«, one does not have ÄnAá¹„ for the final vowel of the first member. Thus expression à¤†à¤¨à¤™à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¤ƒ à¤š in our verses is not difficult to comprehend. The present verse seems to say that in a compound like brahmaprajÄpatÄ«, there is no separation. The dvandva com- pound brahmaprajÄpatÄ«Ì is not attested in AV. It is, however, attested in the TaittirÄ«ya-Ä€raá¹‡yaka (4.1.1). The line à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ is comparable to KÄtyÄyanaâ€™s Vt. à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¤ƒ on P.6.3.26 (à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤š), which says that neither is the word vÄyu as a first member of a devatÄdvandva lengthened, nor is another word, before vÄyu is lengthened, e.g. vÄyvagnÄ«, agnivÄyÅ«. The AV example of

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 550 this phenomenon is indravÄyÅ«Ì (AV 3.20.6) which is not divided in the PadapÄá¹­ha, even though there is no lengthening. The last verse is somewhat unclear. It seems to be saying that this pro- hibition of avagraha should apply to all dvandvas, and an example of this would be ahorÄtre (AV 6.128.3). See CA (4.2.6) below. In view of the fact that CA (4.2.4) below specifically relates to those dvandvas where the first member has its final vowel lengthened, the proper examples for the present rule can only be compounds like indravÄyÅ«Ì (AV 3.20. 6), where we do not have lengthening of the final vowel of the first member. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥ª. à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (4.50). Translation: [There is no separation of members of a dvan- dva compound with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] where [the final vowel of the first member is] lengthened, before the consonant-initial second member. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¥’à¤ªà¥‚à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§à¥¨. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¤¿à¥’à¤¤à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥Œâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥§à¥¨.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¹à¥’à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤®à¥à¥’à¤¦à¥Œâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥ªà¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¥’à¤µà¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨.à¥§. à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¥‘à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¥€â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥§.à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥¬)à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¿(H: à¤®à¤¿)à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥’à¤¨à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘ à¤¸à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥’à¤½à¤…à¥’à¤¨à¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥‡â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¤¡à¤¾(W: à¤°à¤¾?)à¤®à¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Examples cited by the CAB on this rule are found listed under APR (217, pp. 136-7) in the same order. This rule and the commentary on this rule answer some of the ques- tions raised in the verses cited in the commentary on the previous rule. The condition vyaÃ±janÄdau excludes the compound satyÄnrÌ¥tÃ© from being indivisi- ble. Here, the second member, i.e. anrÌ¥ta begins in a vowel, and the lengthening

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾551 in satyÄ- comes about through euphonic combination -a+a-, rather than as lengthening of the final vowel of the first member, before the second member. The verses cited in the commentary on the previous rule also bring up the ex- ample devÄsurÄÌá¸¥ (AV 6.141.3). As far as the verse cited in the commentary on this rule, Whitney has justifiable criticisms. He renders the verse as: â€œAfter irÄ, amÄ«vÄ, and puraá¸¥ [avagraha comes in], for in those cases the vowel is long by nature; but where a short vowel is lengthened, there no division by avagraha takes place.â€ Then, he remarks: â€œThis is a very blundering statement, so far as concerns the in- stances given in the first pÄda: puraá¸¥, of course, could form no copulative compound; amÄ«va forms none such in the Atharvan, and it also, though a femi- nine with a long final vowel, as a separate word, always shortens its final in composition (amÄ«va-cÄtana, e.g. i.28.1; amÄ«va-han, e.g. RV. i.18.2); irÄ, too, is found only in the compound irÄ-ká¹£Ä«rÄ (x.10.6), which is not copulative.â€ Of the three words cited by the verse, for amÄ«vÄ, there is a plausible ex- ample from the PaippalÄda AV (1.10.1): amÄ«vÄyÄtucÄtanam. A variant for this is cited as amÄ«vÄyÄs tu cÄtanam. However, if we accept the reading amÄ«vÄ+yÄtu+cÄtanam, then the first portion, i.e. amÄ«vÄ+yÄtu could be a kind of dvandva referred to by the verse. This reading is rejected by Vishvabandhu, in favor of amÄ«vÄyÄs tu cÄtanam, cf. VVRI Vedic Word Concordance, Saá¹ƒhitÄ Section, Pt.I., p.385, footnote e. However, considering the reference to yÄtu in the same hymn, PAV (1.10.3), there is some reason to support the reading amÄ«vÄ+yÄtu+cÄtanam. For iá¸Ä in the verse, one could possibly point to the compound iá¸Ä+prÄÅ›itrÃ¡ (ÅšB, 2.6.1.33). à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥«. à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.51). Translation: [Members of the word] á¹£oá¸aÅ›in [are not sepa- rated with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha], due to [con-]fusion. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¥€ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µ- à¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤‡à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¥’à¤ªà¥‚à¥’à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤·à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥’à¤¶à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥¯.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤·à¥‹à¥’à¤¡à¥’à¤¶à¥€ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥’à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥’à¤½à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥­.à¥§à¥§, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥§.à¥¯.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 552 Note: Whitney has some important comments on this rule. We agree with his opinion â€œthat the rule reads á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä« in stead of á¹£oá¸aÅ›a is surprising, since both words (each in but a single passage) occur in the text.â€ On the statement of the rule that the word á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä« is not split because of sandeha, which Whitney translates as â€˜interfusion,â€™ he comments: â€œOr, it may be, â€˜on account of doubtâ€™- that is to say, of doubt as to the form to which the constituents should be restored, their mode of combination being an entirely anomalous one. It is to be observed, however, that our treatise has itself (at i.63 = CA 1.3.1) given special directions as to how á¹£aá¹­ and the following daÅ›a are com- bined together, so that to the student of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya the pada-reading Å›aá¹­- daÅ›a ought to occasion no difficulty.â€ Whitney has pointed his finger at a very important dilemma. In stead of saying that there is behavioral contradiction, however, one may understand the situation somewhat differently. It is difficult to say that the rules given in this or any other PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya were actually the ones followed by the creators of the PadapÄá¹­has. The PrÄtiÅ›Äkhyas, on the other hand, seem to take the existence of the PadapÄá¹­ha for granted, and then try to account for it. This being the case, the author of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya was ob- ligated to observe that the word á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä« was not divided in the PadapÄá¹­ha, and the expression sandehÄt refers to his own rationalization as to why the Pada- pÄá¹­ha did not divide this word. On the other hand, the rule CA 1.3.1 is almost a rule of word-derivation, showing the leanings of the author of the PrÄti- Å›Äkhya in the direction of general grammatical theory. Whitney himself has given ample proof of such leanings on the part of this text, which go well beyond the narrow scope of a PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya. The notion of sandeha as a cause for non-separation is also found in APR (217a, p. 134): à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡. The examples of this rule are also found in APR (p.137). Also cf. VPR (5.34: à¤ªà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤¬à¥à¤­à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥) and (5.38: à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥). à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¬. à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.52). P adds a daá¹‡á¸a after this rule as a correction. Translation: [There is no separation of members with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha in the word] ahorÄtra.

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾553 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤¹à¥‹à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¥‹à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¥‘à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‘à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥§à¥¨à¥®.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤¹à¥‹à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ [à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘]à¥¤ à¤‡à¥’à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤®à¤ƒà¥’â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥¬.à¥«)à¥¤ Note: Whitney says: â€œThere is nothing in the character of either ahorÄtre or á¹£oá¸aÅ›a, so far as I can discover, which should withdraw them from the action of rule 50 (= CA 4.2.4), and render their separate mention neces- sary.â€ I feel that Whitney is overlooking here the reason sandehÄt given by the author of the PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya in CA 4.2.5, which most likely continues into this rule. As I see, these are irregular changes. The change of á¹£aá¹­ + daÅ›a to á¹£oá¸aÅ›a is irregular by all counts. Similarly, the behavior of the first member in the compound ahorÄtre is equally irregular, and hence the confusion. The stem form is ahan, which changes to ahar, and, especially in this compound, behaves like ahas. Thus, these cases are indeed more complicated than the cases listed under CA 4.2.4, where we have nothing more than simple lengthening of the final vowel of the first member of the compound. We should note another curious fact. While the APR (217, p. 137) lists ahorÄtrÃ© among its examples of indivisible words, it does not list ahorÄtrÄÌ- bhyÄá¹ƒ. On the other hand, it lists both á¹£oá¸aÅ›am and á¹£oá¸aÅ›Ä«. This makes one wonder whether the expression ahorÄtrÄÌbhyÄm was intended as an indivisible word. However, no editions record any variants. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥­. à¤…à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.53), C, Hcb: Â°à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥. Others: à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥. A, B: à¤…à¤µà¤¤à¤¿Â°. P: Â°à¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚- à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥. Translation: [There is no separation in the PadapÄá¹­ha with an avagraha] for the root aÃ±c, as well as for older junctures [i.e. junctures of older constituents of a compound-expression]. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤…à¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤œà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥ à¤š à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥€à¤ƒà¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥®.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥’à¤¤à¥€à¤šà¥€à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥©.à¥¨à¥­.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥€à¥‘à¤šà¥€à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥§. à¥©à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¤‚à¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ [à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¥’ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘] à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¤¿à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥§à¥©.à¥«)à¥¤

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 554 â€˜à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤­à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿[à¤·à¤¿?]à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‰à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¤°à¤šà¥à¤š(H: à¤œà¤°à¤‚ à¤š) à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯ à¤‹à¤•à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥â€™ (source?) Note: Consider Whitneyâ€™s criticism of the commentary: â€œThe com- mentator ends with a verse which seems to say precisely the opposite of the rule of his text. … â€˜when both members are severally separable, both the newly added and the ancient, separation by avagraha is to be made of the ancient one: an instance is rÌ¥k-sÄmÄbhyÄm.â€™ But this is mere non-sense, as it stands, the word cited being a case where the last-appended element is inseparable, as following a long vowel (see rule 33 = CA 4.1.55, above), and where, there- fore, the division be suffered to remain between the two original constituents of the compound. If the theme of the declension had been rÌ¥k-sÄman, instead of rÌ¥ksÄma, we should have an instrumental dual rÌ¥ksÄma-bhyÄm, which would be a true illustration of the rule. One may conjecture that the last line originally read jare nÄvagrahaá¸¥ kÄrya rÌ¥ksÄmabhyÄá¹ƒ nidarÅ›anam, and that it was amended to its present form by some copyist who knew that the Atharvan read, not rÌ¥ksÄma-bhyÄm, but rÌ¥k-sÄmÄbhyÄm, but who was careless enough to overlook the discordance which he thus introduced between the text and its comment.â€ I do agree with Whitney that there is discord between the rule and the verse as it stands. However, Whitneyâ€™s emendation of the verse and his attrib- uting to the copyist so much of the initiative do not seem appropriate. Perhaps, we do not fully understand the meaning of the expression pratividhye te or pratividhyete in the cited verse. In my view, it is most likely that this is a mis- take for an original pratiá¹£idhyete. Assuming this to be the reading, the verse would mean: â€œWhere the separation is prohibited for both the old and the new members, the separation should be carried out with the old member, for exam- ple in rÌ¥k-sÄmÄbhyÄm.â€ Here, the avagraha is prohibited before -bhyÄm, be- cause it is preceded by a long vowel, and it is prohibited between rÌ¥k and sÄmÄbhyÄm, because it is an old joint. In such a case, the verse says that the avagraha should be done between the old-members. Such an understanding removes the dilemma posed by this verse for Whitney. The first three examples quoted on this rule by the CAB to illustrate the formations with the root aÃ±c are found listed under APR (217, p. 136).

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾555 à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥®. à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¥¤ Whitney (4.54). C: omits à¤š. Translation: [No separation of members with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha occurs] in the words such as samudra. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š …(missing commen- tary)à¥¤ Note: The missing commentary is clearly due to the carelessness of the copyist. However, Whitney unjustly criticizes the commentator: â€œThis, however, gives us reason to believe that the commentator had performed his work in his usual brief and unsatisfactory style, and had done very little toward filling up the gaá¹‡a.â€ I do not see how the copyistâ€™s carelessness can give rea- son to believe such a thing. Invaluable help is offered by the fact that the samudrÄdigaá¹‡a is fully listed in the APR (217c, examples 59ff.). This is a list of words whose seem- ing parts should not be separated in the PadapÄá¹­ha. Given the close relation- ship between the CAB and the APR, there is every reason to believe that the commentator would have cited the first few words from the APR list. For a possible reference to the samudrÄdigaá¹‡a in the CAB, see CA (4.1.38). We must, however, keep in mind that the membership of the sa- mudrÄdigaá¹‡a as intended by the CA must have been somewhat smaller as compared to the list found in the APR, because a large number of cases of in- divisible expressions listed by the APR in the samudrÄdigaá¹‡a are taken care of by the CA with specific rules, cf. CA (4.2.1-7). Since Whitney had no access to the APR edited by Surya Kanta, he made a determined effort on his own to fill out this gaá¹‡a. However, now we have a historically more authentic collection in the APR and we need not dwell upon Whitneyâ€™s collection, except as a reflection of what one finds in the manuscripts of the AV. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¯. à¤µà¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ Whitney (4.55). Hb: à¤µà¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ŒÂ°. D: à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆÂ°. O: à¤µà¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ˆÂ°. P adds a daá¹‡á¸a as a correction after à¤µà¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‡à¤£.

Note: Whitney criticizes the formulation of this rule as follows: â€œThe form of statement which our treatise has adopted for its rule respecting the separability of negative compounds is not particularly well chosen.â€ However, compare the CA rule to APR (220, p.166): à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤®à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤œà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 558 The verse cited by the CAB is clearly a mutilated version of APR (220). The APR (220) itself, in Surya Kantaâ€™s edition reads b: à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¯ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥, which I have emended to à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥. We should also note that all the posi- tive examples of this rule offered by the CAB including the unattested aprajÄtÄá¸¥ are the first few examples of a long list of examples offered by the APR. The APR (p. 167) also illustrates the condition aprayÄvÄdivarjitam with the exam- ples Ã¡pra-yÄvam (AV 3.5.1) and Ã¡pra-yucchan (AV 2.6.3). Whitney also draws our attention to the form Ã¡pra-yucchan. Regarding the indivisible example Ã¡sabandhuá¸¥ (AV 6.15.2), Whitney points out that this word in its occurrence in AV (6.54.3) is divided by his PadapÄá¹­ha manuscript as Ã¡sa-bandhuá¸¥. Whitney says that this is â€œprobably a copyistâ€™s error.â€ The VVRI edition does not even note such a manuscript vari- ant. Concerning the form aprayÄvan in AV (3.5.1), Whitney (AV Transl. Vol. I., p. 91) says: â€œÃprayÄvan in d, which is read by all the mss. (hence by both editions) and the comm. (= SÄyaá¹‡a), is unquestionably to be emended to - yÄvam; the word is quoted in the PrÄt. text (iv.56 = CA 4.2.10), but not in a way o determine its form (aprayÄvÄdi-). … The commentary raises no objection to Ã¡prayÄvan, and explains it as either mÄá¹ƒ vihÄyÄ â€™napagantÄ san (with irregular exchange of case-forms), or else aprayÄtar, i.e. sarvadÄ dhÄryamÄá¹‡a.â€ The manuscript H for the CAB clearly reads aprayÄvan, and, in his CA edition, Whitney also reads aprayÄvan. For Lanmanâ€™s vigorous defense of Whitneyâ€™s emendation to the form Ã¡prayÄvam, see: AV Transl. Vol.II., p. 991. Whitneyâ€™s emendation to aprayÄvam is now supported by the APR (p. 167). à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥§. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Whitney (4.57). A, B, D: first word à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¤¿. A, B: second word à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¤à¤¿. Translation: [There is no separation of components with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] in [the forms] prÄá¹‡ati and prÄá¹‡anti. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥ª.à¥©à¥¦.à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥§.à¥ª.à¥§à¥¦, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥§.à¥¬.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‘ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§.à¥©à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤£à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¥‘â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥©.à¥©.à¥©)à¥¤

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾559 Note: Whitney observes: â€œBut the rule is an exceedingly insufficient exposition of the treatment by the pada-text of the forms of the root an with the prefix pra. Division is, in fact, omitted only when the verb, and not the prepo- sition, has the accent; but then not in the two forms specified only, but also in the participles - as prÄá¹‡Ã¡t (e.g. x.8.2), prÄá¹‡atÃ© (xi.4.8), prÄá¹‡atÃ¡s (iv.2.2), prÄá¹‡atÄÌm (iii.31.9), and prÄá¹‡atÄ«ÌnÄm (viii.9.9) – and in the causative as prÄá¹‡Ã¡yati (xiii.3.3). On the other hand, if the prefix takes the accent, it is disjoined from the verb, according to the general usage in such cases, and we read prÃ¡ : ana (iii.31.9), and prÃ¡ : anati (x.8.19, xi.4.14). If the root is compounded with apa, also, the same usage is followed, and we have apÄnatÃ© (xi.4.8) and Ã¡pa : anati (xi.4.14).â€ The APR (pp. 135-6) takes care of Whitneyâ€™s concerns by provid- ing a much fuller list of finite verb forms and participial forms where the divi- sion does not take place, and is, on the whole, a more adequate accounting of the facts of the Atharvan. One way to soften Whitneyâ€™s criticism is to say that the CA rule applies only to those cases, where prÃ¡ is compounded with the root an, and not where it remains apart as an independent word, due to the retaining of its udÄtta accent. In any case, either the rule should have been more specific, or there should have been a more adequate listing, as in the APR (pp. 135-6). It should be noted that the AV form is prÄá¹‡ati, while the corresponding RV form is prÄá¹‡iti. That is also the form found in the TaittirÄ«ya-BrÄhmaá¹‡a (3.12.6.1). This justifies the wording of the rule: à¤…à¤¨à¤¤à¥Œ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥, CA (4.1.61). Pr. (iii.49, 51), which explains taskara and brÌ¥haspati as from tat-kara and brÌ¥hat-pati re- spectively, with loss of t and insertion of s, and vanaspati as from vana-pati, with the insertion of s; but it is unnecessary to remark that such explanations are futile : taskara is obscure, and the other two are without much doubt com- pounds of pati with the preceding genitive of an obsolete noun, being analo- gous with brÃ¡hmaá¹‡as pÃ¡ti, vÄcÃ¡s pÃ¡ti, Å›ubhÃ¡s pÃ¡ti, etc.; and they would doubt- less be separated by the pada-text into two independent words, like these, but for their frequency of occurrence, and, yet more, the irregularity of the accent of their former members as genitives of a monosyllabic theme.â€ We may additionally note that PÄá¹‡ini derives these forms in an analo- gous way, cf. P.6.1.157 (à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¤‚à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥), and the gaá¹‡asÅ«tra : à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ

à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾561 à¤•à¤°à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‹à¤°à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤Ÿà¥ à¤¤à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤š. Instead of castigating the Indian grammarians for not recognizing the â€˜obsoleteâ€™ genitives, one may recognize that their pro- cedure of viewing these as s-insertions, marks a similar fact, namely that these are not synchronically to be treated as genitives. The PadapÄá¹­ha, the PrÄti- Å›Äkhyas, and PÄá¹‡ini, all treat the classical language as the norm, and the Vedic language as a deviation from that norm, and hence there is great deal to be learned from their works about the synchronic perception of language. The PadapÄá¹­ha for RV (1.186.6) reads à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤ƒà¤½à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¤ƒ, in contrast with the AV PadapÄá¹­ha reading à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤µà¤¿à¤½à¤¤à¥‘à¤®à¤ƒ, suggesting that that tradition did not view the s in the form tuviá¹£á¹­amaá¸¥ as an Ägama, but that it was simply a normal transfor- mation of the visarga. The CA rule and the AV PadapÄá¹­ha imply a different intended derivation for the same word. Also see CA (3.4.28) which deals with the same form. The examples offered by the CAB on the present rule occur in the same order in the APR (p. 145). à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥ª. à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥€ à¥¤ Whitney (4.60). à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾563 à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥¬. à¤‰à¤¦ à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.62), I: à¤‰à¤¦à¥‹ à¤¹à¤‚à¤¤à¤¿Â°. Translation: [The preverb] ud [is not separated with an ava- graha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] before [forms of the roots] han, hrÌ¥, sthÄ, and stambh. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤‰à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿- à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤­à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ƒà¥‘- à¤¤à¤¾(H: à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚)â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©à¥ª, VVRI edn.: à¥§à¥¨.à¥¯. à¥­)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤°à¤¿à¥’à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¥‘à¤£à¤¾(H: à¤£à¤ƒ)â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥¨.à¥«.à¥©à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ƒà¥‘à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥«.à¥§à¥¨.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜[à¤‰]à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‘à¤­à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥ª.à¥§.à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¯.à¥ª.à¥§à¥ª)à¥¤ â€˜à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¬.à¥ªà¥©.à¥¨)à¥¤ Note: Whitney notes that the combination of ud + han is not attested in the known AV. Surya Kanta (APR, Introduction, p. 39) takes this as an indication that the Vulgate is not a genuinely ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. A more likely possibility is that the CA rule incorporates considerations of general grammar. It should be noted that the APR (pp. 145-6) quotes all the same ex- amples as cited by the CAB including the first unattested example uddhataá¸¥. This shows that there is a more genuine linkage between these texts and their transmission. Whitney makes some important observations: â€œThe pada-text, however, appears to treat the combinations as inseparable only where there is actual composition, as in the participles, and as would also be the case if the unac- cented preposition preceded the accented verb, for we find Ãºt : hara in three passages (iv.14.7, ix.6.19, xii.3.36). For sthÄ with ud, … it has already been noticed (under ii.18 = CA 2.1.18) that where the preposition would be, by the general rules of combination, disjoined from the verb, it is actually so dis- joined, and that the pada accordingly has Ãºt : sthuá¸¥, Ãºt : sthÄpaya, etc., where the saá¹ƒhitÄ has Ãºtthuá¸¥, ÃºtthÄpaya, etc.â€ This makes it clear that the PadapÄá¹­ha saw no difficulty in separating the members where it thought they were not compounded, and therefore, we need to make a clear distinction between vigra-

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 564 ha and avagraha. The complexities which prevented avagraha, did not always prevent the vigraha. However, Whitney correctly observes: â€œOne would have thought it es- pecially desirable that the pada-text should separate ut-hrÌ¥ta etc., in order to mark the forms as coming from the root har, and not from dhar.â€ à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥§à¥­. à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ Whitney (4.63). J: Â°à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ. Translation: [There is no separation of the preverb with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha] before an h-initial [form of the root] dhÄ. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥Œ à¤š à¤¹à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ [à¤¨?] à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥’à¤—à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤šà¥’ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¥‘à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥§à¥®.à¥¨.à¥©à¥ª)à¥¤ Note: The example ÃºddhitÄá¸¥ is also listed as an indivisible word in the APR (p. 146). On uddhitÄ in AV (19.42.2), Whitney (AV Transl. The VVRI edition does not split this word in its pada-text. One wonders if this form was listed in the samudrÄdi- gaá¹‡a, a list of indivisible words, as conceived by the CA, cf. à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¿à¤•à¤¾565 Translation: [There is no separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha of the constituents of the expression] jÄspatyam. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤œà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤¸à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¾à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥­.à¥­à¥©.à¥§à¥¦)à¥¤ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹ à¤²à¥(H: à¤°à¥à¤²à¥)à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡(H: à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡) à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¤‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥(?) à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‹ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒà¥¤ Note: Concerning the last portion of the commentary, Whitney says: â€œAlthough much corrupted, it is evident that this teaches the same etymology with that given by the VÄj.Pr. (at iv.39: yakÄrÄkÄrayor jÄspatye pade): jÄspatya for jÄyÄs-patya.â€ In the present state of the manuscript, this passage cannot be restored to its correct original. The verse seems to say that the word jÄspatyam is derived from jÄyÄ+patyam, with the deletion of yÄ, and insertion of s. The other suggested alternative is to replace the word jÄyÄ with jÄ. While the CA clearly says that there is no Avagraha for the word jÄs- patyam, the VVRI edition for AV (W: 7.73.10 = VVRI 7.77.10) reads the PadapÄá¹­ha as à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒà¥’à¤½à¤ªà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥, and notes no manuscript variant, except that it points out that the PadapÄá¹­ha on RV (5.28.3) reads: à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒà¥’à¤ªà¥’à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥. Whitney, on this CA rule, also notes: â€œThis rule and one in the next section (iv.83), taken together, show that the true pada reading recognized by our treatise is jÄá¸¥patyam; our pada manuscript, however, gives jÄá¸¥-patyam, with avagraha.â€ In this instance, it would seem that the manuscripts have deviated from the CA rule, while the CA rule represents a situation similar to that in the RÌ¥gveda PadapÄá¹­ha. Whitney (AV Transl. In this particular case, the lone manuscript actually reads jamadagnyÄtharvaá¹ƒ, which Whitney amends without notice to jamadagnyÄtharvaá¹‡a, which is now claimed by Surya Kanta as possibly belonging to a long-lost genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recen- sion of the AV. The manuscript reading can be best emended to jamadagny- Ädyarthaá¹ƒ. Then follows a list of names beginning with Jamadagni. Thus, this is another case of a ghost word claimed by Surya Kanta as possibly belonging to the so-called genuine ÅšaunakÄ«ya recension. Another matter to be noted is that the passage à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ and the following exceptions may indicate either a lapse on the part of the author of the CA, or a change in the AV traditions. In any case, the AV manuscripts do seem to follow this statement of exceptions, rather than following a general prohibition of Avagraha for the proper names suggested by the CA rule. The examples of divisible names offered by the CAB must have been divisible for

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 568 the APR as well, as the APR does not list them among its list of indivisible words. Whitney proposes to amend the expression to sarvanÄmnekÄrÄntena to stand for sarvanÄmnÄ Ä«kÄrÄntena, since the only forms attested in the AV is Ä«drÌ¥k. However, the reading of the rule as it stands is sup- ported uniformly by all the manuscripts, as well as by the commentary. Also, Whitney disregards drÌ¥Å›i given in Ha and Hb, and opts for drÌ¥Å›au found in the commentary. However, the reading drÌ¥Å›i is uniformly supported by the manu- scripts. For a parallel to this rule, see APR (217a). The APR (p. 135) cites the two attested AV examples. The reason these forms are indivisible is that the pronoun to which a form of drÌ¥Å› is compounded undergoes substantial change. For instance, PÄá¹‡ini derives Ä«drÌ¥Å›a from idam, by replacing the entire idam with Ä«, cf. P.6.3.90 (à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚- à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¥‹à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥€). Also see P.6.3.91 (à¤† à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ), which replaces d of tad with Ä, before drÌ¥Å›. à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥ª. à¤¸à¤¹à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Whitney (4.70). A, B, D, M, P: à¤¸à¤¹Â°. Translation: [There is no separation with an avagraha in the PadapÄá¹­ha of the first constituent of a compound] before a form of the root saá¸¥ ending in Äá¹­.

à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¥ª, à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¥¨ 570 à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤¸à¤¹à¥Œ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤†à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤…à¤µà¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¤à¥à¥’à¤°à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥¨. à¥«.à¥©)à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥ƒà¥’à¤¤à¥’à¤¨à¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¥’à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥§à¥ª.à¥®)à¥¤ â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤·à¤¾- à¤£à¥à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤¶à¥’à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‚à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™, à¤….à¤µà¥‡. à¥«.à¥¨à¥¦.à¥§à¥§)à¥¤ â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤¡à¥‘à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥â€™ (à¤ªà¤¦ ! â€˜à¤…à¥’à¤­à¥€à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¥’à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¥’ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¥’à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¥’à¤·à¤¾à¤Ÿà¥,â€™ à¥§à¥¨.à¥§.à¥«à¥ª)à¥¤ à¤†à¤¡à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€˜à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¹- (H, N: Â°à¤¹à¤¸Â°)à¤¨à¤®à¥â€™ (not in AV)à¥¤ Note: The examples offered by the CAB on this rule are identical with what we find in the same commentary on CA (2.4.2). à¥ª.à¥¨.à¥¨à¥«. à¤…à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Whitney (4.71). APR (217h, p. 158) reads: à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤¨à¥‡à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¯à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥Œ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ E, F, H: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. C: à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. A, B, D, J, M, P: à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. I: à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. O: à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥¯ à¥¥. à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯ - à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ _________________________________

à¥¥ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¥ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ª.à¥©.à¥§. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ Whitney (4.73). O: Â°à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ. Translation: The term â€˜reinstatementâ€™ (samÄpatti) refers to the display of the original form. Note: Here the term â€˜originalâ€™ (prakrÌ¥ti) refers to a stage in the deriva- tion of a word, before changes like lengthening, or retroflexion of n or s are effected. The state thus obtained offers us a theoretical starting point for the transformations mentioned above, and while the reinstatement often results in undoing of what Whitney (1862: 219) calls â€œanomalies of Vedic orthoepy,â€ it does not necessarily result into a usable expression of the classical language. This is because the process of reinstatement results in undoing of not only Vedic anomalies, but also of some of the changes which are common in the classical language. Such a reinstatement of the derivationally original form takes place in the PadapÄá¹­ha and KramapÄá¹­ha, in accordance with the rules that follow. Whitney points out that the term samÄpatti does not occur in any other grammatical treatise, though the related term samÄpÄdya occurs once â€œin one of the later chapters of the Rik Pr. (xiii.11, 12), in a passage so obscure, without the light which the treatment of the subject in our own PrÄtiÅ›Äkhya casts upon it, that its meaning has, very naturally, been misapprehended by the learned editor (= Max MÃœller).â€ Now we know that the term does occur precisely in the same meaning as our CA rule in APR (147, p. 99): à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤°à¥à¤˜à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤®à¤¾- à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤ªà¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ. The finite verb samÄpÄdyate is found in the same meaning in APR (214b), which reinstates the final short vowel in the PadapÄá¹­ha for words like jÃ¡nimÄ (AV 2.28.2). The term samÄpÄdya also appears in the MÄá¹‡á¸Å«kÄ«Å›iká¹£Ä, see the note on the next rule. Further it is also found in the UpalekhasÅ«tra (8.18), which is identical with RPR (13, verse 11, sÅ«tra 30). A related term pratyÄpatti occurs in KÄtyÄyanaâ€™s VÄrttika on the Åšiva- sÅ«tras, cf. à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ, MB (Kielhorn edn., Vol.I., p. 14). While this term has the sense of reinstatement of an original stripped of unwanted altera- tions, it has nothing to do with the PadapÄá¹­ha. However, the term pratyÄpatti
